My first ever YOKO TARO game that introduced me to his wonderful ways of storytelling. This game throws in many different gameplay styles and forms of combat that will catch you by surprise as well as a VERY well rounded soundtrack that helps you get immersed into the beautifully crafted world of NieR. I would put this game above many well regarded titles and even go as far as to say this game is one of the best video games ever created to date.

It's not replicant. Didn't connect with the story much personally and felt it was a lot more on the nose with its themes than its predecessor. Not an objectively bad game, but I came here looking for the same charm Replicant had for me and didn't find it, so bear that in mind I guess. Not saying it doesn't feel like a Nier game though; it's very Nier, and a rightful distant sequel to Replicant -- the major differences in vibe being part of what makes it good. Just didn't click with me. Keiichi Okabe's OST was out of this world as always, though.

I was kind of mixed halfway through the game, but I gave NieR Automata the benefit of the doubt and decided to finish it to give a proper review. Unfortunately, it endlessly dragged on, and this game missed a lot of what makes other RPGs good.

A lot of things in the game are ass (not the good kind üçë)

No autosaves. This is UX hell. While yes there are many save points around you and you can usually save from the pause menu when close to one of them, this is just asking for problems. I didn‚Äôt lose anything fortunately, but many people online have, especially if they stumble upon the many troll endings for this game.
Combat is simply not good. It feels unclear and imprecise. Part of this I think has to do with the abundance of vfx that are always present while you‚Äôre fighting making for reduced visibility. All your attacks don't feel varied or interesting enough so it begins to feel like a grind very quickly.
Story: Pretty well written I‚Äôd say, it maintains interest, it‚Äôs just pacing which is off. The 2nd playthrough is BS. You finish the entire game then have to replay the entire thing as 9S with minimal differences honestly. That‚Äôs such a troll move. Just make a shorter and better story instead. Playthroughs 3-4 were good though.
9S‚Äôs minigames kinda suck. I speak from a mouse / keyboard perspective too, so this will also tie in to how I‚Äôve heard that the controls lean more for controller gameplay with minimal effort put in towards a keyboard / mouse adaptation. In these minigames there almost feels like there‚Äôs this phantom stick drift for mouse or something where the direction of the ship keeps changing, it‚Äôs weird, I don‚Äôt really know how to describe it. ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø
Soundtrack is pretty bad. Very few tracks are nice while the rest sound generic. All the music being in made up languages is also a poor design decision as it just sounds like gibberish and doesn‚Äôt resemble any modern languages really.
Character writing is also pretty bad. And when I say bad, I don‚Äôt mean regular bad, I mean Star Wars sequel trilogy level of bad. The interactions between A2 and her pod made me want to kill myself they were so cringe. Characters also have zero personality whatsoever. They are robots and act like robots all the way through and have no development (with the exception of 9S a bit). 2B may have a nice booty, but if she has zero personality whatsoever, that doesn‚Äôt make her waifu material. Come on people.

NieR Automata has some nice things though, no game is ever 100% bad:
Beautiful environment art all throughout. With the exception of the factory seeming a bit bland as well as occasional graphical glitches, NieR Automata has immersive environments that are satisfying to explore.
This game actually has good quest design. Part of this is helped by the fact that NieR Automata has nice map design as well. Environments are not overly big that even running through them instead of using fast travel feels fine.

NieR Automata reminded me a lot of Scarlet Nexus, both games have some unfortunate flaws, and while NA had better story writing and quests than SN, the bad outweighed the good, and I‚Äôd highly recommend you play SN if this game left you unsatisfied.

A truly great game with amazing music and a gripping story. On top of that, turns out after a few completed breakthroughs you can buy achievements?!?

Wasn't sure what exactly to expect from this game when i started it, but quickly got attached to the characters. 2B and 9S are very likeable and enjoyable characters, The story is very confusing at the start but it all molds together into a beautiful tale as you go on. The game is equal parts a deep and thought provoking story and a fun action packed combat game. The dialogue has moments of pure comedy and moments of heart aching drama. 

Pros: Super fun action, cool character designs, likeable and fun characters, multiple layers to the story.

Cons: English voice acting is rough in some places, specifically for Adam and Eve.

Overrated. Boring. Too easy. Float-y physics/controls. Constant camera changes that are just annoying. Invisible walls absolutely everywhere. Despite being easy, the enemies are bullet sponges. Numerous unskippable dialogue and slow-walk sections. Maps are too big and they are barren so exploration is meaningless. The enemy AI is absolutely basic and as brain-dead as it gets. Do not go into this game expecting a competent action game. I read various online posts that said the combat isn't great, but "isn't great" is giving it too much credit. The combat design is just flat out bad.

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
Fantastic game that missed the GOTY mark for me due to several poor design choices that severely hampered the overall experience.

Scrolling down the review page for this game, I could find almost no reviewer - even among the ones that did not recommend it - that had actual problems with the game itself. Most of the cons listed had entirely to do with PC port performance issues, of which I had none. Like most others, I enjoyed this game, but you are likely well aware of all the reasons you should buy it. Fair enough, because I like it too, but a couple of gameplay choices prevented me from loving and wanting to replay it.

You see that gif of 2B elegantly evading an attack and then mounting a stylish counter attack on the store page for this game? When I first saw that, I was stunned because it was one of the smoothest animations I had ever seen. Fortunately, NieR blesses you with this caliber of gorgeous animation throughout the game. Combat in NieR not only looks beautiful, however; it's impressively fluid and dynamic: 
[*]You can wield 2 of the four weapon types simultaneously 
[*]When playing, you choose one weapon type for light attack and one for heavy. [*]Each weapon functions differently depending on which attack type it's assigned to (meaning there are a significant amount of combinations possible).
[*]You can swap between two sets of weapons with a single button press.[/list] 
All of this comes together to create a flashy, highly customizable combat system that makes you look forward to every engagement.

Unfortunately, everything I just said is really only true for about half of the game. Once you get a third of the way through the entire game, in one of the most confusing design choices ever made, the game forces you to play as a weaker character that throws away what made NieR's original combat fun. 9S only has one button for attacking and can only wield one weapon at a time instead of cycling between four weapons like was previously possible. He has a minuscule movelist as a result of this, so you have little choice other than to spam one attack chain over and over again when playing him. His attacks are also much slower and the few moves he does have don't flow nearly as well as those of the other playable characters. 

I am utterly baffled that the developers thought that reworking the combat system to be far worse and then forcing you to play as a character with this inferior system for half the game was a good idea. 2A is fun to play because she plays like 2B with some additional flavor. That's what 9S should have been. 

While 9S' combat abilities are substantially worse, there is something he's capable of that 2B is not: hacking. Regrettably, this in no way makes up for his weaknesses from a gameplay perspective; quite the contrary. Hacking is an extremely boring minigame, its appearance should have been sparse, but it thoroughly suffocates gameplay during the second and third campaign. Eventually, it gets to the point where you're having to hack over and over again in rapid succession near the end of the game. You also have the option to voluntarily use it against opponents in combat, during which it is wildly overpowered since there is little stopping you from spamming it against bosses. The only reason I refrained from doing this was because of how dull hacking is.

Finally, I find it rather irritating that there is no real New Game+ mode in a game with such a heavy focus on combat and upgrades. For those that know how the story is structured, I don't mean the 2nd and 3rd playthrough, of course. I'm talking about when you beat the *entire* game and want to start from the very beginning with all your weapons and upgrades. This is, sadly, not quite possible. Instead, the developers added an option to let you replay any part of the game, but neglected to include any form of enemy level scaling, which removes the point of doing so. If you were to go back to the beginning of the game after beating it, you would oneshot everything and combat would be 0 fun. 

None of these issues are enough to prevent Nier from being worth your money though. While the gameplay is exceptional in many ways (when you're not forced to play a weaker character), the story really was the best thing about NieR:Automata. At its climax, it is a love-letter to philosophy with plenty of emotional and memorable moments. Although I didn't always enjoy playing it, I'm glad I pushed through the moments where I didn't to see this game through to the end.

After years and some patching from the devs, I can finally enjoy this game. It has amazing soundtrack and gameplay. Not a lot of this kind of games around. The story is intriguing and the side quests aren't optional. It lacks in visual department, but is solid overall. Definitely recommend.

A fun game with beautiful story and nice plot twists.

I do recommend using some mods available in nexusmods to play it to make it look and feel much more better. If your PC can handle it of course.

[i]NieR:Automata[/i] is not only one of the best video games ever made, but also has one of the most well-written stories that I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing for the first time back in 2017.

This is a game that helped comfort and shape the person that I am today, and fix the relationship between my best friend and I as we weren't on the greatest terms at the time of its release. Who I would later introduce to the series in 2018 and is now a franchise that we bond over.

Video games are so much more than the average person thinks they are. And Yoko Taro has proven that with the help of PlatinumGames by making this game a reality.

"A future is not given to you. It is something you must take for yourself."

After completing all NieR Automata endings i can confirm that this game is an absolute masterpiece and definitely the best game i've ever played in my life.

Endings D & E are really insightful especially if you're someone like me who struggles with clinical depression and feeling unworthy, made me cry a lot and realize a lot of things about myself that i used to not take for granted. And what not, realize that your existence in this world, even if it doesn't matter right now, someday somehow it will.

The philosophies of Nietzsche, Kant, Camus, Pascal and Kierkegaard are very present in this game, and even tho they are opposing philosophical currents, the narrative treats them in a way that no other medium ever did. If i have to describe this game in other ways, i would say it's a love letter to existentialism and all of it's currents.

This game changed my life and the way i think about myself for the better, and if you do try it, i hope it does the same to you too.

Ok wow, Editing my review because I just finished the game and I'm happy to say that it is the best story game I've ever played, and that's not because I've played bad story games, this masterpiece is a true 100/100, and should be for everyone. This game is truly a work of art on a Michelangelo level, and if you have the money laying around you MUST buy this game and experience it for yourself. 

The character development is some of the best, the 3 main characters are all developed some perfectly and all have very large roles, which is great so no one character has a large role but then the other main character is almost a side character, only one other game that I can think of has done this similarly which is Detroit:Become Human, but even then I don't think it was on the same level of this masterpiece of a game. The characters also have an intriguing relationship, and works perfectly in the end to create a great ending that will leave any player confused, sad, and happy all at the same time.

Now for a short(er) part of the review, The Music, all that I really need to say is that it's perfect and makes the game just the right amount of dramatic to make any scene hit harder than a freight train. The music makes absolutely any scene perfect, it makes even the Minecraft soundtrack scared. Not to mention the fact that most of the songs are in the NieR language, which is insane on its own how the creators put that much effort into the MUSIC. Also wanted to mention that there is a song that literally is in 3 languages in the soundtrack (English, Japanese, and the NieR language).

My only pet peeve with the game is in very little spots the graphics look bad, but that doesn't subtract from the beautiful story, and entertaining combat. Overall the game is 1000% worth buying, the game is just perfect and even when you finish the game you'll want to both play through it again but realize how long it took and how you wont be able to experience the story for the first time ever again. And sorry for the long review even though I know someone has a whole 20 paragraph paper in here.

It sat in my library unplayed for far too long. When I finally got round to it I was blown away.

Nier Automata seems to be one of those games which has a place in many hearts as a masterpiece of storytelling. I'll start by saying that while I personally didn't find the story to be quite as profound as it seems some people have, this is still a game I very much enjoyed and would still recommend.

First, the feel of the gameplay. I quite enjoyed the combat, an action combat system that I feel is more skill oriented than many other action RPGs. You could play this game without even being hit if you wanted, if your evasion skills are good enough. Combos such as light attacks into heavy attacks and just swinging weapons around generally feels good. I also love the speed of running when traversing the world, makes it feel like you can get through even the big open areas fairly quickly.

Second, the soundtrack. The soundtrack is amazing, perfectly matches the ambiance of each area and/or situation and many soundtracks seem to be dynamic and change their sound depending on where you are or what you're doing. It also makes it hit that much harder when some locations change along with game progress.

And lastly... The story is still great. Though I wouldn't quite hold it at 'masterpiece' level. It is certainly unique in the way it is structured and it is an interesting story. I particularly enjoyed A2's bit of a character arc. The story has weaknesses though, the main one of which I feel is that it is a little short. Don't get me wrong; I'm not against a shorter RPG! I get tired of playing 80+ hour long ones. But for this game, which I cleared the main story for in about 28 hours + some side quests, I feel that there just wasn't enough time spent with the characters to properly develop them or be properly emotionally invested in them, both with the main cast and a few side characters. If the game were just a bit longer, maybe I could have gotten a little more invested in these characters. Again, the story is still good! Just not perfect.

Overall, I do recommend this game. In my opinion, it's merits go beyond it's story, it's honestly just a fun game to play, and having a good story just makes it that much more worth playing, even if it's not quite life changing.

Edit: Just thought I'd add one thing I really liked about the presentation of the story in parts. A lot of dialogue (especially new mission dialogue, etc) is done vocally whilst still in control of your character. That's a great thing in my opinion! I hate when a game has excessive cutscenes that take away control of the character too often for minor dialogue (like Xenoblade Chronicles 3... and a lot of other jRPGs). Nier Automata strikes a really good balance with this, cutscenes all feel important, add to the experience and are not excessive. This was something I really appreciated about the game!

// [b]I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS[/b]! i CANNOT stress it enough how i love this game. it's a masterpiece! hands down a mind blowing game! i never knew that i can love each and everyone of the characters even if they're the enemies. a lot of times, i questioned myself as a player because of the things i needed to do in the game. it's not because the game mechanic is bad; it's because of the psychological aspect that made me think i shouldn't be doing it. that's not even the best part. just when i thought i had finished the game, it throws me into a new run showing a new point of view and a new story! more depressing and heart-tugging content? YES PLEASE! it made me go in a wild roller coaster ride.

the combat is also fun! it's very smooth and it doesn't feel repetitive even though the world is action-packed and basically chaotic. it feels so satisfying when you perfectly evade enemy attacks and counter them. there are several different weapons you can choose from that show different animation combos so you can definitely mix and match as per your preference. i must say that i wasn't a fan of the hacking mechanic at first but it grew on me after several hours of game play. it's very easy though.

now, the music? it is amazing. it is soulful. it matches the theme so well! it's the kind of music that builds your emotions up and delivers all the feels where it needs to be. it's perfect! i definitely think that it contributed a lot to make this game a masterpiece that it already is!

i would also like to say thank you to the random strangers [spoiler]who sacrificed something important in order for me to push through. you have successfully made me tear up. your sacrifices were not in vain[/spoiler]. we made it! GLORY TO MANKIND!

One of, if not the best JRPGs I've played in all my life. And I've played quite a few, irrespective of my Steam library üëÄ

The combat is fun and satisfying, and there's depth to it. And the gameplay often switches to entirely different genres, keeping it fresh and engaging and you on your heels as you Armored Core and twin-stick shoot your way through enemies, both in the open world and digital spaces. 

The music score is easily one of the best I've heard in all my life, so much so that I listen to them quite often. The lyrics make no sense, but carry more emotion than most other video game music scores.

The graphics is okay. It is on the higher end but nothing amazing, as is typical of JRPGs - you just learn to live with it, and at some point you just forget it's a problem at all. 

The story is unexpected, (unexpectedly good, heh heh) but very well written. The characters are well designed, memorable and impactful. They make clever use of 4th wall breaking to enhance the immersion, and it's quite good. Though in the end you are left with more questions than answers, you feel a sense of satisfaction that your actions made an impact in the game's world - I shall say no further or I'll risk spoiling it. 

Yes, there are bugs. And unfortunately the developer could not be arsed to fix them - but don't let that prevent you from experiencing this game. Fortunately Kaldaien's Special-K mod does the trick for most people.

Highly recommended. This goes into my "games worth playing atleast once in life" list. Made me buy the game üëÄüëÄüëÄ

Nier Automata is the perfect example of why I love Japanese games. They manage to have deep themes but propose them lightly. Themes such as identity, soul, memories, honor, duty, accompany the player throughout the game. At the base there is always a state of melancholy, of survivors in an almost deserted world populated by machines and androids.
The game combines different gameplay styles in an elegant and sometimes, especially towards the end, furious but successful way.
The only note I can make is that if you are a persevering player who loves looking for objects, towards the middle of the game in Normal mode you will be too powerful and will no longer have any difficulty completing it. Perhaps some side quests are superfluous, and the quantity of objects, weapons, materials is really excessive and you will find yourself completing the game with a huge unused baggage, unless you want to persevere once the game is finished. The idea of the division into chapters is interesting, but perhaps breaks the general atmosphere, especially the first few times. But I understand that it is useful as a function of the story. However, this game is highly recommended for fans of the genre.

One of my favorite games I have ever played in my 35 years of gaming, one in which I originally had no interest in playing when it first came out.  I am not really into RPG/JRPG's or have ever played a Platinum title.  After seeing this game praised for the last 6 (+) years, brought up time and time again, even in our current hell-scape of "live service/ever-evolving titles, watching creators like SkillUps review praise the combat; I finally gave in.  A couple years ago I tried it on GamePass but didn't have or make the time to put into its opening sequences (still had my preconceived feelings adding to it) and before I knew it; it was gone from "G.P.".  I kept seeing post or cosplay's centered around 2B, the game, or its underlining story pop up on post or my timeline; don't get me started on the soundtrack when it is brought up about your current favorite games OST.  Finally I pulled the trigger and purchased it, hoping that I would spend the $1-60min value Spool (from Funhause) taught me all those years ago would pan out and DAMN did it ever!

Until Destiny I never really understood the concept of "end game" or appreciate the value of good side content or story-line quests (that 2nd part not so much from D1/D2 more along the line of S.O.t.T.R. or God Of War).  This game takes that mindset to a whole-nother level.  Not only was I hooked in my feelings after finishing 2B's story, I was excited to see 9S's side of the story unfold from his perspective and what was really going on behind the scenes at the "bunker".  What's this, there is a whole 3rd side plot with a fleshed out story from a character that we only met briefly, and heard minor back story plots of through the previous two play-through's?  I would be lying if I said I didn't shed a tear or two after both of the final story endings.  

I beg, anyone that has the slightest bit of interest in this game to give it a try.  While I can't guarantee you will enjoy it as much as I (or others) have, within the first 90 minuets you will know if this is your kind of game.  Multiple game genre's crammed into that opening sequence(s), all which expand on (heavy) through each story-line.  Don't let the JRPG tags fool you, this game is so damn deep, the build (chip) ability, the story, hell the amount of content this game offers is still worth the full asking price as if it was released yesterday.  If nothing else, add it to your "wish list" and wait for it to go on sale; you wont be disappointed.

Hope this will give someone the nudge they need to take that first step and give this game a try.  If it has, please let me know what you think after finishing the first play-through or you have gotten far enough along to give it an honest "review".  Again, I am just a 40 something guy that enjoys a good game; especially one that can make me think about it when I am living my day to day responsibilities.

The main character was perhaps one of the most finely crafted and compelling protagonists I've ever encountered in gaming. Their depth, development, and relatability elevated the overall gaming experience to new heights. The narrative itself was a masterpiece, skillfully woven with intricate details, unexpected twists, and emotionally charged moments that resonated long after the game concluded. The storytelling prowess on display was truly extraordinary, making it a standout among the myriad of games I've played. The music, another integral aspect, contributed significantly to the game's immersive atmosphere. The well-composed soundtrack enhanced emotional beats, underscored intense moments, and seamlessly complemented the unfolding story, leaving a lasting impression on the overall gaming experience. It stands out as one of the best games I've played, and the desire to revisit the journey, to once again immerse myself in its narrative and relish the exceptional music, speaks volumes about its lasting impact.

This game has earned a place among my all-time favorites, not just for its technical excellence, but for the profound emotional connection it fostered through its exceptional protagonist, masterful storytelling, and a musical score that resonated deeply with the essence of the narrative. The prospect of replaying it is not just a desire but a testament to its enduring appeal and the indelible mark it has left on my gaming repertoire.

The game is a spectacle to go through. The story, The gameplay, The music, The characters, everything about this game is amazing. I cannot say how much I personally love this game and hope anyone out there curious if they should give it a shot to definitely do so. The storytelling is astonishingly great. throughout it all I kept smiling and getting exiting for whats next to come. Usually with open world games I find exploring the world or going off doing other stuff kinda a chore however this is not the case with this game. I find myself loving just going around doing other stuff besides the main quest line. Not many open world games succeed in this in my own opinion.

Although for some, The difficulty might be a little much for some people however if you are willing to commit and push through and make it till the end you wont be disappointed. I love it and sure hope more people out there is willing to give the game a shot. Its far more than just "hot android lady with big thighs" that some people might assume the series is at a glance.

The game is a stunning example of storytelling, with a rich and intricate plot that will keep you engaged from start to finish. The world-building is also masterfully crafted, with every detail carefully thought out, creating a fully-realized and immersive world that is a joy to explore. The characters are equally well-crafted, with their own unique motivations. The music is a standout feature, with a beautifully composed soundtrack that perfectly captures the tone and mood of the game. It is both immersive and evocative, enhancing the player's experience without ever feeling overpowering. The designs in the game are also noteworthy, with each element following the same overall composition while still managing to maintain a sense of variety and uniqueness. There is a clear attention to detail evident in every aspect of the game, and it all comes together to create a truly beautiful and captivating experience. I'll only recommend Nier Automata if you are determined to get the full experience up to Ending E. Otherwise don't bother.

The first route (run) is only half of the game... And you'll have to redo that first half without much change to unlock the rest of the story with a third route... I don't think that was a good idea. The game itself proves that the second route could be fused with the first one. Also try to do the side quests as much as you can, they are better than the main quests for the most part with better atmosphere setting.

Speaking about design choices... Nier gameplay sucks. Everything is tedious and feels like a chore. Combat is dull and pods have an unnecessary amount of focus.

However there are some highlights. Nier is also a semi-meta game. Don't expect anything like Stanley Parable but there are some nice bits... which is the reason why this game is praised this much. Along with the deep lore coming from Drakengard and the awesome OST sung on "Chaos Language".

NieR: Automata - A Masterpiece of Emotion, Storytelling, and Gameplay

Introduction: 
NieR: Automata stands as a beacon of excellence in the world of video games, seamlessly blending captivating storytelling, emotional depth, and innovative gameplay mechanics. Developed by PlatinumGames and published by Square Enix, this action RPG released in 2017 has left an indelible mark on the gaming community with its thought-provoking narrative and mesmerizing world.

Storyline and Characters: 
Set in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity has been driven to the brink of extinction by alien invaders, NieR: Automata introduces players to an android named 2B, alongside her companion 9S, as they fight to reclaim Earth for humanity. The storyline delves into themes of existentialism, consciousness, and the nature of humanity itself. As the narrative unfolds, players are taken on an emotional rollercoaster, encountering a diverse cast of characters, each with their own struggles and motivations. The depth of character development and the intricacy of the storyline contribute to an immersive experience that resonates long after the credits roll.

Visuals and Atmosphere: 
Visually stunning, NieR: Automata features beautifully crafted environments that range from desolate landscapes to futuristic cities, each meticulously designed to evoke a sense of wonder and despair. The game's art direction is complemented by a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack, composed by Keiichi Okabe, which adds layers of emotion and intensity to every moment of gameplay. From the eerie silence of abandoned ruins to the adrenaline-fueled battles against towering machines, the game's visuals and atmosphere work in perfect harmony to create an unforgettable experience.

Gameplay and Combat: 
At its core, NieR: Automata offers fast-paced action combat that seamlessly transitions between melee and ranged attacks. Players control 2B as she gracefully maneuvers through hordes of enemies with precision and fluidity. The combat system is deep and rewarding, allowing for a variety of playstyles and strategies. Additionally, the game features RPG elements such as leveling up, customizable upgrades, and a diverse arsenal of weapons that keep the gameplay fresh and engaging throughout.
Beyond its combat mechanics, NieR: Automata introduces innovative gameplay elements that challenge traditional gaming conventions. From bullet-hell sequences to platforming sections and even text-based adventures, the game constantly surprises and delights players with its creativity and ingenuity. These moments of gameplay diversity serve to enrich the overall experience, ensuring that no two moments in NieR: Automata feel the same.

Replayability and Endings: 
One of the most remarkable aspects of NieR: Automata is its branching narrative structure, which offers multiple endings based on the player's choices and actions throughout the game. Each playthrough reveals new layers of the story, encouraging players to explore different paths and uncover hidden truths about the world they inhabit. The game's replayability is further enhanced by its New Game Plus mode, which allows players to carry over their progress and discover additional secrets that may have eluded them on their first playthrough.

Conclusion: 
In conclusion, NieR: Automata is more than just a video game; it is a work of art that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and gameplay. From its captivating narrative and memorable characters to its breathtaking visuals and innovative design, every aspect of the game is crafted with meticulous care and attention to detail. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or someone looking for a truly transformative gaming experience, NieR: Automata stands as a shining example of what the medium is capable of achieving. Dive into its world, and prepare to be swept away on an unforgettable journey that will linger in your thoughts long after you've put down the controller.

I only have 7 hours in the PC version, but have finished the game on PS4, by which I mean that I'd got the endings A, B, C, D and E (highly recommended), and to tell you the truth... The very end of the game is something truly special. If I were to compile a list of 10 most unique and influential games I've ever played, NieR: Automata would definitely be on that list. It's an awesome blend of smooth action, ranging from a third person hack n' slash/shooter, to a top down shooter and an occasional 2D platformer, with solid RPG elements, delivering a story that still resonates with me years after finishing the game. And although it sounds pretty weird (which it is), it makes for one tasty Japanese dish. Just writing this review makes me want to go back and re-experience the game again. If you haven't yet had the pleasure and you are a Platinum fan, go grab this for yourself. I'm almost certain you won't be disappointed. Unless you have an aversion to sexy looking androids that is.

This game has changed my life in more ways than I can count, the hack and slash combat is the best I've ever played with, the story is 2nd to red dead redemption 2 in my opinion and after beating the story I am left with depression and a massive gaping hole in my soul. 100/10 would recommend any day of the week.

This game is probably my favorite game of all time. The way combat works is ridiculously satisfying, the soundtrack is incredible, and it has some amazing storytelling that's weaved into the gameplay. The side quests are exceptionally well-written even if they're not super interesting mechanically.

The only real downsides are that, for an ARPG, there's not a lot of interesting progression. Levels are basically only for stats, and you'll have most of the abilities in the game within easy reach before you roll credits the first time around 1/3 of the way through the game. The game's also on the easy side. If you do too many of the side quests (and given how cool the narrative beats are, you likely will) then you'll end up fairly overleveled going into the main plot, and there's not much interesting resource management regarding items and such.

Regardless, this is still a game that I'd recommend everyone play through to the final credits before accepting the game's last request. And then maybe play it a second time.

Also, you'll see a lot of older reviews bemoaning bugs and issues with the port. This game got a patch a few years ago, and I played through the game more than once without a hitch. Might be awkward if you're playing with a KB&M tho, can't speak to that.

A really good Action-RPG with a buttery smooth movement (at least when playing with a controller). The story is excellent, with it's multiple endings building ontop of each other, and giving you more info about the whole world with each playthrough. Beeing diverse in moods, surroundings and characters, makes the game feeling really big and perfectly ballanced, while also not letting out the fanservice. i would go as far as saying, it is a 10/10 game. 

The only bad part about is the PC port itself. When released it was poorly optimized, and thus really laggy. The controls with mouse and keyboard weren't especially good either. In the meantime there were a few updates and Patches, so that the game runs well, but the controlls did not change much to the favor of the game. If you want to enjoy it in the fullest, do yourself a favor and use a controller and search what mods to install in a guide in the community tab of the game.

Nier: Automata is fantastic. Its mature storyline is full of mystery and philosophy, which are addressed via compelling character work that goes into the depths of the human experience and the complexities inherent in AI. Combined with some amazingly tight and fluid gameplay that effortlessly brings together a plethora of concepts, the many endings and tremendous replayability make it even more outstanding. Taro and Platinum Games deserve credit for developing a game that appreciates the player's time with frequent rewards and deserves to be played.

HOT ROBOTS

I'm surprised I never reviewed the PC version before now. This is my third favorite game ever, under only Metroid Prime and Yoshi's Island. And it's literally my favorite fictional story ever.

People who haven't played this yet - you have no clue what you are about to experience. It's so insanely cerebral and bizarre, but completely coherent and beautiful. [i]"Haha 2B's panties lulz"[/i]. No. This game is Yoko Taro's fever dream of an exploration of what it means to be a sentient and feeling being. Automata spends 30+ hours building up a group of lovable, morally righteous characters and then proceeds to strip them of everything they have and emotionally deconstruct them, all while the entire reality of the world they exist within is constantly being peeled away layer by layer, exposing more and more of the grand conspiracy deep under the surface until eventually it's like there's nothing left but the choice to either see the beauty in it anyway or let it all destroy you in rage. Shit's fucking nuts. It goes hard.

As far as gameplay - it's excellent. One of the best action games ever. 2B and A2 both control beautifully and look badass in combat, it's all wildly fluid with flowing animations between every possible action and tons of special animations for very specific attack chains, it makes combat feel really visceral. The movesets are a perfect balance of complexity and simplicity, dodging is extremely satisfying, and the constant subgame of simultaneously controlling your pod is very satisfying and unique. 9S is fun to play as too, but his gameplay is mainly comprised of a very slick and engaging series of little twin stick shooter style minigames that escalate in difficulty perfectly. I mean this is the team that makes Bayonetta - of course the game is fun to play.

And finally the soundtrack. This is one of the greatest soundtracks ever, for anything. Seriously, Incredible.

I don't even know what else to say. Anything negative I could say is nit picky. This is a game I'll never forget.

P.S. - For anyone who needs to hear this, the first time you beat the game? Yeah, you didn't beat the game, not even close. Load that save up again. Yoko Taro is a weird dude.

The misconceptions around this game are insane. No, you do NOT need to play this game five times to reach the "end". At most you play half the game twice as different characters before the other half begins.
Ending E is truly one of the best/touching endings I've seen in a video game. Never give up and keep going.

The combat is decent, but not good enough to last more than a dozen hours or so. The story is fairly barebones unless you replay the game like 5 times which is kind of an insane expectation frankly. It just seems like a cynical and cheap way to pad out the game length.

Originally purchased as a gag to mess with a few of my friends, but I decided to give it a legitimate shot and I regret nothing. This game is fantastic. One of the best Hack-And-Slash type games I've ever played. In-depth story along with very entertaining and unique boss fights. Once I thought I had seen it all, wham! What do you live for?

9th April, 2023: Stopped playing the game as there's literally nothing else for me to do, did all the content this has to offer, will play again some day for sure, it is a must.

August 3rd, 2023: Still thinking about this game almost on a daily basis, still don't know what do I live for. The anime was cool, even though it was slightly different but with the same results when it comes to plots, sad that it didn't caught the emotion the game offers, but I was already expecting that from the anime.

October 29th, 2023: Out of the blue, I just remembered that I forgot to mention a mod that I used to be able to play with keyboard+mouse in a proper manner: NAIOM. This mod solves the input issues as well as other little things regarding the controls in the game. It also allows you to re-bind trivial keys that in the game you can't. You can find the mod in the nexusmods website as well as guides in Steam.

December 16th, 2023: 1-2 months ago I didn't have internet connection at home so I decided to play some NieR:Automata offline... total playtime after the session: 112h; still makes me sad... uninstalled NieR:Automata and bought NieR Replicant ver.1.22474487139... to dive deeper into the lore.

January 7th, 2024: Finished NieR Replicant ver.1.22474487139...'s story a few days ago, a lot has been answered, and even more questions showed up. Between the two games, I don't know which one is the saddest, maybe both together, because they complement each other. I am now doing what is left to attain 100% in it.

This is such an amazing game. One of my favorite that I've played in years. Stylish art direction, tight controls, one of the best game soundtracks I've ever heard (probably second only to the original NieR), and a mature, twisty story that will keep you guessing. I think this game is best described as an action game with heavy JRPG influences. I guess you could also say it's an action RPG, but however you want to classify it, it's a stylish and slick action game with a really cool story. 

There is a lot to of content to dive into here. This game is intended to be played through multiple times, but one great thing about this game is that you could honestly just play through the main story with the primary ending, and you would still have get an awesome game experience ...But if you do that, you would really be missing out on some great stuff. 

Like it's predecessor, it takes a lot of game design cues from other genres, also like it's predecessor, not every idea is a home run, there are a few annoying design choices here and there, but it still all works. I honestly wouldn't change a thing. 

From the opening moments in this game, it becomes pretty clear that this game is probably not what you expect. In fact that's how I recommend anyone experience this game: go in blind, don't follow any guides, and stop watching game play videos. Just experience this game organically and be ready for an incredible ride. I really can't overstate how awesome this game is.

Nier: Automata is a masterpiece that masterfully blends its unique, captivating storyline with innovative gameplay. The game's narrative is deep and thought-provoking, offering a rich tapestry of themes that explore the nature of consciousness and what it means to be alive. Its characters are incredibly well-developed, each adding depth and emotion to the story. The gameplay is a seamless blend of action, RPG elements, and platforming, with combat that is both fluid and satisfying. The game's world is beautifully crafted, featuring diverse environments that are a joy to explore. Moreover, the soundtrack is nothing short of phenomenal, enhancing every moment of the game with its haunting and beautiful compositions. Nier: Automata is not just a game; it's an experience that stays with you long after you've finished playing.

It's solid. Certainly not the 10/10 masterpiece everyone says it is, but a good game overall. Core gameplay is fluid, and while it is button mashy, it's fun to me personally. Reminds me of Devil May Cry, Dynasty Warriors, etc. I don't particularly enjoy the side-scrolling, diet bullet hell sections when you pilot aerial units; it just doesn't compare to the melee combat at all, but it's serviceable. 

The story is overrated and predictable in my opinion. It is a trite retelling of the work of several notable French philosophers, with none of the weight or significance of the former. The characters are all significantly underwritten and derivative. 2B and 9S are cookie-cutter protagonists that I struggle to feel any kind of emotional connection towards. The writing simply does not give you a reason to, and their personalities certainly don't either. The game tries to build up to emotional moments, but without properly likable or fleshed out characters, it falls flat. 

Where this game really excels is the soundtrack. It features one of the best scores I've ever heard in a video game to give full credit where it's due. The score is what creates a memorable backdrop out of an otherwise uninteresting world.

On the music, art, and gameplay alone, I recommend this game. The music and art are super beautiful. The combat is also the most satisfying I've encountered; super responsive and flowy. Movement / traversal in the map is also fun.
The story didn't quite click for me, but it didn't stop the game from being super fun to play. The story is on the sad side, tonally.
If you're on the fence because of the camera oggling the main character 2B, I'm sad to say it doesn't really improve on that (even the alternate outfit is skimpier than the default). I personally endured the oggling to enjoy the music, art, combat, and movement / traversal.

I don't think any other piece of media has ever made me feel the way I felt while playing this game. Yoko Taro has created something truly special.

Also, if you know even a little japanese, play it with JP audio.

It was recommended to me by my good friend Skillup ;), who was full of praise over this game. However, when I played through path A and B, although definitely enjoyed it so far, I had some complaints as well, so my opinions didn't align with Skillup's yet at this point; the prologue, with it's hour long first level without save points, sort of forced me to start with a Normal difficulty play-through, which wasn't challenging enough beyond the prologue in retrospect. I also wasn't a fan of 9S, not his design and not his play style. Furthermore I didn't really think the relationship between 2B and 9S was very well developed making the dramatic conclusion fall on deaf ears a bit. The combat was enjoyable, but I wasn't really too engaged with it either, most likely because I'm not much of a hack and slash fan or a twin stick shooter fan for that matter. Most of all I didn't like Adam and Eve. Too contrived and not that original or interesting. Throughout my time with path A and B, I was a little bit disappointed, but still eager to play on.

Then the more the game continued after path A and B, the more my enjoyment grew, with every new layer of depth, so grew the quality. In the end all this had formed a whole that was so well put together, that all my complaints diminished, or entirely disappeared. 

In the end I just kept on wanting more; more side quests, more twists, more cinematics, more time with 2B. I understand now why reviewing games you're so passionate about is so difficult. Your thoughts aren't structured, you're overwhelmed, it's not one detail that makes a game good, it's quality seeps out of every line of dialogue, every objective, every animation, character model, every event, etc... 

I love this game. There's not enough characters left to explain why. I honestly wouldn't know where to go on with...

If you think this is just a triple A Hack n' Slash game with some random story about machines and androids fighting each other, you're wrong, very wrong, SO DAMN WRONG, but let me not spoil you. I'll just say to you, that myself consider this game as a masterpiece.I'll just give you a warning: while this game has multiple endings, to get the TRUE ENDING and actually see the "Part 2" of the story, you MUST finish both Ending A and B. After that, THERE IS MORE STORY! Just saying that because many people I've know in the past said to me that they beat the game, but they just made through the Ending A, while the REAL ENDING(s) are after the Ending B. After beating these two "initial endings", MORE STORY AND GAMEPLAY will be unlocked. I don't want to be very specific here to not spoil anything, so just enjoy the ride. Also... consider doing some of the sidequests, there are very interesting stories.
   I got a bit off on what i was going to say, but in short: if you enjoy a good story, is willing to get into some philosophy dilemmas, wanna have some existential crisis, and many many more until the end, this is for you. This has been made entirely for you.
   Also, consider checking the Anime show of the game, it's pretty good too. It's called "NieR:Automata Ver1.1a" ;)

Just finished my first playthrough (ending A) and this game left me speechless. It has by far one of the best soundtracks and atmospheres in the whole gaming industry. Whatever Square Enix smoked while creating this game, they should continue smoking it. Loved everything about the first experience. Just a big thank you for creating this masterpiece of a game.

Just lost 4 hours of progress. 4 hours of boring side quests. Thanks Windows Defender for blocking this game from saving, and THANKS to this trash port which doesn't have a fullscreen message when a save fails.

With that rant out of the way, it's really a bad game. All side quests are just filler and you have to play them, otherwise you're under-level and can't play main missions properly. I consider them filler because they're all the same: go talk to A which asks you to deliver message to B (which is ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE MAP); the worst offender: escort A to B (I REALLY hate those ones, because A is REALLY slow). The port, as said in the first paragraph, is just plain bad. You know it's bad when the community recommends A LOT of mods to play the game properly. The game also stutters frequently when moving around the map (Cyberpunk 2077 really spoiled me in this regard, that game's asset streaming just works).

I guess the main missions and lore are the only "good" things this game has. And "NG+" has a cool concept to it. Though I can't recommend it for the price I paid (16‚Ç¨) ESPECIALLY on PC.

The game is fun but kinda overrated.
Pros:
- The spectacle is a highlight and really cool
- Cool world design
- Game play variation (Flight Unit + Hack and Slash)
- Music is unique but not very catchy (still cool tho)
Cons:
-The difficulty is bullshit just play this on easy if you don't want the stress
-The story has to be the most overblown piece of media ever
    -Lack of character interactions and character in general its all so one dimensional and simple
    - To beat the main story it takes 40 long ass hours way too much for such a simple story
    - I came expecting an existential crisis but i honestly didn't care for the characters so it didn't really make me cry or feel
-The game is too long in general most of that time is from the open world which is too big for such a simple story it drags on and that's without me even doing the side quests or getting the other endings. The game play also starts getting old around 30 hours in,
Overall:
This game is not the masterpiece people claim it to be and that's ok its still fun but why tf are people saying they cried over this, what is there to cry about. The androids barley talked to each other and some of the emotions seemed forced almost to make you feel bad. All 4 main endings were just bad and I had hopes after each it would get better but it never did. Ending A: barley a conclusion, Ending B: same as ending A, Ending C: Didn't feel earned and made me feel nothing. Ending E: Didn't feel nothing. If you play this, play it for the game play, music, and spectacle not the story. I was left severely underwhelmed.

NieR: Automata is a tour de force in the gaming world, seamlessly blending an enthralling narrative with breathtaking action. Set in a post-apocalyptic world where androids combat machines, the game takes players on an emotional rollercoaster, exploring profound existential themes that transcend typical gaming experiences.

The storytelling is nothing short of extraordinary. The narrative unfolds in unexpected ways, with layers of complexity that delve into the nature of humanity and the meaning of existence. The characters, particularly 2B, 9S, and A2, are beautifully crafted, each contributing to a storyline that is both heartbreaking and uplifting.

The combat mechanics are a true highlight, offering a perfect fusion of fluidity and depth. Engaging in battles feels like a dance, with melee and ranged attacks seamlessly transitioning to create a visually stunning spectacle. The diverse arsenal of weapons and the strategic depth in combat customization provide an ever-evolving gameplay experience.

One cannot discuss NieR: Automata without acknowledging its phenomenal soundtrack. Keiichi Okabe's musical score is a work of art, enhancing the emotional impact of every scene. The dynamically adaptive music adds an extra layer of immersion, making each moment unforgettable.

While the open-world segments may feel somewhat sparse to some, the overall design choices contribute to the game's uniqueness. NieR: Automata challenges traditional gaming norms, opting for a more unconventional approach that pays off in creating a distinctive and memorable experience.

This game is not merely a form of entertainment; it's a profound journey that lingers in your thoughts long after completion. NieR: Automata is a testament to the artistic potential of video games, offering a rare combination of storytelling, gameplay, and music that elevates it to the status of a true masterpiece. If you seek a gaming experience that transcends the ordinary, NieR: Automata is an absolute must-play.
this is the best thing that has happened to me in the past 6 months

Imagine the perfect video game with a perfect soundtrack with perfect characters with perfect art and level design with perfect world building and essentially with everything being perfect, that is Nier: Automata to me. Also A2 is underrated.

Very good game! The story line, connections, Character development is spot on in my opinion. The flawless fighting mechanics and animations and very well done. The amazing music adds to the touch of each zone, boss fights and just when roaming the map. This game has a ton of stuff to do. side missions, weapons, exploring the zones, chips, etc etc. The only thing is that this style of game is not optimized at all for MNK! but that's ok. I have been able to play through just fine on mnk but it can be difficult at times when it comes to aiming with the flight suits. Just used WASD for aiming instead of the mouse. Regardless this game is VERY good. It is a very fun robot slashing game that you can lose hours into easily. Highly recommended for anyone who likes story games and rich game play.

When I first played Nier:Automata, I didn't enjoy it. I found the gameplay boring and tedious, the sidequests dull and similarly tedious, and eventually I abandoned this game. However, I decided to play this game again months later on a whim, and I'm extremely glad I did. After pushing myself a bit further, I began to see the true reason why people praise this game so much: the story. At first the story didn't seem like much, and its not meant to. But as you continue to play, go down this sort of lore rabbit hole and get more and more questions and thoughts. Even after completing the game, you still don't know much and you are encouraged to do further playthroughs as new characters. It is in these subsequent playthroughs that you began to truly see the masterfully written story of Nier:Automata, and its true ending absolutely blew my mind.

TLDR: I abandoned this game after buying it because I thought it was boring and overrated. I eventually decided to push myself to keep playing and it is now one of my favorite games of all time.
A real masterpiece.

this game WILL crush your heart

A doll is just a doll? Then why does it hurt to see them torn and slashed? A machine is just a machine? Then why does it hurt to see one breakdown? Why do we project these feelings onto these objects? is there meaning to be found in that? Is there meaning to be found in what seems like nothing? Is there something crucially important about the empathy we share for these objects as the reality of a seemingly uncaring world seeps in?

NieR Automata is many things to me and is many things narratively, no game has won my heart like the NieR series has and none have since. I could spend literal hours talking about how much of Nier is about the things that feed conflict and why they happen despite our best interests, despite what we know is 'right', and the desire to break that cycle of conflict, even when it's too late to stop. It's about an infatuating love between two people who also want to kill each other, it's about the mistakes of ancestors creating countless misery for their descendants. It's about language/culture barriers creating monsters where there is none. It's about personification of non-living beings that desperately want to be alive. About the death of god(s) and how we cope with that. It's about sacrifice and what your willing to do to see this world's end and for others to do the same. It's many things and I adore all of it.

Emil and 9S are probably my favorite written characters in the medium of video games and I hope that can be usurped someday. 2B (and hell most of Taro's characters) is a tragic character that just wants to not hurt the one she loves despite needing to countless times, I hope she has a wonderful life with 9S at the end of the game as much as the world of Automata will let her have, which it's ending is left up to mostly interpretation. I will never understand people who write off 2B as a no-note character with only a fat ass to keep her relevant. Eitherway, I adore this game and have 100%ed it, I can't wait to see what Taro does next if at all.

I just finished Part A. This game port is a hot mess. Random screen shutters and FPS drops, horrible Controls and Settings that lacking destroy any immersion that could exist while playing. The combat, when working, and story was decent so far, but that's about it for the positives.

Recommendations / Tips if you are willing to buy the game on PC:
1) Download NAIOM if you are planning to play with Mouse and Keyboard - Without this mod, i would have refunded this game 100%. (Just google it)
2) This PC port is not worth full price - get it on a SALE.
3) 100% Play with a Controller (XInput - only type the game supports by default)
4) IMHO the DLC is a cash grab, don't waste your money on it.

[u] EDIT:  [/u]  
Just finished Part B. Can be summed up as Arkanoid / Galaga Hacker Android edition. Story was actually more interesting. Provides a lot more back story from the Robots perspective / point of view. Auto-Chip on Easy mode makes the gameplay less frustrating.

To begin with I do recommend this game however I'm left feeling that disappointed with it after the true ending that I honestly question alot of it and wonder if this game IS actually good or if alot of it is just coasting off 2Bs ass.

When you first play this game it's fantastic and you go through Route A.
Not everything is explained at first and your expecting that because you know Routes B and C are coming.
You complete (A) and then begin (B) and slowly start to realise the games making you play the exact same game you just played and completed....but again...only this time with uninteresting 9S.

It promises to tell you more of the story but what it actually does is give you maybe 20% different scenes that could easily have been put into 2Bs (A) route. It feels like a cheap trick to force you to play as 9S and clock up more play time for what is essentially just 30 minutes of different scenes/content.

My playtime was 45hours. Without doing 9Ss (B) route that probably would only have been 32 hours since the game forces you to redo everything.

You then get A2 (C) route...only it's not just A2 because the game forces you to play as 9S for half of her story.

-----Spoilers-----

This then boils down to an ending were the twins die, Yorha  is destroyed, the machine life form splits personality and fights itself (never explains this or which side actually won the argument) then that the final fight is between A2 and 9S were both die, the machine network launches a shuttle into space to find a new world (WHY!? they literally say they want to be/know what humans are/were and yet leave), it never states if all the machines left on Earth switch off after this or stay alive to form a new separate network or to be disconnected like what Pascal was.

The final part is a battle were you have to fight the credits as a hacking shuttle. Then a 3 minute scene just showing the pods getting parts to rebuild the 3 androids (Where are these specialists parts coming from and when did the Pods become engineers/mechanics) and.....that's it.....

No explanation on alot of stuff and other things left open ended without any conclusion. 
It just feels like an empty ending which had an opportunity to be incredible but just flat without any bang.

Pros:
Combat is fun.
Characters are interesting.
Story is captivating.
World is pretty.
Lots of missions.
2Bs ass is hypnotic.

Cons:
Lots of running around.
Lots of back tracking.
Lots of questions never answered.
Twins die needlessly.
Game makes you replay route A but as 9S.
A2 could have been fleshed out more.
Story makes no sense at times.
My personal urge for GOAT in every medium.

If I were to give one critique, it's gameplay has a few flaws and feels a bit easy, at least on normal mode. Due to abilities like auto heal and healing when an enemy is defeated, by the time you are at the late game it almost feels like the fights/bosses are easier than the early game. These easy fights are a bit narratively dissonant with the tense and emotional moments in the story. This isn't too bad because you can always change the difficulty, just a minor nitpick.

I recommend this game to everyone. It's story, action, music, and art make it one of the best games of all time.

To be honest, I have some mixed feelings regarding this game. Automata is the only game that I have played in the series, as I have never played Replicant or any other Nier games before. I think Nier Automata is a good game, yet it might be slightly overhyped by the media and the community. 

First and foremost, this is not a triple-A title and you cannot expect a huge investment into the quality and the design of the game. In fact, as a game that is released for almost 7 years, the graphics do show its age. Afterall, the PC version of Automata was ported from PS4, still you can expect a smooth and stable gameplay after being patched a few years back.

The story plot should be the biggest highlight here, as the game is frequently praised by its unorthodox story-telling. This is not a straight forward story, even a strange, eccentric, confusing story at times. I remember when I finished the game, I had to watch a 10-minute video explaining the key points of the story to clear the fog. The story might seem too complicated and I am a bit reserved in the application of philosophical content into the story. Sometimes these ideas seem to force its way into the story, which brings unusual development to the plot. Though the game might not tell my favourite story, the gameplay is nice and creative. The shift in perspectives in the game, from 3D to 2D, to the mini hacking game, are innovations that offers a lot of freshness to the game. Combat is also smooth and decent.

Overall, Nier Automata is a nice game, but do not over-expect. The game may be one of its own kind, yet some of the innovations it brought requires better execution. It is an interesting experience to finish the game and I would certainly recommend playing it to discover and experience the game yourself.

Finally, I finished this game in 2024, albeit not getting all the endings.
PLEASE JUST PLAY ON NORMAL difficulty; if you are not as skillful in the hack and slash as me, I died in the tutorial several times, and then I lowered the difficulty to keep my sanity intact, lol.

What I really like:
1. How "Alive" the characters are, even the NPC/side character. You can feel their character development as you progress throughout the game and learn about their past.
2. 2B Japanese Voice "Nani" at 9S Nagging.
3. I Lost a lot of progress because of some random Mackarel...Damn you, Jackaass!
4. The story itself feels natural and humane. It does not force the player to believe in something. We care because we feel included in their journey.
5. Do You like DMC hack and slash? Yeah, smash those buttons and slash all the enemies.
6. You don't have to read the journal/secret document you found; most of the main points related to the plot are summarized by our character (dubbing).

The negative:
1. this is not a negative for all people, but if you like the linearity of a story, then this game is probably not for you, there are 26 endings, with 6 of them being the main ending (?) and 20 of them are jokes ending that may or may not have a correlation to the main story.
2. lock at 60 fps, but i dont find it makes my experience worsen
3. Sometimes, it feels like playing bullet hell if you find yourself dealing with dozens of gunner enemies/elites.

Well, I don't really have more negative things to say about this game; the game is absolutely beautiful: the characters, the voice acting, the world, and the story. I'm glad to play and finish this game.

I hope you guys have the same wonderful experience. Cheers!

One of the most creative and memorable games I have ever played, and one of my all time favourites.

It has it all: it looks great, it sounds great, it makes you think. Most of all it just made me want to experience everything it had to offer because I never wanted it to be over. I played all of the side quests because I genuinely wanted to see what would happen; I didn't even notice or care about the rewards. I'm listening to the soundtrack as I write this, and I'll probably keep listening to it forever. I even did some fishing.

It made me laugh, it made me sad, it made me actually cover my mouth in shock like I was in an old timey film. It kept inventing a load of things I've never seen in a video game before, right up until the end. As I said at the start, in just the couple of weeks it took me to finish, it became one of my favourite games ever made, and I'll always be a bit sad that I'll never be able to experience it fresh ever again. I only regret not trying it sooner.

Nier Automota is one of those games which is hard to describe to somebody in a couple of words, and is simply a "go play it yourself" sort of game. If I was to explain exactly what Nier Automota was, and how the story and interconnecting pathways worked, it would probably put you off. It might seem convoluted, or too complicated or like a game that isn't fun and is just pretentious for the sake of being pretentious. 

To put it into simple terms, this is an action-heavy, guns-a-blazing, sword-a-swinging RPG. It's gameplay is a blend of a bullet hell mixed with anime-heavy (aka quick, fast, furious) real-time combat which turns this game into... A bullet slasher? I don't know how to describe it. Regardless, it's incredibly fun. Combat is satisfying to engage in, it's always intense and every battle feels like a proper battle, which you, the player, conquered and survived. Of course, gameplay is intermixed with a lot of talking (typical of any JRPG) and cutscenes which will showcase the story to you, a lot of running around, admiring the beautiful, forgotten landscape of a dystopian, war-torn earth, and some... Other, 8-bit inspired shooter gameplay which I won't really talk about. 

Frankly, I don't really want to talk about the gameplay in this game. Sure, it's great... Nothing that blew me away though. It's not really going to have people's jaws dropping. Because really, this is more like a philosophical tale shown to you with gameplay attached to it. What Nier brings to the table first and foremost, is an incredibly gripping story which cements it as an all-time, if not the all-time great in gaming storytelling.

I just want to summarise my playing experience with this game. This was a game which had me thinking it was really good, to really great, to a masterpiece. There's simply nothing quite like Nier Automota. This games goes places with it's story other developers and storytellers would simply be afraid to go to, and it tackles topics to the core, rather than just scraping over the surface, like many modern games do. I highly, highly encourage everyone to play this game at least once in their life, because it's the type of game that is life changing, and will make you think about life in a different perspective to the one you saw it through before playing. If you want a game that is mechanically good and feels fun to play, this is definitely a good game in that regard, but if you disregard the rest of the game you really are going to waste your time. There's plenty of good, mechanically fun games but this game is so, so much more.

[i][b]NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢[/b][/i] is an incredible game that tells a fantastic story.
[b]Note:[/b] this review does not contain any story spoilers.

For many years, it was marred by a poor PC port. However, on July 15th, 2021, the game's fundamental technical issues were addressed, and it is finally a game I can wholly recommend. The gamepad controls are tighter and more response, tools like FAR (Fix Automata Resolution) are no longer required for play (modding is still supported so these tools have use but were previously required for a (technical) vanilla experience) and in my entire 100% playthrough, I ran into zero crashes. [i]NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢[/i] is both a narrative masterpiece, and a competent PC port as of its final update.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
The game has you assume the role of 2B, 9S & A2, three YorHA units whose skillsets are fairly unique. The gameplay, both in terms of how you play and how you progress the narrative, is structured around its five core endings, labeled A-C. Each playthrough is unique, and you won't simply be repeating the game to reach a choice screen that allows you a different option. Rather, each time you complete a primary ending, you start anew from a fresh perspective, having both the narrative take on a new angle, as well as the gameplay, through the character you play.

Combat in [i][b]NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢[/b][/i] is hack-n-slash style, slicing and dicing through enemies around you. You have two weapons slots, either of which can be equipped to use a variety of light & heavy weapon types. The first slot is for Light attacks, the second for Heavy. Combos in the game consist of various numbers of Light + Heavy attacks in rhythmic succession. Each weapon in the game details its Light / Heavy combos in simple numeric fashion.

Augmenting the combat in the game is the Plug-in Chips system. Offensive, Defensive, Support & Utility chips which can be plugged into any of the characters to aid in your gameplay. You're allotted a limited number of points for equipping chips, and the better a chip is, the more points it will take. For example, a chip which increases your damage by 20% will require more points than a chip which increases your max HP by 5%. Chips can also be combined to level them up, creating better chips which consequently cost more points to equip. This is called Fusing.

Finally, we have Pods. They're small robots that follow you around and can be equipped with tools to aid you in combat. From Gatling guns to lasers to sonars which detect nearby hidden items, the Pods serve both an offensive & utilitarian purpose in the game. They have both a primary & secondary fire functionality, where the secondary fire is based off of the currently equipped skill. These are much more powerful, albeit at the cost of a modest cooldown. Pods are also closely intertwined with the narrative.

Outside of the hack-n-slash combat, you'll also face sequences of bullet hell-style gameplay, as well as brief "hacking" minigames. These are typically brief, though hacking plays a much more prominent role later on.

The gameplay is structured around several zones, all of which will be fast travel-accessible by midgame. Each zone will have its denizens offering side quests that you can optionally complete as you progress the main story. The main story will also take you through all of the zones, so you won't miss any areas of the game as you follow its narrative.

Each of the three characters in the game play in different styles, though 9S is very different, where 2B and A2 are somewhat similar. Each of the three primary endings (A-C) will offer you a unique spin on the game.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
[b]Note:[/b] I'm intentionally keeping this section of the review bare and focusing on the technical aspects of the Endings system because I wish to avoid spoilers. The narrative in this game is worth going through blind.

Arguably, the narrative of [i][b]NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢[/b][/i] is its strongest suit. The gameplay is solid and satisfying, but the story is something else altogether.

Told through its three primary endings, the actual "final ending" can be found through Ending E, which is unlockable very quickly after completing Ending C, as only Endings A-C require full playthroughs of the game. Ending A sees the game through the eyes of 2B, where Ending B is 9S and Ending C is A2. Endings D is the closest to a "choice screen" style ending, but once A-D have been completed, E becomes available and will tie up the game in a fantastic fashion, making for a breathtaking closing.

While this sounds overwhelming, the formula is as follows:
[olist]
[*]Finishing Ending A
[*]Finish Ending B
[*]Finish Ending C/D
[*]Finish Ending C/D (What wasn't chosen above)
[*]Finish Ending E
[/olist]
After completing the game for the third time (and unlocking Ending C/D, depending on choice) you will gain access to Chapter Select, allowing you to jump to the final sequence of the game and make the other choice. By doing this, you will unlock Ending E and see the final narrative of the game, which is absolutely incredible.

The game in total has 26 "endings," though only A-E close with proper credits. The rest can be unlocked at various parts in the game, both in humorous and creative fashions. After a non-primary ending is unlocked, you simply reload at your most recent save and continue.

[h1][b]Performance[/b][/h1]
[i][b]NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢[/b][/i] targets a locked 60 FPS and is hard capped at this framerate due to physics being tied to the framerate. While disappointing at first, I was able to quickly adjust to this, and the game is rock stable on decent hardware. At no point did I encounter any bugs/glitches, I never dipped below 60 FPS, and through my entire playthrough, the game didn't crash a single time. The settings menu is modest with decent confugration, and it still looks rather pretty by today's standards. This can be helped with higher resolution texture mods as well.

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]
I 100% completed this game in around 65 hours. If you're only in it for the narrative, it can be completed in 25-35 hours, depending on your style of play. This was a fantastic experience from start to finish and is now among my favorite games of all time. If you're a fan of third-person hack-n-slash games or of JRPGs, this is a must-buy.

I was really excited to play this game after watching the anime on CrunchyRoll. When I finally got it, the game lived up to, and even surpassed, my expectations. However, the game design seems to discourage continuous play. The lack of an autosave feature, coupled with infrequent save points, means that dying ‚Äì which happens quite easily due to enemies that can kill in one hit ‚Äì often results in starting over from near the beginning, and with fewer resources than before. Despite being determined to finish the game, I'm finding it incredibly challenging. If you enjoy a tough gaming experience, this might be the game for you, but personally, I find that this level of difficulty detracts from the enjoyment of the game.

Edit:Decided not to continue, it's a great game but with some frustrating design decisions, I have a full-time job and only get to play on some weekends. with this game design, it's going to take me a year! at least to complete this game, no thank you.

My previous review was a joke. But that's not what this game deserves. This game is a masterpiece and so creatively designed that it is one of the GOAT. The story is intriguing and complex. The replayability is far far more well thought out and crucial. It may not have made me cry the way Red Dead Redemption 2 did, but this game will hold a place in my heart next to it for sure.

NieR Automata is a masterpiece, plain and simple. There is no angle that this game can be viewed upon in which its unending perfection is not crystal clear. It is the embodiment of a video game, and yet, one of the most thought provoking pieces of media I have ever had the joy of experiencing. It's equal parts hack and slash, bullethell, twin stick shooter, and open zone RPG yet it holds itself together effortlessly forming one of the most coherent experiences to date.

The combat is fluid, and each of the three playable characters differentiate themselves in such a way that experiencing every route just for more gameplay worth it. However, do know, that once those credits roll for the first time, you are all but required to go back and experience Endings B through E. Never have I seen alternate endings enhance an experience to such a degree, and never have those endings kept exceeding even my wildest of expectations.

The game contains expertly crafted meta-commentary on everything from minor aspects of the games industry, to thoroughly crafted examinations of the human experience, life, and love lost. It's story is engaging from the very beginning, and will only sink its teeth in deeper as time progresses.

Lastly, from a technical standpoint, this game is a marvel. Every issue lamented regarding the PC port appears to have been ironed out, with stellar visuals that have aged like a fine wine. Steam Deck support is stellar at a near locked sixty frames per second, without compromising on visuals. When playing at the desktop, the game supports Ultrawide resolutions flawlessly.

I cannot sign this games' praises enough, do yourself a favor. This is a piece of high art that everyone should experience.
