[h1]NieR:Automata - First Impressions Review (2 Hours In)[/h1]

[h2]Overview[/h2]
[list]
[*][b]Game:[/b] NieR:Automata
[*][b]Played For:[/b] 2 Hours
[*][b]Platform:[/b] Steam
[/list]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
Two hours into NieR:Automata, and it's already clear why this game has captured the hearts of so many. Developed by PlatinumGames and published by Square Enix, it presents an immersive experience that combines stunning visuals with an exceptionally crafted soundtrack.

[h2]First Impressions[/h2]
[list]
[*][b]Visuals:[/b] Right from the start, the game impresses with its visuals. The design of the dystopian world is both haunting and beautiful, filled with intricate details that bring the desolate landscapes to life. The character designs are striking, blending a post-apocalyptic aesthetic with a sleek, futuristic look.
[*][b]Soundtrack:[/b] The music is, without a doubt, one of the best I've encountered in gaming. Each track perfectly complements the mood of the game, enhancing the emotional depth of the narrative and the intensity of the combat. It's a testament to Keiichi Okabe's genius.
[/list]

[h2]Gameplay and Mechanics[/h2]
[list]
[*][b]Combat and Controls:[/b] The first two hours showcase the game's fluid combat system. The blend of melee and ranged attacks is intuitive and satisfying, with a smooth learning curve. The controls are responsive, and the ability to customize them adds to the player's comfort.
[*][b]World Exploration:[/b] The early stages of the game already hint at a vast world full of mysteries and secrets. There's a sense of freedom and curiosity that comes with exploring this beautifully crafted environment.
[/list]

[h2]Story and Setting[/h2]
[list]
[*][b]Initial Narrative:[/b] The story begins to unfold intriguingly, setting up a rich background for the characters and the world. The plight of the androids and their battle against the machines is compelling, and it's clear that there's much more to be discovered.
[*][b]Character Development:[/b] Even in the first two hours, the characters of 2B and 9S are intriguing. Their interactions hint at deeper backstories, and I'm eager to see how their relationship develops.
[/list]

[h2]Performance and Technical Aspects[/h2]
[list]
[*][b]Graphics and Optimization:[/b] On PC, the graphics are breathtaking, with a smooth frame rate and high-resolution textures. There have been no noticeable technical issues so far.
[*][b]Sound Quality:[/b] The audio quality is impeccable, with each sound effect and musical note adding to the game's immersive quality.
[/list]

[h2]Early Conclusions[/h2]
NieR:Automata promises an epic journey. Its combination of stunning graphics and what could be one of the best original soundtracks ever makes it stand out. There's a sense of depth in both its gameplay and narrative that beckons for more exploration.

[h2]Preliminary Rating: 9/10[/h2]

[h3]Highlights:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The game's visuals are a feast for the eyes, beautifully rendering a post-apocalyptic world.
[*]The soundtrack is not just good; it's a masterpiece, enhancing every moment of the game.
[*]Combat is fluid and enjoyable, promising further complexity and excitement.
[/list]

[h3]Areas to Watch:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The story has just begun to unfold, and its development will be crucial to the game's overall impact.
[*]Long-term gameplay variety and depth will be key to maintaining the initial excitement.
[/list]

NieR:Automata, in just two hours, sets a high bar. It's more than a game; it's an audio-visual experience that captivates and enthralls. I'm eagerly looking forward to delving deeper into its world.

Clearly the best gaming experience ive ever had.

Great game, great playtime, great story, and somewhat thought provoking. The combat doesn't turn stale, and the side quests are fairly fun too. Aside from some blood boiling design choices, I had a blast.

NieR: Automata stands as a testament to the boundless potential of video game storytelling and design. PlatinumGames and Yoko Taro have collaborated to craft an unforgettable experience that seamlessly blends action-packed gameplay with a deeply emotional narrative.

Graphics (9/10):
The visual presentation of NieR: Automata is nothing short of stunning. From the desolate, war-torn landscapes to the meticulously designed character models, every aspect of the game's graphics contributes to its atmospheric brilliance. However, occasional texture pop-ins and minor framerate dips keep it from a perfect score.

Sound and Music (10/10):
Keiichi Okabe's hauntingly beautiful score enhances the emotional depth of NieR: Automata. The dynamic music that shifts seamlessly with the gameplay adds an extra layer to the overall experience. The voice acting is exceptional, capturing the essence of each character with authenticity.

Story and Narrative (10/10):
Yoko Taro's storytelling prowess shines in NieR: Automata, delivering a narrative that transcends the boundaries of conventional video game plots. The intertwining stories of 2B, 9S, and A2, coupled with existential themes, create a thought-provoking and emotionally charged experience. The multiple endings encourage replayability, each offering a new perspective on the narrative.

Gameplay (9/10):
The combat mechanics in NieR: Automata are a symphony of fluidity and intensity. The combination of fast-paced action, diverse weapon types, and the hacking minigame adds depth to the gameplay. However, occasional camera issues and repetitive side quests slightly hinder the overall experience.

World Design (8/10):
The open-world structure of NieR: Automata is ambitious, but the execution falls short in certain aspects. While the interconnected environments contribute to a sense of scale, the lack of diversity in the landscapes and some bland textures diminish the overall impact.

Character Development (10/10):
NieR: Automata's characters are its beating heart. The journey of 2B, 9S, and A2 is a rollercoaster of emotions, with each character undergoing significant development. The connection forged between the player and the android protagonists is a testament to the game's narrative brilliance.

Replayability (9/10):
The multiple endings and hidden secrets make NieR: Automata highly replayable. Each playthrough reveals new layers of the story, encouraging players to explore different choices and outcomes. However, some may find certain sections repetitive in subsequent runs.

Overall (9.5/10):
NieR: Automata is a magnum opus that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. Its emotionally charged narrative, coupled with stellar visuals and an unforgettable soundtrack, makes it a must-play for fans of the medium.

Absolutely amazing experience all the way through. This game is so story rich and emotionally captivating. The game play is fun and quite challenging at moments, and I really like the movement and combat systems, the characters are charming and very well written. Came here at first out of curiosity, seen people talking about this game forever, along with the music, and came out thoroughly sad and questioning life, which not a lot of games have made me do!! 

All in all, if you're thinking about playing this game, DO IT. It's an experience worth going through, and even though some moments are hella slow and frustrating, push through, it's worth it. Great game to end off my year with, gonna be thinking about this one for a while

What is there to say? Fantastic, engaging game. Replicant centers around loss and sacrifice, Automata takes that and asks if the loss and sacrifice of self-aware machines is meaningful. Already played this on my PS4 with a platinum trophy but wanted to revisit it years later. With the updated graphics on my ultra wide monitor, this game still holds up. Absolutely love it.

Games are meant to be a unique type of media that is fundamentally different from books, movies and everything else. Games are intended to create an experience that involves the player deeply and on all levels. Games are aimed at leaving memories that feel alive, real and personal. Sadly, not every game is a game. Gladly, Nier: Automata is a game. Probably, it is THE game. The game you ought to play to understand what games are capable of.

I hated Nier: Automata for 18 hours straight. I struggled to play. I did not understand why I even bought the damn thing and spent hours reading guides and trying to make this horrible piece of software work and not crash. But there was something... something I couldn't quite put my finger on at the time. Something that kept me returning to the game.

Games are often praised for their story, or graphics, or music, or gameplay... But it is not the story, nor the graphics, nor the gameplay, nor even the music that makes N:A a masterpiece... But it is the story, and the graphics, and the gameplay, and the music that make N:A a masterpiece. For it manages to create a wonderfully cohesive experience where every separate piece is meaningless on its own, but all the pieces fit together perfectly to form an amazing whole.

Everything has meaning. Even my 18 hours long suffering. Especially my 18 hours long suffering.

If you ever wanted to experience a game as a truly interactive medium, a holistic and unique experience you cannot possibly get by any other means, do yourself a favor and play Nier: Automata. You might regret it. You will not regret it.

PS "I walked the same path... And there's one thing I want you to remember... Never give up!" I am Ghost--a faithful player of Nier: Automata. And one day we will meet.

Update:

Five years later the game is still a technical disaster and is still unplayable with KB&M because of the hardcoded double-tap dash and overall clunky KB&M camera and combat controls. It was never addressed. The only way PC players can play the game using their native PC controls is a fan-made NAIOM mod. And that one currently relies on an outdated and unsafe library, i.e. is basically unusable.

Since 2017 over 7.5 million copies of the game were sold. It's not a huge number, but not a small one either. How much does it cost to add just one missing binding? It's not a rocket science, it was done by modders and it's even easier to do by devs.

Me from 2018 was willing to give it a pass, grab a controller and install the whole zoo of fan-made fixes (the famous white screen issue + other troubles). I gave a positive and inspired review nonetheless, but now I realize that I shouldn't have done it, because in the end it was a disservice to future me, other players, and the game itself.

A good game can be destroyed by bad implementation/port. And this is what we see nowadays with a lot of games. People refund N:A because they can't play it. I did refund a number of games because of the same issues N:A has and gave them negative reviews. When players are pointing at the issues, things change. When players do nothing, things continue to deteriorate.

Good game, very bad port, no one cares fixing the issues, review changed to negative.

(BTW, Virtuos is listed as one of the developers and that company is known for making bad PC ports - Horizon Zero Dawn is one example, so I wonder if they're the culprit here too...)

The first hour and a half of the game is the worst experience I've ever had in gaming. Everything else so far has been amazing.

This game is spectacular, nothing short of an absolute masterpiece. I've played it multiple times now and there hasn't been a run where I haven't learned something new. This is by far my favorite story in any game, and potentially in any medium whatsoever (though I haven't yet read some books that may surpass it). Beyond anything about the details of the plot, the story explores on a higher level philosophical questions about humanity, identity, mortality, and more. The game equips the player with an understanding of these things, so that as it progresses, the player may make informed decisions. And the presentation of the final credits alone so well encapsulates the game's positions that it will have the player bawling if they have followed all the way. I cannot possibly recommend this game enough.

Where to begin with this strange game. O boy. The best way to describe it is "it shows its age" 
Playing this game with a controller is highly recommended, as the game decides to be twinstick shooter, side scroller, top down, and open world at the same time. In addition, the normal bindings on keyboard are strange to say the least. 
The game definetly shows its age in the lack of combat depth. Upgrades for the most part dont really do much and arent really important, and as well as this the actual combat is a basic hack and slash beat-em-up, but it isn't exactly the most engaging. The hacking minigames are by far more interesting and used in a better way in the story in general. 
Speaking of story, the story to this game is a highlight. After the first ending,The 2nd through the 5th do a much better job of asking questions and making you feel for the characters. My one complaint is I wish the second playthrough had more variety, as the first half feels exactly the same, except more hacking minigames. 
The soundtrack is otherwordly, and the design in general is amazing. 
Came for 2B, stayed for an melencholic and nihlistic story expierence.
One of the best game i overlooked before and decided to buy and worth it! just go for it.

NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢ is nothing short of a gaming masterpiece, seamlessly blending compelling storytelling, innovative gameplay mechanics, and a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack into an unforgettable experience. Directed by the visionary Yoko Taro and developed by PlatinumGames, this game transcends traditional boundaries, delivering an emotional and thought-provoking journey that lingers long after the credits roll.

The narrative unfolds in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity's remnants have sought refuge on the moon, leaving Earth to be ravaged by powerful machines. Players assume the role of 2B, an android warrior, and are accompanied by a charming companion, 9S. The story is a rollercoaster of emotions, exploring existential themes, the nature of consciousness, and the price of war. The multiple endings provide a depth that encourages replayability, offering new perspectives and revelations with each playthrough.

NieR:Automata's gameplay is a perfect marriage of action and RPG elements, with PlatinumGames' signature combat style taking center stage. The fluidity and variety of combat moves are exhilarating, making every encounter a spectacle. The game seamlessly transitions between different gameplay perspectives, including traditional third-person action, side-scrolling, and top-down shooting segments, keeping the experience fresh and engaging.

One of the game's most notable features is its soundtrack, composed by Keiichi Okabe. The music is nothing short of a masterpiece, perfectly complementing the narrative's emotional beats and enhancing the overall atmosphere. The haunting vocals and evocative melodies are integral to the game's emotional impact.

Visually, NieR:Automata is a feast for the eyes. The desolate landscapes of a post-apocalyptic Earth are juxtaposed with breathtaking moments of beauty. The character designs, especially the enigmatic machine lifeforms, are unique and memorable. The game's art direction is a testament to the creative vision behind this project.

Beyond its technical and artistic achievements, NieR:Automata succeeds in creating an emotional connection with players. It challenges conventional gaming norms and poses questions that linger in the mind long after completing the game. The melding of a gripping narrative, dynamic gameplay, and a haunting soundtrack elevates NieR:Automata to the status of a true masterpiece in the gaming world.

In conclusion, NieR:Automata is not just a game; it's an emotional and intellectual journey that pushes the boundaries of storytelling in the medium. Whether you're a fan of action games, RPGs, or thought-provoking narratives, NieR:Automata deserves a place in your gaming library. It's an experience that will resonate with you long after you've put down the controller.

If anyone is deciding between playing the ps4 version or the PC version of this game, please just go play it on PS4, because you will have a hard time getting it to work correctly on the PC by using MODS and even after that the gameplay and framerate is not as smooth as it is on PS4. The game itself is so confusing and might require me to play it again just for the story and or just watch the cutscenes again to understand. The music and combat are amazing! The enemies and the world are lacking in my opinion and needed some more creativity and freedom with more to explore. The way the story is laid out and divided really left me salty about it's design style and wished that it was redone to make it a lot better. So far it's a decent game. The music definitely well deserved of the VGA music award for best soundtrack of 2018.

EDIT: The game has gotten a lot of fixes and now runs like butter without any issues whatsoever. The FAR mod has also been updated to fix a ton of stuff the official update didn't tackle. I appreciate the modders hard work for this game. The game is now worth getting on PC.

This game is awesome. I have been wanting to play it for years having seen it mentioned in many reviews.
If you own a game pad then it is absolutely worth playing despite the cons.

Pros:
- Combat is action packed and a ton of fun. There are a lot of weapons and skills to learn, but if you aren't into it you will also have fun with just the starter set which can get you all the way to the end.
- Innovative story telling. You get to play the same story from multiple angles with many unexpected turns.
- Deep philosophical story. Makes you think about love, emotions, purpose of life. Very well written.

Cons:
- Keyboard & Mouse controls are abysmal. Don't buy if you don't have a game pad. I wish they had thought of better way to PC port this part.
- Camera is bad. Even playing on a game pad often the camera just looks up from your feet making it difficult to see the battlefield.
- Prologue is unnecessarily hard. If you are playing for the first time it can take an hour to complete the prologue and if you die you have to start from scratch. Don't be discouraged, once you get past that it will get easier. It is worth it replaying the prologue until you make it!.

The game looks beautiful, plays beautifully, and has an amazing story. I went in being told that you have to play the game five times to get all the endings. That's not really true, and without spoiling it the worst it gets is the first half of the game is split into two, but the second time all your side questing, levels, and junk is carried over so it goes much faster, and then the third time is the second half of the game. 

With that said, if you're into the 30 hour story RPG, I recommend it, the action is on point, the animation is beautiful, and it never once felt too grindy for the main story beats, in fact I was actually a little over leveled by the time I finished it. If a long involved story sounds exhausting to you though, maybe give it a pass.

NieR: Automata stands as a testament to the boundless creativity of Yoko Taro, a visionary director whose unique storytelling and gameplay design have left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. This game is not merely an experience; it's an emotional journey, a philosophical exploration, and a work of art that deserves every bit of praise.

Pros:

‚Ä¢ Philosophical Depth: Yoko Taro's narrative prowess shines through in NieR: Automata. The game seamlessly weaves a complex and philosophical storyline that delves into the nature of humanity, consciousness, and existentialism. Every twist and turn leaves players contemplating the profound themes long after the credits roll.

‚Ä¢ Emotional Resonance: The emotional impact of NieR: Automata is unparalleled. The characters are beautifully flawed, their struggles resonate on a deep level, and the game skillfully manipulates player emotions. From heart-wrenching moments to unexpected revelations, the emotional rollercoaster adds a layer of depth rarely achieved in gaming.

‚Ä¢ Innovative Gameplay: The fusion of various gameplay genres, including hack-and-slash combat, bullet hell sequences, and RPG elements, creates a dynamic and engaging experience. The game constantly keeps players on their toes, offering a refreshing departure from traditional conventions.

‚Ä¢ Aesthetic Brilliance: The game's hauntingly beautiful world is a visual marvel. The combination of atmospheric environments, stunning character design, and a haunting soundtrack composed by Keiichi Okabe creates an unforgettable atmosphere that enhances the overall experience.

‚Ä¢ Multiple Endings: The branching narrative with multiple endings adds replay value, encouraging players to revisit the world of NieR: Automata to uncover hidden truths and alternate perspectives. It's a testament to the game's commitment to storytelling and player agency.

Cons:

‚Ä¢ Some Repetitiveness: In certain sections, there's a degree of repetition, especially during subsequent playthroughs. However, the narrative revelations and changes in perspective often justify revisiting familiar scenarios.

In conclusion, NieR: Automata is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. Yoko Taro's creative genius, combined with a deeply philosophical narrative and innovative gameplay, elevates this title to a level of artistic excellence rarely seen. With utmost sincerity, NieR: Automata deserves a perfect 10/10, solidifying its place as one of the most profound and impactful games of its generation.

I do not understand the hype that surrounded this game. I did not enjoy it and was not inspired by it all. Below are some rants, spoilers be warned.. though the trailers do like 90% of the story for you.

Rant 1: The story that is lauded as good by so many, is only impressive to someone whose deepest philosophical thoughts are spoon fed to them by bad game or TV stories. It is not deep. The philosophy of this game is war is bad, humans did war, humans are bad. 

Rant 2: The insight of are you still you if you lose some of your experiences is expressed through out the game. The start of the game and the end of the game. Truthfully these are androids and machines, they aren't loosing much if their physical form dies and their consciousness is transferred into another body. The game literally opens with that concept, and it is handed off like, "oh well let's carry on." Which that is the way it ought to be given the characters. Towards the end it though it tries to give weight to the preservation of their forms they currently have because they might loose something valuable. Though the fast travel system counters even that, because you are surrendering your physical form to get your consciousnesses put into another android body. The contradictions about personage and spirituality throughout the game frustrates me.

Rant 3: The auto-saves, quicksaves, and saves aren't consistent. The game tries very had to warn you that it doesn't autosave, but in reality when it matters it does. When you fight a boss and die, you restart at that boss and have to collect your setup from your previous body. If you die out in the world, you respawn at one of the quick travel hubs and have to run back to where you died to retrieve your setup. Then there is just "save" which I'm not quite sure how is different from quick save. Maybe I don't understand the distinction, or lack of it, because I beat this laughably easy game in 2 or 3 sessions.

Rant 4: The personalities of the characters is awful. You have 2B who is a "srs bznss" type that becomes slightly softer towards the end, but only slightly. 9S is an awkward kid who is trying too hard to befriend 2B. Then there is the operator that talks to 2B like she is a friend, but one that she has to help. The there is the main villians, which are JUST SO BAD. Design wise, it was like SE was like, "What's better than Sephiroth? Two Sephiroths!!!1!!11!!!!"

Rant 5: The characters are all making human-like expressions. You kill a boss and he is like, "so this is death.... it's so cold and dark" The dude is a machine made android who is like a couple days old. He doesn't know what the cold is. He doesn't know what the dark is... not like a human ever would. Yet they ham-fisted those words out of an android's mouth. It is just terrible writing. There are plenty of other examples just about as bad as that, but it was the one I found the most offensive.

Rant 6: PC port is awful. Now, I'm not having the random crashes that I've read other negative reviewers give. Heck, I'm even running it on Linux and not getting crashes. What makes it an awful PC port primarily is the control scheme. If you keyboard and mouse, which if you are a PC gamer there is a 99% chance you use a keyboard and mouse, then you have to suffer through double-tapping to dodge and start a sprint. While that is slightly annoying, I'd say most of us can handle that. What makes that just the worst, is that due to keyboards not having a pressure sensitive controller like a joystick, we all do "inching". "Inching", if somehow you don't know what it is, and apparently the game devs who ported this over to PC don't, is just tapping forward in short quick strokes to move in the direction without going full speed at just pressing and holding. We all do it, if you play on a keyboard you develop the skill almost instinctively. You know what trying to inch on a keyboard ends up being? A double-tap that activates dodge, causing you to instead travel a long distance rather than a incremental distance. To get past a section of the game where I was trying to inch forward on KB, I finally gave up on with KB and switched to controller. It took me 3 tries with KB, and one shot it with a controller... so I guess I'm glad I have a controller. Why does my controller with only 18 buttons, have more functionality than my KB & mouse in a game? Now on my KB I can reach ~ - 6, tab - y, caps - h, shift - b, and cntrl - space for a total of 31 keys, 21 keys if you don't count mod keys, movement keys, and caps. Under my mouse I have 20 keys, 18 if you don't count left and right click. Then as PC gamers we can get extra fancy keyboards, extra keyboards, and other accessories such as foot pedals. So why with so many potential buttons do I not have the option to separately keybind dodge from double-tapping movement? Did a clown write the HID stack for this game?

Rant 7: This game looks lazy artistically. Most of the areas only have a couple of colors. Geometry is simple and textures are simple. I just played through Dark Souls and though it was release 6 years earlier, it was more visually impressive. I could have given art a pass for this game if it was made in the 2000's, but the teens!? The late teens!? The art is just uninspired.

Rant 8: The camera is just awful. We've all played games with awful cameras, nearly every game has one. We all just kinda get used to it and have keybound manual camera control somehow. This game makes it worse though, by taking complete control away at times. Suddenly you find yourself in a forced top-down view, or side-scrolling view. You can barely see your character sometimes for all the sprites and HUD elements in the way. I don't know, they tried something a bit different and I didn't like it.

I didn't like this game. I powered through it, hoping it would get better, I trusted that I had to be missing something with how many love it. I got through one of the endings, and that is all I have heart for doing. There are supposed to be multiple endings, but I don't have the heart to find one better. Trying to find the best ending is kinda like picking the best turd in the toilet... it is still just a turd. For me, the best ending is the one where I can say I did the game and have experienced and now the torture is over.

Rant 9: I am writing this rant after a couple of days of having beaten the game with the first playthrough. I say first, because I think it is obligatory to say first, though for me it is very probably also the last. When you beat the game the devs actually encourage you to play through again. Ugghhh..... that is such a lazy to way to extend game play time. They are obviously trying to encourage you see alternative endings. Then 2B also says at the end "It always ends like this." [spoiler] and then kills 9S [/spoiler], that's a spolier that you can see coming a million miles away. She is either prescient or experienced saying something like that. Given her stand-offish nature and at some point she says something like "we are in a cycle of life and death" I'm going to say it is experience. [spoiler] She has probably killed 9S, or some model like 9S, before. Given the names of the androids, the letter is the model of an android and the number is probably their sequential revision, or re-incarnation of that model. [/spoiler] Ughhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh.... So 2B is stand-offish because she doesn't want to get attached to 9S, like Edward Cull;en from Twilight, and the lore of the game is basically The Matrix II. I guess I can't say this game isn't inspired, just that it is inspired by two of the worst stories made in the last couple decades. FFS is this what passes off as good?
Made me bawl my eyes out. That's how good it is 10/10.

[h1] üïò          IMPRESSION:[/h1]
* Year 2017: Game released 
* 2 hours later: Stop playtesting, because something is not right
* Year 2023: I trust the review, saying it is a Masterpiece that worth buying
* 2 hours later: Updated patch made great improvement from what I remember
* 8 hours later: Lost track in the quest and stopped playtest
* 20 hours later: Game is good, but not recommend for busy gamer.

[h1]  üîä         TESTER MUST KNOW:[/h1]
* Buying YoRHa Edition = Buying DLC as well
* The DLC outfits are require completing certain ranks & level 60+ to unlock
* High rank in area = Enter chapter 6 of route B with 9S story to get outfit
* Game world timeline: Future year 11945
* Must study & understand the story before we start playing
* No checkpoint save in Prologue for 1-2 hours
* Prologue = Chapter 1 + different scenario on each new game+, still no save allow
* Require go thru Prologue again for new endings each time
* Auto Chip = Auto aim & auto attack
* Black Box = GPS for dead body + Self destruct ability 
* Change pod program to activate scanner at Flooded City
* 2B doesn't have Hacking Skill, only 9S has it
* Uncapping above 60 fps will cause glitches
* FAR mod = Fix screen & graphic issue
* Unlock Chapter Selection Menu when completed 5 primary endings

[h1] üíé          SAME GENRE COMPARISON:[/h1]
* Total of 26 Endings available, main endings are only five of them
* Many NPC & enemies are cute robots
* Each NPC has own unique characteristic in dialogue 
* Able to pilot mech with fast-pace combat style
* Diverse boss fight 
* Customize a death message while mission failure, it is prepare for online player
* Optional to repair other player dead body or retrieve their chips
* Lose exp point if cannot retrieve back the last death
* Optional ride on animal for traveling
* Optional fishing gameplay
* No auto save

[h1]  ‚ö†Ô∏è        RUMOR CHECKING:[/h1]

* Camera lock is very frustrating ‚ûú The solution is disable auto chip & reduce camera speed
* Ambiguous Quest? ‚ûú Not happen if player study to understand before continue playing
* Freeze in UI tutorial ‚ûú Happen if player idle for 10 min at the 1st time, and we must repeat wait for 10 min for 2nd time, or maybe 3rd time for 3rd endings, just because it is a masterpiece.

You need to play this game. Do 3 playthroughs please. You'll be missing out if you don't. First two are similar just from different perspectives. Third is a sequel hidden within the game. This is one of those "insider" games where people who know the history behind it all will go through the punishment for the sake of irony and gamer cred. There is an extended universe here stretching for who knows how many terrible games all the way back to the PS2- era from whence it all started, namely Drakengard. Drakengard 1 was an absolutely abominable and masochistic experience in all the ways possible. It took all of the worst design decisions possible for a game and made it the entire selling point, finishing off with an apocalyptic, End of Evangelion- esque storyline to really hammer the point home that you are not playing a game, you are slowly going insane. It was designed to be bad and soul destroying on purpose.

Nier Automata is a continuation of one of the endings of Drakengard where you are playing in the aftermath of the previous games, but to which there is seemingly no relation. What I find curious is that there are a lot of Drakengard and Nier games, which implies some sort of deep worldbuilding or story, but storywise they are all extremely cryptic and gameplay wise either outdated or plain clunky. The reason I have explained all this to you is that without this context, Nier Automata is just a curiosity with some strange design decisions and with a game director that likes wide hips on his women. If on the other hand you know the previous games and the grief one has had to go through with them, you start to understand that part of the appeal is due to the cult following behind it. I am sure Platinum Games did all they could to persuade game director and Sith Lord Yoko Taro to maybe make the game experience a little tighter and to trim the fat but for naught, which leads me to believe that the game was intentionally designed to have that little bit of needless frustration baked in to really give it that Drakengard "flair."

The core gameplay is quite enjoyable and reminiscent of Bayonetta, about as fast and fluid, but not nearly as deep. As I mentioned earlier, there is something not quite right with the game, because the game design is all over the place and constantly stops itself short. Sometimes you'll shift into a shoot-em-up section, sometimes the camera pans overhead to give you a birds eye view of the action, and later down the line you are expected to start hacking minigames in the heat of battle. All of these ideas are half-baked in a way where the difficulty comes from how badly they are designed. On easier difficulties, you'll be blasting through all of these sections wondering what is even the point, and on harder difficulties they crank up the damage so that every little mistake is punished with the force of a sledgehammer. If that wasn't enough, you can craft and equip upgrades with perhaps the worst system I have ever seen for such a thing. You can gain levels, although this too is something the game doesn't really use to it's full benefit.

Even stranger is how your hack-and-slash experience is also simultaneously a bullet hell game, since you are expected to dodge and weave through all manner of projectiles while on the ground. While it sounds like a cool concept, this too is very clunky if not unnecessary, because the core gameplay is not designed with such accuracy in mind, so instead, you are given a robot that can shoot these projectiles out of the air, but even this serves to add another layer of redundancy to the game because this aiming, beyond locking-on, is absolutely impossible. 

What you have here then is just a mish-mash of cool ideas that have no synergy with each other whatsoever. All of it is frustrating on some level. They are not ever thought out to the point where you could practice them as a skill. These ideas clash so badly with each other that it's a miracle they even got it all working. The arcade influence is obvious, but this is a game that is purely style over substance. The gameplay isn't unbearable, but is marred with all manner of useless fluff that is more of a hindrance than of a help. 

You have multiple endings, too, and there are 10 - 20 of them. Surely this is a sign then that this is first and foremost a story driven game, to which I say yes and no. Yes, because there is somewhat of a story however convoluted, shallow and obtuse, and no, because the majority of the endings are joke endings that bring you to a black screen that shortly describes what happened through text. Cue credits on fast-forward, and this is not just a figure of speech, this is what actually happens. That's right, they don't even bother giving you so much as a cutscene for most of them, and then laugh in your face for expecting anything else.

At this point you come to realize that this is a game that is making a show of taking itself seriously, but at the same time openly mocks you for trying to take it seriously. It makes you jump through all manner of hoops only to be rewarded with a slap in the face with a meta joke or a fourth-wall break. I feel as if I am being tricked into thinking there is a point to all of this, only to later find out that there really was no point. This is the true sign of a game that simply had no idea what in the hell it went out to achieve, but took you along for the ride anyway.

Now, with all this said, you would expect this to be a negative review. In a very meta sort of way, this is a game that is indeed deep, but which is exactly why it encourages you to enjoy it on a surface level. It is all one big inside joke, laughing at the player who tries to make any sense of it. I somehow feel this is a very cynical and satirical game, but why and aimed at what I'm not entirely sure. It is a flaming spiteful mess, it hates your guts and it hates itself, but it offers such a bizarre experience that for me, it somehow manages to redeem itself. If you were to patch up the game's flaws and strange decisions, it would actually be to it's detriment because it is such an integral part of it's identity.

Can I recommend it as a straight-laced action game? No. As a story-driven game? No. I think a post-modern commentary or art piece that goes to absurd lengths to prove a point is the best way to describe it.

This game absolutely subverts expectations. On the absolute surface level, it looks like a PS3 era hack-n-slash with hot anime robots, but delving deep into it reveals it's one of the finest examples of storytelling through the video game media. If you played and loved 'Spec Ops: The Line' you'd absolutely love this. The lore and the world building in this game is absolutely fantastic which is backed by an amazing soundtrack. Without getting too much into the spoiler territory, the way the game handles existentialism, fascism, morality, different branches of philosophy is simply genius. Having said all these, the standalone game is unplayable with a Keyboard Mouse setup and you have to use a controller to get the most out of the game mechanics, but there's a cool mod called NAIOM that allows you to play this with a Keyboard-Mouse combo as flawlessly as you can do with a controller.

I keep coming back to Nier Automata because of the rave reviews, and finally have come to some conclusions:
1. It's a good game. Not great, but definitely good & quality. There are countless other games I enjoy playing more.
2. It's for modern-style anime fans, of which I am not.
This review is not for the fanboys, but for everyone else.

If you're a juvenile boy:
The allure of an anime girl as the main character is probably a big draw and you probably don't mind the absolutely cringe-ful soliloquy of villians' dialogs. You probably have the spare time to play through the game 3 full times, as advised. And you may not have been exposed to much sci-fi literature/media yet and think that the story elements here are unique.

For the rest of us:
There's plenty of good in the game actually!
Character movement feels great; with options like double-jump, dash, and your floating robot pod to grab onto to slow your long falls.
Combat is fun button mashing with nothing being too complicated, suiting an action movie/game look.
Music is excellent, as are the graphics & scenes. The minor pop-in of assets and the desaturated color aesthetic may bother some.
Clever use of the system chips you slot in your android character for upgrades and base features -- all game HUD elements are default chips that you can choose to remove at any time (to free up a minor bit of space and/or see the effect... including death by removing an obviously necessary chip).
Camera changes and actual genre changes for some scenes keep gameplay fresh.  The camera becoming fixed to an axis & zoomed out gives you some standard 2-D side-scroller gameplay, and at other times you hop in a robotic flightsuit and take to the air in dedicated scenes playing basically a shoot 'em up. I dig those change-ups, and they're done well.
Story is interesting, good sci-fi tropes but nothing spectacular.
There are a number of little design things that all add up well; such as communications being a hologram pop-up on-screen projected from your character itself.

On the easiest difficulty with a few upgrade chips that give certain features, the game almost plays itself during combat. ;-)

From my research, it seems that fans demand you play this game through fully three times. The first 2 times are similar where you play a different character through the story the second time, but the third time is the "real" story or where it gets interesting.
I'll probably never experience that myself, I keep dropping the game and trying it again months later during just the first play through.

No matter what I write, I won't be able to sum up this experience or do it justice.

 Nier: Automata is a combination of great graphics, fun and diverse gameplay, emotional storytelling, incredible music (seriously the OST is mind-blowing) and compelling characters. You might be driven away at first if you're not a fan of the anime-like visuals or revealing outfits (or at least that was my case), but you would be doing yourself a disservice if you were to ignore such a masterpiece based solely on a first impression.
 I wish I could wipe my memory to replay ending C and all the Pascal related quests (if you have played the game you will understand how this is an unfortunate choice of wording on my part but also agree with me). All of the runs are just so good and cohesive and entertaining and well though-out and meticulously planned I was amazed by every detail. And it's not just the main content that will impress you, but also the missable side quests and archives. Every weapon you collect, every enemy you kill, every robot or android you encounter, they all have a story; this just goes to show that the amount of time that went into this game is insane and I, for one, greatly appreciate that.
 If you haven't tried this game out yet, I don't know what you're waiting for. This is your sign to  delve into Nier: Automata and discover if life has meaning.

This game is very clearly designed to be played using a controller, so playing using mouse and keyboard is not a pleasant experience.  It is not even possible to assign functions such as attacks or fire options to the mousekeys, so the mouse is pretty much just there to point the camera in the right direction. All attacks have to be assigned to keys. This made especially the top-down view parts really hard, but also the "normal" 3D parts were annoying, since one hand had to keep track of navigating, attacking, targeting and firing while the other was busy panning the camera to see the enemies.
This may very well be much easier and more intuitive when using a controller, but I wouldn't know, since I don't own one.
On top of that, the game informs you that there are no quick save, but there are supposed to be save options somewhere during the game. I played for around half an hour before I died first time, and I didn't come across a single save option during that time, so I had to start all over from the very beginning.

Possible spoilers ahead, do not read until you've unlocked the ending E.

This game has its flaws: 
1) Unbalanced difficulty levels, the difference between Normal and High is astonishing, and it feels very strongly on the first chapter (introduction / demo).
2) The story from the 9S perspective is a bit more rushed than 2B's perspective, as if you start the Missile Supply mission, you basically will be stuck until to the start of the Route C, so any side quests that you forgot to complete, will be unavailable until you unlock the Chapter Select.
3) The lack of wardrobe... I mean common, I don't like to see 2B pants everytime I jump... (guess I didn't play this game for 2B at all), 9S and A2 are basically stuck with the replicant outfit from the DLC, which you need level 80+ to obtain from the "tournaments". 
4) Was better if they were more unique sidequests, not just collecting some material and looting...

Incredible story:
1) You have to play at least twice to understand completely the story, while is very complex as per design, sometimes it feels also linear (A & B -> C / [D -> E])
2) If you go to recordings and datasheets, there are pretty amazing details where it explains the main story (about project yorha and N2 - spoilers).
3) Because the humans went extinct, the androids and also the machines are having the existential problem (machines don't want to end the war, as the only goal is to kill the androids... / Project YoRHa founded by an android for the android based on a lie etc) + a nihilistic philosophy 
4) There is also good side mission stories which some of it may apply to the main story or not (e.g the missions with 60 and 21O / Emil quests).

Excellent graphics, good mechanics and excellent soundtracks:
1) For an rpg game, I can say the graphics are very good, a good example if you go to the Desert, and see how detailed are the particles etc.
2) Interesting game mechanics, you have various mini-games which occurs during hacking which I think is pretty unique at least from any average RPG.
3) The songs, just wow, it s incredible how unique and dedicated are based on a specified stage / or how the specified character / protagonist feels (e.g going into the Tower, 2B vs Adam - last round etc.) AND I LOVE THE 8 BIT VERSION OF THESE SONGS :D


In conclusion, this is a very good game, I dare to say it s a masterpiece, at least based on its story.

It is truly difficult to review this game without spoilers, but this game is so worth the time. Some of this game's best twists and turns are [spoiler] baked into the gameplay and structure of the game itself, specifically how the game ends, but then continues on in the form of multiple core endings and a full alphabet of other endings for the player to unlock. I am so happy that I, eventually, unlocked all of the endings and content, as there is a treasure trove of surprisingly core world-building tucked away in side quests, hidden archives, and random conversations with machines that would easily miss if you played the "main" story and stopped there. While it was a slog getting the last few percentage points of some of the achievements to fully 100% this game, even through the last hour of playtime I learned things about the story that I'm glad I know. For instance, there's a core character who you meet early on, Emil, who turns out to have a whole story of his own that you don't get to fully explore until you are very high level, after you've already beat the main story. There's also an entire interactive side-story from the perspective of a machine being trained to fight that only unlocks after you beat all three arenas, which is extremely difficult unless you are close to max level, again well after the main story is concluded. It is so engaging and sad, and worth the effort. This leads me to believe that the "main" story is, in fact, a story among many stories. [/spoiler]

To say that I loved this game is a gross understatement. This game was fun, totally unique, quirky, odd, and deeply philosophical, as well as being delightfully self-aware at the right moments. [spoiler] There are moments where the game pulls back and you, the player, are suddenly aware of yourself playing a game, and elements of the actual game itself become part of the game world [/spoiler]. It's also deeply moving at points. As you progress through the game, you notice that [spoiler] the machines that you are fighting at times seem more human than the androids you're piloting, and this entire game feels like a love letter to existentialism, played out on the stage of machines versus androids, but who is really pulling the strings in this proxy war, and what does it mean to be "human" anyway? [/spoiler]

Like I said, the best things about this game are heavy spoilers, but I also really enjoyed the world. It's bleak, it's relatively colorless, and there's ALOT of lore and machine life to explore.

There is one piece of advice I have to give to the people like me who generally play everything on the hardest setting. Don't with this one, at least not on your first one. You likely won't make it past the tutorial. There is such a massive imbalanced difficulty spike moving to the hardest two settings that most enemies will one-shot you from the get-go until you can build appropriately. 

In summary though, I'm so glad I took the time to fully complete this game, as difficult as that was to do without [spoiler] buying the Steam achievements with in-game currency, which is another quirk of this game that I don't think I've ever seen before [/spoiler]. Very much worth the time I have put into it over the last few years and really appreciate the work that the creator's put into making it as fun and thought-provoking as it was. Really great game.

Without a doubt one of the best and most unique gaming experiences I've ever come experienced.

There are RPG, J-RPG, bullet hell aerial combat, 3D platforming/sidescrolling, top down and even retro style elements in the game. 
The camera transitions seamlessly to these various angles and playstyles keeping things fresh and intriguing. 

There is A LOT to do. There is always something to keep you busy, whether you are following the main quest or taking detours to complete side quests. 

While the story itself isnt the most amazing one i've come across, the game does have ways of making you feel invested in its protagonists. You either love them or hate them... Well honestly 9S is the only one you either love or hate. 2B and A2 are queens. 
Even some of the other less relevant characters like shop keepers and camp members have a story here and there and you can feel something for them as well. 

Pretty much every playthrough offered something new and surprising that I did not expect from the previous. 
And my god was that secret [spoiler]E-ending bullet hell credits sequence[/spoiler] amazing.

Soundtrack is AMAZING. Not to be glazing, but this has to be one of the best video game soundtracks of all time.

The bosses are very well designed and unless you are severely under-leveled (which is very difficult to accomplish unless you're just blatantly ignoring every side mission), then they aren't overwhelming. 
I would even suggest upping the difficulty level to make things a bit more challenging if you feel like it isn't enough for you. 

The graphics are pretty, nothing too amazing, but it is not too taxing on your system either. 

I feel like this game is one of the greatest games ever made and should be experienced at least once by any fans of the genre.

Do yourself a favor, and play this game. Nier:Automata has left a mark on me unlike any other game I've played- from the music, to the story, and the compassion of the characters, Nier:Automata hooks you in and keeps you there. The combat is very fun and strategic, leveling and building your character is grindy, but not boring. The story is very lengthy, with 5 main endings to play through, a new shocking discovery through each route. With choose-your-own-path endings, you can experience all sides of the story and still have more questions to ask. The atmosphere is extremely developed, with the environment and music declaring the exact mood of the set and making you feel as if you're there. The graphics are stunning, especially for it's time. 2B, 9S, and A2 are all lovable characters who you learn about through their gameplay. I only wish there were more Nier games to extend the series, for I can't get enough of the amazing storytelling and gameplay this game offers.

[h1]A future is not given to you. It is something you must take for yourself.[/h1]
Once in a while, one encounters a game where the core genre it belongs to is difficult to make out. Well, [b][i]Nier Automata[/i][/b] is most definitely still a stylish action title, but is nonetheless a unique mix of solidly implemented tropes and mechanics from a variety of action video games.
[h3]I never quite realized how beautiful this world is.[/h3]
In actuality, however, it‚Äôs only a modestly good-looking title. The character models are well realized and animated, especially in gameplay, and the general art direction for the environments convey a strong sense of isolation. That being said, limitations are apparent without needing a thorough examination of the graphics.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2850372163 
Still, it shouldn‚Äôt really be an issue for a [i]Ryzen 9 3900X, 64GB RAM, 1070Ti, Windows 10 Pro[/i] system to run, even at 1440p and 60hz, right? Well‚Ä¶ not really. Without MSAA, 60fps are maintained usually, though some intense areas still dip into the 40s. Employing any multi-sampling to curb the nasty aliasing thoroughly tanks the frame rate to below 30. Beyond that, technical and stability issues are thankfully absent. Full keyboard rebinding is possible, and I‚Äôm pleasantly surprised to confirm gamepad rebinding too‚Ä¶ that being said, the former‚Äôs controls are spread out and cumbersome to the point that it‚Äôs a lot easier to just play on a gamepad.

On the audio front, the music is plain and simply beautiful. Simple enough in terms of dynamic layering, but epic orchestral arrangements are backed up with chill-inducing vocals, kicking in when the action ramps up (or alternatively turning into high quality chiptune occasionally)‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs sensational. Everything just clicks together in the sound department: weapon attacks and general sound effects are appropriate and satisfying. While I found the voice acting delivery overall excellent, be wary of the stereotypical ‚Äúanime gasp‚Äù that‚Äôs often thrown about by the characters in dialog.
[h3]Everything that lives is designed to end.[/h3]
In the very-distant future, androids and machine-lifeforms are locked into a forever war on Earth, with humanity having left it desolate for millennia. As part of YoRHa, an elite military force of androids, you play as combat model ‚Äú2B‚Äù - and are joined by your chipper and endearingly awkward, scanner-type sidekick ‚Äú9S‚Äù - to conduct reconnaissance and data-gathering on the curious behaviours of the adversary. An ever-destructive journey for the protagonists ensues, as they struggle to comprehend the bewildering nature of their enemies‚Ä¶ and slowly unravel multiple long-running conspiracies that shake their beliefs to the very core.

Story connoisseurs might quickly read through the lines and pick apart the plot twists and revelations long before they‚Äôre officially spelled out, while the philosophical questions raised seldom have much depth. Also, to get the full picture, you have to play through the whole story at least three times over, so strap yourself in. Past all that, the journey of the main characters is engrossing enough that I found myself significantly emotional by the end of each‚Äôs individual tale.

Also, there is no autosave. The game makes sure to remind you, because there is, indeed, no autosave. Did I mention there‚Äôs no autosave? If you forget, the 45-minute long prologue will remind you harshly...
[h3]We are perpetually trapped in a never-ending spiral of life and death.[/h3]
For most of the run-time, [b]Nier Automata[/b] is a hack-and-slash, with unique flair courtesy of the developers Platinum Games. Mix-and-match two weapons into your light or heavy attack slots, swap through your ranged pod‚Äôs basic and charged attacks, and string together simple yet satisfying combos against a variety of foes. On the normal difficulty level, evasion and offense are still emphasized, as you cannot afford to tank a lot of hits by default. To help with this, your dash/sprint function works as attack evasion if timed right, which you can then string into powerful riposte. 

Elements of bullet-hell are apparent from the beginning: adversaries fire large damaging orbs as projectiles, which can either be shot through with your floating pod or otherwise dispersed with melee attacks. Several hidden abilities are left for the player to discover, but as a whole your movement and combat kits are straightforward, if lacking in depth.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2884849489 
With growing frequency over time, you engage in a hacking minigame that plays out like a more traditional twin-stick bullet hell shooter: you control a little ship and have a limited time to destroy a central node before you have to try again. I found these generally enjoyable, but the growing frequency made them a bit of a chore to go through by the end.

[h3]I often think about the god who blessed us with this cryptic puzzle‚Ä¶[/h3]
RPG elements are sprinkled throughout the experience. You level up through defeating enemies and completing quests. Both of these, as well as exploration, reward with minor crafting/trade items, or the odd weapon and equipment upgrades. Side quest design is lackluster ‚Äì the bulk of them function as fetch quests. Go here, kill some creeps or find some item, come back, sometimes do that again, and be rewarded. 

It‚Äôs the written dialog that primarily make these worthwhile‚Ä¶ that and getting something to make your damage numbers larger. Also, through these, you further get to explore a majority of the map‚Äôs varied biomes ‚Äì overgrown city ruins, urban areas turned into scorching wastelands, an amusement park kept alive by your enemies, and several more.

You can also fish in bodies of water.
[h3]‚Ä¶and wonder if we‚Äôll ever get the chance to kill him.[/h3]
One can break the difficulty into pieces through the plug-in chips system. The playable androids can have various improvements to combat, defense and movement slotted into memory ‚Äì at the same time, you can make more room for enhancements by taking away unnecessary HUD elements (but don‚Äôt touch the OS chip!... or do). Chips of the same level can be combined to provide a greater effect at the cost of more memory usage.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2884834102
With the right setup, equivalent-level enemies and bosses will falter quickly. Level scaling is still present to ensure you don‚Äôt quite curb-stomp all opposition, and high-level enemies will demand your full attention to ensure not dying immediately, but - outside of a few optional gauntlets ‚Äì a skilled player wouldn‚Äôt have to die often. 

If you do die, it‚Äôll sting: you lose your equipped chips and have to recover your old body before it disappears or before you die again. Or, you can reload a previous save.
[h3]Become as gods![/h3]
Finishing the first story on the most critical path would require about ten hours of playtime. Subsequent stories are real emotional rollercoasters ‚Äì and take another combined 15-20 hours to complete. Thus, the proper finale is after the 30-hour mark. Side content can take a lot longer to explore, though be mindful of their repetitive and uninspired nature if the gameplay becomes boring. Hilariously, a bunch of endings are ‚Äúfake‚Äù and require the player to go against objectives or even common sense at certain moments ‚Äì rewarding you with a few lines of text on how you screwed up and adding to the completion tally. So, don‚Äôt eat that fish, no matter how tasty it is.
[h1]Glory‚Ä¶ to mankind.[/h1]
[i]Sure, combat is simple and the quests are boring ‚Äì but come for [b]Nier Automata‚Äôs[/b] otherwise satisfying gameplay, and stay for the emotional story. Difficult to talk about, yet easy to recommend.[/i]

The best way I can describe what playing Nier Automata was like is that it was a unexpected masterpiece. 
I went into this game with so few expectations after my first bad experience playing (I was playing on mouse and keyboard) but I can now safely say that this game is one of my all time favourites.
And I can say with 100% certainty after finishing the game 3 times over, doing all 26 endings, earning all the achievements (with the ones I cared about I did legit), and finishing every single side quest except for 2 (including dlc) that my only regret with this game was that I will never be able to experience it for the first time again.
I BEG YOU please buy this game whether it is on sale or not, it is worth playing to the end. And I mean the VERY END (Don't just stop after beating it once or twice).
10/10 - Glory to Mankind

NieR:Automata and its surrounding franchise can be described as nothing less than a personalized masterpiece...

Following a pair of androids, the player navigates through what most would call a stereotypical setting consisting of barren wastelands controlled by none other than rouge and mindless machines. But what makes this game different from any other game of the type? The brain of Yoko Taro, the game's creator.

Before NieR:Automata, the name Yoko Taro was almost unheard of and only known through his previous "underwhelming" game franchises such as Drakengard and NieR Gestalt. Although they have excellent stories and amazing soundtracks, Yoko's Drakengard and NieR were commonly known for their downright terrible gameplay and somewhat oversensitive themes. This all changed when NieR:Automata was released. NieR:Automata captures all that was fantastic about Yoko's previous works and combines it with newly imagined gameplay. Automata tears you apart by mixing well-known settings and engaging gameplay with Yoko Taro's specific storytelling through music and human weakness, leading to a combination of belief, trust, lies, and eventually nothing less than straight defeat, all while indiscriminately following the story of Drakengard and NieR and the long-lasting consequences of its characters.

If you're a fan of story-rich games, NieR:Automata and the newly released remake of the original NieR Gestalt/Replicant will provide everything and more, making every other fictional story look inferior in comparison.

There has not been a real game that has caught me like this game has in my whole game-playing career of 22 years and honestly I am very impressed with this title especially down to the story and the soundtrack which is by far the most powerful and touching music collection I have ever heard.
I'm a fan of androids and the future, especially futures that are set in a post apocalyptic setting like Nier Automata that gives the player a sense of lonelyness through the beauty of the environments such as the abandoned shells of buildings that were once inhabited by humans.

The game story mainly revolves around a couple of androids named "2B" and "9S" who are a part of an advanced human- made android division called YoRHa that is fighting an army of machine lifeforms.
The game seems pretty straight forward off the get go but, I assure you that there is SO much more to the story that meets the eye that strongly meets the criteria of a AAA title in my opinion.

There are a whole bunch of references to previous titles in the series, mainy Nier gestalt/replicant which is the same universe and path that Automata is set from. For a pretty well detailed and entertaining analysis to catch up on the series: (Mr clems Nier analysis) --- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EnwEbOHo7Aw

The art direction is also very unique and interesting, everything from the clothing the characters wear to the weapons that they wield and everything around them is all very suiting and fits well.

The gameplay is pretty fluid with combos, dodging, parrying and far range attacks making you feel like an unstoppable android bent on the survival of humanity during battles as well as the movement around the world giving you unmistakable scenery changes to make sure that you know when a new area is entered regardless of how small the different areas are.

Upgrading weapons is a nice experience by giving a sort of cryptic back story to each one that unfolds with each level it reaches (min1-max4 depending on weapon) with a whole bunch to collect, some hidden pretty well.
upgrading materials are easy to come by for the better part but some are more rare than others in true RPG fashion that adds a grind element that isn't too taxing which is nice.

Upgrading your character is another story as it is done through items called "plug in chips" that are essentially boosts to your stats like running speed, damage buffs and recovery that can in themselves be upgraded into more efficient chips that can contribute to some really game-changing playstyles, coupled with some items that boost certain stats, to make you feel like even more of a badass.

There is a currency in the form of "G" possibly gold but I'm not sure, that can be aquired through the basic killing of enemies that gradually goes up depending on chapter and enemy type OR through hunting down boars and mooses for meat and fur. On top of those methods there is also FISHING that is pretty straight forward and not only gives you fish but also other area specific items depending on where you set up (City, sea etc). And last but not least sidequests for that all important material and currency that is much desired but the sidequests also flesh out the story of the game along with adding some carefully placed backstory that makes me suggest doing them as they come in to enrich yourself properly in the story of the characters and the world around you to gain a better idea of past events/lore.

This review ISN'T a REALLY IN DEPTH review because I think everyone should actually give the game a try and feel it for themselves. Yoko Taro and platinum games have really made this something special in my opinion despite platinums previous issues they really pulled through on this title which is why you might want to experience it first hand and not just look up a walkthrough. Buy it one day, on sale or not, don't just play through it once and be all like "Meh, that's it?" but actually continue the story (For reference there are 3 main endings with a few choices thrown in as well requiring 3 playthroughs each getting a little more wild and wonderful)

Also I started playing this game on a potato computer and it ran at a main 40fps solid and now on a more beefy machine a solid 60-100fps with each computer having completely different parts and brands including GPU so not too sure why everyones reviews are "Wah game not work! Me too dumb to fix Grrr I bad review"
This review IS BASED ON THE ACTUAL GAME and not a sorry excuse of a computer or helpless user.

10/10 from Me personal GOTY 2017 and even more so in 2018 after actually completing the main story and secrets.
Recommend greatly to people looking for a fun and challenging game with some nice RPG elements and also people looking for a deep story to follow which may or may not break you emotionally if you pay attention.

I am on my 3rd play through.

First of all, getting into Nier, you will notice that the soundtrack is mesmerizing thanks to Okabe, Ishihama, and Hoashi's collaboration. I think the music is probably one of the best that I have heard in recent years. The graphics are distinct and immersive in the open world, showing a desolate and serene environment, with contrasts to your home base. And the voice acting is also top notch, though there are nuances if you go through the English and Japanese dialogues.

The PC version may have some bugs. I wasn't able to get past the starting screen until it was eventually patched, so Square-Enix really needs to extensively test their ports out earlier on. Once I got past that, it was fun.

Great Music and Visual design. Combat has some nice ideas for mechanics and story has some interesting ideas for themes - as well as potential for great characters - but nothing ever feels thought out and most of the time contradictory. Most notably: Machines and Androids are constantly described as emotionless, yet the japanese pathos cinematography makes everyone gasp in shock and awe throughout the entire game. Most egregious: the longer the game goes on, the more it tried to throw whatever deepities and pseudo-philosophical-word-salad at the wall - either to see what sticks, or because the writers didn't have concrete ideas either - while becoming an entirely incoherent mess The game did so, while pretending to add something substantive to my mind. I read someone else critiquing this piece of media as "the writing of a teenager who just found their first look into philosophy" - a quasi "i am 14 and this is deep" - The Game - and i sadly have to agree. Overall disappointment at the potential.

Is it a "Bad Game"? Yesn't? I find it hard to pass a dichotomous judgement. But it's messy in almost all places and vastly overrated at ~90% positive reviews. Especially if you account that most negatives are from people complaining about technical issues.

TL;DR: I just hate the game and just venting my feelings, It's not a review, just RANT. better for you not to read it.

[b]First of all,[/b] I was very let down; the gameplay is really braindead, just hit the hit and dodge button, and "have to hold down" the R1 button to keep my pod shoot, that is all the gameplay had delivered to me. 

[b]The theme of the game[/b], I know it's supposed to have a depressing vibe and the emptiness of the world but the game is really flat, barren, and has lazy design ideas to me: the building that doesn't even have a desk or something human once used, or something that gives you a feeling that this place human used to live once, used to had a civilization once. It's just a stupid rectangular box, a copy-pasted. 

[b]The music:[/b] pascal's village and the ending song were really good, other than that just forgettable to me, especially the combat soundtrack.

Was the writing written by a robot as well? I could not find any real emotion expressed through the characters or maybe they are just robots? 

9S, I understood his feeling after the incident. He's right to do that, it's just that the way the game itself depicts 9S's anger or grief is just so blunt as well as EVE. after that point on the character 9S completely turned out into the one-dimensional, and I don't give a sh1t about the story anymore.

The plot is interesting but not for the storytelling, and the dialogue is not enough talking to convey the character's development to me, or maybe they just failed to deliver the main message to me. 

I wonder if this game didn't have Lolita fetish maid costume, booty fan service, or banal things such as sexualized characters. Imagine, a protagonist is just a man instead of 2B (e.g., the protagonist of Stranger of paradise). there still are people who would care about this game in the first place? prolly not...

2B's outfit: android wears high heels, the skimpy outfit in combat, and in that world? that's so obvious, it's just stupid fan service and successful to lure people.

Sorry, If I'm harsh, just hate the game that uses fan service as a tool to promote or sell their games. For me, this game is not that good in multiple things that's why I think this game just uses the fan service to sell the game. just like Atelier.

As it was praised to the heavens so much, I had very high hope for that, but it turns out really shallow to me. but I don't think the game deserves to get a thumbs-down. just average at best action and wannabe philosophical game.

NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢:

Summary:

Offering a fresh blend of action and RPG gameplay styles, NieR: Automata is the follow-up to the 2010 cult hit NieR, and combines the design talents of Drakengard designer Yoko Taro in collaboration with development team PlatinumGames. The game tells the story of androids 2B, 9S and A2 and their battle to reclaim a machine-driven dystopia overrun by powerful weapons known as machine lifeforms.
Invaders from another world attack without warning, unleashing their secret weapon: the machines. In the face of this insurmountable threat, the human race is driven from the earth and takes refuge on the moon. The humans develop an army of android soldiers to fight back against the mechanical horde, but succeed only in slowing its advance. To break the deadlock, a new breed of android infantry is sent into the fray: the YoRHa squad. In the forsaken wasteland below, the war between the machines and the androids rages on. A war that is soon to unveil the long-forgotten truth of this world...

My opinion :

But what a game !!! From start to finish the game will have managed to make me stay without boredom. The synopsis of the story is very interesting and the different characters well exploited with a good background. The phases of actions, rest, sadness ... are very well managed with varying degrees of difficulty. The fights are beautiful and even grandiose I had the impresion to never do the same fight with the music just exceptional accompanying it's moments. I also enjoyed the moments of fighting in Flight Modules which reminded me much of the old game of the time ...The hack system is very good and funny without being complicated at some point . Unfortunately I find that there is too much use of the hack with 9s it is a pity but not disturbing . The game itself is very long and interesting I have 70 hours of game and I have just finished 100%, I have to start the game again from the beginning because of a certain end: D. For the blow "you Will not get your money's worth "and it's rare. One small defect is the optimization of crap that there is for each port console is very boring as always ...

2B : Female model android created by humans who fled to the Moon to avoid extinction by the Machines. The first playable character and protagonist of Branch A.

9S : Scanner type android who is best served when hacking, however he is still able to keep up with other close-range attackers. He has a very gentle and kind personality. The second playable character and protagonist of Branches B and D.

A2 : A prototype model that was used in order to create the superior 2B and 9S. She doesn't like to speak and often keeps to herself. The final playable character and protagonist of Branch C.

Pascal : In spite of being a Bio-machine, Pascal is a pacifist. She is highly intelligent and has an interest in the history of both humans and Bio-machine. (Fuck why Pascal I loved it very much)
