I mean it's NieR Automata of the NieR series. One of the intriguing storyline with versatile combat mechanism. It's soundtrack will take you to another dimension and make you experience gaming like you never have. Once you reach the ending E (the True ending) of this game, you'll never be the same. The depth in writing of this characters is immaculate and make you feel like you're one of them, rowing in the same boat. 

If not all, play it for the ass, it's totally worth it

Firstly, let me express wholeheartedly that this review and its title hold an exceptional place in my heart. It's dedicated to a once very dear special friend of mine. He introduced me to this game, and I often found myself falling in love with the experience because of him.

I'd like to share a short passage that you can take away from the game itself. The keyword here is to enjoy the beauties of life because nothing is permanent. Gratitude unlocks the abundance of life, making what we have enough, and more. It turns denial into acceptance, chaos into order, and confusion into clarity. Gratitude gives meaning to our past, brings peace to today, and creates a vision for tomorrow.

So, in a nutshell, I dedicate this review to them.

The narrative unfolds in a future where Earth falls under the control of alien machines, pushing humanity to seek refuge on the Moon. Tasked with eradicating these metallic invaders, the YoRHa squad, a skilled unit of warrior androids, ventures to reclaim their homeland from the clutches of various factions with ulterior motives. In this tale, you step into the shoes of android 2B, accompanied by the newcomer 9S.

One might assume androids would be dull protagonists, yet in NieR: Automata, these robots are intricately crafted with poignant personal stories, surpassing many other characters in depth. What truly sets them apart is the evolution and revelation of their genuine personalities throughout the game. 2B, initially stoic and rude, unveils a more emotional side over time, while Nines, always playful and coquettish, exhibits moments of profound seriousness.

While the plot may seem straightforward initially, it swiftly takes a philosophical and existential turn, posing the ultimate question: what does it mean to be human? Upon completing the game for the first time, a pause for reflection is inevitable, as the narrative transcends expectations. The end is not a conclusion but rather a commencement to a deeper exploration of the profound themes embedded in the game.

Initially, it might appear that NieR: Automata's storyline would hit a dead-end, given its focus on Android protagonists and machine enemies. One might expect them to be devoid of intelligence, silently serving either humans or extraterrestrials. However, as you delve deeper, a realization dawns‚ÄîAndroids possess their own will, thoughts, and emotions, restrained only by the teachings and rules instilled by their creators.

While the theme of barriers between humans, machines, and androids has been explored in various works, NieR: Automata elevates this exploration to an extraordinary level, particularly through the character of 9S. Unlike 2B, who dutifully follows her masters' commands, 9S introduces a dynamic shift as the narrative progresses. It becomes evident that both machines and androids harbor secrets, and the days of humanity may be numbered.

Throughout the game, numerous questions surface, and the moral choices made influence which of the 26 possible endings you might encounter. NieR: Automata defies predictability, knows no bounds, and immersing yourself in its world proves to be an unforgettable experience.

The game world unfolds as an expansive open environment, allowing characters to freely explore scenarios while presenting enticing side missions and concealed areas. While the map isn't overwhelmingly vast, it cleverly capitalizes on the verticality of its buildings. In certain missions, revisiting previously explored points reveals them rejuvenated with fresh adversaries.

A notable feature is that specific secondary activities only unlock post the initial campaign completion‚Äîsome even requiring two endings‚Äîfueling the motivation to embark on the entire journey anew, particularly after an unexpected conclusion. Given its RPG nature, Automata boasts a comprehensive progression system, enabling the equipping of items and mods to enhance character attributes. The ambitious blend of hack-and-slash dynamics with the depth of RPGs proves successful, although the interface can be somewhat bewildering.

While the visual detailing in the sets may not reach the pinnacle, and technical limitations become apparent in fog-covered areas, the indisputable quality of the level design shines through. The game offers a commendable array of environments, ensuring a diverse and engaging exploration experience.

Bold, challenging, and featuring charismatic characters, NieR: Automata isn't just recommended; it's a must-play. Seamlessly merging the best of hack and slash with RPG elements, the game provides an addictive experience, despite minor pacing issues and a lack of complete originality. The robust combat and meticulously crafted open-world spark curiosity, enticing players to explore every possible ending.

This game offers a comprehensive package with refined, dynamic, and rewarding gameplay, coupled with cohesive and customizable systems. It caters to a broad range of players, ensuring accessibility for diverse gaming preferences. At its core, NieR: Automata delivers a captivating narrative that lingers in your thoughts long after you complete the game. Much like my experience, be prepared to emotionally invest in the characters' hardships throughout the plot.

Don't hesitate to give it a try; this isn't merely a game but an immersive experience. You won't regret diving into NieR: Automata and letting its unique narrative unfold.

NieR:Automata is an incredible game that offers a unique experience to players. The graphics are stunning and add to the atmosphere of the game. The world offers a sense of exploration that keeps you engaged and wanting to see more.

The story is one of the best aspects of the game, with an intricate and emotional plot that explores complex themes such as the meaning of life and the nature of humanity. The characters are well-developed and their relationships with each other are explored in a way that makes you care about their journey.

The gameplay is fast-paced and fun, with a variety of weapons and abilities that allow you to approach combat in different ways. The boss fights are particularly memorable, with each one feeling unique and challenging in its own way.

The soundtrack perfectly complements the game's emotional and atmospheric moments. It's one of those soundtracks that you can listen to outside of the game and still feel the same emotions you did while playing.

This game is an absolute masterpiece that offers a captivating experience in literally every aspect. Whether you're looking for a deep and emotional story or fun gameplay, this game has it all. It's a must-play for anyone who loves games that make them have an existential crisis and cry.

Nier: Automata is the child of an uncompromised vision

First impressions were mixed for me. The character design of our lead protagonist, kanata wielding, maid outfit wearing female combat android 2B, leaned into its anime roots with impressive conviction. Your mileage may vary, I was interested. The first hints of the plot were intriguing, and the frenetic combat system impresses with tight, reactive controls and a rich collection of scenarios and game modes. 

The color scheme, on the other hand, limits itself to muted colors and sparse textures, giving the entire game world a worn, washed-out feeling. The choice of having about an hour of tutorial without the opportunity of a save point seems weirdly cruel and antiquated, especially because that first hour has a really steep difficulty curve. Said tutorial also neglects to introduce any of the RPG elements in the game‚Äôs collection. So when I was finally let loose in its modestly dimensioned open world, I wasn‚Äôt quite sold on it. 

Things improve at a slow but steady rate, though. A growing stable of weapons and other upgrades bring variety and novelty into the combat. The spectacle fighter mechanics click somewhat with the bullet hell shooter elements that show up whenever one of the enemies has a gun.  The plot picks up and maintains steam on its way to some very weird and intriguing places. Side quests surprise with quirkiness and and often surprising depth. 

Questions remain, though: Why is almost every enemy a variation on the theme ‚Äúrusty beer can‚Äù? Why is our protagonist so cold towards her enchantingly naive sidekick? Why do I have the option to kill my protagonist by deinstalling her OS? 

On the gameplay side of things, it‚Äôs wasn‚Äôt smooth sailing either: Over time, I settled on a combination of weapons and upgrades that broke the difficulty curve, and at that point, combat started becoming samey, except for the impressive boss fights. The dialogue seemed stilted and inelegant. The game kept its fast travel mechanics locked for a little too long and its ultimate gear upgrades were a little too grindy to obtain to bother with for me. 

And then the game ended with a moderately satisfying ending, dumped me into the main menu, winked at me and gesticulated towards the ‚ÄúNew Game‚Äù button. Which dumped me into the shoes of emo twink 9S, who had so far been the sidekick. 

And so I went through the whole story again, but with a lot more context this time. Also, there were instances in the first playthrough where 2B and 9S had split up, and the stuff 9S was up to during these times threw an entirely new light on things. Gameplay added a lot more bullet hell shooter elements, and the weird, impenetrable little plot kept growing and changing and turning into this epic greek tragedy, until a terrifying climax left me shaken, looking at the main menu and hitting the ‚ÄúNew Game‚Äù-Button again, impatient to what would be different this time. 

Everything, as it turned out: playthrough 3 hides the second part of the game. The plot keeps escalating and escalating, the existential dread is turned up to eleven. Time ceases to have any meaning. The fourth wall shudders and cracks. Several tens of hours filled with escalations and re-interpretations later, the game finds a suitably weird, thought-provoking and mind-blowing ending. 

And then, the god-damn end credits turn into a unique, sublime mind fuck of an EXPERIENCE I would on the pain of death not dare spoil, but which every gamer on this planet should experience.                                             Seriously, it‚Äôs that good.

And when I was done picking my chin up from the floor, something amazing happened: All the weirdness, all the inexplicably awkward design choices revealed themselves to be the outgrowths and consequences of a uniquely strong artistic vision. Seriously, I can practically see the contempt on Yoko Taro‚Äôs face while he blazes past every fork on the road that would increase player comfort but even slightly tarnish the coherence and integrity of his creation. I mean, I realize this was a work of a small army of creative talents, but they must have had a mind meld going on in that studio of theirs, because I, at least, really felt like I connected to a person through this one, a visionary artist with a few blind spots in map and UI design, and maybe a bit too much into waifish maids. 

The Credits. Man, those credits. 

TLDR: The story people have played this long ago, as every one of them should. The gameplay tribe should know that the offerings here are serviceable to good, but you‚Äôll get to be gobsmacked with the rest of us, and isn‚Äôt that kind of experience the reason we‚Äôre here, after all? I know I am.

NieR:Automata is basically what would happen if existential dread and pure optimism decided to have a child and that child was a video game.

This game will make you feel sad, nostalgic, happy, and missing it when its over by the end. I'd say the soundtrack is the major culprit of this. The soundtrack of this game is masterfully crafted to get higher during intense moments, get more rompy and epic when you are exploring a lot, and get all nostalgic and sad when you are just chilling talking to people in quests. It knows how to really set the tone, and the story is gripping enough that it has a lot of emotional range to work with. 

Seriously every song has like 4 versions that play dynamically depending on where you are and what is happening and that contributes to an atmosphere this game has that is out of this world good. I believe the term for this is synethesia. Where all your senses combine to elevate an experience. This game is very good at that.

Like look, I'm sure if you're scrolling on by 90% of this game looks like an animu hack and slash with 2B, who everyone basically thinks of when they think of anime waifu. While I can't entirely deny that is the case, I'd say thats just the wrapping on the outside. Inside the game is a thorough deconstruction of ideas of humanity, philosophy, and what is right and wrong, and what it even means to exist and be alive.

Its also manages to have one of the most heartwarming for real endings in gaming history. I won't spoil it, but a lot of players will have sacrificed much of their time to get you to the true happy ending that couldn't be possible without them. You'll know why when you get there.

Thank you all for your sacrifice.

NieR:Automata is a hack and slash, like I mentioned before. But even though the story is awesome and the music is like getting an ear massage by the breath of angels doesn't mean that the gameplay is boring. Its actually pretty friggen great. Combat is tight and visceral. Slashing enemies feels good and even on replays I still found it very engaging. Parrying feels amazing and its not too difficult to get good at. Some enemies with massive health bars can be a drag to kill, but none of them are part of the main story and you can always ignore them and come back later to fight them when you are stronger. 

The leveling system also carries between characters so even if you stop playing as 2B for awhile and play as 9S or A2 you still get to keep your same level of strength, even if the playstyles are pretty different.

9S plays like a CIA secret spy agent and hacks everyone with a special minigame. He isn't very tough physically though so don't push him too hard or he'll fall over since the clumsy little dude legit gets knocked by like, every hit. His hacking is neat though. He even has a special quest dedicated to him hacking robots where you fight in an arena as one of the robots you hacked before.

I'll give you a hint. Use the T Rex robot. Win. Thats the hint. You don't need anything else. Stop standing around, I'm not gonna give you any more information.

A2 and 2B play a bit similar since they both use 2 weapons, except 2B is a tank that can take all the hits and has a pretty balanced moveset that uses combos and A2 is aggressive and has a moveset that mostly revolves around smacking things while screaming until they stop moving. She can also absolutely destroy her health in exchange for a massive power boost. I didn't use this much though because, while it is powerful, it can kill you if you aren't careful.

The game also features a Dark Souls style death system where if you die, you drop all your equipped chips and money right there. If you make it back to your body you can get your stuff back. Its as fun as it sounds.

Later on if you die its a bit more permanent. But I fortunately didn't have that issue much because by then you've gotten enough good gear and are practiced enough at the game that death is rare. At least it was for me anyways. I think I died maybe twice after that point but that was mostly because I goofed doing 9S's hacking minigame attack on an enemy while trying to eat pizza at the same time and then kind of stood there while an enemy robot kicked my face into smaller tinier pieces of face.

Overall if you're worried about difficulty and just want to see the story, or just want to watch 2B kill robots while you slowly eat cheetos out of a bowl, you can turn on auto mode by equipping the chips in your inventory. This will make her AI take over the hard part during combat so you can just kinda hit two buttons and without having to be bothered with things like paying attention or actually playing the game and instead spend your time ogling the protagonist.

You people know who you are.

Its also good for disabled people since the game allows you to customize exactly what is auto and what isn't. You could, for example, have the shooting be auto while you focused on slashing the bad guys. That way you still get to participate, but don't have to be super spot on with your reflexes to play the game.

Thats a nice feature for accessibility.

So who are your 3 protagonists?

2B is a quiet killer android girl that deep down just wants to be loved and hates her job. She kills robots and tries to save the earth but that of course is complicated by the fact that earth is already kinda screwed over by robots and the apocalypse and there isn't much she can do about it. She does what she can, and that is how she rationalizes the uphill battle she fights in.

9S is a happy go lucky curious android boy that deep down has a lot of pent of anger and fear and asks way too many questions that get him way too many unhappy answers. He and 2B are partners but hoo boy if they don't have a lot of issues to work out by the end of the game. He also kinda loves 2B. He kinda hates 2B. He also kinda wants to bang 2B. (I mean who doesn't tho) 

He's a complicated guy.

A2 is an angry android girl that deep down is an even angrier android girl. She is played by Cherami Leigh who usually plays happy ladies and it is odd to listen to her curse and gutterly yell at people but she does a good job at playing an impatient soldier girl that just wants to murder everyone who won't leave her alone to let her stare wistfully at the sunset while remembering all her dead comrades.

These have intersecting stories that connect over the course of the game and let you get to know each one in a different context. While 2B and 9S have a lot of the same campaign arc, they follow entirely different paths during most major beats of the game. For example 2B will have a boss fight in a dark factory with a shielded robot. 9S will hack the robot sometimes to shut off the shield so he can be destroyed. However AS 9S you actually have to hack the robot yourself while 2B fights it. So yeah, you are treading old ground. But its in an entirely new context which still keeps it interesting.

These 3 will become important to you by the time you finish this game. Even when they do dumb stuff, you can't help but like the guys. Like sure A2 is mean as heck to Pod who is legit only there to help her. But A2 is only a mad girl because life was mean to her. So you can't really ever fault her for her behavior. Its not like anybody was there to show her manners or how to cut her hair properly WITHOUT using a sword. Considering most of her friends are dead, I'd say her attitude makes sense tho.

All told this game is pretty fantastic and is a gem of a game. I'd go so far to say its one of the best games ever made. It has the laughs, the tears, and a soundtrack every youtuber seems to want to use as background music when they say sad stuff or ask for money.

Seriously, ya'll always play City Ruins in the background of your videos, but never the Amusement Park theme.

So I highly recommend this game. Yeah I know its got a bit of a price tag and hardly goes on sale. You'll thank me later though. Its a masterpiece.

It kinda kills me to leave a negative review because the story and world building are both amazing but so far it's been a really frustrating experience for all the wrong reasons.

1) Soo little effort has been put in to make the PC port run well, all the controls are optimized for console and provide far too few options to adjust. The worst of which is, and i kid you not, if you move your mouse in a circle you start petting your pod/droid which causes you to stand dead still for 4 seconds even if you are mid combat. This has happened HUNDREDS of times already for me and caused very annoying deaths, and there is no way to turn it off. I also really dislike the dodge being a WASD double click and can't change that either.

2) The camera switches between 3D, top-down and side view. When this works well it can make platforming smoother but most of the time it just feels like the game is taking control away from you and makes it harder to look at what you want to.

3) Bullet-hell gameplay sucks. I'm here for the story and combat. To me these sections feel like a boring and unforgiving mini-game.

4) Tutorial is way too hard, long and contains no checkpoints. At the end there is a boss fight who has several insta-kill attacks that kick you back 30 minutes of grueling tutorial with unstoppable dialogue. And the strange thing is that it gets so much easier once the main game stars. The tutorial has literally the sharpest difficulty spike and least forgiving save system in the whole game for no reason.

5) Your sidekick loves pushing you off ledges and getting in front of people you want to talk to and chests you want to open, causing you to speak to him instead.

6) Melee combat is more fun, but the game heavily incentivizes you to just constantly run from the enemy while shooting backwards.

As I started out saying, I really want to like this game, the philosophical themes really resonate with me, the writing is clever and the world pretty. All in all I will probably finish the game for these reasons but for a AAA game that has been out for so long there are just a stupid amounts of annoyances.

Nier: Automata is like a fever dream that you never want to wake up from. It's a game where you play as a hot android who gets to slice and dice through a post-apocalyptic world filled with killer robots. And if that's not enough to get your motor running, then I don't know what is.  But here's the kicker - the game also has a talking robot head as one of its main characters. 

Yes, you read that right - a talking robot head. And not just any talking robot head, but one that has a sassy attitude and is always ready with a snarky remark.  If you're looking for a game that's equal parts action, drama, and absurdity, then Nier: Automata is the game for you. Just be prepared to have your mind blown and your expectations shattered. Oh, and also be prepared to talk to a talking robot head. Because that's just how this game rolls.

This is a no spoiler review. I Heard good things about the game around when it was released but didn't play it. 6 months ago I started to listen to the game soundtrack and fell in love with it. A month ago I started playing the game and recently finished it. Now when I listen to the soundtrack, it's hard not to cry. This game is a gut-wrenchingly sad but beautiful tale that has left me to spend a good deal of time putting the pieces together, contemplating what the intended message of the story actually is. It's by now means a perfect game, and many of the "flaws" are a matter of taste or  opinion, but if you enjoy the opening act, chances are you'll enjoy the entirety of the game. 

For me, the soundtrack alone would have made the game worth playing. I listen to a lot of music variety and the score from this game is very close to the top of anything I've heard.

 The movement and fighting mechanics feel very good but I think they are under-utilized. Given that the game has 4 difficulty levels, the majority of fighting mechanics feel superfluous and entirely unnecessary, though I only played the game on level 2 (normal). Mostly it comes down to whether you can evade/jump at the correct time to dodge attacks and how quickly you can button mash the same 3 basic attacks to hack through enemies. I enjoyed the fighting mechanics, but I don't see myself going back and repeating the game at a higher difficulty level. 

The side content is interesting and often tries to hide some deeper meaning within, but is mostly unnecessary to the overall game. That's the curse of open-world style games, I guess. Most side quests have some amusing/charming elements to them, but sometimes they just feel like a slog and weren't very well polished. It sort of feels like the director focused his attention on the main quest and let the interns work on the side-quests, only ensuring that the writing agreed with the overall plot of the game. In other words, they are hit-or-miss. 

The main factor that makes this game a massive hit is the plot and storytelling of the main quest line. It takes the ideas of many Western philosophers and presents them in a way that is emotional and entertaining. It tries to make you think about life. And death. And this is where you will either love or hate this game. I'm not even sure there is an in-between. The opening act should determine whether it's a game you'll enjoy. Obviously I loved it, and will be returning to play some of the director's other games...

[h1]Overall score: [spoiler]9[/spoiler][/h1]

Entertaining (although shallow) story, fun combat, unique bosses, interesting side quests. But between the unique bosses are a lot of running around, grinding, repetitive mobs, misleading maps, non-toggleable quest markers, not-very-useful fast travel that always seems to be disabled for the places you need to go, and invisible walls blocking you from travelling intuitive direct routes. Pulled up video walkthroughs more than once just to understand the intended route to get around some infuriating invisible wall and get to the next bossfight. Most of my gameplay time was running and grinding mobs, which is just not fun for me.

Nier: Automata isn't just a game; it's a symphony of gameplay and music that orchestrates a mesmerizing journey through a post-apocalyptic world. PlatinumGames' combat finesse, a seamless fusion of hack-and-slash and shoot-'em-up brilliance, turns every encounter into a visceral dance of blades and bullets. Keiichi Okabe's musical masterpiece acts as the emotional backbone, enhancing the narrative and propelling the gaming experience to unparalleled heights.

Yet, amidst the brilliance, there are occasional hiccups. The camera angles, usually a dance partner in the combat spectacle, can be a bit rebellious during intense sequences, occasionally disrupting the fluidity. The PC port, while serviceable, imposes a 60Hz cap, leaving high-refresh-rate monitor enthusiasts yearning for a more visually fluid experience.

However, Nier: Automata's allure goes beyond these technical quibbles. With only Ending A under my belt, the promise of multiple endings teases at unexplored narrative depths, beckoning players to return for more. The game's ability to seamlessly intertwine music and gameplay creates an unforgettable symphony that resonates, making Nier: Automata a must-experience for those who crave a unique and captivating adventure in the realm where the extraordinary meets the eccentric.

I originally played and beat this on console back before I had a good PC, after getting the true ending I ended up having almost 100 hours on the game.
This game is something very, very special and is one of the BEST game I have ever played, this is my favorite game of all time! And for good reason. Everything about it is perfect, the gameplay is fun, flashy and fluid with diverse combos for weapons and chip sets/skills to work along side each other. The soundtrack is one of the best game soundtracks I have ever heard. You will not regret playing this game. I highly recommend working to get ending E which does require multiple playthroughs, but it's not like you're playing through the same thing multiple times. It gradually gets different and plays out in the form of several acts. This game deserves no less than a 20/10.

one of my favourite games also amazing soundtracks

NieR: Automata is one of the greatest games I have ever played. The visuals and atmosphere are top-notch, and work in harmony with the soundtrack to create a game that can truly be considered art. The story, concepts and ideas are so far beyond what I ever expected of a video game to elevate it to the same level as some historic philosophical works. The experience is something I never will forget.

That said, the PC port is iffy. Some people have no problems, some people (like me) will get a constant 40 FPS and choppy experience on maxed out graphics or on the absolute lowest graphics, even with the community mods designed to fix that.

EDIT: After playing NieR: A., I can safely say that this is my favorite game of all time. That still does not excuse the poor PC performance that I had and the hours I spent having to mod it to get it to work at a decent framerate. If you can, play on console or wait for a remaster (the game could use it!)
After 40 hours of playing, completing all 4 main endings A B C D E, an indescribable feeling, a great game, a meaningful world, a game that must be played

I really really liked it, but didn't really love it. At times you felt big emotions for the characters and at times I found myself not caring at all with what was happening.

A cool way to reveal the story/plot, I can kinda appreciate the artistic way of telling the story in "multiple playthroughs" but then again did I have to watch the end credits three(four?) times? Cool places to explore, good voice acting, fast paced, but at times very repetitive in combat. 
Hacking minigame got boring after the fifth time, and then you are forced to do it couple of hundred times more.

Remember to stack up on heals before you go start the final fight.

Everything that lives is designed to end. We are perpetually trapped... in a never-ending spiral of life and death. Is this a curse? Or some kind of punishment? I often think about the god who blessed us with this cryptic puzzle and wonder if we'll ever have the change to kill him.
Glory to mankind
so good

If you came to the store page because of the hype around the game or because you think 2B is hot, then this review is for you.

2B is hot. The game is not.

I solely believe that everyone that claims to love the game just love the character design and music, because that is the only strong point that Nier:Automata has to offer. 

Anything that is said about beautiful scenarios and atmosphere is overstimated. 

The scenarios present are as little as four that I will not spoil because god knows you will buy the game anyways if you are as far into the reviews to get into a negative one.

But keep in mind that while this games tries to be a hack-and-slash, a bullethell, an RPG and a story-rich adventure, it does all of those and also fails at all of those. 

It's a jack-of-all-trades and master of no one.

I'd be positive about it if it wasn't by the fact that the main hook is the story. 

And I kid you not, this game has the most foreshadowed, predictable plot twist I have ever seen. So much that I was left out feeling that there had to be another twist, something else because by the end of it I felt that it was telling me that the Earth was round and expecting me to feel astonished by that fact.

If you are coming here not for the positive reasons I listed above and are looking for a story rich original game..., keep looking. 

This one has nothing to offer but round butts and a funny twink. For most, that was enough to give this game a positive review.

But not for me.

Some of the greatest examples of videogames as a medium for storytelling.

Being a fan of Bayonetta and PlatinumGames in general, was only natural I'd like this. Though, there were some things I didn't like. One of the most disappointing and frustrating games I've played in a long time. I really wanted to like this game since it is innovative, has an immersive story with great music and has some truly amazing cut scenes. However, problems began early with the map system - there's a quest over here (where??), nevermind, that quest is underground. And, Oh, the quests!! Even on easy mode, some of these are near impossible. The turning point for me was a side quest called "Family Squabbles" - ridiculously difficult and made me uninstall the game. Games are meant to be fun, not something you smash your controller out of frustration over. Time to move on and leave this game to the huge fanbase. Anyone got an extra controller for sale??

Lovely emotional rollercoaster of a story with a beautiful OST and customizable fighting styles. Do the side quests if you want to better immerses yourself in the world building and understand some of the concepts for the main story; recommended but not a requirement. This is a game you need to play multiple times to see the whole story. Will make you question what it means to be sentient.
amazing game gives you a challenge and very unique narratively this is a must play game for people that want to experience something fresh

Love. Love the characters / Love the style / Love the fighting system / Love the open-world / Love the music / Love the story. If you watch animes you`ll love this game. I always recommend this game to my friends.

The best single player game I've ever played in my life. 

It looks like some stupid "jp hack and slash starring a kinky french maid dominatrix", but it actually plays like a christopher nolan/denis villeneuve movie w/ hans zimmer OST.

I highly recommend you see the yt video "How NieR: Automata Tells the Ultimate Humanist Fable" after you finish all the endings, as there are far too many philosophical themes baked in this masterpiece.

Pretty good hack-n-slash adventure, with a decent story, and catchy soundtrack.

After hearing so many people sing its praises for years, I was actually expecting the story to be much more interesting and deep, with all the talk about its "philosophical themes" and "existential questions" and whatnot... but it turns out those are really there as window dressing more than anything else. The story isn't deeper just because NPCs have a theme of being named after famous philosophers. 

The narrative does have a couple of interesting twists & fourth-wall-breaks, but overall, I don't think it's as groundbreaking and earth-shatteringly good as some other reviews make it sound. Set your expectations accordingly.

Also, this PC version has some problems, you may want to download some community mods to fix a few things, but it's not too bad.

Works great on Steam Deck.
Ye
Pretty lady; I don't know what's going on. Combat is fun asf.

NieR:Automata is hands-down one of the best single player experiences on the market.  The combat is satisfying and flows effortlessly once you get used to the controls.  The story is excellent and constantly defies your expectations.  Despite the game being about machines, the story can get very profound about humanity and what it means to be human.  I genuinely feel bad for those who got the first ending and didn't continue playing to see the other endings because they missed out on half the game.  Make sure to keep using the same save file so you can experience all this game has to offer, you won't regret it
One of my all time favorite Square Enix games.
kurczaczki no fajna gierka :steamhappy: :3
cool gam
It's a masterpiece for me, nothing more need to be said

bad texture 
perfect sound and story + 2B's butt:)

If you don't want to read, skip side quests; main story missions only make this game a bearable; I can't imagine the time suck to 100% this game for the lore; its not worth it.

There is something frustrating I'm finding with Japanese game development and its not just the Souls Like, One Hit Deaths but the pure lack of functionality. There is literally a character to tell you in the Resistance Camp "there is no auto-save" and other complains are listed as basically an FAQ on why design decisions were made... It does get easier with the Access Points but man to these devs just miss some basics when it comes to game play functionality and fluidity.
Very mediocre, nothing special, there are only two good things about this game: Pascal and Emil.

Maybe 81 hours is not a lot compare to other games/ gamers, but this game is still great. I played to get 100% of the achievements and enjoyed each and every time i got to the game. Story rich, great gameplay, amazing sound/ music/ VA and the animation is great.
SPOILERS ABOUT THE GAME:












First spoiler is that you can play as few characters which means that in order to 100% the game you would have to play the game 2 or more time, each time in with different character.
Second spoiler is specifically about the achievement "The Minds That Emerged" -  if you wish to get this achievement keep in mind that you will have to delete ALL of your data saves/ worlds. you CANT save any of the world which means that it should be your last achievement to get if you want to fully explore and enjoy the game. I don't know if you can copy the save file from the game folder to save said file so the risk is on you.

This game is a masterpiece from beginning to end, the music score, the story, and many genres of video games all put into one this is a game you can keep coming back to and play, with it's countless endings side quests and different characters to play as, after finishing this game there are still things i'm discovering ,since it's release I have never played a game that compares to this beautifully executed masterpiece I honestly gave up playing other games because i feel no other game will ever be up to par with nier automata, until Nier 3 comes out maybe that will surpass this and that's probably a big maybe. stop wondering if you should buy this just get it!!!

NieR: Automata offers an immersive experience that stands out as a masterpiece in the gaming world. The game captivates players not only with its gameplay mechanics, but also with in-depth storytelling and an atmospheric world.

The game's story is unusual and complex. This epic story about the struggle between humanity and artificial intelligence transforms the game from a mere entertainment tool into a thought-provoking work of art. The in-depth character development and plot twists draw players into a labyrinth of thought.

Graphically, NieR: Automata is a stunning visual feast. The game's world comes to life with exquisitely designed environments and detailed character models. Visual effects and the overall aesthetic of the game provide players with an unforgettable visual experience.

The music further enhances the atmosphere of the game. The music changes according to the various moments of the game, adding emotional depth. The fast-paced music during action scenes increases the excitement of the game, while the touching melodies and instruments during melancholic moments give players the opportunity to make an emotional connection.

Another remarkable feature of the game is its gameplay mechanics. A fast-paced combat system and a variety of weapon options provide players with an experience that suits a variety of play styles. These mechanics increase the replayability of the game and provide long-lasting enjoyment.

However, like any game, NieR: Automata may be subject to some criticism. Technical issues, poor performance and some bugs can negatively affect the gameplay experience. However, the overall experience of the game outweighs these technical issues.

In conclusion, NieR: Automata is not just a game, but a work of art and storytelling. With its in-depth story, stunning visuals and emotional soundtrack, it offers players an unforgettable experience. This game has earned a rightful place among the extraordinary works in the gaming world.
Nice story plot
It's pretty good :3

Hope you like crashing. This game has not been fully fixed with updates. The PC port had a lot of known issues when it was first released and when I originally started playing you had to download a MOD to fix the most basic issues (FAR). I was told the game has received multiple updates since that time that should fix the problems, but I still experience random crashes playing this game. I have zero stability issues with my PC and no issues with anything else crashing. Brand new clean install of Windows 10, Latest Nvidia drivers and the game still closes itself periodically. There are no error messages or any indication that anything is wrong with the game. I'm playing on a 12600K, 3060ti and gen4 nvme drive. The crashes happen at completely random points so sometimes I may get 20 minutes of playing in before the game closes and other times maybe i can play for an hour. Did I mention the game only lets you save and very specific areas and the autosave is very unforgiving? You will be replaying a lot of content, which brings me to the game itself. 



This game gets in the way of itself. I do not find the repeated playthrough method of story telling very enjoyable. When I first beat route A and popped into route B to start playing 90% of the exact game again, but this time as 9S I almost immediately lost interest in the game. The new content was sprinkled so few and far between and was things like, you may see one 20 second cutscene you didn't see on your first playthrough and then are back to the same quests, the same horrible to traverse map, (the map system in this game is also awful), killing the same enemies and following the same main quest. I stopped playing for over two years because of this, but since I do enjoy many aspects of this game I decided to give it another shot recently. After beating playthrough B, playthrough C starts with a huge difficulty spike. I was level 40 upon entering the C playthrough and the lowest enemies I was encountering were 45. Many of the enemies were all the way up to level 60 and could nearly one shot me. The game floods you with extremely annoying tactics to inflate difficulty like making you lose the ability to move your character, lose the ability to attack, lose the ability to jump, lose the ability to see (98% of your screen a massive red blob of pixels while you're fighting huge mobs of extremely over leveled enemies). Even with this I still pushed through, because I was determined to beat this game. I am now quite close to the end and still can't finish the game thanks to it randomly closing. There is a lot to like about this game, the world is interesting, the actual gameplay itself is fun and varied, the characters are likeable, etc, but so much gets in the way of just experiencing the story. Many herald it as one of the best games ever because of this, but I do not find this an enjoyable method of experiencing a game especially in this day in age where I have very limited time to play games and an endless backlog. 

````` 

Just to be fair I am updating my review. I tried to continue the game since I was desperate to finally finish this on my Garuda Linux install through Steam and it actually worked fine without crashing. Not sure what the deal is with the quirks I was having on my Windows install. The game overall is pretty great and I am happy I was able to see it through to the end and experience the ending. I would probably overall still recommend playing the Xbox version though so you don't have to deal with these potential crash issues. The game is definitely worth experiencing. I am going to go ahead and change my recommendation to recommended.

It does what it sets out to do very well, but it's definitely not for general audiences. Get a spoiler-free (very important!) idea of the kind of game it is and if it sounds like your thing, it probably is, and if it doesn't, it probably isn't.

Nier: Automata is a game that defies all expectations and breaks new ground in the action RPG genre. It is a stunning example of what happens when a talented team comes together to create something unique and thought-provoking.

The game dives deep into complex themes of existence, consciousness, and the human condition. It blurs the line between androids and humans, forcing players to question what it means to be alive. The storytelling is incredible, with multiple perspectives and branching paths that keep you engaged and emotionally invested.

Visually, Nier: Automata is a treat for the eyes. The environments are beautifully designed, ranging from post-apocalyptic cityscapes to serene and mysterious landscapes. The attention to detail is astounding, creating a believable and immersive world.

What truly sets Nier: Automata apart is its combat. The fast-paced and fluid action is a joy to experience. From hacking enemy robots to engaging in intense boss battles, the combat never gets repetitive or boring. The game constantly keeps you on your toes, challenging you to master different playstyles and abilities.

The soundtrack deserves a special mention, as it perfectly complements the gameplay and enhances the emotions conveyed by the story. The haunting melodies and epic compositions stay with you long after you've put the game down.

Furthermore, the game provides a significant amount of replay value. Multiple playthroughs offer different perspectives and expand on the narrative, revealing hidden secrets and uncovering additional layers of the story.

One small drawback is the occasional technical hiccups and performance issues on the PC version, which can hinder the overall experience. However, the game's strengths far outweigh this minor inconvenience.

In conclusion, Nier: Automata is an absolute gem that pushes boundaries and challenges conventional storytelling. It is a masterclass in art direction, gameplay mechanics, and narrative depth. If you're a fan of thought-provoking stories and unique gameplay experiences, Nier: Automata is a must-play.

The start is BRUTAL! Absolutely RUTHLESS! And if you die you have to do it all over again! It will take roughly 30 minutes to an hour, from start to finish if you're playing on the hardest difficulty, to finish the intro area if you don't fail and yes, you're going to be doing it over and over again. But here is the kicker, if you complete the start, you will know everything you need to know for the rest of the game and be prepared for it. Honestly, while I hated it at first, the more I played it the more I realized that this tutorial area teaches you everything you need to know and then some. Once you understand and know the game from here, you don't feel like anything else that they throw at you is anywhere near as bad and rightfully so. From there you truly get to enjoy the world and the game. It may be hard but I definitely believe that you should give this game a try.

I do want to note, however, that the keyboard controls are complete and utter garbage. Use a controller.

Here's what's good about Nier: Automata:
The heavily detailed open world, combined with somewhat fourth wall breaking gameplay mechanics makes for an extremely immersive experience
The combat system is surprisingly deep. The fast, fluid movement feels so satisfying to play. Hacking is also very fun!
The graphics are incredible and the music is god-tier
This game is so full of content, and there are secrets everywhere. Rather than putting out a half-baked, unfinished mess, PlatinumGames really put their heart and souls into making a completed game, and it definitely shows.

There are a few bad parts too:
Getting all achievements is a grind
Sometimes this game tries to be too immersive. For example, there are many long sections of the game where the pause menu is completely disabled, so you cannot save or load data. Meaning your only option is to hard reset the game, which will cause you to lose progress! This is just poor game design.
The "Hard" difficulty is unbalanced. I chose to play the game on this difficulty thinking it would make combat more interesting, but really all it does is make enemies hit 3x harder. So for anything but the weakest enemies, you're basically a one-shot kill.

Overall, the bad parts that I mentioned are extremely minor compared to all the good things about Nier: Automata. It's a well-rounded, complete game, and as someone who has never played a game like this before, I was constantly surprised with every new thing I saw. I highly recommend playing it!

I haven't quite gotten to ending B yet, but I love this. It's hard to explain. It feels very niche while also being very accessible. The combat is simple but carries depth, while being exceptionally fun. The story carries surprises and invokes emotion and introspection that I didn't expect. Overall this will hold up as a great gem, not easily forgotten. Everybody should experience this game at some point in their life.

Update: I got the three consecutive endings... my life is changed and I'll never be happy again. What has happened to me.

This is a beautiful, artistic game with a strong message. For that, it is worth playing. The combat system is very crisp and free-flowing. If the visual style seems dreary, it's because the style is part of the message. Even if there is some repetitiveness, it's worth playing to the end to see how the story unfolds. 

It's also worth playing Nier Replicant before this game to get more of the story. There are some important references to that game in this one. Nier Replicant (the remaster) is not as crisp as this one - it's an older game - but I think it has a stronger and more emotional story. It depends on your preference. I consider Nier Replicant a masterpiece, and this one comes in second to the first as a very original, artistic and well polished game.

Definitely something different and worth playing. I hope they make yet another Nier sometime in the future.

A post apocalyptic humanist tale, extensively exploring positive existentialism. This game has an ethereal atmosphere supported by a beautifully graceful soundtrack. It's rich in lore  (I hope you like stage plays and mobile games, because it's all relevant and canon, baby), has a masterfully written story down to side quests, and is filled with engaging characters. The game play is varied and features my favourite fight of all times. It will leave you thinking about more heavy topics than I can list. Most importantly, it will make you feel. So. Much.

If this game doesn't change you for the better, I don't know what will.

I'm only a handful of stages in, but this is easily one of the most dramatic use of screen movement I've seen in any game. Every battle you're in feels impactful, from the overall just stunning visuals, to the unique rising music. 

It's a third person action-adventure RPG with bullet hell combat elements. Think Devil May Cry meets any of the dodge and shoot projectiles before they overwhelm you genre. 

Battles will go from your typical third person action combat to a top down camera where you must bullet hell, to then put you in a sidescroller style locked camera, to shifting you into a aircraft to do your typical bullet hell things, to then have that aircraft transform into a gundam to do the top down bullet hell again. 

It sounds like a lot, but it's so seemless, it teaches you fairly well and exposes you do different elements early. Progression is fantastic. Bosses are absolutely immersive. There's an open world element. That's not even touching on the actual plot or story for the world, which is equally interesting and very unique. Combat is tight and fun. A fair amount of customization options.

I waited way too long to play this. I've hit the 6hr mark, haven't even scratched the surface of the game and already see exactly why people hail this game as a masterpiece. It was crafted with love, with attention to detail, with depth that you'd only get from PS1-PS2 era JRPGs in which the world is shameless exactly what the creator wants it to be and a story to tell regardless of how niche it might be. It becomes very clear some of the commentary being made about various subjects early on. 

The only advice I give is that you have to work for your first chance to save. Make sure you're committed enough to get there. It's not incredibly difficult (I'm on normal difficulty), but I definitely got careless thinking  I'd probably respawn. Nope, start the game from the beginning. I think the method is intended though, because after restarting it took me a quarter of the time to get back to where I was, and wasn't painful.

Nier Automata is a fantastic game and definitely a must play for fans of hack and slash games.

The story of Nier:Automata is excellent with some great emotional moments like [spoiler] Pascal's Village and Ending E. [/spoiler] The side quests are also great with the stand out being Emil's Memories which allows you to access t[spoiler]Emil's garden. [/spoiler]. The last ending you get is one of the most powerful emotional experiences in the game is worth the journey to get to. 

On the gameplay side of things, I really liked how the game plays with camera perspectives as well as the bullet hell sections of the game. The hack and slash part of the game is pretty good with some weapon and pod varieties but it felt a bit lacking in depth  alternative combos. There is also some customization that can be done with your equipment chips which felt fairly unique in that you can remove UI elements for some additional power.

Lastly, the soundtrack of Nier:Automata is one of the best among all the games I have played so far and really elevates the entire game to another level of quality. I really liked the Chaos language tracks of each location in the game. Some standout tracks I liked was the theme park theme and Weight of the world which plays at the end credits. 

In summary, Nier:Automata is definitely a must-play for fans of unique stories with great soundtracks.

This is one of the greatest games ever made hands down.....Don't let the scantily-clad anime androids put you off.....not only is the gameplay addictive and the graphics gorgeous, the narrative of this game will both amaze you and cause you to spin out into existential dread at the same time.  One of the few examples of a game that perfectly utilizes the unique characteristics of the video game medium to tell a story, and at that, a story that has massive philosophical relevance to the time we currently live in. NieR is a good game. 

If using Keyboard & Mouse, the NAOIM input overhaul mod makes it a great game. This mod includes proper mouse control, a dedicated dodge button that may be binded, and just overall functionality. I had to set the third person X & Y Axis sensitivity to 3.0 using a 4k resolution.  The mod isn't perfect as some of the hacking sequences later in the game can feel a bit scuffed.


Combat is fluid and flows very well once a few plug in chips are installed. 

The game is effectively divided into 3 arcs: 2B, 9S, & 2A.   

9S's story can be tedious.  You play the same plot line again from 9S's PoV; unfortunately, this means about 1/2 the content is simply repeated.  However, the story beats unique to 9S are vital and very well done.

The third arc is all new content once you've experienced the first two arcs. 

Some of the vistas and environments are best in show. 

Music is very Ghost in the Shell and works incredibly well. I don't know who was who's inspiration, but Yoko Kanno's presence was very much felt in Keiichi Okabe's work in this game.

[h1]NieR:Automata Review[/h1]

First I would like to say I never played any of the other nier games or drakengard games. I know they are connected. But for my gameplay experience it didn't effect me or I didn't felt like I needed to play other games to get the context. Also I want to keep this review spoiler free as much as possible.

[h2]Story[/h2]

Story is basically you play the role of android 2B and her assigned partner 9S as humans try to take the Earth as they take shelter in Moon. Story on surface level feels really simple but the more progress in the game the more you start to see cracks on this premise. What NieR:Automata does very well is asking you philosophical questions and come to conclusions about the actions you make in the course of the game. Overall, the story was stellar and once of a lifetime experience I would say.

10/10

[h2]Setting and Environments[/h2]

NieR has an post-apocalyoptic setting which has tinge of sad but haunting beauty behind it. While some areas can feel colorful and vibrant, some areas feel a bit empty and not as interesting as the other locations. [spoiler]Looking at you desert.[/spoiler] Eventhough this is an open-world game it didn't have to be an open-world. In my opinion linear world would fit this game more because sometimes world can feel really empty like you are just going from A location to B location without anything interesting happening.

7/10

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]

NieR might be a story heavy game but still shines in its combat thanks to PlatinumGames experience in this genre. Combat more revolves around weapons and chips(character upgrades basically) while different weapons offer you different playstyles while chips make you empower those builds or if you are struggling with the game help you in certain scenarios. Personally I'm not a fan of the Bullet Hell type of games and NieR has a lot of those still I throughly enjoyed it. Only criticism I can give is you have to finish the game 3 times to truly finish it. Second playthrough takes away a bit of your freedom and limits your playstyle. If you don't like the new mechanic it can be a bit dreading to play. Also eventhough second playthrough has an important part in the story it feels samey and gets boring real quick.

8/10

[h2]Graphics[/h2]

Although this game isn't groundbreaking on it's graphics I would say it looks still beautiful. And it shows you with it's environments and characters. Overall nothing gorgeous but nothing atrocious. [i]Also you can modify the graphics and models with mods to make it more beautiful[/i]

7/10

[h2]Music[/h2]

If have to summarize the NieR's music I would simply say 'hauntingly beautiful'. Keiichi Okabe's work on this game elevates most of the areas and boss fight and sometimes even taking the spotlight I would say. Making it an unforgettable experience. I still listen to it this and never get tired of it.

10/10

[h2]Overall[/h2]

NieR:Automata is a great game that I will not forget. It was an experience filled with happiness, anger and sadness. Especially the ending section. I would highly recommend.

9.5/10

[i]Personal Note: I never reviewed a game before but was compelled to it and felt like NieR had to be first. Because of this game's impact on me. So even if you don't like story heavy games I would still recommend you to try because few games can offer you this experience.[/i]

It's beautiful. It's tragic. It's sometimes incomprehensible. It's a 3d action platformer, a 2d platformer, a bullet hell, a twin stick shooter, a meditation on consciousness, and it has 26(!) possible endings, most of which you can only get after several playthroughs. Play it.
If you also think Nier Automata is more than a game, chat me up

This isn't my first time playing Automata, and let me tell you Automata is nothing short of a masterpiece in its respective genre. I started out with NieR Gestalt on PS3/Xbox360. So when this game was announced I decided to play the demo prior to release and decided to get the full game, and after progressing past the demo and reaching the "city" I am sure any NieR fan knows exactly what I mean here and hearing the orchestra pick up slowly and then the vocals kick in... Well from that point on that the game was going to be nothing short of something special. To see this series come as far as it has from where it started back when I couldn't even count on hand people I knew who even knew what the series was or even cared for that matter. It's astonishing to see where it is now and if I was told by my future self then that NieR would go on to become as successful as it is now I would have never believed it, but alas here we are and with all that said if you're still one of the people who has not played NieR Automata or on the fence then you owe it to yourself to play this game as there is nothing quite like this unusual and expertly crafted world by Yoko Taro.
amazing game

I'll start by saying this is a good game, but I have no idea why some people act like it is the pinnacle of society. The strongest part of this game is the story, which I will admit is cool and is probably the major reason I was able to complete all of the "core" endings. That being said, however, the story has its issues and like before, I can't understand why so many think it is comparable to the greatest literary works in our world. I'll even go so far to say that if you haven't played at least Replicant, half the story will have very little impact on you and you'll probably actually dislike it. I also believe that the story doesn't really pick up and get "decent" until the 3rd ending, and it doesn't get "good" until the last ending.

The combat has a lot of potential but it isn't realized that well. There are a bunch of weapons, different combos, pods, chips, and upgrades. This is all well and good, until you recognize that all of that is pointless because the enemies are bland and repetitive. They barely react when you hit them (if it wasn't a 1 shot), and increasing difficulty just makes the fight take longer because the enemies now have 5 times the health, with no new AI or movesets. Upping the difficulty also increases enemy damage to a ridiculous amount and until you have leveled up and gotten some good chips, everything will 1-2 shot you. The difficulty scaling in this game in general is weird to me. Easy is pretty much just watching cutscenes with some button mashing in-between when you have to fight something. Normal is still just watching cutscenes with some button mashing in-between when you have to fight something. Hard jumps into unfair territory where you either pay in the most boring way possible to stay alive, or you are dead.

Although I said the story is good, a lot of the characters involved are pretty bland. I know it was a design decision to make them like this, but it wasn't a good choice in my opinion. Many people will say there is a lot of character growth in this game, and I would like to disagree heavily. A great deal of the "character development" for Automata is established outside of this game in side material like the books/manga. The game itself hardly contains any of this context, so we are left with a lot of dry performances between characters that have no personality or chemistry.

Following tradition from Replicant/Gestalt, the side quests are absolutely tedious and horrible. If I wanted to do fetch quests I would play an MMO. There are some gems hidden in the heap of trash, but good lord was it not worth the trouble sifting to find them.

This all leads up to my biggest gripe with the game: rail shooter sections. I understand the desire this series has to change genres rapidly, but holy hell why are there rail shooter segments? Not only why are they there, WHY ARE THERE SO MANY OF THEM? Who likes these? I almost stopped playing every time one of these pop up, including right at the very beginning of the game.

TLDR and my major takeaway: When they are on sale, pick up Nier Replicant and Automata. Play through all of Replicant's endings (better game IMO), and then try to get to ending E in Automata. These are good games and while they have issues I think they are worth a playthrough if you snag them on sale.

TL;DR: One of the most unforgettable experiences in all of gaming, a must-play for anyone who considers themselves a fan of the artistic medium that is videogames. [b]S[/b].

NieR:Automata is my favorite game of all time. I'll admit it, I really love this game. It's been I think a year or maybe two since I first played it and my feelings have barely changed. 

The gameplay is very reminiscent of the character action game genre, albeit it is also an RPG. The open world is there, but it isn't really a selling point as there's very little to do in it. Level design is on point at basically all times, even when levels are reused on subsequent routes. It's not too long either, even if you plan on achieving all of the game's major endings. There are a few points in the game where it is a little too difficult or too easy, at least on normal mode, but it never overstays its welcome. The hard mode's balancing is ridiculous and I don't really find it rewarding to play whatsoever, even though normal mode can get a bit easy near the end of the game. Overall, 9/10 in gameplay, it could be better but not by much.

The story is... excellent. I'd rather not spoil anything, but its a game that you will think about for years after playing it and the story is the reason why. 5/5.

The art is good, even by modern standards for a game that's already 5 years old. In a few places it isn't ideal, and the character designs are... a bit much at times, but there's a reason why 2B is one of the most iconic characters in modern gaming. 4.5/5, it has already aged very well.

They came up with an entire new language for the music, completely unnecessary and just a massive flex, but I'll respect it. 5/5, fantastic, some highlights are the first route's final boss theme and the end credits, as well as the title menu. Weight of the World is one of my favorite songs just period, and even though I prefer the Japanese version, which I don't believe is present in the English release, it's still fantastic.

The game gets a total of 23.5/25, or 94%, which gives it an [b]S[/b]. This game is a must-buy, but at $40 USD it might be worth waiting for a sale.

[h3] This game is an optimization of the previous work in many aspects, including the improvement of the writer's wicked sense of humor. [/h3]
Game: The characters no longer walk stiffly, but there are also some erotic elements. The plot has been complemented a lot, but the save file is still the same old routine. When setting up the battle chip, the game may crash, and the disgusting save mechanism will return your save file directly to the morning, wasting hours of gameplay. The map is also a problem. Sometimes there are no things in the area, but there are small red dots. There are too many air walls on the map, which may cause players to lose their way.
There is no particularly profound discussion in this generation's plot, at least I don't think there is as profound as the previous generation. I have always wanted to say that if you want to create a work that discusses human nature, especially in the robot genre, you must learn to program yourself and understand the difference between a program and a person. You can't just write a person and put a robot's shell on it to tell a morality that people praise.
I didn't see the concept of "transformation", I only saw the setting, which disappointed me about this game.

[b]STORY: 8.5 (Superb) -[/b] I wish that I had the proper words to describe just how excellent NieR:Automata's story is. Since I do not have those words, I will have to settle for calling it simply beautiful. You are immediately thrown into the thick of it from the moment you first start the game and never slow down until it‚Äôs over. Viewed through a literary and narrative lens, Automata‚Äôs storytelling is a masterwork example of the art. At no point does the narrative stray into nonsense or give the feeling of filler material, all while maintaining an ultra serious and dark tone with truly deep themes while never breaking the vital flow. As you play through the game you can clearly feel the story change and evolve in a way that feels believable and alive. The single negative point is that so much of that beauty feels somewhat rushed, leaving you feeling there should have been a bit more.

[b]CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT: 8.5 (Superb) -[/b] If there is one aspect to creating JRPGs that Yoko Taro excels at more than others, it is character development. As with the main story, the main characters evolve and grow right in front of you in ways that make them seem to have a bit of real life. Each one is distinct in every way including the various individual challenges they face and the burdens they bear throughout the ever growing chaos around them. The voice acting is top tier with the actors clearly putting their hearts and souls into their parts. They also know how to convey and draw out emotions almost too well. The dialogue is superb and exceedingly well-written. I can't think of a single time it did not fit or add to any given scene nor an example of it being poorly presented. Even NPCs are treated with a level of depth and detail that make them feel like a living part of the game. As with the main story, the only negative I can find is the feeling that there should have been just a little bit more.

[b]MUSIC 10: (Perfect) -[/b] This soundtrack is another example of being a masterwork of the art. I personally feel that this is one of the single most amazing soundtracks in all of gaming and even across all of media. The attention to detail with regard to timing and adding an emotional level is stunning to say the least. Each track is distinct, of the highest quality, and fits any given environment or scenario to absolute perfection and offers such diversity and variety in styles that it never becomes boring to listen to even tracks that a player hears frequently while in-game. My one disappointment is that there is not more to listen to.

[b]VISUAL PRESENTATION: 9 (Magnificent) -[/b] Yoko Taro's unique and distinctive design work is part of what made him famous and maybe infamous. That style is on full display in Automata and to a level not seen in any of his other works to date. Where his vision truly shines is in his ability to portray that odd and sometimes disturbing style in a way that is still relatable to practically anyone. NieR:Automata is without question the best example yet of this so far. You can just sense that you are experiencing something special and remarkable as you move through the game. The cinematography is essentially perfect for cutscenes, capturing the action and emotion in a way that let‚Äôs you almost feel like you are there with the characters.

[b]GAMEPLAY: 9 (Magnificent) -[/b] The best description I have heard for NieR:Automata's gameplay is 'liquid smooth'. I tend to struggle with super fast and active combat systems so I was a little intimidated by Automata when I first started playing. To my delight, I quickly fell into it without any real need for a learning curve. The response time is incredible and the flow is flawless, even with as fast-paced as the combat system can get. The various functions are integrated seamlessly and are easy to grasp. The customization is quite extensive and feels rewarding, especially when expanding your arsenal. This is one of the finest combat and physics engines I have ever had the pleasure of playing within the genre I adore so dearly.

[b]CONENT: 9 (Magnificent) -[/b] There is a recurring theme with this game...it always seems to feel like there is never quite enough. This category is where I felt that sense the most. NieR:Automata is certainly a large game with a great deal to experience. The various zones are fairly expansive and are all seamlessly interconnected, making the world feel even larger. What makes it feel like there should be more is that it all goes by so fast that you are often left wanting more. I would say that this recurring theme is not so much a lack of content but more a testament to how easily the world, story, and characters hook you and draw you in.

[b]GRAPHICS*: 9 (Magnificent) -[/b] I feel that this category is NieR:Automata's weakest aspect. At the time of it‚Äôs release in 2017, the graphics weren‚Äôt top of the line or hardware extreme but they were certainly higher end. There were some odd persistent graphical problems and anomalies, mainly with regard to texturing and model detail. Even with the recent major update, many of those original small issues remain. While these can be noticeable, they are by no means immersion breaking. If you are willing to venture into the world of modding, every flaw in this category can be rectified.

[b]TOTAL (CORE): 9 (Magnificent)[/b]

[b]TOTAL (EXPANDED)*: 9 (Magnificent)[/b]


[b]FUN FACTOR: 9 (Magnificent) -[/b] I personally love and play JRPGs because stories are what I love for. The more detailed and immersive, the more emotional and moving the story and experience is the more I lose myself in them. However, JRPGs have traditionally not been known for being purely fun to just jump into for the gameplay (though modern entries are quickly changing that). Story and character depth aside, NieR:Automata is one of the most fun JRPGs I have ever played. This game is fun to just pick up and play for the sake of playing. I have a blast running around taking out enemies every time I load up the game and there is little more satisfying that wrecking wave after wave of machine lifeforms.

In my personal opinion, NieR:Automata is one of the finest and most unique JRPGs of all-time, a true gem of the genre. What flaws do exist are almost entirely drowned out by the overwhelming positives this game offers. If you are in the market for a deep and emotionally charged story, I highly recommend this game. You will have your emotions twisted and your existence questioned by the time the roller coaster comes to a stop to let you off.

The best single player experience I have ever had in a video game. Yes there are many endings, but the first 5 matter the most. Play through them all, there will be pain, there may even be tears, but beneath it all is a beautiful story that makes you contemplate what meaning is.

I had very high hopes for Nier Automata due to the high praise it was getting from everyone and it still managed to beat my expectations. As someone who doesn't usually play JRPGs I must say it felt a bit weird at first but I gradually got the hang of it.
 
[NO SPOILERS]

Nier Automata is probably the most gripping game I have ever played. Everything felt so well crafted from its Incredibly beautiful and tragic story to its heavenly music, along with likeable characters and a beautiful world. The game also focuses on some though provoking topics like philosophy, existentialism, literature.

The game has 26 "endings" named from A-Z. The main story takes about 35 hr. to complete and takes you through endings A,B,C,D,E. All other endings are basically "joke" endings which are pretty easy to achieve (except ending Y). Reaching to ending Y takes a lot of grinding and took me nearly 80 hr. to achieve.

From a technical point of view, the game ran smoothly without any issues. It is probably better to use a controller but I played with mouse and keyboard and faced no issues.

This was a once in a lifetime experience I wish I could experience like the first time.

If you're into bad PC ports and controls, generic [strike] weeb [/strike] anime characters, cringe worthy voice acting and dialogue and one of the worst possible starting sections in a video game I've seen, then this game might be for you, I guess.

A fantastic sequel to Nier Replicant/ Gestalt that improves upon the first game in almost every way. The Gameplay is super fun and fluid and its really fun experimenting with the different chip upgrades as well as weapon combinations. 9S's hacking ability was also really fun though it might be a bit difficult for new comers at first. The game is also really good visually and the artstic style of the game stands out. However i will say story wise the game is a bit less compelling than Nier Replicant however the story is still fantastic and the story of 2B and 9S is very tragic. Lastly the soundtrack was also amazing with some really good tracks that keep you engaged with this beautifully dark world.

to be able to save the game you have to finish the prologue. what the game doesnt tell you is that it takes 45+ minutes to finish the prologue, which is a boring repetitive mess and a slog, plus win 2 boss fights, and if you die during the boss fight you have to start the entire process over again. this is a terrible design that one could argue is made to keep people from being able to refund the game by going over the 2 hour limit.

i dont have the time or patience to spend 45 minutes boring myself, just to retry a boss and be able to move on in the game, the rest of the game and story be damned.

not to mention, as is tradition with most japanese made games, the game is hard locked to 60fps and some animations and cutscenes are tied to the games frame rate, meaning modding the game to go above 60fps breaks the game.

The three main areas: city, forest, and desert are beautiful and alive with characters. The melee combat starts off kind of weak and the range kind of slow, but as you level and add upgrades to one or both combat types things improve nicely. The upgrade and weapons systems are deep and allow you to focus on several different build types. The weakest point of the game is the camera, but it is not a big enough issue to harp on; sometimes when it zooms in or out too far it makes seeing your surroundings and enemies difficult, but it isn't a game breaker. Overall it is pretty short if you stick to the main quest, but it offers replayability in unlocking the other endings (which I almost certainly won't do).
