So, this is going to be a interesting review since i haven't done one in a good while after my Alan Wake review, but a lot's kinda happened so i haven't been able to do one yet, most of it's personal stuff I don't really want to get into, but before I start reviewing, I might as well state the reason why I got this game, two reasons why is because that first, I recently preordered Alan Wake 2, and that doesn't come out until later in October and second, because after I finished Death Stranding, my uncle recommended me to play this game, so after a few months, I did, and this is the result, as usual, Sections for Story, Music, and gameplay, and this time, World, trust me.

Story: The story is actually really good, like specifically, when it comes to characters, you can really get attached to them, like say Pascal, the machine is a lovable character and just wants peace [spoiler]until the village gets attacked later in the story[/spoiler] and from what i've seen, the lore apparently way more deeper then I realized, not as much as say Destiny per say, but it's still deep, so I encourage you to check the lore in your spare time, it's complex as hell but interesting, oh, and let's not forget about how you progress the story, specifically, if you want to finish the game, you gotta beat it at least 3 times to get the full story, and how it does it, well, reminds me a lot of MGSV actually, because when you go through each playthrough, it feels like a free built in DLC that expands the story, where this game feels like it has something MGSV doesn't really have: Chapter segements.

Music: Beautiful and really good, It fits the world really well, and really dramatic, not much I can say here really, just loved the music because Weight of the World kinda made me cry after i finished playing

Gameplay: Loved it, It has the same feel as say DMC, oh and Pods are your best friend so try and use them when you can, and hell, even the sidequests themselves feel fun aswell, kinda shocking i know, but it's a first for everything, and when you die in game, the game will keep your corpse until you come back and collect it, which is pretty helpful despite this game not being a souls-like

World: Best way I can describe it is that it's like a Ghibli film but darker and philosophical then Grave of the Fireflies, but also very peaceful (if you ignore the killer machines), and just that when you walk around the world, you can't help but feel, well, kinda sad for some reason, at least, that's how it felt for me.

Final Thoughts: Nier Automata is a game that has managed to make me cry after playing the game, and I personally think that's saying something, I love the story, personal favorite, and IS in the same level as Death Stranding in my opinion, and has themes in it that remind me of Everything Everywhere all at Once, the final thoughts are short because i realize that most of what I wanted to say didn't need to be censored, Honestly, doing this i thought I had to censor most of the story segment, but I didn't need to and only censored one part of it, which is...actually, you just have to see it in game to see what I mean, so, in other words, keep on keeping on for the glory to mankind.

I am a bit mixed on this since it started so high. But it sure ended low. I'll explain without spoiling. Game completed entirely on Normal difficulty. The tie breaker between good and bad was broken by technical problems.

-The Bad-
*Anything to do with the mini-game which is unlocked later in the game. It overstays its welcome by several magnitudes and becomes such a detriment that it actively sucks the fun out of the game. It breaks the flow of the game a lot. There is no way to alter the core gameplay through chips or weapons like everything else in the game. The first time will be the same as the last. What starts off as a novel and interesting idea for a game within a game, it is quickly shown to be shallow and repetitive. It's not bad. There is just way too much of it. You are warned. If you buy this game, by the time you know what this is it's too late.

*I had this game crash 4 times total. 3 of those were at the final ending for the main story. Coupled with my frustrations at the mini-game sections, it totally robbed me of the joy of seeing the proper ending. Great port, SE. Well done. I also ran into what is known as the "white screen of death". It is a white screen only but button inputs still seem to work. I mashed buttons and got out of it somehow but it's still noteworthy.

-The Good-
*This game has a really fun combat system with several weapons that pair together in different move-sets. You can have a variety of attacks to dispatch your foes. There are also many ways to customize your characters through various chips. [i]Edit: This has a very big and obvious caveat that ties into the first main "bad" point I made.[/i]

*There are many side quests that take you to all parts of the game's world.

*Most of the characters are likable.

*A very unique and interesting approach to story-telling and camera work.

*Incredible OST.

The game is fine. I loved some aspects and not others. A literal mixed bag for me. However, it's entirely serviceable but I'm not sure I'll be revisiting this any time in the near future.

[h3][b]Keep in mind that the ultimate conclusion cyclically aligns with the initial outset.[/b][/h3]

[b]NieR: Automata[/b] stands as a profoundly intellectually stimulating and emotionally immersive opus. The intricacy of its narrative is imbued with finesse, with each facet of its structurally delineated artistry showcasing uniquely exquisite conceptualizations. This aesthetic allure unfolds in multifarious layers, masterfully interwoven.

The underlying philosophy coursing through NieR: Automata delves into profound existential and nihilistic inquiries, offering an intriguing opportunity to illuminate the labyrinthine tapestry of meanings woven within its narrative and philosophical framework.

[b]"[/b][i]Everything that lives is designed to end. We are perpetually trapped in a never-ending spiral of life and death. Is this a curse? Or some kind of punishment? I often think about the god who blessed us with this cryptic puzzle, and wonder if we'll ever get the chance to kill him.[/i][b]"[/b]

Friedrich Nietzsche, the herald of the trenchant aphorism "God is dead," expounded upon the metamorphosis of morality and beliefs in the modern epoch. Within Nietzschean philosophy, this aphorism signifies the gradual erosion of traditional religious convictions, giving rise to a metaphysical void. As contemporary society distances itself from theological conceptions wherein God is the fount of meaning and values, an existential abyss and tormented existence emerge. In Nietzsche's "Thus Spoke Zarathustra," composed in 1883, the intricacy of the "eternal return" concept is meticulously explored. It posits that in an infinite and cyclical cosmos, every event, past, present, or future, inexorably repeats, bearing profound existential implications. The protagonist, Zarathustra, confronts the vision of eternal recurrence, initially overwhelmed by the weight of an existence perpetually echoing itself. Nevertheless, as the narrative unfolds, Zarathustra transcends this nihilistic perspective, embracing the notion as a challenge to live authentically and forge one's own purpose amidst the repetition of existence.

[b]"[/b][i]Everything that lives is designed to end. They are perpetually trapped in a never-ending spiral of life and death. However, life is all about the struggle within this cycle. That is what 'we' believe.[/i][b]"[/b]

The contemplation of death lies at the heart of profound ontological inquiries within philosophical currents. Death, the most somber inevitability in human existence, bestows upon us the poignant capacity for reflection. The absurdity encapsulating death may not represent the initial definition of death proffered in Jean-Paul Sartre's 1943 magnum opus, "Being and Nothingness," but it serves to underscore its logical primacy within Sartre's oeuvre. Sartre's conception of the absurdity of death embarks on a philosophical voyage, unfurling into a nuanced examination of the human condition confronted with its inexorable and inescapable terminus. For Sartre, death ascends to the zenith of absurdity because, despite our Herculean efforts to ascribe meaning to life, death remains the immutable event that terminates all our achievements and aspirations. It represents the ultimate and insurmountable divide that renders ephemeral our endeavors and struggles. Thus, the existential paradox is evident: despite our freedom to elect our values and purposes in life, death serves as an unyielding constraint, causing all semblance of meaning to dissipate in the face of finite existence. This dialectic between freedom and death begets profound anguish; even as we consciously select our actions and values, we are eternally confronted with the inevitability of ultimate annihilation. Hence, death, in Sartre's worldview, emerges as a pivotal element of human existence, not solely as life's conclusion but as an incessant reminder of the transitory nature of our endeavors. It stands as a mirror reflecting our ceaseless struggle to unearth meaning and purpose, even when confronted with the void of inherent significance.

[b]"[/b][i]A future is not given to you. It is something you must take for yourself.[/i][b]"[/b]

In the work "Existentialism is a Humanism," penned by Jean-Paul Sartre in 1946, a cogent apologia for existentialism is enunciated, championing the primacy of human existence over essence. Sartre underscores that human beings are fundamentally endowed with freedom, thrust into the world devoid of preordained purpose, thereby bearing the responsibility to craft their own meaning and values. Existence, he contends, precedes essence, and within this radical liberty resides the agonizing, yet transformative potential for each individual to mold their own destiny and genuinely embrace their human condition. The cosmos' void endows us with a unique quest to construct our essence.

The musical tapestry of NieR: Automata unfurls as a sublime labyrinth of harmonies, resonating within the very core of the game, surpassing the boundaries of mere convention.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7jna9bvhdRE

The painstakingly crafted score by Keiichi Okabe materializes as a symphony of emotions, akin to rivers of consciousness navigating the tumultuous waters of hope and desolation. Each musical composition stands as a sonorous poem, rich in subtleties and hues that beckon profound, uncharted contemplations. The vocals, often ethereal in nature, transport us to an ethereal realm of human expression where words falter, and melodies assume the role of tacit narrators, revealing the depths of the characters' souls. The interplay of diverse musical genres, from classical to electronic, forges a sonic mosaic that reverberates with the intricacies embodied in every facet of this masterpiece. This musical arrangement is more than a mere backdrop; it is the very protagonist of the narrative. The music does not merely accompany; it converses, divulging secrets, voicing anguish, and echoing the profound existential questions permeating the narrative. Of particular intrigue is the unique lexicon employed within these melodies. The "Chaos Language," conceived by composer Keiichi Okabe, materializes as an abstract tongue, devoid of recognizable semantics or syntax. Instead, it comprises vocal sounds that conjure emotions yearning for expression. The incorporation of such an exquisite language into the vocal compositions within the score engenders a sense of both peculiarity and familiarity, echoing the theme of communication and comprehension among disparate beings, whether human, android, or machine. This concept finds eloquent expression through this medium.

This endeavor to elucidate select facets of artistic expression within a video game, albeit a modest one, scarcely captures the magnificence of this universe and its interpretation within the crucible of human cognition. Nonetheless, this endeavor remains rooted in the pursuit of expression. In the end, [b]do you think video games are silly little things?[/b]

This game is an absolute masterpiece. With a thought-provoking narrative, fleshed-out characters, and original setting, Automata makes for a truly unique experience. The game's art and music are well-executed and integrate into the gameplay in unexpected ways. (The soundtrack itself deserves its own commendation, perhaps even outshining the game itself.) The gameplay mechanics are refined, and satisfyingly stylish at all times. Director Yoko Taro is known for juggling nuanced narrative themes with bombastic set-pieces, and Automata is his crowning example.

The only downside to this release is the state of the PC port. The 60 fps cap would be tolerable if it were not also saddled with major frame-pacing issues and poor optimization. The artistic visuals are hampered by limitations like the low draw distance and 900p cutscenes. (This can all be mitigated easily by a mod from Special-K called FAR. Alternatively, the console versions of the game are very stable.)

Great Game. Story line is amazing

=== STORY ===
Thousands of years into the future, aliens have invaded Earth, using machine lifeforms as their army, forcing humanity to flee to the Moon.  Here, they regroup and counter-attack by creating the YoRHa, a military force of advanced androids with the mission of eliminating the invading force and reclaim Earth for humanity. In this virtually never ending conflict, the story follows 2B and 9S, a couple of YoRHa androids as they travel to Earth to complete missions and also learn about the world that is and was,, themselves as well about their supposed enemies. 

A little side-note: despite being related to the Drakengard series and Nier: Replicant, you don‚Äôt need to have played or know about these games before playing Automata. It could help you understand a bit more some details in the game but in general, Automata is like its own story, son don‚Äôt worry about that.


=== GAMEPLAY ===
The game is a mix of action-RPG with Open World. 
Combat is your standard hack and slash; light and heavy attacks, jump, run as well special attacks. Stats automatically upgrade as you level up.

Special attacks and weapons can be unlock/upgraded by completing mini-quests (collect certain amount and type of materials and money) or finding them during you gameplay (around certain area, quest reward, bought on store). There‚Äôs a ton of options/variants to choose from but most of them aren‚Äôt too distinctive one from another (especially when it comes to weapons) and in the end, you‚Äôll end up using just a few from all that bunch.
Combat in general is nice but it can get kinda repetitive after a while.
When it comes to the Open World part, the game offers a fairly decent map to explore around. You start in a main area that connects to the rest of the other areas, which you gain access as you progress in the game. Each of these areas have its own ‚Äútheme‚Äù sort of speak and does a good enough work to represent them, some more than others though.

The RPG element comes in the form of chips. These chips are divided according their function (attack, defense, support, etc.) and can help you create a build for your standard gameplay or for specific scenarios and even personalize your UI to some extent. You have ‚Äúmemory space‚Äù which you can fill with these with each one using an X amount of space, depending their level (you can upgrade them) and/or rarity. You can upgrade the memory space later in the game.


=== VISUALS & SOUND ===
I think this is some of the strong elements of this game.

On the visual side, you can see they put a lot of work on each aspect of the game: the characters (especially the characters), weapons, environments, menus, etc. It‚Äôs pretty cool to appreciate the details in each one. You can kinda have an idea of the character traits of each character when you look at it and their designs, same of the weapons (even the weapons have backstories so its look is not necessarily just because).

About the music, the OST does a great job on help you immerse in the game. The fights, the story, dialogues, even the side-quests, the OST has the right theme to go along with the ‚Äúcurrent mood‚Äù in the game. It hardly fails in this and I appreciate that <3. I haven‚Äôt heard the OST alone yet but I can bet it must be awesome to hear it while imagine the scenes in the game.     

  
=== FINAL THOUGHTS ===
Leaving aside the gameplay and visual/sound aspects for a moment, I think the core of this game are the characters and how the interact, learn, grow, get emotional, etc. and not just the protagonists; the support/side-characters, even most of the NPCs you‚Äôll probably know once are pretty interesting!  The gameplay is just a drive sort of speak to help you navigate in this broken world full of interesting characters waiting to be discovered. Interaction is the key word in this game and‚Ä¶is just a fascinating experience.
The gameplay is good, visuals and sounds are pretty good but the story and characters will stick to you from start to finish. I think this a game everyone should try, at least once.


SCORE: 8.0

I played this game for ~2.25 hours on Normal difficulty before my first death.  This game is now having me restart from the very beginning of the entire game since it was never saved at all.  A game introduction without training lessons and without save points is infuriating.  I really wanted to like this game but it stresses the hell out of me.  When I checked the intro screen there was actually a Load Game option, about 2 hours in, but selecting it just restarts the game anyway.

Update:  I've played over 50 hours in this game, getting through the story.  Wow, I am still very disappointed with this ending.  Very surprising that it doesn't take long to get through the story and that it ends where it does.  There are so many upgrades left waiting and so many missions left unfinished, with no desire to just go back and play previous parts of the game.

ùêÅùêÆùê≠ ùê¢ùê≠'ùê¨ ùêßùê®ùê≠ ùê£ùêÆùê¨ùê≠ ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê†ùê´ùêöùê©ùê°ùê¢ùêúùê¨ ùê≠ùê°ùêöùê≠ ùêöùê´ùêû ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùê´ùêûùê¨ùê¨ùê¢ùêØùêû; ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê¨ùê≠ùê®ùê´ùê≤ ùê®ùêü ùêçùê¢ùêûùê´ ùêÄùêÆùê≠ùê®ùê¶ùêöùê≠ùêö ùê¢ùê¨ ùêûùê™ùêÆùêöùê•ùê•ùê≤ ùêûùêßùê†ùê´ùê®ùê¨ùê¨ùê¢ùêßùê†. ùêíùêûùê≠ ùê¢ùêß ùêö ùê∞ùê®ùê´ùê•ùêù ùê∞ùê°ùêûùê´ùêû ùê°ùêÆùê¶ùêöùêßùê¨ ùê°ùêöùêØùêû ùêõùêûùêûùêß ùêüùê®ùê´ùêúùêûùêù ùê≠ùê® ùêüùê•ùêûùêû ùê≠ùê® ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê¶ùê®ùê®ùêß ùêöùêßùêù ùê•ùêûùêöùêØùêû ùêÑùêöùê´ùê≠ùê° ùê≠ùê® ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê¶ùêöùêúùê°ùê¢ùêßùêûùê¨, ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê†ùêöùê¶ùêû ùêüùê®ùê•ùê•ùê®ùê∞ùê¨ ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêöùêùùêØùêûùêßùê≠ùêÆùê´ùêûùê¨ ùê®ùêü ùêöùêßùêùùê´ùê®ùê¢ùêùùê¨ ùüêùêÅ ùêöùêßùêù ùüóùêí ùêöùê¨ ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê≤ ùêüùê¢ùê†ùê°ùê≠ ùê≠ùê® ùê´ùêûùêúùê•ùêöùê¢ùê¶ ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê¢ùê´ ùê©ùê•ùêöùêßùêûùê≠. ùêÄùê•ùê®ùêßùê† ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê∞ùêöùê≤, ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê≤ ùêûùêßùêúùê®ùêÆùêßùê≠ùêûùê´ ùêö ùêúùêöùê¨ùê≠ ùê®ùêü ùêÆùêßùêüùê®ùê´ùê†ùêûùê≠ùê≠ùêöùêõùê•ùêû ùêúùê°ùêöùê´ùêöùêúùê≠ùêûùê´ùê¨, ùêûùêöùêúùê° ùê∞ùê¢ùê≠ùê° ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê¢ùê´ ùê®ùê∞ùêß ùê¶ùê®ùê≠ùê¢ùêØùêöùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêßùê¨ ùêöùêßùêù ùê¨ùêûùêúùê´ùêûùê≠ùê¨.

ùêàùêß ùê¨ùê°ùê®ùê´ùê≠, ùêçùê¢ùêûùê´ ùêÄùêÆùê≠ùê®ùê¶ùêöùê≠ùêö ùê¢ùê¨ ùêö ùê†ùêöùê¶ùêû ùê≠ùê°ùêöùê≠ ùê¢ùê¨ ùê≠ùê´ùêÆùê•ùê≤ ùê†ùê´ùêûùêöùê≠ùêûùê´ ùê≠ùê°ùêöùêß ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê¨ùêÆùê¶ ùê®ùêü ùê¢ùê≠ùê¨ ùê©ùêöùê´ùê≠ùê¨. ùêìùê°ùêû ùê†ùê´ùêöùê©ùê°ùê¢ùêúùê¨ ùêöùê´ùêû ùêõùê´ùêûùêöùê≠ùê°ùê≠ùêöùê§ùê¢ùêßùê†, ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê¨ùê≠ùê®ùê´ùê≤ ùê¢ùê¨ ùêÆùêßùêüùê®ùê´ùê†ùêûùê≠ùê≠ùêöùêõùê•ùêû, ùêöùêßùêù ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê¨ùê®ùêÆùêßùêùùê≠ùê´ùêöùêúùê§ ùê¢ùê¨ ùêßùê®ùê≠ùê°ùê¢ùêßùê† ùê¨ùê°ùê®ùê´ùê≠ ùê®ùêü ùê¨ùêÆùêõùê•ùê¢ùê¶ùêû. ùêñùê°ùêûùê≠ùê°ùêûùê´ ùê≤ùê®ùêÆ'ùê´ùêû ùêö ùêüùêöùêß ùê®ùêü ùêöùêúùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß ùê†ùêöùê¶ùêûùê¨ ùê®ùê´ ùê¨ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùê•ùê≤ ùêöùê©ùê©ùê´ùêûùêúùê¢ùêöùê≠ùêû ùêö ùê†ùê®ùê®ùêù ùê¨ùê≠ùê®ùê´ùê≤, ùê≠ùê°ùê¢ùê¨ ùê†ùêöùê¶ùêû ùê¢ùê¨ ùêöùêß ùêöùêõùê¨ùê®ùê•ùêÆùê≠ùêû ùê¶ùêÆùê¨ùê≠-ùê©ùê•ùêöùê≤.

good
Loved EVERYTHING, game, cinematics, story, 10/10

From what I've read across spoiler reviews and analysis of this makes me appreciate what it's trying to say. It uses the video game format to ask philosophical questions differently than a movie or book would be able to. But that doesn't change the fact that it should not take 2 playthroughs of the same route to get to the meat of this experience. I know it's silly sounding, but I could watch 10 films covering the same themes before I get to the point of this game. It reminds me of Neon Genesis's terrible communication of its themes which made my time watching the show feel like a waste. Also, Nier isn't saying much about ideas like nihilism or existence. It feels like an entry-level commentary on giant questions that can't be answered. It has strokes of cool ideas for a video game but damn it does not connect for me.

good cake

"Glory to Mankind!"

I can't believe such a beautiful and deep story can be made with androids/machines as your main characters. Excellent story, beautifully deep music tracks and such well-written characters. 

This game really makes you think about concepts such as nihilism, fate, etc.

Also, it might not be very clear, so please don't stop after finishing your 1st playthrough. This game has 5 main endings achieved through 3 playthroughs. And all of those playthroughs are completely different. The real story is gradually unfolded across these 3 playthroughs, so just stopping at the first playthrough will leave you with an incomplete game experience. 

Hope everyone has as much fun, and more, as I did playing this masterpiece.
damn machines
Very fun :3

I know this is very cheesy, but I'd say that [i]NieR:Automata[/i is not just a game; it is a life experience. An incredibly emotional journey. Every single moment of this game is extremely captivating, with a complex story and surprisingly interesting characters that makes you crave for more. Yoko Taro's signature "backwards scripting" tempts you to tamper with every single aspect of the game, as the smallest of the details holds a depth and significance to the story. There are also a couple of jaw-dropping twists.

In terms of gameplay, the control of the characters and combat is very fluid, with a fast paced action with dodges and counters very reminiscent of another of Platinum Games' work: [i]Bayonetta[/i] (with a pinch of [i]Devil May Cry[/i]). Every attack strings together beautifully, with every single move being cancellable through the dash/dodge button, making combat a very reactive waltz of slashes and strikes.

The length of the game is also very long, easily surpassing 40 hours of gameplay, including sidequests (which probably take over half of those 40 hours). While the game has a lot of backtracking (especially until the game's "fast travel" is unlocked), it's not tiring as the beautiful landscapes and flowing movements of the characters are always a joy to watch.

The game has a customization system in the form of "Chips" that enhances the characters performance and can grant some game-breaking passive effects that can make even boss battles completely trivial. On the other hand, those bold enough to pick the Very Hard difficulty will find those Chips a godsend, as enemies one-hit kill the player in this mode.

Lastly, the atmosphere and soundtrack of the game are absolutely fantastic. I also recommend playing with the Japanese voice-over, as the original voices are top notch. The English cast is pretty solid, though.

Even if you never played the original NieR games or Drakengard, you will enjoy this masterpiece of a game that will make you actually reflect on "What it means to be alive?"

Great game 10/10 always diverts expectations and is a one of a kind game with its abstract story that has a very profound meaning. Would recommend to anyone who wants 40 hours of rich story telling, fun game play, and an excellent soundtrack to top it all off.

Fell for the "hehe 2B is hot" memes, finished the game with a [spoiler]broken heart[/spoiler].

Asides from being a beautiful game with a gorgeous soundtrack and a fun combat system that makes for great spectacle [i](it's literally extremely attractive androids fighting an army of gigantic machines)[/i], it's an extremely deep and philosofical experience that has a unique perspective on "the big questions". The writing can be over the top at times but it's extremely solid overall; turning a fun game into an unforgettable experience.

The only real cons are some of the hacking minigames, some of the fights not living up to the standard of most of the game, and the fact that it's really long, but if the pros sounds like something you would like, then 1000% give it a go. Seriously tho, this is far from your ordinary game, this is one hell of a masterpiece packed into a fun game.

I really enjoyed my time playing Nier: Automata. The game does a lot of crucial things really well. The characters are well developed and a plot that has twists and turns and made me bond with the characters even more. The OST is stellar and brings an atmosphere to each unique area of the game. The combat is very fluid and enjoyable especially once I learned how to chain combos and properly use different weapon types. The only downside I can think of is the game is a mediocre console port. The graphics quality (especially some textures) leaves a lot to be desired and the game encounters random crashes from time-to-time.

I loved the game so much I 100% completed the game and I have no regrets whatsoever. Very few games have such an impactful ending that I thought about and had such intense emotions about it.

It's a really good game with an amazing, albeit a bit confusing story, really fun combat and gameplay, and silly yoko taro stuff. If you go on the adventure that is getting every single ending, this game has about 70 hours of mostly quality gameplay and content to offer to you. 

The only thing I personally disliked was the second playthrough. The reason why [minor spoilers] is that [spoiler] I really really really hated playing as the second character [/spoiler] but I was able to rush through it, and so it was a relatively small part of the entire experience. Overall the game is incredibly solid and I don't regret pre-ordering it at all.

NieR:Automata is a game I respect because it's quite unique, but I must be honest. I enjoyed very little of the experience, save for the credits of the last ending, which is more for novelty than anything else. Story was a huge disappointment for me, which is an issue when it's the main selling point of the game. It's occasionally interesting, but lacks any real substance. For a game that's supposed to be deeply philosophical, most of the interesting topics aren't addressed much. The first playthough was actually pretty interesting story wise, but the second is not nearly different enough and the third is too edgy for my tastes. Combat is very brainless and is pretty disappointing considering other work Platinum has done. I had to really push through for the true ending, and while it's the best part of the game I don't think it was worth forcing myself through 20 hours of mind numbing gameplay. The only aspect of this game that met expectations was the OST, which is certainly very good (though I wouldn't say it's the best). I don't regret the purchase, but I do wish I enjoyed the experience more, and I can't in good faith recommend it.

Nier Automata Is truly a testament to videogames being a form of art.

All you have to do is; Play this game. Play this game. Play this game. Play this game. Play this game. Play this game. Play this game. Play this game. Play this game. Play this game...

Trust me it doesn't matter that it is no longer in mainstream, it is just worth it, I bought it a long time ago, and now I decided to finish it, and it is just worth it. Even if after buying this game you won't have enough money to buy bread for tomorrow, it is worth it to starve for one day.

The first ten hours were a slog. I just didn't get it, ya know. I almost gave up, but man am I glad I didn't. Then one day, it just clicked and I started to enjoy but also appreciate the enormity of it all. 

I could fill many pages expressing my absolute amazement. Suffice to say, this is one of the best games I have ever played (and I'm 45). It challenges and expands what a game can be. I'm 94 hours in, I have 100% of achievements, I got all endings, finished all side quests, all story lines, and even chose to delete my data at the end, just so I can say I did it all. 

Now I'm tempted to start over on hard mode. I don't want it to end.

Juegazo. Gran historia filosofica. Graficos decentes pero con un dise√±o espectacular. La jugabilidad es muy buena, un tanto simple y con bastante contaminacion visual (al punto de que por momentos no tenes ni la mas minima idea de que esta pasando) pero aun asi es disfrutable. Awesome game will not disappoint.
good

There are some interesting storytelling moments and meta-interactions that take full advantage of video games as a medium that I've never seen in any other game and truly push the form forward, and I really wish they made up more of the game. Unfortunately they're surrounded by hours and hours and hours of boring and predictable slog including replaying the entire first campaign with maybe 20 minutes of actual meaningful additional content just to get to the true final campaign which itself is only a few more hours of actual content. The hack and slash gameplay is solid but not complex or varied enough to stay interesting for the whole runtime, and the I'm 14 And This Is Deep plot doesn't make up for the just ok action. It's obvious within 10 minutes of starting the game that it's about "What if robots became sentient, and what's the difference between AI and Human Intelligence?" but the game has absolutely nothing interesting to say about these cliches because 20 hours into the game even though you regularly interact with an entire society of sentient robots the main characters still refuse to admit robots can be sentient, despite themselves being sentient "androids" which is totally a huge difference! The game's "twist" that Androids and Machines both have the same AI is comically transparent and unimpactful, and Bladerunner had more to say about the trope of an android questioning its own humanity 40 years ago in an hour and a half movie than Nier does in 45 hours of game plus tons and tons of shallow text logs. The weird and off-putting anime holdovers like the main character's cringe loli outfit make the shallow philosophy seem even more unserious, and add to the feeling that this game is mainly targeted at 17 year old weeb stoners
Good
The things I would do to re-experience this game for the first time

I don't know of any other game that makes such good use of the fact that it's a game to tell such an incredible story. I truly don't think the full scope of it could be told in any other medium. 

Video games sure are neat huh
real
tobulas zaidimas
ebic

The game suffers from some of the same outdated design elements as so many other Japanese games, unfortunately. Some examples: Not allowing you to save unless you are in a specific location, deactivating fast travel destinations seemingly just to inconvenience you, making you replay long sections you've already mastered if you ever die (which fortunately won't happen often), a barely usable map which will lead to you looking up a quest location online at least once (mark my words), and of course the player character for no particular reason running around basically butt naked.

But the game is so creative, atmospheric and out-of-the-box that it is easy to look beyond all of its flaws.
loved the story so so much.

Be still my heart, from the music, setting, storylines and characters, what a rollercoaster.  No, not that rollercoaster.  This game really does live up to the hype and never has a game made my eyes water from emotion (I didnt cry, YOU cried).

NieR: Automata‚Ñ¢ is a masterpiece. It is a game that is both visually stunning and emotionally resonant, with a story that will stay with you long after you finish playing. The gameplay is also top-notch, combining fast-paced action with a deep and rewarding RPG system.

The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity has been driven off Earth by an alien invasion. The only survivors are a group of androids who have been sent to reclaim the planet. You play as 2B, a combat android who is tasked with destroying the machines that have taken over Earth.

The story is one of the game's strongest points. It is complex and thought-provoking, and it explores themes of identity, purpose, and what it means to be human. The characters are also well-developed and relatable, and you will find yourself rooting for them throughout the game.

The gameplay is a lot of fun. It is a mix of hack-and-slash action and third-person shooting, and it is fast-paced and exciting. You can also hack into machines to control them, which adds an extra layer of strategy to the combat.

The game is also visually stunning. The environments are beautifully rendered, and the character designs are unique and memorable. The soundtrack is also excellent, and it perfectly complements the game's atmosphere.

Overall, NieR: Automata‚Ñ¢ is an outstanding game that is sure to leave a lasting impression. It is a must-play for anyone who enjoys action RPGs, thought-provoking stories, or simply beautiful games.

Here are some specific compliments I have for the game:

- The story is incredibly well-written and thought-provoking. It explores complex themes of identity, purpose, and what it means to be human in a way that is both engaging and thought-provoking.
- The characters are well-developed and relatable. You will find yourself rooting for them throughout the game.
- The gameplay is a lot of fun. It is fast-paced, exciting, and strategic.
- The graphics are stunning. The environments are beautifully rendered, and the character designs are unique and memorable.
- The soundtrack is excellent. It perfectly complements the game's atmosphere.

I hope this review has convinced you to check out NieR: Automata‚Ñ¢. It is a truly special game that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

A masterpiece that may never get to experience again, yet it aims toward constructing a meaning in a world where hope is in actuality buried. It's not just some silly little game, it's a compelling narrative told in a distinctive style that fills in all the blanks as you get to know the characters and story. I never played a game by the creator, so everything was so odd in the beginning, but that obliviousness added unique touch of flavor that resonated with me at the end. The game's great storyline forces the player to consider their ideas and behavior. Teaches the player that there are various points of view and decisions that have implications rather than an objective truth or morality. Demonstrates to the user that life is not defined by a single aim or objective but rather by the experiences and connections made along the road. In a brutal and chaotic world, the game invites the user to discover their own purpose and value. There are many references to human culture, behavior, nature, and philosophies. The characters reference it either explicit or implicit from the perspective of not having lived in the modern human world, but in an post-apocalyptic world where our traditions seem absurd to them; reminding us to elicit gratitude of things we gotten used to. One of my favorite philosophical notions from the game¬†is that according to Jean-Paul Sarte, "Existence precedes essences," meaning that a person's existence is shaped by their experiences and choices rather than being predetermined at birth. I believe in the universal scale, that everything is balanced in all aspects of reality, and that there is a certain amount of randomness that imparts some significance to our mere existence and suggests that our lives are not entirely predetermined. Our self-awareness gives the capacity for decision-making, which I like to refer to as constrained free will, allowing us to experience to degree of free-will. This is because experiencing is the ultimate objective of living things, which was likely foretold and deliberately carried out by higher sentient entities (god/gods) for what appears to be like an eternal of us. Holy cow i didn't mean to ramble on like this, i don't wanna go too deep into it;ANYWAYS! The game's outstanding visual and auditory experience¬†completely immerse the player in its world and feelings. Beautiful visuals, fluid fighting, and a variety of gameplay elements keep the player interested and entertained in this game. The game also includes a fantastic soundtrack that perfectly matches the atmosphere and tone of the game. The music in the game is dynamic and alters depending on the player's surroundings and position. It is a game that will make you laugh, a little horny[2booty], cry, think, and feel. It is a game that will stay with you long after you finish it. It is a game that will change you(if you're open for the change)

This is actually an odd game for me to review. I originally played this a few years ago for about 6 hours or so and got bored. Then recently I agreed on doing a game swap with a friend (I play a game they want me to play and they play a game I want them to play). While I wasn't particularly looking forward to playing this again, I'm glad I did. The game is basically one big artistic vision. There are some things I don't like but overall the game is good if you're into that kind of thing.

First thing to note is that this game has several different routes/endings. The first 2 routes play in the same time period and essentially you have to play through those bits twice but with some differences in perspective. However, the whole main story is played in a linear fashion so you can't miss out on any main route or ending. Anyway, I'll start with the things I liked:


[u]Positives[/u]

-Graphics are decent for a 2017 game, nothing amazing but it looks good.

-Sound effects are great.

-Variety of "plugin chips" to customise your gameplay, though I kinda just kept one set on for combat: counter+, anti-chain damage, max hp and auto-heal and never died ever again and then I had another set for when you play as 9S for hacking+ stats and auto-heal.

-The story from route C onwards was a lot more interesting than route A and B, though I will go into that more in the negatives part. The overall story was a great experience though and while route A isn't as good as the others, the prologue does start the game off strong. Some small details in route B are pretty nice and definitely appreciated.

-The music is an interesting one. On route A I felt like the music varied from "it's OK" to good, but then from route B onwards they start playing several variations of the songs and damn they are really good. You can really feel the emotion in the music and it's amazing.

-Chapter Select from finishing route C/D allows you to go back and finish stuff you might have missed.

-Customisable settings for the standard gameplay camera. Really cool.


[u]Neutral[/u]

-I didn't really vibe much with the combat which was one of the reasons why I stopped playing in my initial attempt at playing years ago. The movement feels kinda "floaty" and I didn't really like experimenting with different weapons much because the beginner sword is fast and does decent enough damage anyway. Could just be a me thing.


[u]Negatives[/u]

-The Route A part of the game is mostly "meh". Although it gains more value after finishing the game, on your first playthrough it can feel rather... generic gameplay-wise. The map is absolutely terrible to navigate and look at before you unlock more of it from the teleport vending machines. Fortunately map and side quest progression is saved throughout route progression. The main story in route A is purposefully simple and because of that it's kind of confusing at that point while you're playing as people do rate the game's story as good. Another thing to note is that they play the credits after you finish this route... so some people might actually think the game ends there when it actually doesn't.

-Route B is mostly the same Route A but with a perspective change, additional cutscenes and the ability to actually be able to finish some side quests you literally cannot finish in Route A. I already grasped what the story was going to be about 3 hours into route A, I didn't need to spend another 9~ hours in Route B to have it shoved in my face more. I wish they kinda cut this route down a bit and spent more time on route C/D+.

-Side quests. Oh boy. Some of the side quests are interesting but most are basically just showing you the same repeated theme of the game even more and IMO felt like a waste of time (I do get that it's supposed to add to the setup though). I just stopped doing side quests after finishing Route B and started enjoying the game more.

-Dynamic Camera -- I get that the camera being dynamic and changes angles is an artistic idea and it's kinda cool from an art perspective... But in some cases for the gameplay it sucks so much to play with and is frustrating.

-Most of the world map is frustrating. The Abandoned Factory is extremely annoying to traverse for side quests but at least it looks cool. The main city area (outside of the hub) is badly designed where there are loads of edges that you have to perfectly time your double jump for to climb up. Also in the same city there are parts that feel pointlessly blocked off so it forces you to have to walk around the side. In the desert you are able to slide around, but it's annoying more often than not as it cancels your sprint momentum.

If our journey inevitably leads to the end, what truly is the purpose of life?
If life doesn't have a clear purpose, why do so many people work hard every day?

Imagine a scenario where machines emerge with potentially hostile intentions. Initially, they just function based on their programming, without genuine thought. But if they evolved to think autonomously, are they equal to us? If they are equal to us, why must we fight? If we don't fight, are we the ones who will suffer?

Such contemplation can birth unease and apprehension. And from these feelings, fear emerges. But it is the fear of those that are different than us that may ultimately be our undoing, guiding us down a journey filled with cruelty and anguish.

Who truly has the authority to determine life and death? Even when we're gone, the world keeps going. If that's the case, is there a point to living? Is there a point to feeling fear? Is there a deeper purpose to human existence?

Perhaps our bonds and connections with others provide a semblance of purpose. Without these ties, what gives life or even fear its significance? Someone with many bonds has an abundance of reasons to cherish life, while someone without such ties might struggle to find an anchor to hold onto in this existence.

The controls are just so fun and responsive: the gameplay is snappy and you can do complicated movements with ease. The story is really emotional and the multiple endings kept me coming back for more.

[h1] Perpetual Existence and Finding Meaning [/h1]
NieR: Automata is the [b] SEQUAL [/b] to NieR Replicant, taking place some years after the events of that game. This is an action based game, with some sprinkle of RPG elements, where you play as 2B/9S, in a future Earth where Earth has been invaded and been taken over by machines and aliens.

The game itself has multiple endings. As the game itself is meant to be story rich and story heavy, in order to really experience the full story of the game, it is recommended for the player to go through each of the "Routes" to experience the full potential of the story. 

[h1] The Pros [/h1]
Let me get the first two things before hand. NieR: Automata has one of the best video game OSTs I've heard in the last 20 years of gaming experience and the story, [b] especially [/b] if you know the context from NieR Replicant, is practically a gaming masterpiece. The story talks about strong themes about finding meaning in life, and the world building Yoko Taro has in the Nierverse is intriguing to say the least. The game does an excellent job in keeping you invested on what is going on, and there isn't really a moment in the game's story where you feel anything is being forced or unnatural. By the last credits in Ending E, you would really feel a giant hole in your heart, even more so if you have played NieR Replicant. Note: playing NieR Replicant is not required to understand the story for Automata (as you will be playing from the perspectives from characters that are not present in Replicant), but playing Replicant does add a lot of context that makes emotional scenes hit even harder.

For the most part, the combat itself is pretty enjoyable. The animations are fluid, and though the combat itself isn't that complex, it's pretty satisfying to say the lease. It's very satisfying to master your dodges in-game, while you bash machines with basic combos.

Gameplay note: Side quests in this game, unlike Nier Replicant, are completely optional and you can skip all of them if you would like. However, side quests in this game are a pretty decent way to also further experience the world building story portion for Automata. Overall, most of the side quests consists of fetch quests and combat with the occasional puzzle based ones.
  
[h1] The Cons [/h1]
NieR Automata is almost a perfect game, but the PC port has some issues to take note of. The primary issue are the occasional graphical hiccups and texture pop-ins that does sometimes distract the players. Textures itself on the PC, vary from decent to something that looks like it's from the PS1 era. I've only experienced 1 lock-up during my 40 hours of gameplay (had to do a hard game restart, but only lost about 5-10 minutes of playtime at the time). Aside from that, if you could get used to the graphical hiccups, the base graphics itself for a 2016/17 game looks not bad.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Personal ratings:
Gameplay: 9/10
-Simple but satisfying combat
Graphics: 8/10
-Graphics look aesthetically pleasing at times. Occasional graphical issues on the PC port.
Music: 10/10
-One of the most memorable OSTs in any video games out there
Story: 10/10
-Amazing story. Masterpiece if you have played Replicant.
UI: 8/10
-UI and GUI is serviceable. Mini-map can be cluttered if you take on too many sidequests at once.
Overall Experience: 10/10
-Post-anime depression is real

Also note: the English dubbing in this game is very good. It is recommended to play this game in English first (if you do not know Japanese), as many dialogue can be missed during the middle of combat.

[h1] Ending Notes [/h1]
Came for 2B, stayed for existential depression, 15/10. Also you can pet the pods.

While I still wholeheartedly believe the first game has the better world, story, characters and soundtrack, and I urge anyone who enjoyed this to play NieR Replicant, what NieR:Automata brings to the table cannot be understated. Replaying it for the first time since launch has brought back the rush of feelings that cemented this as my GOTY for 2017. The characters are well developed and incredibly likeable, the world is rich and full of secrets, and the beats and themes of the story really hit hard culminating in what is still one of my favourite endings in a video game.

If pushed for some drawbacks, I'd say the combat is far from Platinum's best and most of the bosses are pretty lackluster. Yoko Taro's habit of making you replay large portions of the game with minute story differences is something you'll either love or hate. The PC port also still has it's share of issues especially with audio cutting out, but it's a damn sight better than it was at launch.

But seriously, get NieR Replicant.

[b]Nier Automata[/b]: Analysis... This game has themes of Depression, Dystopia and Despair... The Game play is a combination of Hack n Slash and Bullet Hell. 
Not recommended to the faint of heart, but for those who love high difficulty in games and isn't afraid to feel overwhelming emotions or delve into existential topics

[b]Visuals:[/b] Gorgeous, stunning and dynamic
[b]Soundtrack:[/b] A blessing for the ears, especially the vocals

[b]Gameplay:[/b] It is recommended to have a controller if you want an easier time
[Hack n Slash] It is possible to play on mouse and keyboard
[Bullet Hell] Terrible on mouse and keyboard. Please play these sections on controller

[b]Difficulty:[/b] Set it as you like, this game is hard and will challenge you regardless
[Easy] if you're here for the story and characters
[Normal] will test your abilities.
[Hard] if you want to push your gaming skills to the limit
especially on mouse/keyboard: it is at times harder than games like Elden Ring and Sekiro (perfect for those who love making things more difficult on themselves like me :D)
[Very Hard] if you want to experience no hit hell which is extremely fun and frustrating

You can always change the difficulty if things are too easy or too difficult
(But if you're a true gamer, take on a higher challenge than you're used to and have fun improving)

Good luck to you. Glory to Mankind.

TLDR: A masterclass in game design, direction, music score, gameplay mechanics, and writing. It keeps changing expectations as multiple hooks increase your momentum as you approach the ending. 

Not many games have the credentials to call themselves industry-changing, and it's not a necessity to do so. However, every now and then, one stands out with fresh takes on the medium, but only in some fields. Maybe it's the gameplay, art direction, or some cinematographic script that turns a game into a memorable experience. And yet, Yoko Taro brings us an example that shows us how boundless gaming can be as a medium for storytelling. From the get-go, one could say Nier: Automata is another Japanese action game with exaggerated character designs and a convoluted story, but as the player makes progress, it reveals itself as something far more engaging.

Gameplay is cinematic and makes use of a little robot companion with auto-lock to make it as flashy as possible, because just using your melee weapons alone won't give you the feeling of slashing through mobs of robots. Minigames that in other titles may feel bothersome or gimmicky are crafted so that the player never loses synergy in combat. Bullet hells are designed into enemy attacks, and sudden camera changes transform this game into many different genres in a matter of seconds. Role-playing elements with some inclusion of text adventure dynamics force the player to carefully consider the effects of some characters‚Äô fates. There was no chance Nier: Automata could combine all these traits, and more, into its core without turning into a product held together with duct tape, and yet its formula finds a perfect harmony among all these elements to evoke all its themes.

If you‚Äôre into philosophy, this will be right up your alley. The compact game world and quests convey a dark future where existence is constantly being debated by artificial lifeforms. Without spoiling anything, its main cast go through many different perspectives regarding the human condition of being by exploring multiple thinkers and their works. The player might not be aware of all this existential baggage, but the messages are embedded for easy appreciation and, eventually, further reflection. It also helps that the game‚Äôs ‚Äúroutes‚Äù examine different angles on how to search for a purpose in life. Combined with a majestic soundtrack composed with perfect understanding of tone during gameplay, memories will be engraved into the player‚Äôs mind for a long time.

Of course, there are some flaws, as there are in every game. The start of the game is quite slow, maybe even sluggish. The map doesn‚Äôt help that much in tracking side quests. The auto-lock is your best friend, but sometimes it will not focus on the bigger threats you want to tackle first. And yet, I can guarantee you will overlook the rough edges around this gem. Even when the pace starts to get dull, or the gameplay stale, Nier: Automata will throw something new to keep you engaged and, eventually, give you a reason to see it through. The reason behind this is that, even if the game depicts a sad and meaningless world, certain [E]nding will convince you that life, indeed, is worth fighting for and full of hope. 

I hope this title inspires further developers into being more disruptive, creative, and inspiring. This game had no right for being so good while being so experimental, as there are some titles‚Äô artistic visions that overwhelm their playability. And yet, Nier: Automata brought us one of the best experiences in gaming history. I hope everyone gets to enjoy it.

So, this very quickly became one of my most beloved games. Fun gameplay (Hack n Slash with some bullet hell/shoot 'em up segments to keep things fresh), beautiful and very memorable soundtrack, and a really well written, emotional story that gets you thinking.

There are a couple of annoying things, such as the lack of checkpoints during the prologue. For this reason I highly recommend starting the game on Normal (or even Easy if you want) until you get to the first save point, then turn it up to your preferred difficulty if you feel so inclined. The mouse & keyboard controls are also not great, I would highly recommend playing with a controller if you want the best experience.

Anyway, if you're even a little bit curious, I would highly recommend giving this game a chance. It truly is something special.

Don't get me wrong, this game itself is wonderful. I love the game play and the story. It and works well on my computer and the Steam Deck.

My major complaint, which is why I am not recommending this game, is how cloud saves works: I had an issue once with my cloud save being wiped and had to restart my game. Goog thing I wasn't too far in my game. The other issue which is more irritating is that cloud saves carry screen settings between systems. This causes the graphics and screen size settings to change every time I switch between playing on my PC and my Steam Deck which have very different graphical settings. It is so annoying that this is something that was a choice by SquareEnix and/or PlatinumGames developers and even though in reality it is so small, it is annoying that they haven't fixed this already. I tried emailing their support to see if I could forward the issue and got this response:

"Thank you for contacting the Square Enix Support Center.

We understand you have concerns the display settings for NieR: Automata when changing platforms to play, and we'd love to help.

Updates in regards to the display settings being saved depending on the recent platform played is information that has not yet been announced and we are not able to comment at this time.

We do appreciate you bringing this to our attention, and rest assured that it will be forwarded to the appropriate party.

For now, you can stay up to date on our website (http://na.square-enix.com) for information on our products (both current and upcoming). We apologize we cannot assist further at this time.

Should you have any other questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to us and we'll gladly assist further.

Take care and stay safe!"

Hopefully this does get forwarded to the right someone, but this has been an issue for so long that I doubt it will ever be dealt with, especially for such an old game. If you are planning to play this game on only one PC and have the specs or only have the Steam Deck, it's a great game. If you want the flexibility of how you can play, I honestly can't recommend this game. Maybe if this changes I can give it the recommendation I would love to give this game.

An incredible emotional and philosophical journey, NieR:Automata is a game and a story that will take your breath away and touch your heart again and again. And again. Maybe even another time. From beautiful scenery and epic battles to existentialist questions of the meaning behind concepts of life and death, love and hate, sacrifice and desire, and simply being human. An excellent merger of various video-game genres with seamless transitions, attention to detail, and near-limitless combat customization/movement techniques, all in a unique open-world map with an extraordinary soundtrack that words simply cannot describe. Truly an unforgettable and rewarding experience across all of its many endings.

Glory to Mankind.

I really cannot recommend this, and I think this might be one of most overrated games I've ever played. I have finished route A and started B, dropped. This game should have been called NieR:Repetitive‚Ñ¢

For the most part, characters are extremely bland. I think majority of people actually praising this game are doing because they are horny for 2B and p much every other female android because it was critical to the story to make every single female character sexualized. 

Combat and camera are biggest offenders of this game tho. Weapons are painfully boring. Combat stays the same from start to finish. Enemies are sponges, literally. U won't feel impact of hitting them, and they sometimes take forever to kill. Combat is incredibely easy because you can just abuse perfect dodge constantly, and it's insanely easy to pull it off. Game loves to change between 3d and 2d ( 2.5d? ) and it SUCKS. Platforming is terrible. Your support character is stupid, and will constantly get in a way of you. O yeah, did I forget to tell you that your character will constantly trip on any rock/wire/bush? XD

OST is good for the first time you hear it, but entering/existing zones automatically switches to their OST with no fade, it's insant. AND IT ALWAYS STARTS FROM THE BEGINNING. Boss OST slap tho.

Game looks incredibely cheap, I get that they wanted apocalypse amotsphere but amount of reused and copy pasted assets is ridiculus for game of this "quality". A lot of invinsible walls. You see huge opening in building? Well no, you can't enter it. 

Saving system is atrocious but I didn't mind it that much because game was so incredibly easy, it was really hard to actually die after initial prologue. 

Animations of character look amazing, and I never got bored of them. 

Story.. where do I start. I won't spoil, but you need to finish 2 routes in order to get to "good part". Keep in mind that route A has huge amount of bad sections, and B literally expands on them and makes them worse. Side quests for the most part are garbage ( there were few good ones, but sadly very little ). You can't fast travel until like first half of route A. And guess what, in route B you can't fast travel either until certain point in the story. Keep in mind that entire game is based on: start quest on X spot, run to Y, return to X. That's it. That's literally it. It's just running, running, bland combat, and running back. 

2/10 because of pretty animations and serviceable OST.

I'm not sure I've ever wanted a game to end less. Just beat the A campaign, and diving into NG+. Thankfully, this game still appears to have plenty of fresh content.
I don't want to spoil anything, and I'm sure there's heaps I don't know yet. The campaign is really well paced, balancing reflective moments with crazy action. Although there were a few times where I dived into side content, every time I focused on the main missions I didn't want to put the game down. When the credits rolled it felt like the story was over, but I have so many questions.
The combat is amazing, and 2B's animations are some of the most fluid I've ever seen. Some games have difficulty balancing flashy animations with responsive controls, but this may be the best implementation I've played.
All in all, can't wait to dive in further and see what the rest of the game offers.

A truly excellent game, with incredible depth.

The great:
The music in this game is just absolutely fantastic. Great variety, awesome ambience, beautiful and evocatively charged emotive works throught - makes you want to just pause and admire.

Voice acting is absolutely stellar too. Every character, even machines you're meant to think are emotionless and soulless, deliver their lines with meaning and gravitas.

Combat variety is wonderful and enemy types are very diverse, each giving you different types of difficulties, optimal approaches and flexibility in how you may choose to approach them. Sure, you may choose to just hack-n-slash them all to bits - but there's no "if you don't follow the dodge-dodge-x-dodge-jump-y-dodge-x-(...)"or whatever "formula" you lose without. Play to your strenghts and have your fun. This isn't a [with palpable derison] "souls-like" game...

The good:

Combat is reactive, varied, fast paced and wonderfully creative with multiple modes (odes to 2d side-scrollers, to 2d asteroids-like's, and more general 3d hack and slash and others) with an often wide range of tactics and strategy available to employ.
Controls can sometimes be a bit finnicky and unreactive (utilizing certain moves or attacks may often leave your character static longer than the animation would make it seem necessary, and your commands - dodge, attack, move - in that state would be ignored -- equally some "hold to complete" moves can be interrupted and without any indication you will be holding the button to no effect and need to repress - sometimes more than once - to continue) but for the most part, controls are very snappy and responsive.

The story is... Well, the story itself may be a bit of a tossup - a lot of it is built up on games you may have never played (the original NIeR released in 2010 I think, and maybe other media) -- but the delivery is engaging and fantastic. Lore is drip-fed in a way that causes enjoyable "I want to know more" effects, but lets you pace your way in.

Characters, for the most part, are very deep and get fleshed out progressively over playthroughs, letting you form bonds and actually care for and about them.

The not-so-great:
[minor SPOILERS]
I mentioned "playthorughs" so, yeah: This isn't a game you beat just once and move on. Or even just twice.
In fact, the first two playthroughs - the second of which offers expanded lore and cutscenes and different perspectives and dialogue on what you knew of from playthrough 1 ("A") - are merely the prologue for the latter part of the game - which greatly expands the lore, the setting, and the emotional aspects of the game itself. There are technically 27 endings to the game, though only 5 really matter (and the 4th and 5th don't require a full replay).

I got 6 endings (the most important 5, and a "joke" ending by accident) in around 36 hours so it's not that bad and while you may be asked to replay some dumb intro-fetch-side-quests, mostly the game remembers what quests you finished in the last playthrough and will not repeat them or let you start over where you were.

The bad:
Combat can be a bit unforgiving early before you have access and use of "plug-in chips" which give you boosts to damage and defense, auto-use of recovery items when you're critcally wounded, and other boosts which will dramatically change your gameplay options.
The game doesn't do a very good job of explaining how to use them, how they work, or how you can upgrade them by combination and/or build your own multiple chip decks to switch by need and opportunity.
But once you get the hang of it and build a deck or two that suits you, it is night-to-day.

In conclusion:
This game was a sleeper hit when it was released, blowing everyone away by its depth and approach to storytelling.
And with good reason.

I loved almost every second of it and hold it in very high regard. It may not be for everyone, but I think almost everyone will get some degree of wonder and a cherishable and great experience with it if they last at least as long as ending B.

This game evoked in me interesting questions about consciousness and the nature of war. The ability to deliberately do such a thing is rare in this medium and thus I feel comfortable writing that this is a piece of art, not just escapist entertainment.

A couple of negative points come to mind though:
1. Graphically, the environments are aging poorly 
2. More than a few plot lines are not completely explained. If you want to dive into the rabbit hole you'll find 3 previous games, anime, manga and even stage plays (!?)

Many potential players might dismiss Nier:Automata based on their initial exposure to it. The game's character design is visually appealing and popular in cosplay and fan-art communities, and this is the content that sparks interest on social media. As a result, these characters have gained immense popularity among people who haven't actually played the game, leading to a superficial perception of the game, or worse still, complete ignorance of the games existence.

Some individuals may approach the game with expectations of finding more visual, sexual stimuli, while others might be discouraged by the vacuous references they've encountered online, assuming the game lacks substance.

However, once players delve into it, they will find a narrative and characters that are certainly not lacking in substance. It would be a disservice to spoil anything specific about the story, so I will leave my description vague. But I will say that the game blends exposition and implicit world-building and has an emphasis on thought provoking philosophical themes.

The music is exceptional. There is a running joke within the Nier community that these games are like buying a soundtrack with a game thrown in as an added bonus.

From a technical standpoint, while the games graphics may look a bit dated, with plenty of low resolution textures and few detailed models, but the art style is inspired and consistent. Many of the environments are able to be beautiful despite having a minimalistic design.

The gameplay is particularly interesting in the way it blends different genres. At first glance, the games appears to be a 3rd person action, brawler, but it cleverly incorporates elements of RPGs, shmups, bullet-hell, platforming, and more. Side quests, collecting weapons and upgrades, and a fishing mini-game further enrich the gameplay and replayability.

One aspect often overlooked is the game's general feeling of movement and combat. The developers specifically intended to create highly satisfying and enjoyable character movement, and they succeeded in this goal. Many other action games could learn from the techniques employed in this game.

Despite its widespread popularity, Nier: Automata is such an excellent game that it could arguably be considered underrated. Personally, I find it difficult to overstate just how exceptional this game is, ranking it among my favorite pieces of media ever.

This game is art, like, actually art, and among my favourite games.
It is also one of the best action games I have ever played.
It is also incredibly flawed, and I could spend hours dissecting what I disliked about certain story beats, or certain characters.
It's a game full to the brim with pseudo-intellectual drivel that will make you want to yell at the screem.
It is also a surprisingly thoughtful exploration on human nature.
It's also one of the very few video games that ever made me cry, multiple times even.

At the end of the day, it's a game worth having an oppinion about, and if you're even mildly curious, I think you should check it out

Few games have ever stayed with me like Automata has. The music, the story, the characters, all of it has such a incredible depth and richness. I feel sorry for people who gave up only after ending A, this game is a masterpiece.

As of writing this review, I've played NieR: Automata about 6-7 times from beginning to end. My love for this game is so immense that I am able to get lost in it time and time again. My entire life I have always felt like an outsider. My interests are not what people would consider the norm. In that sense, this game is perfect for me, and has been perfect for me since I first played it in 2019. I'm not going to go into the specifics of the game in-depth, as this review is just going to be my love letter to this game.

NieR: Automata is what I consider one of the two most important stories I've experienced with the other being Umineko. The main messages that both stories share is love, and embracing the future. That sounds simplistic, but the ways in which the messages are portrayed have struck a cord with me that I don't think I'll ever forget. Reflecting on this game as I was playing it for this playthrough I've realized just how much of an impact this game has had on my worldview. Feeling alone all the time as a kid, I was lost. I didn't know what I wanted to do with my life, and all I ever really did was escape from the world. However, this game showed me humanity. The good and the bad, the beautiful and the ugly. This game is just so... human. The true ending of this game was eye-opening and showed me that others do care. It's humanist message has taught me a lot, and my future is more full of hope and love because of it. The world is full of fighting, and all manner of horrible things, but I believe in humanity. Thank you Yoko Taro, and everyone else who worked on this game.

I hate this game. Please buy it.

A timeless masterpiece.

I played it on console when it came out, since then, im so in love with this game. The music, the characters, the story and the mechanics making this game a true masterpiece, its my favorite game/game series of all time....
2B hot as hell

I was recommended this game to play earlier this year, and I have to say it is absolutely perfect. I love everything about it from the story to OST. I highly recommend it, definitely still holds up even in 2023 as a great game in my eyes.
The game is good.
Legitimately one of my favorite games of all time

Yeah its one of the best games i have ever played, the story, the music, the characters, the combat, the graphics all of it is just put together so well. If you go for all of the main endings (which you should be doing anyway) its a long game with lots of things to do and there wasn't any part where i was bored or thought it dragged on. 

Just a 10/10 game don't sleep on it GET IT
ass

My favourite game. The game is decent on its first playthrough, second one is "eh" but mixes things up a little. Third is why it's the best ever. And damn it is so, so worth it.

very detailed

Thank you Yoko Taro

Catching story, difficulty shifts to being more easier in the endgame, early game is relativelly hard and completing prologue on the hard to realism is the whole another lvl experience. Music changes from dynamic to atmosperic in the right moments. High epilepsy warning tho, due to the implementation of picture distortion as kind of game mechanic, there is some points in the game where it can trigger seizure
So far I'm halfway through route B. What can I say: amazing music, great gameplay, anime boobs, emotional story, basically the perfect game. 10/10 so far
