[h1] [Y]orha's [E]nd [/h1]

Funnily enough it took me around half a decade of picking this game up only to stop playing after 2-3 hours. Randomly, I decided that after 3 solid years of not playing, I would I try to replay this again. I felt that I'd changed enough as a person that I might enjoy this game more now. I guess I was right.

Nier is probably the culmination of Platinum Games. It might not be their best hack & slash but you can see how they used everything they learned in the past to make this game. Witch time, "infinite" combos, a slapping soundtrack and a very strong sense of self
I think the newest additions for Platinum are things like: 
1. Weapon variety is probably the strongest thing this game has. There's a move set for each category of weapon, but in those categories you have a TON of options. 
2. Plug in Chips. You can create a decent variety of builds and playstyles. I went for a lifesteal, full aggro build and it was totally viable. You can go full ranged or focus on defence, mobility, utility, raw damage, crits etc

But undoubtedly the strongest aspect of this game is how much it builds on the previous game "Replicant" while being its own thing entirely. I love the world this is set in. The atmosphere, the scale and the soundtrack come together and shit dude. When you think of an area, your mind just instantly puts that track on, and you start bopping with your head. It was the same in Replicant. I fell in love with this world and funnily enough you can see that through my use of "Map mode". It gradually went lower as i played because i remember all of the routes. 

They cleverly avoid pointless backtracking by giving you Fast Travel which is an insane QoL that I sorely would have wanted in Replicant. Side quests are defo worth doing in this game too. Some might be hit or miss but never egregious, while the ones that are good are damn good. 

[h1]Conclusion [/h1]

What a fun game. Simple as that really. Playing the different Routes was very fun, with the gameplay differences keeping things fresh. The story kept unraveling slowly and pulling you in. I feel that some parts of the story could have been sharpened up and some parts could have been trimmed to tidy up the playtime, but all in all, a good experience. The ending is the highlight of this. If you can pull through, I doubt you'll be disappointed. 

PS: A2 better ass than 2B. Fight me.

Great game with enriching story and excellent character design.
However, some actions seem unable to perform using the keyboard > a joy controller is needed.

This game is 100% worth picking up. The story is very engaging and the characters are ones you will want to spent time with. Also, gameplay is varied so you won‚Äôt get bored. There are lots of third-person action games, but also top-down, twin-stick shooter, side-scrolling platform, and the game moves smoothly between all of them. 

However, there are some issues. You slide a lot when you move, especially on sand, making picking up items from the ground irritating. There are also multiple parts where you have to walk extended distances while your character is injured, so you have to move very slowly. The first time I tried this part, I got punched behind some debris and got stuck for a while. Then I got punched down a hole I couldn‚Äôt escape from. Even the time I got through it without out issue was so very dull. Who thought this was compelling gameplay?

That said, it is still absolutely worth picking up, even at full price.

This game is HIGHLY overrated. I can't believe some people consider it to be a masterpiece. It's mediocre at best.

1) Not a single character in this game has any personality. They are ALL so dull and ininteresting and their motivations make very little to no sense. I could not care less what happen to any character in this game.

2) The story tries to be subtle and intellectual but it's actually boring and pretentious. Calling this a "good story" is like calling a banana duct-taped to a wall "art". And to the people who say "You actually have to complete the game 3 times to have ending C to understand it and to make it good" just GTFO. It's like saying "You have to read all the Harry Potter books to make the first one good", it's just bullshit. First playthrough should be good on itself.


3) The open world is not ugly but it's not pretty either. It feels really outdated, even considering the game is from 2017. Everything is low-poly with mediocre textures. The only location that look "good" is the circus/fair. The world doesn't make you want to explore it. 

4) The combat system feels nice at first, but once you realise that you can be nearly invincible if you spam the dodge button, the combats lose ALL interest. Combine it with the fact that you can buy 99 small heals + 99 medium heals + 99 big heals for a fairly cheap price and you won't EVEN need to dodge attack. And finally, the combos and fighting possibilities lack a lot of depth and you fight every enemies in the same way.

5) There are some questionnable game design decisions that make the game tedious. For example, the fact that retrieving your body triggers 3 pop-up windows. Or the fact that you have to reactivate some teleporter mid-game. Or the fact that 2B stumbles on pebbles and rubbles. And many other small things that make the game annoying.

6) The "side quests" are nothing more than UPS quests: Talk to a NPC, go pick up 3 metal bolt in a field or talk to another NPC in the middle of nowhere then come back for reward. Some quests are a little more "interesting" like "kill this group of enemies in less than 30s" or "reach this destination on foot before the NPC" but that's about it....

The good things about this game are : 
-2b, you can clearly see that the devs spend more time on her than on any other characters or assets in the game. She has good design and she's well detailed.
-The animation (combat, runing, etc) are GREAT. That's the reason why combat and movements are enjoyable at time, even though combat is button smashing.
-All the mech phases/shoot'em up are good
-The music and sound design is good, except for some dialogues that are not dumbed for some reasons.

The game is not trash, but it's really dull, lame and even annoying sometimes (regularly).
I 100% believe that without the "waifu"/ "sexelegant" design of 2B, this game would have NEVER had that much attention and fanbase. People who worship this game have probably little to no cultural background to call that a masterpiece.

I guess it IS playable, but during playthrough it annoyed me in so many ways, i would not possibly recommend it. Starting with good ol' ps1 graphics, it prolongs with an odd story of "battle" androids, for whatnot reasons looking like a sex doll and a pedophile dream. Their behavior is random, motivations are uninspiring, there is no sympathy for them, on top of that, exloring the world is unrewarding, cuz most of items are just materials or ability "chips", which gives you no visualisations and makes you want to auto-equip them. Some parts of the game are pure cancer, especially when you need to go from point A to point B while being infected with the virus. Interesting concept of replaying the game from the POV of another character is ruined by a poor level design, basically making you replay same boring maps all over and over again, that being said without noting how many times you have to replay boring prologues if you want to achieve all the "endings" (most of which would be just a couple sentences of text). As a cherry on top, at the endgame you get hours of mindless grind if you want to do all the achievements (you can buy them INGAME though, which is a fckng joke as well). I had some fun playing it here and there, but i wouldn't buy it for more than 5 bucks, and i definetely wont be buying a prequel

Nier Automata is a fantastic game which tries to combine many genres and playstyles into its rich narrative driven world. Although, it's a JRPG game, I'd still gladly recommend anyone to try it even if they are not into the art style. The rich narrative (most likely one of the best you will ever experience), interesting hack and slash combat, outstanding soundtrack as well as the beautiful post-apocalyptic open world are worth to be checked out by any video game fan!
However, despite its overwhelming positives it's worth to note that it's not an AAA game and the open world as well as the graphics (not by any means boring or bad) might not be up there with games like RDR2 or the Witcher 3.

[b]Comment:[/b]
I was hesitant to play this game and expected to not enjoy it because of 2B butt meme and all that, but it's easily one of my all time favourite games. An amazing and beautiful game through and through.

[b]Good:[/b]
[list]
    [*] The soundtrack is amazing.
    [*] Captivating and emotional story.
    [*] I enjoy the world a lot.
    [*] Likeable cast of characters.
    [*] Character movement feels nice and fluid.
    [*] Interesting mix of different camera angles and gameplay elements for different areas of the game.
    [*] Plugin Chips (character enhancements) can be customized to suit your playstyle.
    [*] Side quests add to the experience rather than just being chores.
    [*] No difficulty based achievements.
    [*] Exploration is encouraged and rewarded.
    [*] Additional customization options within easier difficulty settings makes the game more accessible for people with disabilities.
    [*] Limited unofficial moddability, but it exists.
[/list] 

[b]Neutral:[/b]
[list]
    [*] Knowledge of previous installments adds to the experience, but is not required to enjoy the story.
    [*] Combat can be a bit button mashy.
    [*] The map and menu takes some getting used to.
    [*] 60 FPS lock. Unlockable, but speeds up certain elements so I don't recommend it.
    [*] Graphics look outdated for its time, but it doesn't make the game any less enjoyable.
    [*] Fan service in female character designs. Something to keep in mind if it's something you feel strongly about.
[/list] 

[b]Bad:[/b]
[list]
    [*] Without Movement Speed plugin chips, dashing is faster than running, incentivizing you to spam dash to move around.
    [*] I can't stop obsessing over it.
    [*] I hear the soundtrack playing in my head all day every day.
    [*] I even bought a body pillow.
[/list]

There's nothing I can say that hasn't been said already. I did everything I possibly could in this game, upgraded every weapon to its max level, did the same with each POD, completed every side quest that I could find, achieved every possible ending, read every archive. Each moment was a joy, and I felt so complete when I saw every ending on my save file, each 100% indicator in the menu. 

Despite this, I still erased it all. Slowly, I watched all of my work fade away into nothingness, all to help a stranger somewhere in the world. 

This game is something special, and I have never felt so satisfied finishing anything in my life.

[h1]NieR:Automata is a masterpiece[/h1]

[i]Spoiler free[/i]

[h2]Summary[/h2]
NieR: Automata uses every element of a video game (gameplay, storytelling, perspective and character building, music, the enviroment etc etc) woven together to create a story and convey emotions in a way that can only be done through the medium of a video game. 

When I saw the screenshots and trailers of the game I did not want to play it. But years later I'm glad I finally did. And like any piece of art it might not resonate with you, but if it does... 

...well here is one of the best games you will ever play.

[h2]The story[/h2]
Gameplay wise the game starts with a bang.
The story starts slow, but picks up and is a big part of why this game is a masterpiece.

(slight spoiler ahead about how you engage with the story not about it's contents) 
[spoiler]When you think you first finished the game, but have so many unanswered questions know that this is the whole point of the game. You go through the story again (and quicker, and different) through a different lens and start unpacking the story bit by bit. It caught me by surprise how much I liked this aspect as I'm not one to replay singleplayer games.[/spoiler]

You will not understand everything at first.
One tip I can give is to keep going forward and don't waste too much time on sidequests (at first) that you don't like or stuff you don't understand. Keep going forward 2B.

[h2]The soundtrack[/h2]
It's insanely good and I really mean 10 out of 10 good. It's not just that the songs are great and well composed. How the music fluently intertwines with where you are and what you're doing is something I have never seen before in a game. How does this work? Well: every track has multiple versions on top of that there are versions with and without vocals and if that wasn't enough most of them have an 8 bit retrofied version to fit a certain gameplay element.

[h2]The combat system[/h2]
The combat system is very simple at first glance but is actually deep and intricate if you are willing to go for it. So it's really up to you if you want to engage in the beauty that the combat system has to offer. Different characters offer different playstyles and depending on the weapons you wield you open up more deviations and different combos. The combat is also as smooth as it can be.

[h2]The RPG elements[/h2]
The RPG elements of building your character are light but set up in a smart way that really fits the theme of the game. I wont go into much detail and again you can choose to not really engage with the system but if you start doing so (for example later in the game) you'll have a lot of fun.

[h2]Does it feel dated?[/h2]
Stylistically it's beautiful and the game does not feel that dated. 
A lot of newer games can learn from the action and RPG elements you will find here.

[h2]Does it run on the Steam Deck?[/h2]
Yes, this game should be Steam Deck verified, because Proton was made with NieR:Automata in mind (no joke) and you'll feel that when you run the game. I played 90% of the game on the Steam Deck.

This game is heart-wrenching, gorgeously cruel, and agonizingly lovable masterpiece. I adore every aspect of this game, yet I have such a hard time going back to it, like many of the Nier/Drakengard games. The music and environments are a cinematic marvel, the characters feel so real and authentic even thought they are just characters in a video game (even more so amazing because they are androids.) I have never played a game that made me feel quite like Nier Automata did at the end. The only other game coming close being Drakengard 3. If you are looking to try a game in the series, I urge everyone to experience this one. Feelings aside, this game has great voice acting, beautiful environments, music that will make you swoon, combat that is so satisfying and rewarding to level up, and such a lovable cast of characters who feel very real in their struggles. I recommend this game to everyone I meet, but I also urge caution at the harrowing, heart-sobbing, tragically enchanting marvel that is Nier Automata.

Telltale's The Walking Dead made me cry, sure, but Automata is the only game that made me tear up during "final" final credits instead. What an amazing experience. Glad that I went unspoiled about it for years and played it with zero knowledge now that I have a computer that is capable of running it.

Game's far from being new and considering that you are probably interested in it, I'll share only things that I [i]personally[/i] didn't really like about Nier: Automata:

‚Ä¢ Route B (9S's route) is straight up painful to replay. You are effectively forced to replay the game AGAIN after beating it for the first time with zero to none alterations to story compared to first Route A. Pretty much exact thing that we've seen in original Resident Evil. Imo second character's point of view should have been completely optional. Second Act of the story is locked until you beat Route B. Honestly a questionable decision because apart from couple of scenes and cutscenes, 95% of the Route B is a direct copy of Route A.
‚Ä¢ Yoko "Yes, I loved playing NES when I was young, how can you tell?" Taro. Overused twin stick shooter minigames in form of flight and hacking, especially during Route B. By the end of Route B I got so sick of it, I built 9S around direct combat instead of hacking.
‚Ä¢ Difficulty balance? What difficulty balance? Normal difficulty is too easy, hard difficulty is too unfair (unless you enjoy getting one-two shot by an enemy that is not the most common class I suppose). I guess you'll be able to finish on Easy using only one foot. Feels like that there's supposed to be a difficulty in between but it's missing.

And... that would be it, honestly. Oh, and minor spoilers but I feel like I definitely need to mention this - special thanks to dev team for letting us to finish and leave the game without burning ourselves out. When you finish Route C, you are given an ability to [spoiler]straight up purchase achievements you have locked with in-game currency. Story-related achievements are non-purchasable but you are able to pick up every misc. achievement you miss[/spoiler]. You are still free to stick around and unlock everything yourself, of course. However this is a great help if you feel that you are "done" with the game and developer doesn't force you to see everything (especially considering how grindy most japanese games are), they appreciate you for seeing Nier: Automata through the end and I absolutely love it.

Do give it a shot if you are into "watashi no kokoro watashi no tamashi" games. You won't regret it, trust me.

Such an amazing game, this is a must play if you love RPGs with deep stories and characters, and don't mind a dark depressing tone. The story, characters and world building is some of the best I have ever seen. It might not be the most visually stunning game, but the world is beautiful and has a very unique feel to it. The story is extremely deep, multilayered and has a lot of emotional moments, its one of those games you still think about months after you beat it, and the developers leave a lot of secrets for you to figure out on your own without directly telling you what is happening, which makes the story more satisfying when you piece everything together. The side quests do a really good job of deepening the characters and world, and a lot of major plot reveals happen in these, which you might miss if you don't do them. The combat is simple but very fluid and fun and has a decent variety of weapons and combos. If none of that sells you on the game, 2B is hot af. This game is easily a 10/10 and one of the most memorable games I have ever played. Also the sound track is god tier and probably top 5 best game sound tracks of all time.

[h1]NieR Automata is the first game to truly stand up and greet ludonarrative dissonance as a friend.[/h1]

There‚Äôs a choice you can make during the playable credits sequence of NieR Automata‚Äôs fifth and narratively conclusive ending: whether or not to make the ultimate in gaming sacrifices by helping a stranger, who you will never know or meet, with the game‚Äôs final challenge. It was a sacrifice I agreed to. I could say that I believed wholeheartedly that I wanted to help another player, especially since said final challenge is deliberately near-impossible, and it was only because of someone else‚Äôs sacrifice that I made it through. But in truth, I have no real answer as to why I willingly made the choice. The thought that keeps running through my head is a line from Matrix Revolutions: that the answer to why I persisted is simply because I chose to.

That ability to make carefully considered decisions that have no true purpose or meaning‚Äîthe very core of free will‚Äîis a defining human trait, and the fact that this is something that cannot be taught or given to other living beings is a problem NieR Automata is almost pathologically fascinated with. It‚Äôs a fact it dances with, argues with, screams at, cries about, and mourns from its first seconds until the moment its final credit rolls. No, director Yoko Taro doesn‚Äôt have answers to the questions that the game poses, but he engages with what it means to be human in ways no game operating in AAA space has before, and certainly not one where you spend countless hours stylishly slicing up robots while dressed like the ma√Ætre d‚Äô at a FetLife dinner party.

NieR Automata lets its anime-inspired freak flag fly in the early hours of the campaign, giving absolutely no indication of the depths it will reach. Taro knows that 2010‚Äôs NieR was a thoughtful but mechanically uninspired game, which is why he brought in action-game savants Platinum Games to help assist with the sequel‚Äôs numerous gameplay styles. Within this game‚Äôs first hour, it‚Äôs at once a scrolling-screen Gradius-style shooter, a full-3D hack-and-slash action adventure, a 2D platformer, a tactical RPG, and a large-scale mech-combat jamboree. Later, the ability to damage enemies through a Geometry Wars-style mini-game becomes a gameplay staple. Throughout NieR Automata, it‚Äôs as if Platinum Games is showing off, and if they earn that braggadocio it‚Äôs because the developer excels at every single genre field the game chooses to play in‚Äîa rare jack-of-all-trades that masters all.

Most of the game, however, is spent in 3D-action mode, exploring a city-sized open world that strangely alternates minute to minute between PlayStation 2-levels of graphical austerity and breathtaking, lush moments of natural beauty that weren‚Äôt possible on that system. And all of it is bolstered by one of the most eclectic and evocative musical scores ever bestowed on a video game.

The game takes place 8,000 years into the future, where humanity has been supplanted by a race of deadly robots as the dominant species. Man‚Äôs last hope of retaking the planet is in an army of hyper-powered, silver-haired androids acting under orders from our lunar-based government to cleanse Earth of the machines. We initially play as 2B, a leather-clad, cold-hearted, all-business soldier who ends up saddled with 9S, a hacker-model android with the personality of an awkward 14-year-old. Their mission is simple reconnaissance and errand-running at first, with a plethora of machine-crushing sidequests and plenty of the kind of varied, large-scale, multi-part boss fights that Platinum is famous for (and accessible here within a couple of playtime hours). The waters get muddy fast, though, once it turns out the robots may not all be the mindless killing machines humanity says they are.

It‚Äôs obvious upfront that something might be off, as the supposedly lethal robots are redolent less of Terminators or the Borg than they are of the kindly robots from Hayao Miyazaki‚Äôs Castle in the Sky, only dwarf-sized. Most of them wander aimlessly, and many of them don‚Äôt even attack when 2B or 9S wander too close. One particular robot, Pascal, waves the white flag the second he sees 2B, and invites her to a village where robots have discovered the futility of war, and have begun trying to figure out what to do with their sentience. Despite no physical resemblance or similarity to humans, across the world, the robots clumsily fumble toward humanity, savoring our joys, and dreading our mistakes in equal measure. One of the game‚Äôs more bizarre, yet oddly affecting moments has our heroes coming across a hidden enclave full of robots trying to approximate human love by rocking empty cradles back and forth while chanting the word ‚Äúchild,‚Äù miming sex acts on each other, and screaming out for someone‚Äîanyone‚Äîto hold them.

Despite working in a genre whose ethos more or less relies on the concept of killing anything that moves, at any given moment, the game confronts the player with the shared values and ongoing personal development of the Other, and gives us multiple options, including flat-out murder, for engagement with it. There are narrative and gameplay consequences and advantages that result from every decision. Even the necessary fights against the deadliest of characters have justifications that require a measure of understanding and empathy from the player. NieR Automata is the first game to truly stand up and greet ludonarrative dissonance as a friend, and actually start the conversation about our bloodlust versus our empathy, while not short-shrifting the argument for either side.

Taro employs every dirty game-design trick in the book to get his points across, up to and including some of the mind-trippy visual distortions in the game‚Äôs user interface, and it‚Äôs all in favor of story above all else, which never once takes the easy way out. Said story isn‚Äôt afraid of offering up a high body count, indulging in non sequiturs, or laying a guilt trip on a particularly cool gameplay segment, and in general is utterly fearless at bringing us face to face with what it means to have latent humanity in a game genre that so very often holds empathy in contempt. There‚Äôs power and glory to be had while playing NieR Automata, and perhaps the greatest testament to what‚Äôs been created here is how much of that glory involves mercy, not murder. And that, coming from the developer whose greatest moment prior to this one involved a gun-slinging witch punching the face of God into the sun, is miraculous.

When I heard that this game was a story-rich ARPG with 26 endings, I knew I had to completionist it, and coming out of the other side of it I'm both impressed and disappointed. 
Off the bat, the story is perfect for this kind of game, simplistic in it's story telling with a lot of subtext to be explored, characters comparable to the likes of studio ghibli, and successfully avoiding ludo-narrative dissonance. For the most part, the core gameplay isn't anything special but is robust and interesting enough to hold up across 60 hours without getting stale. I say for the most part because of a handful of bullshit difficulty spikes (mostly during remote control sections) and a lot of RNG heavy grinding, although the latter is mostly a result of completionism.
My main disappointment came from the potential of this world and the message behind the game. after finding out that only 6 of the endings are meaningful and the rest are jokes kind of removed the impact of even having 26 endings but the linearity of the main endings still creates a significantly rich story. I only hope that the prequels will make up for this.
After all I've said and done, I'd still highly recommend this game and as long as you expect to only have 6 significant endings you won't be disappointed by them (and you'd know when you're done), and don't be afraid to lower the difficulty if the bullshit spikes are hurting your enjoyment of the game.

The term "masterpiece" gets thrown around a lot in gaming, but in the case of NieR:Automata it is truly earned. This is one of those rare gaming adventures that I wish I could experience for the first time again. The visual design, graphics and gameplay are all superb and effortlessly transition into different genres all the while being underscored by an unforgettable and dynamic soundtrack. The game is constantly evolving in surprising ways much like the machine lifeforms you'll be combating throughout the story. All of this would be enough to make NieR:Automata a top-notch action RPG but what really makes this game important is the questions it asks you through the combination of all of these elements. NieR:Automata doesn't just ask what it means to be a video game, but what it means to be a conscious being in a godless universe. Yoko Taro and the PlatinumGames crew have used the medium of video games to tell a story that can only be told through the interactive medium. NieR:Automata is a showcase of the power of video games, not just as entertainment, but as art. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll have an existential crisis or two and maybe you'll learn something about yourself and those around you.

No autosave feature means that I have to play for sometimes up to 2 hours before I can take a break, I understand the developers are trying to stick to the story and how the androids would only be able to save at black boxes but this is just taking the ****. Seriously? Can I not get a save point after fighting a boss when my health is low and I need to make my way back to black box to save? No, I can't. It doesn't help that when my health gets low the screen turns grey the music gets washed out and a ******* beep sound keeps playing, this wouldn't be a problem if I could heal which I can when I'm on ground but for some reason, during any of the flying sections (some of which last for hours) you can't even open your menu (which has your inventory, settings, map ect;) which means I can't heal or change the difficulty AT ALL for any of that flying section which (like I said) could last for hours depending on what difficulty I was stuck at.

A Masterpiece of Emotion and Adventure - Nier: Automata Shines Bright!

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ

As a lifelong gamer, I have experienced countless virtual worlds, but few have left a lasting impression as profound as Nier: Automata. This game is nothing short of a masterpiece, blending an emotionally charged narrative, breathtaking visuals, and exhilarating gameplay into an unforgettable journey.

From the very start, Nier: Automata grips you with its captivating story. The plot explores profound themes like identity, purpose, and the essence of humanity, all while unraveling a mesmerizing post-apocalyptic tale. The game's characters are richly developed, each carrying their own burdens, and their struggles resonate deeply with players. From the enigmatic 2B to the quirky 9S and even the rogue-like A2, the protagonists' journey is an emotional rollercoaster that tugs at your heartstrings and leaves you pondering long after you've turned off your console.

Visually, Nier: Automata is a breathtaking marvel. The world is gorgeously crafted, ranging from desolate ruins to lush forests, and each environment feels alive with meticulous detail. The contrasting landscapes complement the game's thematic depth, and the unique art style gives the game a distinctive and unforgettable look. Character designs are striking and complement their personalities perfectly, adding an extra layer of immersion to the overall experience.

However, the true brilliance of Nier: Automata lies in its gameplay. PlatinumGames' signature action-packed combat blends seamlessly with RPG elements, creating an addictive and fluid system that never ceases to amaze. The smooth transitions from intense aerial battles to ground-based combos make every encounter feel like a beautiful dance of blades. The variety of weapons, combined with a customizable pod that provides different abilities, ensures that combat remains engaging and satisfying throughout the game.

Furthermore, the game cleverly implements multiple gameplay styles, ranging from intense hack-and-slash sequences to bullet hell-inspired shoot-'em-up segments. These inventive changes keep the gameplay fresh and exciting, preventing any sense of monotony from setting in.

Beyond the main story, Nier: Automata features a plethora of side quests and optional content, each offering valuable insights into the game's world and characters. These diversions are thoughtfully crafted, contributing to the overall narrative and providing an opportunity to further connect with the beautifully crafted characters.

Moreover, the game's soundtrack is nothing short of spectacular. The hauntingly beautiful melodies, coupled with hauntingly poignant vocals, further amplify the emotional impact of key moments. Composer Keiichi Okabe's work is an auditory marvel, enhancing the immersive experience and making it an essential component of the overall package.

In conclusion, Nier: Automata is a gaming gem that leaves an indelible mark on all who venture into its world. It deftly combines an emotionally charged narrative, stunning visuals, and exhilarating gameplay to create an experience that transcends the confines of traditional video games. This is not just a game; it's an emotional odyssey that will stay with you long after the credits roll. If you are seeking a profound, thrilling, and emotionally rich gaming experience, Nier: Automata is an absolute must-play.

If you are familiar with Yoko Taro and his work, then you will know exactly what I mean when I say that [i]NieR: Automata[/i] is an [i]experience[/i]. And if you've played any of his other games to completion, you'll know pretty much what to expect from this one. But if you aren't familiar with Yoko Taro, there are a few things you should know about him before listening to the hype. Bear in mind that none of these things are intended to dissuade you from playing [i]Automata[/i]--to the contrary, I very much think that you should!--but setting some expectations ahead of time will prepare you to have the best possible experience with this game.

The first thing you should know about Yoko Taro is that he is out to troll you. He knows what the average gamer will expect from a video game, and he will absolutely take full advantage of that knowledge to mess with you at every turn. Some of the ways he messes with you will be fun, subverting your expectations in an enjoyable way. Others will be frustrating beyond belief, but constructed in such a way that you will either feel compelled to overcome them or give up and throw the game on your backlog to gather dust. Be forewarned, this is true many times over for completionists--the man has no compunctions whatsoever about wasting your time, and it's easy to imagine that some of the decisions that made it into this game, did so solely because he thought they would be funny at your expense. None of them will prevent you from completing the story, but many of them will crop up in incredibly annoying ways if and when you go for 100% completion.

The other thing you should know about Yoko Taro is that he is weird, and his games reflect that. He is a man that wears the head of one of his characters over his own head at all times in public. (His answer changes every time someone asks him why.) He includes attractive women in skimpy outfits in his games, not for any purportedly thematic reason as some creative types do, but simply because he openly likes ogling them. (This should answer the all-too-common question of why 2B is wearing a maid outfit in [i]Automata[/i].) All of his games include outlandish (and often horrifying) plot developments and colorful characters who are all broken in a variety of strange and tragic ways. If anything, [i]Automata[/i] is easily the most grounded of all of his games up to this point, but those who have played the [i]Drakengard[/i] series or the original [i]NieR[/i] will know that isn't saying much.

[b]So if [i]NieR: Automata[/i] is a weird game with trollish elements made by a weird guy with a fetish for maid outfits and spherical head-helmets, why should you play it?[/b]

Because it is very, [i]very[/i] good. It will surprise you in ways I can't explain due to spoilers. It will delight you with its [i]beautiful[/i] soundtrack and deliciously smooth free-flowing combat, courtesy of the character action masters at PlatinumGames. It will shock you with revelations that completely recontextualize earlier parts of the game, making the multiple playthroughs required to see all of the endings (and the all-important "true" ending) feel earned and worthwhile. It is one of those rare games where everything, even the trollish bits, were included for a specific reason to elicit a specific reaction, and that reaction lands damn near every time. It's a roller coaster ride of a game, in more ways than one, and it's an [i]experience[/i] you won't quite get in almost any other game.

I talk in some of my reviews about intentionality in game design, usually in the context of a mediocre developer just throwing some stuff into their game because they thought it sounded good or because it's what other games are doing. [i]NieR: Automata[/i] is the antithesis of this way of doing things, down to the smallest details, like the options menu [spoiler]being structured like a console for the android you're controlling[/spoiler]. I can't think of a single thing about this game that wasn't incorporated for a reason, even if that reason is as silly as Yoko Taro wanting to mess with players by [spoiler]making it nearly impossible to catch a certain specific fish in order to complete a pointless log[/spoiler], just because he knows that will bother some people.

TL;DR: Play this game. Ignore the hype, go into it with an open mind, and see it through to the true ending (which requires three playthroughs, but trust me, that's a good thing).

ADDENDUM (minor spoilers for a sidequest): A quick note to those who harp on about the "deep philosophical themes" in this game--[spoiler]remember the "Jean-Paul's Melancholy" side quest? The one with the haughty existentialist machine who is too good for his followers' gifts? Remember how that quest ended? That's Yoko Taro laughing at you. Just so you know. ;P[/spoiler]

All I want to say is that, if you do plan on playing this game, I'd recommend playing NieR Replicant, the game preceding NieR:Automata, first. The knowledge of things and events that occurred in NieR Replicant enhanced so many moments from NieR:Automata for me and I can assure you that I would have enjoyed the game much less without the knowledge I had from NieR Replicant. Also, NieR Replicant is just a great game in it's own right, so it shouldn't be a chore to play it. And if you don't want to play it and just want to play NieR:Automata or you want to play NieR:Automata first because it interests you more, then do that. I'm not your mom.

This game is just a masterpiece, I would recommend to anyone and everyone. The story, music, setting, and overall tone reminds me of Metal Gear Solid games (during their heyday back between 1999-2004) even if they gameplay and combat is rather different from those games. It's the sense you get when playing that you are taking part in a story that really, truly matters. The soundtrack is one of the best that I have ever heard in a game, I listen to it in my free time when I'm not even gaming and I almost never do that with any other games.

The way it plays is kind of a combination of a twin stick shooter (Pod mechanic) and a hack and slash/character action game but without an emphasis on combos. But there are also airborne sections which play like a mech style of game. It never got boring to me and I was really bummed when the credits rolled, not because the story was bad ...only because the story was over and I really wanted it to keep going. Luckily, I found out that the game has multiple endings and you have to play through it several times to get the true ending.

The voice acting and storytelling is top notch, it is better than many games with much higher budgets. There is a new Anime series that was recently released and it is equally well done. Yoko Taro (the writer/director of the game) is the greatest and I hope Square is working with him to make a sequel to this game, it would truly be a mistake not to. 

If you see this game available for $20, by all means, do grab it. Although it is totally worth $40, I own it on Steam and Nintendo Switch because that port was amazing.

A Worldbuilding Masterpiece. It's simply incredible how well this world was constructed and expanded upon in NieR and NieR: Automata.

The game takes place several millennia after the first installment, which is why you don't immediately recognize the world. However, all the important locations, although completely devastated, hidden, or expanded, are still there. Through archive data and dialogues, you can also learn why the world has evolved in this way.

The story is also on its own level. By repeatedly shattering the worldview, it can be compared to Attack on Titan. But there are also numerous side quests that add even more depth to everything. Along the way, you are constantly confronted with moral questions that are not so easy to answer and leave you pensive.

The gameplay is perfectly executed, as expected from Platinum Games. 2B controls in a hack-and-slash manner, while 9S provides a good variation through machine hacking, which also supports the worldbuilding by allowing us to experience the emotions and thoughts of the machines.

The graphics, and especially the soundtrack, are beautiful as well. I haven't seen anywhere else where the OST consists of a mix of different languages, which is intended to represent a kind of future language.

I've completed the game in its entirety for the second time now, including all the endings and side quests, and it has definitely made it into my top 10 games. I'm really excited to replay NieR: Replicant now.

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ

"NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢" is a captivating gaming experience, presenting a rich and intricate lore that rivals the best anime series. It lets you dive headfirst into high-stakes battles and dramatic scenes.

The music and voice acting are second to none. The soundtrack, particularly when paired with the original Japanese voice acting, redefines excellence. The enchanting melodies linger long after the game ends, and the voice actors' performances are so compelling they leave a memorable imprint.

With no spoilers, I can't stress enough the thrill this game offers. The combat system is not just satisfying‚Äîit's immersive, pulling you right into the heart of the action. As you upgrade your weapons, you get to diversify your gameplay with innovative builds and combos, making each battle uniquely exhilarating.

"NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢" boasts a variety of well-crafted mini-games, from hacking mechanics to 2D platformer sequences and thrilling spaceship battles‚Äîthere's never a dull moment. The 9S section could be a bit repetitive, but it's a minor flaw easily overlooked due to the fresh narrative perspective it provides.

The storytelling is an artistic feat, visually and narratively. It subtly conveys profound messages, delivering a powerful narrative through epic scenes and touching dialogues. It creates room for player contemplation, stimulating your imagination. The epic boss fights, underscored by the harmonious music, and the meticulous character development elevate the narrative to new heights.

The story and lore of "NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢" have created an indelible impression. The unforgettable characters‚Äî2B, 9S, A2, and a host of intriguing side characters‚Äîwill remain etched in my memory. Their evolving relationships, filled with friendship and romance, resonate deeply. It's a rare game that can leave such a profound impact, earning it a well-deserved spot among my top 5 favorites.

I wholeheartedly endorse this extraordinary gaming experience and extend a heartfelt thank you to everyone involved in crafting such a remarkable game.

I won't delve into the gameplay side of things, it's pretty universally accepted that the gameplay of NieR:Automata is mediocre. The story is seen as absolutely incredible though, which it isn't, it's also fairly mediocre.

I don't doubt that when the game came out the story was profound and revolutionary, now though, it's just your typical "AI/human realises AI can be conscious" story. You've seen stuff like this way more times already, and a lot of those times done far better. The characters are one dimensional and experience a very linear character arc. AI believes machines aren't conscious and they want to kill them all; AI faces proof that the machines are conscious, still doesn't believe they're conscious and wants to kill them; AI after a lot of proof realises that the machines are conscious but still kills them anyway; machines did something bad to the AI, now AI wants to kill all machines and believes they're not conscious; AI realises machines are conscious and no longer wants to kill them; THE END.

The characters also have additional character arcs involving them realising they like someone as a friend, in an equally linear way.

Side quests barely have any story to them, it's mainly that they'll throw a random concept out there like idk a machine having a sister, and then just leave you with that concept without any real conclusion aside from "they lived happily ever after".

For the first 20h, basically no story is told at all, nothing profound, nothing really that interesting, there's a couple mysteries thrown around too, but we know literally nothing about them. Then for the next 10h or so you'll find out what all that story before meant, and then for the last 5h or so you'll get the conclusion to that story with some honestly fairly decent plot twists.

I'd give this a mixed review if I could, but well steam doesn't have that. If you've never experienced any media portraying the same themes as this game, and or you don't really have any of your own opinions about this, then you'll probably thoroughly enjoy the story, otherwise I wouldn't really recommend it, aside from just taking it out of your backlog.

I had a hard time getting into this one but I'm really glad I persevered.  I spent a lot of time on route A (32 hours) and mostly enjoyed it when I played but found it forgettable and it rarely stuck with me when I wasn't playing.  The combat is mostly combos and dodging and frankly I'm just not very good at that.  I found the opening hour impossible until I changed started playing on easy.  I often didn't know what I was supposed to be doing and there often seemed to be very intentional barriers to actually enjoying it.  

All of that changed toward the end of route A and the story really picked up.  Route B isn't a repeat AT ALL-  combat was suddenly a twin-stick shooter and it was much quicker (maybe 7 hours).  Routes C/D took another 11 hours and the story got really intense.  Ah- that's what people are  talking about.  I get it now.  

Its a serious time investment but while the first half of this game did very little for me the 2nd half was absolutely brilliant.

The plot and character development alone is worth the price of admission. Gameplay has a decent blend of action RPG and classic elements(complete with the 8-bit sound effects), but it could be described as a bit generic in it's execution. This game isn't very pretty and some may even describe the art style at first glance as drab, empty and ugly aside from the main character models, but after a few hours of playing it kind of makes sense with the general mood of the game.  

All that said, the first bit of praise is the most important. If the plot and characters weren't as fascinating as they were, I wouldn't enjoy this game. I did find that it took a long time for me to get invested, and this was 
after I strongly considered getting a refund because I wasn't having fun with the gameplay. 

Oh, and this game has undoubtedly the best New Game+ I have ever experienced in a video game, and it's not what you think it is.

I originally was interested in this game because of the "fanart" and "fanwork" so to speak, and had already been spoiled on the clusterfluck of a story and multiple endings, as well as how it ties into the first nier series, and in turn Drag-on Dragoon. It was 50% off at some point, so i decided to show support for the developer for making such a..."visually exciting" character.

But in playing this game, there's much more to it. 
There's simply much more to this game than can be experienced by reading spoilers and looking at artwork.

-The voice acting, and even mimicry of human ticks mid-conversation. 
-The Sound track and music scored by a professional music production studio (MONACA)
-The cinematography and spectacle of cutscenes and boss introductions
-the way the game's meta settings line up with in-game story telling: your hud and settings are actually supposed to represent the settings of the android you're controlling
-the great attention to detail: every npc has dialogue, every item has a description, every weapon has a story (in the literal sense) that unlocks as you level it up
-the realistic depictions of characters: your main cast aren't just one liners, or silent protagonists; they have internal dialogue that is not shared with the player, but can be inferred from body language
-an extremely full world of interactables: unlike most game's that advertise "open world", this world really feels fleshed out; you may be annoyed by invisible walls here and there, but the entire world is chock full of interactables and rewards you for exploring and being curious

Because of all of the above, the world created in this game is incredibly easy to become immersed in.

This doesn't even being to talk about gameplay, of which most "story driven narrative" games oft fall short.
If you're complete dogs**t at video games (like myself), you can turn on or off easy mode at any time and simply advance the story, like watching a very convoluted mystery/action thriller.
This game would have been good enough if it were just a movie; but when they could have just stopped there, they decided to slap real and challenging gameplay on top of it, as well as vast variety in battle styles.

This game is amazingly fleshed out, and i understand why it had received the "GOTY" title for 2017.
It's very cliche to say some bull like, "this is more than a game" or "this is a piece of art", but once in a while a game like this will come and very much deserve those sayings.

If you've ever "enjoyed" "fanwork" of 2b, you owe it to yoko taro and yourself to play this game.

Full disclosure: This has been my thoughts after two [W] (joke) endings, playing with KB&M.
Desperately wanted to enjoy this, and I'm sure it's a fantastic experience if you're looking for one.
But I have to address the absolute impossibility of playing this on a keyboard: Even from the very beginning, any top-down section is an absolute mental effort to use WASD and arrows at the same time, while also managing extra presses like firing and dodging.
The camera usage is definitely thought out, but as someone who is used to having fully camera control it is both infuriating and disorienting to manage: The game certainly does its best to make the angles work, but in 3D sections with enemies surrounding you, it is too much to try and wrangle the camera to see what is going on, especially at the same time as the combat.
The bullet hell aspect is definitely interesting, but simply not manageable with all the other problems one has to worry about in fights.
And finally, the reason I'm here instead of trying to get better: Dying (at least in the prologue) sets you back to the very beginning. I can possibly learn Marx's (subtle name, I know) attacks under ideal circumstances, but I can't be bothered to experiment when every failure sets me back to redo 20 minutes of tutorial (and the twin-stick-designed sections).

If you just want the experience, watch the anime instead.

The difficulty levels are unbalanced, while normal is too easy, hard (the next level) is too much, not always, but quite often, unless you are overleveled.

The plot is fine, some moments are really nice, but I can't say it is that great as a lot of people wrote.
And the emotional expressions of the characters, in most cases, are dull.
Maybe it is because I'm not a fan of anime.

Overall the game is OK, worth the money if bought on sale.

A whole lot of deliberation went into this little review. NieR: Automata is a 9/10 game. The gameplay isnt particularly fun, consisting mostly of button-mashing, the barrier for entry is unreasonably high, requiring 3 and a half playthroughs to reach the conclusion, and the worldbuilding is very lackluster, explaining maybe 10% of what the game has to show. And yet, I still gave the game a 9/10. The story here is, without a doubt THE BEST video game story I've ever played. The music is top notch, though not really comparable to any other OST with its uniqueness, and the graphics make me forget I'm playing a video game sometimes. I cant dive into the story without discussing spoilers, so I'll leave you with this: this game is not worth buying UNLESS you actually put in the time to play through to all five endings. If you do, however, you will have an experience unlike any other. I did not enjoy my time with this game, but I most assuredly will next time I play. This game has joined the ranks of my very favourites. A true masterpiece.

This game,, it's broken me down time and time again, ripped my heart to shreds and left me heartbroken, but at the same time, it's brought me back up again. Terrible things happen, and people suffer for what seems like no reason. Yes, this world is terrible, but it's also very beautiful, and it's worth fighting for. 

Real talk tho, the story is absolutely phenomenal. The graphics and music comp are beautiful (astounding, really), and the game play is satisfying and challenging. The game play switches between hack-and-slash. shoot-em-up, and even some bullet-hell type stuff, but it blends and seams together perfectly. To get the full experience of the story, you'll have to play through it at least 3 times, but I swear to you, it's worth it. Just stick through it to the end, listen to the different stories the game offers you. Each story is just as impactful and heart-wrenching as the last.

Some spoiler territory following, but nothing too specific:

[spoiler] I wanted to 100% complete the game. Get every single fish, item, pod, weapon upgrade, quest, every ending. And I got pretty far too. Maybe about 80% completion overall. But then I was left with one last decision by one of the final endings (E). And you know what? I might regret that decision in the future, but I came to the realization that nothing really lasts forever. And I realized that I was ready to part with everything I had worked so hard for in the game, so I did. And I hope it ends up helping someone in the long run, as others have helped me during my play-through. [/spoiler]

This is one of the best games I've ever played in my life. It is something that I will never be able to experience for the first time ever again. And I hope that this review can get others to at least give it a try.

I also want to thank anyone and everyone who has ever sacrificed to help a total stranger, even one you might hate. [spoiler] Thank you Zhang, for your sacrifice. It really meant a lot to me. [/spoiler]

Kiwi [My voice may never reach you. But... I'm rooting for you.] - Pascal's Village

Honestly, this game is peak, 10/10 art, music, story, characters, level design, philosofy, [spoiler] butt [/spoiler]... if I have to point something bad, probably is the tedious side quests, it's just "destroy an enemy, bring me some item and that's it", but their story makes them really worth it. If all of that don't make you want to play this game, a good reason is:

This game is super complex, well written and makes you question the human condition and sentience of robots. The game has so much replay value and it is highly recommended you replay to get the real final endings. Of the 5 main endings, the final is so beautiful and well worth it to get. The other joke endings are also very fun to get but for anyone who has played Replicant, one of the endings may be worth the hard grind to get. 
It honestly is my favourite game of all time, with it's complexity and characters with so much depth you will probably grow very attached to each of the main protagonists. 
The gameplay is also very fun. One of the best things in this game is being able to evade as it makes combat very satisfying weaving in combos and evading, then either robot pew or more hacking and slashing. The other type of combat during the second playthrough is also very fun and mixes up how you play.
The music in this game is so well made and I've definitely listened it to outside of the game. However, when you do hear songs in game while you play it becomes the most hype thing ever. Interesting when you do the second playthrough combat, the music changes and it's a vibe.
Overall, the game is perfection or close to perfection. A solid 10/10 or my rating 11/10.
The aesthetics, gameplay, story, soundtrack, dialogues, UI and character customization are all very-well crafted into a most coherent product. Highly recommended.

I spent a lot of time customising with plug-in chips, still haven't found half of them. Game requires you to play it couple of times with slight changes to the story, gives you a different perspective each time. I am on my second play-through, I can't even guess what's still waiting for me.

It's alright... One of those side-ways thumbs for sure for me. It has some really high highs and some really, really low lows. Let's start with the good. The combat, writing and combat scenarios feel extremely fresh in an already tried and true genre. Especially when the game forces you to play a 2d sidescroller suddenly or a top-down bullet hell, its very refreshing and a cool mix of ideas. What doesnt work is that this game's world is extremely empty, it's so barebones it almost feels like a bug or something. I thought a few times that enemies or assets had failed to load because it was so barren. Pair this with an incredibly out-dated save mechanic where auto-saves are not a thing and the fact that you have to replay the game several times to get the "proper" ending/story. This just feels cheap to me, I don't want to sit through / force myself  to play the same game multiple times with slight differences (Route A / B) just to experience the good part (Route C). This, to me, speaks of serious design flaws and marrs what could have been otherwise a really solid recommendation. All in all it does enough interesting things to merit a thumbs up, but just barely.

[h1] Overrated [/h1]

I'll preface my review by saying that this style of action game is perhaps not for me and I obviously haven't finished the entire thing (...but why would you continue to play something if you're not enjoying it after nearly 9 hours...?). Though I have had a lot of fun playing through DMC titles back during the PS2 golden era, and I'm no stranger to punishing titles like Dark Souls or Hollow Knight, this game feels so bland...

Starting with the superficial, it's not a very visually exciting world. Aside from the amusement park, the world is uninspired and devoid of detail. The character models look great and are very well animated, but they're in total contrast to the incredibly muddy and repetitive textures everywhere else.

The combat is fine, plenty of weapon variety and skills to choose from, but it's nothing special. Every encounter plays out essentially the same way.

The difficulty scaling is ridiculous. Normal difficulty level is boring, button mashing is all that's required to progress. Hard difficulty is absurd... the majority of enemies can basically one-hit kill you... and yet that's what 'Very hard' explicitly states - one hit to die. So then, why make 'Hard' difficulty essentially the same thing? On Normal difficulty, you can kill enemies that are 20 levels higher than you without too much trouble. On Hard, you get annihilated by enemies that are even 1-2 levels lower than you if you're not paying the utmost attention. 

What exacerbates the nonsensical difficulty scaling even more is the death system. People online seem to compare the death system to that of Dark Souls. That's just objectively incorrect. Dark Souls titles punish a death by potentially erasing any 'un-banked' 'exp/cash'. You [b] still [/b] have your equipment and your stats (stats that are baked into your character and have a much greater bearing on your build and the difficulty). Death in Nier is FAR more punishing. If you die in Nier, you lose all of your chips which cost a fortune to buy and upgrade. In Nier, your chips are by far the most important part of a build. Without those chips, you are [b] massively [/b] weakened, and should you die attempting to retrieve them (very likely on Hard difficulty), They're all gone - I hope you enjoying grinding mobs! It's just pointless and unnecessarily punishing...

I will refrain from commenting on the story, as that is surely something that needs to be appreciated from at least one completion.

EDIT: Hi, below is my rant on the prologue for this game. Play on normal, play with a controller, if you don't you'll have a bad time. That being said, once the 45 minute prologue section is over, it's a very fun ARPG, which already has a very interesting story about an hour in (it took me like 2 hours to beat the prologue because I hadn't connected a controller for my first couple of attempts). The KB&M controls are BAD, playing with a controller allows much better flow while fighting and much more precise movement.

OK, first impressions guys, first impressions.
I hate the prologue already, hate it with a passion. The first thing you have to do is complete a long 30 minute stage, which gets pretty difficult near the end, with no saves, not one. on top of that, a lot of it is just cinematics and easy fights with low level enemies. The ONLY part that's truly difficult is what I HOPE is the last part of the prologue (Edit: It wasn't), a big ol boss fight against two giant sawblade arm things. I've already died twice to that boss, and I wouldn't mind so much if I didn't have to WASTE THIRTY MORE MINUTES GETTING BACK TO WHERE I WAS! Even Dark Souls hasn't annoyed me this much because they usually have a few campfires rather close to the boss, but nah. If I decide to play again and get past the prologue I'll edit the review to reflect my thoughts on the rest of the game, but I really am not happy with my purchase right now.

Very good.

NieR:Automata is a game that perfectly balances brilliant storytelling, game-play, design, and replay value while entrancing the player with its profound lore, philosophy, music, and stellar voice acting. For these reasons, I can confidently say this is one of the greatest, if not THE greatest game ever made.

For being a sequel, it's presentation of its story is so well done you won't need to have played the predecessor Nier Replicant. Yet the way the story is understandable both with and without playing Replicant, it can usually drive you to play the first Nier just based on how good it felt to experience Automata. 

The game-play balances hack-and-slash, bullet hell, retro mini-games, and a mix of all the former in a unique and incredibly fun way. On the surface, it may seem repetitive and uninspired with games like the Devil May Cry series or Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance being staples of the hack-and-slash genre. Despite, all that being said, Automata perfected hack-and-slash with other game genres in a rewarding and enticing manner done like no other game.

The design is simply impeccable. While the game depends heavily on a good operating system (namely your GPU), the landscapes, character models, areas, and effects are brilliant if your system handles it. 

The voice acting of Automata is some of the greatest ever performed in both English and Japanese Every voice actor nails their role and the performance of 9S's English voice actor is genuinely the best video game voice acting performance ever.

The music is yet another fantastic part of the Nier franchise. Not only does it tend to fit with the story, it adapts to the game and evolves to your situation. The chaos language and having both narrative value and being beautifully composed make for one of the most gorgeous soundtracks across all MEDIA. Only rivaled to it's predecessor Replicant.

The game has tons of replay value with its various endings and three routes. It builds upon it's story with the fact so much is left up to player interpretation. Not in a confusing and disappointing way but rather an interesting approach that leads you to delve deep into the lore and full understanding of it's lore and narrative.

In conclusion, I highly recommend NieR:Automata. This game is one of the most emotionally touching and well written video games ever. 

Final Rating: 10/10

Ruins what could have been good with really bad design decisions. The Combat and story are both just OK, and would have made it more worth if not for a string of choices by the devs that disrespect a player's time.

The save system is just bad. Limited areas for manual saves only. 
And a just bizarre choice of making deaths have a corpse run mechanic or lose actual items. 
Combine those things together with a level progression system that wants you to grind to keep up with monster levels, its just a stack of choices that are designed to artificially extend the time the game takes.

There are better 3rd person action games out there, spend your time and money elsewhere.

The only reason that I don't recommend NieR is its lack of an autosave. Not having an autosave function can be as important to the developer's vision of the narrative as it wants, but that does not stop it from being a enormous inconvenience. I've probably played this game three times over by now, and I'm on my first playthrough. What I have played is a lot of fun and there's clearly a lot to like, combat is enjoyable enough and the characters are all fun to get to know. I just don't want to have played it as many times as I have in such a short timespan. If you can get past the fact that you have to save religiously to avoid having to replay huge swaths of the game, I'm certain that you'll have a great time, if this is the sort of game you're generally into. I can't.

 The story is absolutely amazing and one of the most interesting ideas I have ever seen. You have to play through the game multiple times to get all the details, but at least the first three playthroughs are different, after which you'll unlock chapter selection and be able to view other endings more easily.

The combat is very comfortable, the smoothly moving camera gives an even better effect of the feeling of combat. There are tons of different weapons and skills to decorate your characters with and play the way you want.

The graphics are very nice, but many areas get really foggy and the environment sometimes seems a little blurry. There are several graphic mods that can also transform your interface, but everything looks attractive even without mods.

It was a wonderful experience and I definitely recommend trying this game!

Frankly, I don't understand what all the hype is about. Combat is clunky because the character is difficult to orient in the intended direction and not very responsive to your movement inputs, the characters are annoyingly shallow, there were multiple glaring discrepancies in the first two hours of the game (e.g., 2B acting as commander of the squad in the intro sequence despite not being the commander, robots that breathe heavily when damaged), and other story details that were difficult to accept even given the often distorted logic of jRPGs (e.g., soldiers who need to be told to do basic crap like evade enemy fire and 2B picking up a buzz saw many times her size by hacking it).

So, yeah, it is badly designed and written. I guess I should have expected that from a game whose most popular feature is 2B's ass.

How do you feel when you normally finish a game? 

Exultant? Triumphant? Satisfied? Do you want to shake your fist at the screen or elicit a primal scream?

I felt none of these finishing Nier: Automata. In fact, my heart was eerily quiet. I stared at the computer screen for several moments.

In silent appreciation for one of the most atmospheric, expertly paced, astonishingly well realised worlds I have ever had the privelege to play.

But before we get to that, I want to gush about the music.

The music! My god the music!

From the moment you take your first steps on this superb story driven, existentialist action/drama game about a surrogate proxy war fought between the remnants of humanity (Androids) and the machines that killed them, you find yourself gripped by a sweeping orchestral/industrial soundtrack that is as thought provoking as it is blood pumping. In contrast to most games, for which the soundtrack is something of an afterthought, the music sets the tone here, spanning eery desert wastes, delapidated city ruins and a bizzare machine-run utopic themepark with equal aplomb. Of particular note is Birth of a Wish , a thumping, gloriously cacophonic industrial/gregorian chant played during one of the later mission in the game, Twisted Religion. Never has a piece of music in a video game fit a level so perfectly and never has the argument been made as emphatically as Nier: Automata has that music is an integral part of video gaming as a whole. 

It's a mesmerising underpinning for an ostensibly simple action game. What masquerades as a simple bullet hell/melee combo action game about Androids fighting Machines is actually an atonishingly well realised, if simple, tale about what it means to be human. Throughout the game you encounter machines aping human tendencies, such as declaring their independence or putting on a play, or giving some twisted simalacrum of human emotion in their desperate attempts to become sentient. The Androids behave similarly with main characters and standouts 2B, a stoic, tough-minded female android with a heart of gold, and 9S, a well intentioned, helpful, sweet-but-naieve male android, slowly evolving beyond their original programming and developing the ability to feel, while fighting the urge to do so. After all, emotion is exclusive to human experience, isn't it?

I could go on about the multiple playthroughs told from the perspective of different characters, the almost clinical but gorgeous art direction, the layers of subtle world building invoked in each interaction or each item description. It goes on and on.

The end result is breathtaking. A world as sterile and eerily devoid of life, as it is joyous and brimming with emotion. It's a story that tugs on the heartstrings and reminds us that we all bleed red, even as we wave different colored flags or wear different flesh-colored (or shaped) suits.

Nier: Auomata is a masterpiece, a once-in-a-generation game that inspires you to question what it means to be human. That you have a lot of fun doing so, battling a diverse cast of machines in varied forms across the breadth of a beautifully designed and lonely world, is just the icing on an already delicious, michelin-star level cake.

Unforgettable.

Not a masterpiece by any means.

It annoys me to no end how the public will take open ended story tropes dished out by the author on an emotional whim and say they are ingenious, a true masterpiece. But no, that line of thinking is for the ones who wish to convey to others that they possess higher IQ than what they actually have. There is a method that must be adhered to in order to tell a congruent story. For example, if you take time to detail an item in your story, it better be of some consequence to the ending.

We seem to live in a world where conveyed emotions through music, color schemes, and sobbing characters constitute a good story. But, ladies and gentlemen, that is not a story, that is the icing you put onto the story. Story is a clear objective for the main characters that aligns with the theme the author is trying to present, the cake if you will. Now, not to say Nier Automata does not have a story, it does, and despite a world full of games without one, Nier has a theme as well. But this story is 90% icing and 10% cake. It doesn't even have a clear antagonist, the heart of a story, other than some ambiguous man vs man's nature dilemma. Which, of course means it doesn't have a satisfying ending, despite the options you choose. Which brings me to the rest of the game.

The game is decent in a lot of areas but it's lacking in so much more. Game-play mechanics that force a player to play a style or character they might not want, backtracking upon backtracking, and level design that is not fluent or very intuitive, meaning it's more of a chore to get through parts than it is fun running through them.

Overall, Platinum Star did their job with the combat. However, unlike Devil May Cry or Bayonetta, there's more to this game than just action. Most of the Nier story elements drag Platinum Star's showcase down. There's something to be said about keeping it simple, and that's why DMC and Bayonetta worked, and why Nier struggles to do the same.

Anyway, this is the last Nier title I'll ever spend my time on. I wish the best for the team, as this setting does have potential, but I'm not holding my breath and moving on to the next promising title out there.

I'll say this once before going into the cons : The game is really REALLY GOOD!

Cons : 
1. Lots of game features are unavailable until you progress upto a certain threshold in the game
2. Some features are not unlocked before 2-3 playthroughs of the entire game
3. There is NO AUTOSAVE as the game clearly mentions (repeatedly)
4. You will be running around like a madman for grinding XP and/or finding quest items (or upgrade items)
5. The map isn't technically open-world as there are lots of places that can only be accessed via a specific route that is not always obvious
6. The waypoint system sucks (if censored, the word I said is : "saaaaa-aaaa-cks")
7. The map is very very empty except for quest areas (Although this makes sense according to the story)
8. And as almost everyone should know, this game has 26 endings (A-Z), so choices matter VERY VERY MUCH

Playing this many years post release, I think it's a good game.
The overall story and setting is interesting. It's pretty obvious earlier in the game the message it's going towards, but it's still nice to go through it, and the twists are interesting. Just make sure you play it past the first 2 "endings" or you'll miss the more interesting part of the story!
The only annoying part is the small world. You'll be going to the same areas again and again and again and again and again if you want to do the sidequests. The underlying story for some of the sidequests is interesting, but they're mostly fetch quests, so not really interesting gameplay wise. Upgrading all the weapons is also not needed. I mostly just stuck to a set for the whole game.
The music is really good. I liked listening to it. It adds to the vibe of the world. Though it too can get repetitive if doing all the side quests and farming all materials. So I would recommend to not treat it as a MMORPG and go mats farming for 2 days...

The most difficult part of the game has got to be, by far, the controls.
Installing the mod "NieR Automata Mod Helper (NAMH)" is a MUST. It's a helper mod that helps install other mods. And the first one to add is "NieR Automata Input Overhaul Mod (NAIOM)". Without this one the controls would have been impossible. Seriously, spend a little bit of time to install NAMH and NAIOM. Once that's installed, the controls would still be annoying at times, but wasn't a deal breaker. The mods also fix some of the bugs.

NieR: Automata is a very aesthetically pleasing game with fluid and satisfying fighting mechanics. Throughout the natural course of the story you will play as several different characters. This is a mostly-enjoyable experience - but the game lacks when playing as "9S." You see, 9S has a special gimmick as a scanner-model type android, which is the Hacking Minigame that everyone deeply hates. And for good reason - to be honest, it sucks. A lot of it is mandatory as well, whether because you actually need to hack to progress in the story or because 9S lacks so much in damage that you may as well just resort to hacking. Some of the hacking experience almost made me not recommend the game, actually. It's silly to force players to progress in this way when they came to fight as a hot android lady. Not to mention, the game has a very weak story - Personally, when playing a story game I seek something that makes me feel genuine emotion, but the story is not told in such a way that any dramatic cutscene actually strikes as saddening or anything at all...

One mechanic I will praise is the Plug-in Chip function, essentially allowing you to make your own "build" for the lack of a better term. There are several categories of chips that you can gather to enhance your preferred experience. You can collect or purchase these and even fuse them to make better chips under certain requirements, and I find this to be a very cool idea, however, if you die you will need to recollect your chips off your last body lest you lose them forever. Dying is usually not a problem in this game though, as it is very easy most of the time (aside from the Hacking Minigames, which can often be really frustrating and at some parts even difficult - but you'll not die from these) unless you're on Hard mode. Any other difficulty is a breeze.

Something I do not enjoy is the side quests, which is unfortunate because you can gain a lot of valuable rewards from doing them. Most of them are very dull and dare I say boring, but the story quests can be fun though I think some just drag on way too long.

Despite the many flaws the game has, the characters are very memorable and fascinating nonetheless which is one strength I do think it has - 2B, 9S, and A2 will always be remembered fondly in my heart.

Regardless, the game is worth the experience, which is why I will recommend it, although in reality it is just "okay." The game is somewhat fun when you're actually fighting and slaying machines, but overall is just a very "meh" experience.

Masterpiece

Nier Automata is a multifaceted composition piece. It combines elements in several unique ways: The visuals are realistic or stylistic precisely where intended, the music was written in layers to enhance environmental and narrative development, and the cinematics, camera work, and gameplay is frequently modified to seamlessly frame and suit the scene. So the player in Nier Automata, experiences digital theatre as gameplay, built around action combat core and an interesting story telling format, which is reinforced by its android theme.

As a day-1 one PS4 player, having it platinum'd and all, I can say for certain that it's one of my favorite games! Can't say much about the PC port itself, but as a game, it's very close to a masterpiece (in my humble opinion). I enjoy the hack-n-slash combat and combos you can do between weapon types, the variety of ranged options and skills to use with your pods is a good way to call back on the magic system back in the first NieR.

It's story is deep and makes you think about so many things, but only if you pay attention to it, otherwise it's just a fun combat game. For those coming back from NieR: Replican/Gestalt, these details were lovely (and painful) to witness! There are plenty of philosophical analysis of the story and it's message around the internet so I won't get into that in my review as I'm not great at writing my thoughts out.
