I tried to give this game an honest effort, but I just can't put up with it anymore. I haven't finished my second play-through (you HAVE to play through four times to see the full game) and I'm about to just stop and uninstall... and I NEVER fail to finish a game. It just isn't fun enough. 

The Pros:
The overarching theme is appealing.
There's mass potential for deep, rich story with tons of twists.
The concept of playing through as more than one character is neat.
The area biomes were a good choice. Forest, industrial, desert, aquatic, urban. 
Fighting gameplay is well executed.
The hacking mini game gameplay is good, and actually integrates into the main game fairly well.
2B has a nice back sss..... story. The game exposes it to you plenty.
Multiple endings wasn't nearly as annoying in this game as it usually is.


The Cons:
The graphics are borderline PS2 at times. The are dozens of spots where the devs clearly just said "f-it" with the textures and geometry. The area around the bridge to the theater in particular has got to be some of most amateurish texture composition I have seen in a top tier game in the last 15 years. There are no detailed graphics settings, so you can't crank the game to "melt my GPU mode" even if you have a high spec PC, which wouldn't need to be much since this is clearly using some old gen game engine. Just about any other 2017 game looks better than this game. I'd say 90% of the games graphics went to the characters, which is valuable for exactly one character... (butt, I mean, but then that's just pandering anyway.) 5% went into foliage, 3% into the water, 2% got spread across the rest of the game.

The music you hear the most is cringy and basically forced down your throat. Some songs in some parts are OK, but man, Pascal's village.... by mid second play through I straight couldn't take it anymore and turned the music actually off. There's also some funky logic with how the game chooses when and for how long to play a track. You'll do a quest that changes the music, and then the whole area you are in gets saturated in that song, but not in a good way. It gets super uncomfortable. The logic that good BGM is never noticed applies; the music stands out too much.

The characters are flat as paper (with exception of maybe 9S). 2B is little better than a blowup doll flashing her can as much as the game dares to get away with. "Running butt simulator" I keep joking with my GF. A2 looks interesting, but I hardly got to see her. I suspect she is main for the third or fourth play through, but I can't be bothered to find out. Moving on, the director can't seem to decide which character has what personality. At times 2B will be dangerously curious about the goings on, and 9S will have to pull her back by reminding her that "it's forbidden." butt... I mean... but then the next scene it's the other way around. It's so jarring to have your characters flip around on you like that. Ironically, the robots have more personality. Lastly, the blindfold thing is just strange. If it was one of the characters only, for very good reason, that would have been cool... butt, I mean, but on both mains it's just weird. One might even say "creepy."

The world FEELS microscopic. Yeah, there are areas like the desert or the ruined city that are unmistakably large, but there is just zero content there. This is one of the few games where I felt like I actually should take all the side quests just to try and help fully flesh out a game. It's also one of the most closed open world games I have played in a while. The worst part is they doubled down on shrinking the world by making your stay in any one area brief. You spend all of 350 seconds in the desert area before you're back in the main camp. The thing that really irked me though was the buildings. These things are massive concrete honeycomb play grounds with plenty of places to hide treasures and fun..... and you basically never go in one. They are effectively reduced to massive stone cubes filling the world.

The controls don't work well on PC, which I guess is partly my fault for not using a controller. Worse still there are no settings to fix some of the problems. In particular I would like to put run/dodge on one of my mouses thumb buttons, l337 Dark Souls style, but the game just doesn't have the ability. The mouse doesn't work well for shooting when is side view, and Doesn't work well for hacking game. So I found myself jumping to keyboard for those things, then back to mouse. 

Bottom line, I don't see myself finishing this game, and I always finish my games.

I played this game with the FAR mod and it ran fine, although Alt-Tab caused the game to be in window mode and not return to fullscreen automatically.

[h1]Story[/h1]
It's meh, the story swings but does not hit. It's supposed to be very sad but every one who dies I don't care about because you hardly meet them or would die sooner or later of random super-natural reasons.
Side quest are mostly filler with little story but the game likes to pretend by putting sob music, it works only for the first 2 times. (I am spoiled a bit from The Witcher 3)

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Gameplay is pretty good ,the hack and slash + bullet hell is fun and challenging although combos are difficult to execute because it's a japanese game. The other mode with robots is a MASTERPIECE, I want to reincarnate as a saw centipede.
Tends to suffer from lack of enemy variety and the RPG thing were enemies level up with you in numbers alone.

[h1]World[/h1]
The world is pretty dull, I get that it is a post-apocalypse but did it need to set in the post communist blocks of russia. I am not asking for the Last Of Us but when you start game there so many places were you think you can enter a building only to be surprised by an invisible wall.
Would have preferred to have the main area be on top of collapsed buildings were you had to jump from block to block to reach your destination and die if you fell instead of this walk in park flat zone.

The entire game all 50 hours of it happens in sunny daytime washed in white, I really would have liked to see the stars in the desert like in Red Dead Redemption. Everything is lit the same way all the time, you have white haired characters on white concrete(or sand) on white background sky with their white pods firing mostly white projectiles at dirt brown enemies. (in hindsight, it really is bad)

Game left me meh.

[h1]Detailed story review below[/h1]

[spoiler]
Route A:
It's kinda uneventful you meet 2 guys, meet them again, kill one and then kill the other one, with boss battles in between.

Route B:
Should have been cut or play only the different chapters.
The game does even bother give you a preview of it like in Route C.

Route C:
Finally it's starts, but just ends.

Route D and E:
Haven't bothered looks like different cut scenes that you get by save scumming the last minute.
The game does not care about these 2 ending despite it being supposed the full ending.

So the game is supposed to feel sad but:
- Your squad mates in the first mission die but you don't know them, they don't even have names

- The resistance is the most human like and are the ones you fight for, for the majority/all of the game.
You save them early on and nothing bad ever happens to them at all, their problems are missing a fuel filter, sorting crates and some missing supplies.
The world is on fire/breaking apart literally and they comically fine.
Giant mecha attack, fine.
Earth is collapsing near them in a giant crater, fine.
Boss battle with flying boulder worm, fine
Machine invasion, Yorha infected with virus that makes them kill people, world is on fire, giant castle in the sky and they are just DANDY selling you stuff.
Forgot about eldritch  horror approaching coast.

- The village people die, I don't care about them, they are cartoons. If the game wanted me to care about them why not let me play more as a robot like in the first part in Route B where you play as a small robot trying to help his brother.
Route B should have been 9S having to be play the role of different machines in order to infiltrate some organization/cult.

- The children commit suicide while being defended (and not harmed), but before that happens:
The racing flyer commits suicide because he isn't the fastest one.
The karate bot wants to die in combat because pride ? ? ?
The robot that contemplates life throws himself to his death (actually very funny in hindsight the timing is just perfect, feels like 9S should have said before "Do a flip" like in Futurama).
An ENTIRE cult of death, made out of robots massacred themselves.

Are you kidding me ? How can you not expect any robot to kill themselves when you are not looking ? No wonder I felt nothing.
Forgot about those robots doing the Romeos and Julietas play at the amusement park.

- 9S dies, nevermind we've got a backup just fill him in on the details and it's just fine.
- B2 dies, nevermind she now haunts A2 which becomes her to an extent.
- A2 survies.
- Popola and Devola maybe die.
You know what would I do if they didn't show up to help enter the tower ?
Leave, remote control one of the guards send to defend the tower and just hack the tower.
There is no point in the game where remote controlling and hacking are ever spotted by the machines.

The story swings but does not hit.

And now for the stuff left unresolved and is more interesting than the normal playthru:
- Throughout the game the machines that you fight seem to be posesed and unwilling to attack you and even wishing for death to escape pain. This is never answered by the game and seems to be the real enemy of everyone it also has more emotional impact.
- What about the machine gifts, those visions from 9S.

[/spoiler]

In the vast world of gaming, there are few experiences that can truly touch the heart and soul. One such gem is NieR: Automata, a game that transcends boundaries and captivates players with its mesmerizing beauty and thought-provoking narrative. And for me, as someone on the autism spectrum, this game has become a source of incredible solace and tranquility.

From the very first moment I delved into the post-apocalyptic world of NieR: Automata, I was enveloped by its hauntingly melodic soundtrack. The ethereal tunes, blending with the stunning visuals, created a symphony of harmony that resonated deeply within me. The game's ability to evoke such strong emotions through its music is nothing short of magical.

One of the aspects that makes NieR: Automata truly special is its exploration of existential themes and the intricacies of human emotions. It delves into the depths of what it means to be alive, to question one's purpose, and to forge connections in a world teetering on the brink of despair. As someone on the autism spectrum, these themes resonate with me on a profound level, providing a sense of understanding and validation that is both comforting and empowering.

The gameplay mechanics of NieR: Automata are elegantly crafted, offering a seamless blend of action, exploration, and role-playing elements. The combat is fluid and exhilarating, allowing for a satisfying level of customization and strategy. But beyond the adrenaline-pumping battles, there is a soothing rhythm to the gameplay that brings a sense of calm to my autistic mind. The repetition of actions and the focus required to master the game's mechanics become a meditative experience, soothing my senses and providing a sanctuary from the chaos of the world.

Furthermore, the characters in NieR: Automata are masterfully developed, each with their own unique stories and struggles. As an autistic individual, I often find it challenging to navigate the complexities of human emotions and social interactions. However, through the beautifully crafted narratives of these characters, I am offered a window into the vast spectrum of human experiences. It allows me to empathize, connect, and learn in ways that are deeply meaningful to me.

NieR: Automata is a testament to the power of video games as a form of artistic expression and emotional connection. It provides a safe haven, a world where my autistic self can find solace, understanding, and a sense of belonging. It celebrates the beauty of diversity, embracing the complexities of the human condition and reminding me that my neurodivergent perspective is a gift, not a hindrance.

If you're seeking a captivating, emotionally resonant experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming, NieR: Automata is a must-play. Its enchanting music, profound storytelling, and soothing gameplay have the power to touch hearts and souls, providing solace and tranquility for individuals like myself on the autism spectrum. Prepare to embark on a journey that will leave an indelible mark on your heart and remind you of the power of empathy, connection, and the beauty of being different.

A disappointing game, not worth your time.

Let's start off with the biggest problem: gameplay/combat. The combat and movement are unresponsive. You would expect a combat-focused game to prioritize responsive, smooth, and satisfying combat mechanics. Unfortunately, the combat in Nier: Automata constantly feels like a struggle against the controller. 

The lack of enemy variety is embarrassingly low. If you play the tutorial level, you will have already encountered 90% of the enemies you'll face throughout the entire game. To think that a professional game director would consider having only four common enemies in a 37-hour game acceptable is embarrassing.

The story has been praised as some of the "best" that video games can offer, but I am utterly flabbergasted by this claim. Nier: Automata's writing is clich√©, unoriginal, and poorly paced. I fail to understand how anyone can find this story interesting or engaging. While there are some intriguing underlying themes, they do not compensate for the main story's shortcomings. The side characters are generic, and the villains are so cringe-worthy that it makes me ashamed to be a gamer.

If you value your time, I strongly advise against playing this game. It offers three main endings, but two of them have the same conclusion. Personally, I only completed one ending and resorted to looking up the rest of the story online. 

In summary, Nier: Automata is a train wreck of a game. Its abysmal combat, shallow open world, and lackluster narrative make it an absolute chore to endure. Save yourself the agony and steer clear of this abomination.

I went into this game only hearing good things and wanting to like it, and having played Bayonetta before hand. Unfortunately the one word I would use to describe this game would be "pathetic".

The open world this game features is just that: open, empty, devoid of content. A majority of the gameplay involves you simply sprinting from point-A to point-B, chalked full of unbelievably low effort "go fetch this for me" side-quests. Although some of the visuals are nice, the constant level of detail pop-in, broken Ambient Occlusion, and low-res textures in places do a great job in disrupting that experience. The open world in many ways embodies the word "pathetic" in its attempt.

The combat that is the highlight of past Platinum Games, and unfortunately it has been watered down to two or three combos max per weapon, with a dodge button that is required to be spammed repeatedly at times breaking the flow of combat. And that's combat at its best! For another 8 hours of the game where you have to play through the EXACT SAME story you just played before, you switch to a different character who's heavy attack has been replaced by an initially novel mini-game (something from Undertale it seems), but quickly becomes a chore with not many differentiations. Although I did enjoy the camera changes during the shoot-em up sections, it's not enough to make up for all the other flaws. In total, a "pathetic" attempt at Platinum Games combat.

People who like the game seem to stroke the story the most. I did not find it to be anything special AT ALL. Even if it was good, it wouldn't make up for the 8 hour padding section, mediocre combat, and poor attempt at an open world. I found the two main characters unlikable and inconsistent. And what characters I did enjoy were quietly killed off screen as if to say "Sorry, you weren't supposed to like that character, idiot." Since I didn't find any attachment to the main vehicles of the story, I really didn't care much of anything that occurs in the character-driven plot. Sure there are brief moments but they are BRIEF. The existentialism the story is supposed to emphasise is EXTREMELY light. Like, "What does it mean to be human?" That's it. Not much is delved into that point and the three main characters have very little to say about the topic. 

Also can we discuss the Final Fantasy XV rejects that are the "main villains" in this game? Once again, uninteresting and with an almost embarrassing design. In fact the enemy design throughout most of the game is embarrassing. Aside from a few bosses, EVERY enemy you face is just another version of the rusted out tin-cans you fight throughout the first hour intro of the game. If I play the first hour of a game and I've seen almost all it has to offer enemy variety wise, there's only one word I can describe that as... "Pathetic".

I don't completely understand the reverence people hold for this game or the story after playing it. Sure the music is good but like most video games the music loses its charm after the first 2 hours of hearing it repeat continuously. 

I would not suggest anyone purchase this game. The $20 I bought this game for on sale was WAY more than the experience was worth. There are plenty of other games with better combat, better open world, and lack of padding. The best thing in Nier: Automata unfortunately, appears to be 2B's fat dumpy.

The game play, graphics, and music are incredible. BUT the story for me - a persons who hasn't played in other  game in said franchise I think is extremely weak and tried to get emotion out of you with very cheap writing that made little to no sense. Practically every character in this story is an android or machine life form of some kind, but they have human qualities and have robot qualities depending on how convenient it will be for the story. The androids bleed and feel sick in their stomach but when an arm is completely cut off it will only show machinery without any blood or anything that will indicate of it's existence. A lot of the machine lifeforms fight without any thing to say, but a lot of them will say it hurts when ever it gets hit, which I don't think wouldn't be a weird and annoying thing if they gave a little explanation. I have soooooooooo many things that I found didn't make sense and stuff that should have been explained but they let you just stay confused about for as long as possible until you come up with a conclusion that might or might not be actually true. I got every single ending and fought every boss hidden and normal,done every mission, got and read all the archives and I still don't understand so many things about the ending. But in the end the game itself is fun to play with the amount of effort put into everything other than the story.

Do you remember when as a kid you played a game you completely  lost  yourself in? Time went by so fast. It made you cry, it made you laugh. An unforgettable experience. Maybe it was because you had no prejudice towards the game back then, maybe because you were a kid. Easily entertained. 

Nier Automata is not like that game. Regardless of your prejudice towards it, Nier will grab you firmly and pull you into its immersive world. Fluid movement and combat from the creators of Bayonetta and Metal Gear Rising Revengeance. And unique story that will unravel before those who seek answers. Who are we?

I am a 40 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Tiktok and in less than a week he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I bought this game based on all the praise it got, and from what I hear the story is the real gem and you have to play through to the ending. If you want to slog through boring combat, boring quests, boring characters, etc to get to a beautiful meaty plot ending then stop reading this review right here.

I just... can't. I've played for ten hours now and haven't enjoyed a single one. The first thing that strikes you is the graphics. They're awful. I suspect it's intentional and the plot is meant to reveal why eventually because it takes effort to make graphics that bad. The models and textures are straight out of a PS2 game at best, at least for everything except the main characters. All of this is behind some heavy-handed desaturation that at times is reduced all the way to monochrome for some effect.

Then there's all the particle effects. There's a dodge mechanic that requires some timing, but it's often impossible to use just because you can't see anything going on through the obscene quantity of effects flying everywhere.

The quests are boring. Everything I have done so far has felt like filler.

The combat is okay. Okay is really the best I can give it. Maybe if this "amazing" story developed faster, or the quests were better, or the visuals weren't actively discouraging me from looking at the game, then the combat would be good enough. As is it is the only thing holding up the game and it's just not enough.

Character customization and build variety seemed promising at first, but then it became clear most weapons share move sets. It's still okay, just... not enough to carry everything else that makes this game difficult to get through.

I really want to believe that the story is worth it if I can just slog through this awful experience to get to it but... ugh. I have limited hours in my life until I die and I found more pleasure in the one I spent writing this review than in all 10 I spent playing the game.

This is by far the worst PC port I've ever played.. I'm sure there's worse ones out there but genuinely don't even bother buying this game on PC if you have access to a console. I've played this game on two completely different PC's and have had nothing but problems with this game both times while practically every other game I play runs fine. The game crashes every single time I alt tab out and then bugs out when I try and reopen it and the only solution I've found is to completely restart my computer, verifying files does nothing. I'm sure I'd have enjoyed this game far more if not for all these constant bugs but thanks to all these issues this game has left a pretty sour taste in my mouth, especially considering how insane the hype is for this game.

The game itself is fine when it actually works I guess.. I haven't finished the game yet so I'm not really gonna judge it too harshly but I will say I don't get the hype and I'm pretty far into it, pretty sure I've nearly completed it actually.. The OST is amazing though, definitely my favorite video game OST I've ever heard but that's the only praise I can truly give it atm.

Preliminary scoring I'd give it a solid 5/10 overall, if it weren't for all the horrendous bugs it'd probably be at least an 8/10 though. 

TLDR: Just buy it on console and save yourself the headache.

What initially started as curiosity turned out to be much more than that. I bought NieR: Automata when it was on sale, and I began playing it just to see what it was about. As a new player, I was pleasantly surprised to find out that this game is. Even six years later, this game is one of a kind. I fell in love with the story, played the game to 100% achievement completion (without cheating), and I can honestly say this is one of the best games I've ever played. Regarding achievements, some are difficult to get and can take hours, but if you're dedicated to getting them like I was, you'll be satisfied at the end. 11/10 game by PlatinumGames.
Thanks Yoko Taro

Really cool and fun game. The story is a little trippy especially with how the world is and the lifeforms within and how they behave (Trying not to spoil anything). There are multiple endings (26) though some are random fail states or partially silly endings which you might get a few by accident. This game does not have auto save so you must save manually which has caused some inconvenience (Game crashed which only happened once in all my playtime but set me back about 30 minutes). Also the manual save can put you back a little if you encounter one of the fail state endings by accident. Achievement hunters you can't miss anything so fear not and you can enjoy the game at your own pace either way. 

I put this game off for a few years because I was suffering from depression and the vibe of the world in this game wasn't helping (Maybe a warning to others). Now that I have received treatment this game is very enjoyable and really sparks my imagination (Both scenery and music).
nier: automata is really amazing and impressive

Story of 2B Ends at 20% of the game, just at the start, and that is it. 2B is selling point and has ended so fast, I feel tricked and lied. The game is all the time about 9s boy instead... If you watched trailers of 2B, and got hyped? Then pass on this. Forced drama, lost potential. No co-op.
Ending E was worth the tears

This is my first time playing NieR: Automata on PC. I've played every other port. Once I installed an extra stick of RAM to run mods with, the game took on fresh life. I try to be fair with critics. Not every game is for everyone.  However, if route B tends to drag on a bit long, just play it through. Routes C/D are not as some say the same as Routes A and B with minor differences. They are the continuation of the game, the consequences of all the mayhem from the first part of the game. 

That said, this game combines combat, story, graphics and music to create an atmosphere unlike any found in most modern games. It's not always a technical powerhouse but it doesn't need to be because the Steam community has shown it a lot of love that makes up for some of the downsides. Honestly, it never needed to be a technical marvel before that. That's not my biased opinion. Several million other gamers seem to like it too.

Side quests are your typical kill/fetch quests, but they help establish what counts as right and wrong 10,000 years from now. Though I've always completed side quests as they appear, it's almost better to save some of them until the end because they'll hit harder with context. It wasn't until my second full playthrough (fresh save endings A-E) that I realized how much the side quests hint at or outright reveal about the game world.

The only major downside I've ever experienced from playing NieR: Automata is that it almost always ruins the games that I play directly afterwards. Anyway, if you're on the fence, stop sleeping on this game. Do the thing. :D
Love it!

It's a great game! Not perfect, balancing is a bit all over the place, story and world are decent, it's the execution of the game that's admirable, it respects your time but still puts up a damn good challenge.

I don't get this game. I can't enjoy it. The setting is meh and its world is uninteresting since any interesting bits are diluted to homeopathic levels in an ocean of whatever. The sidequests are just dreadfully boring and uninspired. The map is awfully useless with no shortcut button, 3 button presses required and it always resets to max zoom in and if you've read complaints of people about how lame quest markers are and how they make you just go to the marker with no real investment in the quest... this game tries to solve it by placing fake extra quest markers that force you to search more areas and no active quest marker managemen. Hell, you can't even tell which of the quest in your active quests list is the main mission one.

Combat is messy, repetitive and you need to be defensive and feel underpowered all the time. It just falls short in terrible and obvious ways like doing an air-to-ground slam attack with a huge sword you get no invincibility frames or interrupt enemies' attacks. You can literally slam into a bunch of enemies' stupid flailing punches. I just can't believe this game was made by the same studio that did Bayonetta.

It's a pretty game in a PS3 kind of way, with a lot of attention put into its aesthetics but held back mostly by its engine's awful indirect lighting implementation. Sound is alright with good voice acting and tracks of undeniable quality even if not anything I can enjoy.

[b] NieR:Autotomato [/b] is an excellent [strike] action RPG [/strike] [strike] shoot 'em up [/strike] [strike] hack and slash [/strike] [strike] text-based adventure [/strike] [strike] 2D side scroller [/strike] [strike] walking sim? [/strike] video game.
.....................

This chameleon of an interactive software was made by Platinum Games, so it is safe to say the action portion of this RPG is really darn good. The melee combat is a bit loose and floaty but it's still satisfying enough to play. Healthy amount of weapon selections and movesets, plug-in chips to modify your character stats, support drones and character specific abilities, all of these made available to mix up your gameplay experience. Not to mention the frequent shoot 'em up section, useful for gaining extra exp and is just plain fun.

Character mobility's efficient, functional map and quest tracking. For anyone who's obsessed with "immersive experience", there's an in-universe system that allows you to disable almost all on-screen HUD, a very cool function.  

The boss fights, at least the main story ones are generally fine, except for Hegel due to visibility problem, characters' positioning and the camera controls wrestle with each other, making the whole boss fight not intuitive especially to new players.

In short, the game plays great with minimal flaws.

But I suppose everyone's here for the story.

With confident I can say that it's definitely a video game story.
It's a highly emotionally driven sci-fi character drama, using the tired ol' question of "waht is hooman" and other existentialist ideas seemingly without any interest to re-examine them. What I mean is the sci-fi portion of the narrative is interchangeable, and the so called "philosophical" elements in this game are a bit hit-and-miss, not exactly impressive per se. 

I'm not saying it's all bad, because there are fun ideas worth tinkering with here. Animism, memetic intercultural behaviour, literal boxed emotions, these tragic characters' desperation for sustainable purposes for being alive, some of these are all very fun to watch especially through the machine lifeforms' binary way of thinking. Some of these stories succeeded at analogizing how it feels and how it looks like to deviate from the norm. I can empathize with the depressing and troubled thoughts presented in the game, although not entirely. I also agree that some of the stories in this game are fairly disturbing. 
There are moments of levity here and there, which I highly appreciated. The game's not too grimdark, thank god. But yeah, still many rooms for improvements and expansion for them solid story ideas.

Overall, the game has really great moments, surprisingly relaxing open world vibe, a main story that's not exactly impressive but it is engaging enough and presented well enough for it to be entertaining throughout the whole game. 
The desert area is strangely the most memorable area for me.
I kinda love the machine lifeform's designs. They look like toys with interchangeable body parts that I would love to own.
Such a great and unique collection of soundtracks for sure!

I've had other games screw with me before. And I knew going in that NieR: Automata would. It was kinda hard to avoid people talking about how meta this gets even when I've dodged all the story spoilers just because the game's been out for so long. But I still got a lot of surprises out of this game that I wasn't expecting. I won't spoil any of them for you, but I implore you to get this game, play it to its absolute conclusion, and never once consider giving up. If that sounds like a warning that the game's some kind of insanely difficult Souls-like, don't worry. It isn't. It's not that type of game. The gameplay's fantastic, but the story's the selling point. It's gonna force you to persist in a very different way by the end.

As a game, it's a content-rich, insanely gorgeous open world with a stupidly large amount of gameplay variety. By the time you're done with this, you'll feel like you've played like 15 different genres in one game. And it's all very good, or at the very least, kinda funny. One minute it's a hack-and-slash, then a bullet hell, then a fighting game, a platformer, a puzzler, a picture book, a novel, it goes on. I once thought this was an expansion of what Platinum did with Bayonetta in terms of how much variety it lets its players experience on top of the fantastic fast-paced combat, but man, by the end, I realized how much of an understatement that is. And all that's made even better by the game's absolutely amazing soundtrack, which has a dynamic quality to it that I can't quite properly describe, but you're bound to hear several different versions of a track depending on where you are and what situation you're in, and it's a beautiful touch that serves the aforementioned variety on display.

All of this in service to a story and themes that to some folks might either be the deepest shit they've ever experienced, or the most pretentious. But that always seems to be the two extreme responses you get when you have a game that's trying something different. This certainly does a LOT of things different. And I loved it. For as stereotypically anime as the characters can sometimes get (more so in the English dub than the original Japanese, funnily enough), they do feel genuine. And the questions and dilemmas they're faced with are dealt with in such a way that I feel isn't arrogant enough to actually give some concrete answer to the player, but more so is there to make us ponder on them ourselves.

There ARE some things this game won't tell you outright that you probably ought to know though, so I'll quickly list them out:
- Some side quests become either inaccessible or are failed if you haven't finished them by the time you get to certain parts of the main story, so don't rush.
- There's a few of those you'll have a chance to do again.
- Doing most if not all of them nets you a stupid amount of experience, which you'll need so that you're not underleveled by the game's third act.
- If you do end up finishing the game before completing them, there will be a way to complete them all if you're so inclined.

That's it. Apart from that, there's a lot to find, there's a lot to do, and there's some interesting ways that the game handles buffs, upgrades, and weapons that aren't quite like other third person hack-and-slash/beat-em-up games that I've played before.

I promised no spoilers, so I can't say much more than that. What I will say is that if you're in the middle of playing the game and you're starting to think this game's just 2Booty and philosophy references left and right... well yeah, sure, they're there, especially the 2Booty, but the game's way more than that. Shit gets meta. Too meta. In the best way possible. I'm having a hard time trying to sell this game without basically saying everything about it. It's not going to be some exercise in patience, or that there's some convoluted route you gotta take. You really just... gotta keep playing the game to find out. And remember to save often.

This was a beautiful experience.

nothing about this game is particularly notable. the combat is pedestrian, although there are some nifty boss spectacles littered throughout. other than the conlang, the music isn't particularly interesting- it resorts to the same harmonic tricks ad nauseum. the story, contrary to what some might say, is squarely bog standard. yet i will contend that this is one of the best experiences i've had with gaming. or at least it was, whenever i first played it, in 2018 or so. and despite the fact that i can very easily enumerate this game's flaws (and this is doubly true for nier replicant), yoko taro & crew have an unique touch that leave me wanting more. i think that, if nothing else, is worth noting. the "this game could only work as a game" sentiments are perhaps overstated, but there are some genuinely breathtaking sequences here. not for everyone, and not so revolutionary as consensus would seem to suggest, but a truly resonant game in average packaging.
Superb story, superb characters, combat good and robots eat human.

This is going to be a rant and will have some spoilers

At writing I'm a decent chunk through the third play-through, and still plan to finish.


While a lot of the core game ideas are sound there are so many huge design issues that it is hard to figure out where to start.


1. There are multiple points in the game where you have a very long (20+ minutes) of tedious unskippable fights that lead to a boss that can easily one-shot you (the most notable being the prologue and when doing the hacking tower(s) in the 9s part of the third playthrough). These are terrible one-shots, they occur even at normal difficulty, there is a ton of time spent getting to the fight, and they are not extremely obvious. If you are having one-shot bosses (particuraly at lower difficulties) they should not have 20+ minutes of tedious set-up

2. One-shots are too prevalent at all difficulties. The reason for this is developers hurting themselves. They made healing WAY too easy and fast; this caused all damage that isn't a one-shot to be trivialized as you can pause immediately heal-up with the very cheap healing items or heal with the many plug-in chips that heal. But the solution is not to just make any fight we want to be hard have rampant one-shots from full (even boosted) health, better to not make such insane healing capabilities in the first place


3. This game has probably the WORST open-world in an otherwise ok game. This game screams linear story and mission based game-play and that is when it is at its best in the moderately choreographed fights in missions and not its barren, boring, and lifeless world. And if you say the point is to see that barren world, I can see it in linear missions too.

4. The games non-boss enemy variation is lame. There are different enemies and they do different things, but they are so lame. They are un-fun, samey, and particularly in the shitty open-world way too easy (except when you get randomly grabbed and one-shot). The one saving grace here is that with some TERRIBLE exceptions as mentioned in point 1, you can just ignore and run past most of them

5.  Another enemy issue is health is way too inconsistent, many enemies and even bosses (at least on normal and hard) will sometimes have way too much or too little health, this is an issue i'll bring up with damage too but the variance is just too high some are total sponges that do trivial damage (especially when as mentioned before healing is very easily accessible) and some are complete glass cannons that die in literally under 4 attacks (this for main bosses that are dead before they even finish their starting dialogue)


There many more complaints I probably don't remember right now (not like anyone will actually get this far/read this), but overall while the game is fine the many major oversights particularly relative to the amount of praise I've heard from this game makes this a clear negative for me even if I finish(ed) it.

A beautiful and engaging game that had me hooked within the first hour. Game play combines action oriented combat, RPG leveling mechanics, and bullet hell shooter sections. It sounds like a goofy combination on paper, but this game manages to pull everything together in a really compelling way.

The combat system is fluid and easy to approach, making you quickly feel like a total bad ass as you cleave through hoards of enemies and perform flashy maneuvers like air juggling. Combat isn't shallow though. You have plenty of options to customize your weapons, support programs, and chip load outs to suit your preferred style and challenge your abilities further.

The story is where this game truly shines for me. The plot is interesting, even if it isn't the longest or most in depth of it's kind. It is the kind of story that made me stop and think though. Events stuck with me and occupied my thoughts for days after playing through them. It's so easy to empathize with not only your main playable characters, but a whole host of interesting folks that you meet along the way. I found myself really cheering for so many different people, even when their interests seemed to directly oppose my own.

The soundtrack is beautiful! Especially certain vocal tracks that accompanied dramatic boss fights and big moments in the game. The sound design was solid. I played through the game with Japanese dialogue and the voice acting was on point. I haven't played with the English dialogue, but I would guess they provide similarly compelling performances.

It took me about 65 hours to complete every achievement in the game, but you can get all of the story and the fun challenges done in half of that time.

NieR: Automata is truly one of the most unique games I've ever played, and easily one of the best. It's a post-apocalyptic  open world RPG crossed with side scrolling platforming and bullet hell shooter sequences. A formula that may sound off putting at first, but somehow actually works very well. 

STORY: The story is gripping and engaging, with a splash of humor mixed with extremely dark themes. It may not be the greatest story ever told, but it definitely made me stop and think at times due to it's highly philosophical approach. It also knows how to suck the player into the world and makes for some truly nail biting story elements. 

COMBAT: This is where NieR shines in my opinion. The combat system is fast paced and very fluid. At no point did I ever get frustrated with the controls. Everything about combat felt very tight and feels similar to games like Devil May Cry, God of War, and Monster Hunter at their best. Having the ability to quick swap your pods/loadouts and the ease of accessing your heals and buffs made it all the better.

LEVELING: The leveling system is mostly what you would expect. Kill stuff, get xp, level up. The leveling feels similar to a Final Fantasy game, where you don't get any skills points or attributes to spend. However, what sets it apart from other RPG systems is the ability to install new programs or "chips" into 2B's hard drive. This is essentially how the skill system works. Find or purchase new programs and install them to your liking. You can re-spec your chips at any time and can have multiple hard drive configurations. You can also spend money to add more memory to her drive to get the most out of the available skills. There is also a system of combining chips to upgrade them. I really enjoyed everything about the chip system. Just don't remove 2B's OS chip. Just... don't.

EXPLORATION: The map is an open world environment, as previously stated, but it's not really THAT big. It's just the right amount of sandbox where it feels alive and robust without trying to be too ambitious. There is a decent amount of running from point A to B due to the large amount of fetch quests, but eventually you will unlock a teleportation system for your fast traveling needs. I suppose the worst aspect of the open world are those typical invisible barriers that exist in many games. It may LOOK like you can double jump and mid-air sprint over that fence, but nah. The game doesn't want you to go that way. I have never cared for that type of restriction in video games and it is just as annoying as ever in this game.

GRAPHICS/AESTHETIC: Now I'm not a graphics nut. I don't get upset about having to lock my game to 30 or 40 FPS and I don't care for all of the graphical nuance that most techies strive for.  After all, I did play this on a Steam Deck. That being said, the game is absolutely gorgeous. Even with mid graphics at 800p, it looked amazing on the handheld. The environments are varied enough and are beautiful to admire. Like I said in the Exploration part, there is a lot of running around in this game. But the stunning detail of the environments, as well as 2B being easy on the eyes, make it a pleasure to endure. I don't want to list all of the different settings since I don't want to spoil anything, but there are some very clever and original parts to the open world map. 

STABILITY: I played the entire game on Steam Deck and after getting the graphics settings right, I experienced zero issues. No stuttering, lagging, crashing, or anything like that. There was the occasional graphical glitch, but overall it felt very polished.

MUSIC: I have been listening to the soundtrack to this game for years before ever playing it. It was recommended to me on youtube and I have loved it ever since. I actually used this soundtrack for Rogue Legacy and Deadcells by muting the game's music and playing this in the background instead. Why would I do this? Because it is a masterpiece. The vocal arrangements (ESPECIALLY during certain boss fights) compliments the highly emotional orchestral music perfectly. Is there a ton of hype around the soundtrack to this game? Yes. Is it well deserved? Absolutely.

REPLAY VALUE: At 28 hours of playtime, I've completed the first ending. You could complete it much more quickly, probably 15 hours or less if you really wanted to, but I let myself get immersed in the world and wanted to do as many quests as I could. And while I plan on taking a break from it for a bit, I am absolutely ready to dive back in and see what is different in my second play through. Now how does that rate in terms of replayability? Well, after finishing the game, I still have a strong desire to jump right back in and start up that opening sequence again. So I would say it's pretty good, but this is honestly a difficult category for me to accurately judge since I've only beat it once.

CONCLUSION: Overall this is an amazing game, very close to a 10/10 experience with some very minor annoyances. I would love to explore more of this world and hope there are more of these games planned for the future. The storytelling, characters, and music all feel very avant-garde and fresh while still maintaining a sense of familiarity.

As of writing this review, I am pained to say that I didn't complete this absolute masterpiece to 100% (yet).

     NieR: Automata is the second game of the NieR series which itself originates as a spin-off of a certain ending of the first Drakengard game that I unfortunately, didn't play myself. 
All of these games are directed by a (sick) man called Yoko Taro, who basically is responsible for everything that makes NieR: Automata special, from its genre switch to its story; and let me tell you, the story is some good effing sh*t.
    The original synopsis is pretty simple; Aliens created Machine Lifeforms to invade the Earth, to defend itself, mankind sent Androids to fight them and retreated to the Moon. We play as Model 2 class B, 2B, a YoRHa android, fighting against machines of all kind. Through the different endings and well written side quests of the game, you'll learn to appreciate and love an outrageous amount of characters and; assuming you have a functioning heart, you'll love all of the twists the game has to offer.

     But however close to perfection NieR: Automata is, nothing is perfect in the end, there are a few minus points in my opinion that I have to point out;
 - Genre switch: NieR: Automata often switches genre, in fact, the game intro is pretty much a Space Invader game. While it is not ultimately bad, I've seen people get scared by it and even I happened to be pretty mad on a few (rare) occasions when I had to play almost entirely different games for the sake of the story.
 - Map: While most of it is absolutely fine and the areas are pretty enjoyable to look at, accompanied by some of the best OSTs in the entirety of the video game industry, some places are extremely confusing to get at, I'm looking at you, desert. Some quests will ask you to go through some weird passages that you never thought would be possible to go through, I felt like some places were unclear if you could get to it or not and ended up missing things on my first playthrough on PS4.
 - Additional infos are lost between medias: As I said previously, NieR is a spin-off of Drakengard and Automata is the second game of the NieR series, I've see numbers of people be extremely confused at wtf happened before the events of the game and oh how much I'd love to tell you that you JUST have to play NieR: Replicant, but no. For some obscure reasons, a LOT of infos are hidden behind absolutely unrelated stuff, one of the most important characters in the game's story details are hidden behind a, drums rolls, STAGE PLAY, another pretty interesting story that explains quite a lot about the past of YoRHa is also hidden behind another stage play, hell, there's even canon informations in a gacha mobile game. All of this can make searching for new informations a pain, though there's very good videos on YouTube and such.

    NieR: Automata is still my favorite game of all time, I can't explain how much I love it and the NieR series as a whole, it's not just a game, it's a whole experience of life, a masterpiece of art. 
The story is just absolutely amazing, the OSTs, as stated previously, are the bests I've ever heard, with only Persona able to kind of compete with it and I don't even remember any bad side quest (except the racing one, this one shouldn't even exist).

Please, play NieR.

It's a fine game with an original story concept, but it is WAY overhyped. You will enjoy it, for sure. But the story isn't some super incredible crazy ascendant thing, it's just fine. Everyone goes on and on about how insane the story and music are, but both are about a 7 or 8 out of 10, honestly. If I were you, I'd wait til a sale brings the price down to really low like I did. I think $20 or less is fair.

Another thing that is misinformation: everyone talks about how you have to beat the game tons of times to get the story. No, you have to beat it once. The game "ends" after about 10-15 hours but it's obvious it's not over and they rewind to see the game from a different character, which is not unheard of in games or movies. Also it does not delete your progress, you keep everything as if it was a "new game+" automatically. So yes you are seeing the same story but it's different. Then the game continues normally after that. In other words you play through the entire story once. You do not have to play a 50 hour game 3 times, which is how everyone talks about game. It's not true. This rumor alone stopped several people including myself from initially playing the game. It's just one 40-50 hour game, that's it. If you want to see all the endings, much like any other game just make several different save slots and reload and try a different thing. It's not a crazy slog. I have more hours on this game than listed because I tend to leave my games on pause when I go do my chores, so my real time is more like 40ish hours. That's enough to beat it.

THIS GAME IS ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!

Everything from the lore, main story and characters is interesting and really well done, the soundtrack is just beautiful, with some twists to better fit your current situation.
Gameplay wise, the game does a great job too, with enough types of weapons and enemies to keep you from getting bored of slaying everything in your way the same way over and over again. 
Bear in mind that in order to see the "true ending" you will need to play three campaigns, totally worth it BTW. The first one with 2B, followed by the same one with a few more cutscenes and explanations, as 9S. The third playthrough is the continuation of the other two, where you get to play with another character (which I won't spoil here).

To finish it, a quick tip to those who decided to try the game: for lore reasons, you can't save your progress during the prologue so if you die you'll need to replay it all, save yourself some time and play it on easy mode (at least the final boss, the other parts do not put much of a challenge) and change back to normal once you are able to save.

NieR:Automata is a great game with a heartwrenching story and fun, diverse combat that I greatly enjoyed and got a lot out of. It's a game that doesn't feel like it needs to spell everything out for you, or even really make things all that clear, and while I was fine with that, it did make me feel at times like there were things going on in the background of the story that I wasn't fully grasping. Even with that air of mystery, it's very much worth experiencing for yourself, though in retrospect I feel like I should have played Replicant first, given what I know now.

Given its post-apocalyptic setting, the world is wide open and sparsely populated, though I found the level design absolutely gorgeous throughout. There's a central hub area that you'll spend a lot of time in, with several other bespoke areas branching off from it that provide diversity in level design and setting. In those areas in particular, there are numerous points in the game where you'll be working with a fixed camera angle, either from the side or top-down, which can be disorienting at first as you get used to reading the minimap. Combat is basically hack-and-slash, with some customizability coming from your weapon selection and upgrades you can buy, with some bullet hell elements as well, though neither of these went too crazy for someone who generally doesn't enjoy either genre. And, if you're particularly bad at the combat, there are a lot of upgrades that allow you to quickly regenerate health so you don't have to worry so much about not getting hit.

Story-wise, there's a lot to unpack. The core narrative is straightforward for the most part, but the deeper you go, the more twists and turns it takes, and the more it hints at larger themes and goings-on that aren't immediately apparent and are somewhat left to the player to interpret or understand themselves. Vaguely, you'll have to play through the main game what seems to be multiple times, but these "additional" playthroughs are necessary for getting the full scope of the story, and you'll know when you've seen the game's true ending when you get there. The story, even with its gimmicky structure, is incredibly engrossing, and strongly endears you to pretty much every major character in the game by the end, though I did feel a little bit like the story was tragedy after tragedy after tragedy, and it fatigued me a little by the time I was done.

Regarding some of those background elements - I played Automata first because people say the gameplay is more polished and it's the easier of the two NieR games to get into if you haven't played them. After playing Automata, though, I feel like if you're interested in the story, it might be better to play Replicant first. It seems like people who have the full picture of the two games invariably recommend Replicant first, and only suggest Automata first if the gameplay is more important to you. I have yet to play Replicant, but there are several side-story beats in Automata that treat it as suggested background knowledge, and obviously the game both came out first and takes place earlier (much, MUCH earlier, for the record), so knowing now that I enjoyed Automata and want more, I kind of wish I'd just played Replicant first, and experienced the two games the way they were released.

Ultimately, Automata is a fantastic game, whether you treat it as a standalone experience or intend to play Replicant with it. Great characters, great story, great gameplay, absolutely worth it, even if it's never on sale. Put it on sale more, Square Enix! Come on!

In brief, although with some flaws, this game is without doubt a masterpiece and worth its price. If you're hesitating now, just have a try.
The full comment is here, for those who never played this game before, I guarantee this comment contains nothing that may cause spoiler. So just continue reading at ease.
First, you may wonder where I knew this game and what made me buy it. I know many people are just for 2B (hah). But I'm not. I do that after listened to The Weight of the World (English version) by MONACA, ED of this game by coincidence. That song is pretty good, one of the best I've ever heard. I believe if a game's OST is in high quality, so do this game itself. Then I bought it.
So, this game provides nice and well-designed background music. Although, maybe because its ED is so astonishing, or just because my personal preference (I think Civilization's and Ori's are the best), I have to say the remaining soundtrack is not as amazing as The Weight of the World. But without doubt, its soundtrack is still surely worth a special praise here.
More, the voice of characters, is natural, vivid, and emotional. Pretty nice.
And for characters, their models and animation... What? Don't you know thousands of people buy this game are just for 2B, a character in this game? Maybe that's one of the most successful parts of this game! (laugh)
Graphics quality... Hmm... Not top-level, but still OK.
Finally, game's story... Oh, best in my mind. I think the most valuable part of this game, is its story.
I can even say, it's the story, expressed by video game, maybe the most appropriate medium, make the game, the "medium" unforgettable, moving, provoking, and successful.
Originally, I left hundreds of words there, trying to describe something about this. But finally I found that's difficult. This meticulously-designed story just beyond my words.
I couldn't give you more help about the story itself there, except for one thing, if you are those who never play NieR: Automata before:
IF YOU DO WANT TO PLAY THIS GAME, DO NOT BE CURIOUS, NEVER BROWSE ANYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME'S STORY UNTIL YOU COMPLETE THIS GAME WITH ENDING E.
THIS GAME HEAVILY RELIES ON ITS UNIQUE STORY. ANY SPOILER WILL BRING DISASTER TO YOUR GAMING EXPERIENCE.
OK, and then, let's talk about the flaws.
I don't have a controller. It's terrible to play this game with keyboard. You have to use direction keys to adjust the camera. Wait, where's my mouse? Aha, mouse is "banned", I've tried to bind two attack keys ('/' and '\') to the mouse but failed. If you stick to control the camera by mouse, your right hand has to move between keyboard and mouse frequently. That's thrilling.
Worse, in some scenes, the camera angle will be locked in an inappropriate position, making the battle or travel weird and uncomfortable.
And I guess many people prefer playing a new game under normal difficulty at first, to get the best gaming experience. It often works well, but for this game, that's not true. I wonder how many new players using keyboard under normal mode can complete the prologue in one go. It's approximately impossible to reach the first checkpoint under normal mode if you don't know how to evade.
Worse, this game doesn't provide a proper tutorial about how to evade.
If you find that's too difficult in your first hour, try to change the difficulty to easy, and turn it back when you reach the first checkpoint. You can change it in settings at any time.
I'm sure the attack animation of characters is cool, but sometimes, the battle itself is tedious.
The map is f**king terrible. It can provide you "everything" except your target location. Can't believe people are still using this brainf**king map in 11945 AD. (laugh) That sometimes makes the travel annoying and boring.
So, that's all.

[h1] 2B grinding endings, or not 2B grinding endings [/h1]

It's hard to recommend this game, in the same way that it's hard to recommend Evangelion to someone. You need to have "[b]that taste[/b]" for overwhelming sadness, melancholy and helplessness. Try at your own risk.

The game builds up slowly and demands way too much time from the player: the game is linear, it took me some [b]14 hours[/b] to get to the "good stuff". At that point, it starts getting better. I had a good laugh at ending E, but that is the problem: ending E only comes, as you may guess, after completing endings A, B, C and D and all the grinding that that entails.

The game designers will have the player put up with lots of bull$1t in the name of narrative and creative freedom. Because the progression is quite linear, the player doesn't really have that many options, which, combined with the depressing story, adds to the feeling of inevitability of it all.

The [b]variety of game modes[/b] and combination with platformers, arcade and small puzzles is good, but it's 2023 and there are many games out there that do it better. The play with [b]different cameras[/b] is risky, works out more often than not, but sometimes it can get [b]very[/b] annoying.

Also, if you are looking for a difficult game, there are plenty of better options out there as well.

To make things worse, this is not a good PC port. Many players use mods to make the game playable. The [b]performance[/b] is barely OK, only because my hardware is 5 years newer than the game. The graphics are not that good that would justify it. When the combat gets demanding, you can't afford to have as many frame drops as this game has... and [b]crashes[/b] (see the forums). I don't have to explain to you, how much a game crash kills the vibe.

The combat in this game is awesome, with engaging action system that takes time to master. The story is also phenomenal, keeping me gripped from start to finish with well-developed characters and an enthralling plot.

The open world isn't the biggest I've seen, but it has an amazing dystopian feel that pulls you into its unique atmosphere. This is easily one of my favorite story-driven games, thanks to Yoko Taro's excellent writing and direction. He has once again impressed me with his creative vision and ability to craft compelling, emotionally resonant stories.

One note - if you plan on playing this game, I highly recommend using a controller or playing on console. The keyboard and mouse controls work, but the combat really shines when using an analog stick and action buttons. The controller layout feels much more natural and responsive.

Overall, an excellent game with stunning visuals, memorable characters, and a deeply fascinating world that kept me engaged from start to finish. Yoko Taro's storytelling and creative imagination are on full display here. I would highly recommend this game for any fan of great stories and memorable characters wrapped up in memorable gameplay.

NieR:Automata is a heartbreaking experience. It's like watching a magic show, everytime you dwell deeper into the game, a newer sense of awe emerges. It plays with your emotion, provoking contemplation on your sense of purpose in this world. It starts with "okay this is a cool hack'n'slash" to "why do I exist?". I would give the story itself a B+ (your typical sad, sci-fi Seinen manga plot); but the way the game presents itself through the characters development, playthrough(s), how the story affects your game UI, level design, beautiful soundtrack, and [SPOILERS] meta-game with the game devs and other players: it's just something I've never seen before. I would rank this game as my top 3 story-driven action RPG, maybe the best ever. Don't wait for discount, it will be the most memorable 20-30 hour (50++ if you're a completionist) audio-visual experience in your life.

NieR:Automata is an incredible game. Just one playthrough absolutely shook me to the core and really made me start to think about life. The fact that this game can make you feel such specific feelings and emotions is really impressive and just absolutely incredible. The reviews that say the game doesn't run well are (at least for me) outdated as I got 60 fps or around it most of the time, with maybe the occasional bit of lag. Also, to people that may not be used to this style of genre or game, I get it and I found it to actually be very easy to adjust to considering I don't normally play these kinds of games.
    One of my favorite parts by far about NieR:Automata is the progression. It took me roughly 20 hours to beat, but you can take much more or less time than that. The game is always introducing new content if you are rushing through the story, but you can also discover much of it on your own as well. The game is decently open world-y and that allows you to do a lot of things, including side quests.
    The plot of this game is insane. Sometimes I felt I was so into the game that it was as if reality had escaped, and I was the character I was playing. As if the game had plucked me from my chair and through me into my monitor. There's so many different ways you can play the game as well, with all of the characters, weapons, and other factors, there's a lot you can do in a game that really isn't that big. It's also very emotional.
   The last point I'm going to make here is how much of the game you can personalize. Of course, not everything in this game can be controlled by you, but a surprising amount is. You can play with many different styles using the characters, and of course you can customize how some of them work with the chips, weapons, and all of the different attacks you can do.
    (Summary) NieR:Automata is an incredible game certainly worth the money, even if you don't find yourself interested in this style of game. It's emotional, fun, and a great story which you will (probably) enjoy to the fullest. Also, 2B is incredible. Overall, probably a 9.8/10 game. What a work of art.

One quick edit: I use a laptop with a 10th gen i7, 3050 laptop gpu, and 16 gb ram. I'm just clarifying that because with those specs the game ran well.

Has a nice, deep and sad story, with an amazing soundtrack. Yoko Taro makes the most of the video game format to tell the story which wouldn't translate as well in other mediums. 

The game runs well and the world has beautiful graphics making the story and game experience even better.

I cannot recommend this game to any person who values their own time. (Which I clearly do not)

the first half (2B's segment) is great.
It introduces you to the world, the characters, and the story starts rolling.

Blah, blah, blah Insert spoilers here.

so you finish this segment, then for whatever reason they thought it'd be a great idea to make you do everything again but as 9S (one of the least likeable characters I've ever come across) 9S also has a completely different play style which in my humble opinion is a pile of shit and explains why he was so useless before.

This feels like nothing short of a waste of fucking time, padding out the game with not only rehashed content, but literally forcing you to play the game again with less enjoyable gameplay in order to experience A2's story.

Then you get to A2's story after a gruelling button mash session that has you use up all of your healing supplies, only to discover that there is absolutely no opportunity to replenish them for some of the hardest battles of the game, even after reaching A2's story.

It honestly feels like such an oversight that I am inclined to suggest that the developers failed to play-test the second half of the game sequentially. It can literally soft-lock you in several areas of the game.

I get the impression that most die-hard fans of this game are weaboos that care for nothing other than drooling at their character's ass, regardless of how repetitive and broken the gameplay is, and those very same people can actually relate to 9S because of how annoying and physically weak he is.

It's honestly so disappointing because the first half of the game felt so unique and flowed so well. Based on my experience of this game, and the claims that NieR: Replicant's gameplay is somehow WORSE, I will not be playing it.

Overall, if it looks interesting to you, get it as cheap as possible, play 2B's story, and then ditch the rest.

NieR Automata has left a lasting impression on me and earned the spot among my favourite games of all time. 

The game's combat system is great. It combines hack and slash elements alongside bullet hell mechanics, which keep the gameplay feeling fresh and never really repetitive. It manages to seamlessly incorporate gameplay into the very fabric of its world, somewhat hard to describe if you haven't played the game yourself. This attention to detail ensures that every element of gameplay is integrated with the actual canon of the world for the most part, rooting the player into the world of NieR. This is something that I haven't yet seen done before in a narrative (J)RPG, and I quickly became a fan of the detail woven into the world of NieR Automata.

The open world is breathtaking visually, although it can feel somewhat empty at times. When combined with the game's exceptional soundtrack (one of the best OSTs I've heard) exploring the world is very captivating and relaxing. Even the side quests, while simple, are meaningful, and provide context to the game's lore and usually have fun interactions between the multitude of characters and the main cast.

One thing that seriously sets NieR Automata apart from other RPGs I've played before is the deep philosophical themes it explores. Concepts such as existentialism, nihilism, and general philosophy are interwoven into the game's story and are thought provoking, they give the players the freedom to interpret the story and meaning behind it in their own way which in my experience is uncommon in games. The themes impacted me deeply, leaving me with much to ponder long after I finished playing.

The story itself is also captivating, and I was eager to keep playing to find out what happened next. The final ending of the game was particularly powerful and emotional, leaving me in tears during the credits - The first game that has ever made me cry.

After playing NieR Replicant, I have an even greater appreciation for NieR Automata, as the events that take place in the former add another layer of meaning to the latter. So if anything I've said about the game seems remotely appealing to you, I encourage you to give it a try, because I was unsure if this was the game for me. 

Thank you, Yoko Taro, for creating such an exceptional game.

So i bought this game years ago played a few hours and forgot about it because my laptop back then could barely run it. Now that i have better PC i remembered this game and wanted to give it another try but it was just awful experience. Camera is static speed so even if you drag mouse fast it will still turn around at the same speed. If you customize speed in settings it's either fast or slow since the camera is essentially what you get with an analog stick on a controller. Dodging is double tap of direction key and you can't set a key for dodging. This personally just feels super bad and dodging didn't register like half of the time i double tapped(in games with designated dodge key like Dark Souls or Nioh i have no problem dodging). Another thing is some enemies can essentially stun lock you in their combo such as the excavators in the initial intro map and when i got to fight 2 of them on a bridge they stun lock me with a single attack because dodging didn't register and i died which makes the game just play ending credits saying you failed to save the planet or whatever and you're done and you have to start a new savefile and replay whole intro map from the beginning through all the autoscrolling sequences which i just didn't feel like doing again. Even if the game story might be good as people say i didn't get to experience it simply because of the awful controls which make me just not want to bother with the game. With a controller i assume the experience would be better but with keyboard and mouse personally it just feels super clunky

First game I played by PlatinumGames (and Yoko Taro, very cool). Had trouble figuring it out at first, ended up doing just fine later, but I'd still recommend to those deep enough in the reviews here who haven't already played to play it with a controller instead of a keyboard, because there's certain actions (like dodging) that don't have a dedicated button on keyboard, and require you to double-tap a WASD key, so playing on keyboard will make late-game combat (especially with the DLCs) harder. 

As for the story, it has to be experienced blind. It just has to, to give you the full effect. As of this review I have not played the original NieR or its Replicant remake, but I probably will at some point in the future just to get the fully complete picture (not required to understand the story, but there's certain details that I imagine will be clearer with them in mind). 

It feels really good to have played a game that elicited such powerful reactions in me (not those ones, at least not solely) after thinking I'd become desensitized to certain tropes and such in games. Big mcthankies from mcspankies to the madman who rolled around on the floor to advertise T-shirts, as well as the army of programmers, artists, musicians, and other individuals who worked to create this inspiring and devastating work. 

Glory to Moosekind. 

P.S. Please lock that one Resistance member in a box and ship her to wherever Abu Dhabi became. 
You will know who I'm talking about.

I'm going to be honest, I was really torn on whether to recommend this game or not, for a few reasons. However, I found that after getting to the final credit scene, the good does outweigh the bad, but not by much.

The graphics aren't incredible, but the art-style is great. The areas, enemy and character design are all topnotch and unique. The combat is fun with lots of varying styles added to the mix to keep things fresh. The story and its message are great, but it did lose me a bunch of times, which I'll get on to a bit later. The RPG system is great, being able to unlock, upgrade and install different chips to upgrade your character was a really inventive way to work the upgrade system. Of course, there's levelling too. The voice acting is great (played in English), there wasn't a point where any of the lines fell flat, was really well executed. Finally, the best part though, is the music, damn, the soundtrack really slaps! Some of the best video game music I've heard in a long time, super stylised which I loved. All of these combined make for a great experience from start to finish.

However, this game does have some really glaring flaws, which were more design choices, but they really didn't gel with me at all. First of all, which I think is its biggest blunder, is having to play through the first section of the game again, to get to the part that is actually really good. Personally, I felt the first section of the game was really bland, so having to play to again to get to the good stuff was an absolute chore and I can see why many players stop at this point. People argue that it makes the scenes later on hit harder, but I really disagree, if anything, the frustration from having to play the first section again really takes away your flow and interest in the story as you feel its not respecting your time.

Next, the design choice not to implement auto-save. I know this may seem small, but in a game with such a heavy story and difficult combat, having to replay story sections because you died 20 minutes after a save point was available really takes away from the impact of those sections you have to play again. As you'll be playing through them again, frustrated and disinterested, rather than engaged.

Finally, the game doesn't scale with you if you're underleveled. This is particularly annoying when the game is hard enough as it is, but the side-quests to get yourself leveled are countless boring fetch quests or you just need to start grinding enemies. There were many times I had to swap to Easy (stupid, I know) so I could get past a poorly designed boss fight (screw you in particular Hegel!) to progress the story, again reducing your engagement.

These three major issues alone really hampered my experience with this game, however, only having three is an achievement on its own. 

For anyone playing the game for the first time, do all of the side-quests on the first section of the game, you will be thankful you did. Level your chosen weapon as soon as you can and make sure to use the EXP boost chip whenever you can. Also, don't expect just a hack and slash, there is a lot more variety in combat and gameplay than that. Finally, yes, the second playthrough of the first section of the game sucks, but the people posting online aren't lying, it is really worth it getting to the final part of the game.

Overall, I had a good time with this game. It's a great game, but its not a masterpiece in my opinion.
