Hey dear internet. May I ask you a question. What is the answer to the equation of ''A Tarantino wannabe director + a shitty game developer that hasn't developed in ten years + a brain dead community that didn't play the game because of looking at the character's bum'' ? Yep. I just don't get you people. Terrible level and mission design, ok story but you literally have to play it twice to ''understand'' it, not only game has just a single type of enemy but also insufficient gameplay. And some of you retards say ''If Kojima had his name on this game, it would be considered to be the best game ever.'' Yeah bro sure why not XD. A linear game that only has basic mechanics of Bayonetta to be the best game (and its not even improving as the game progress. Oh it also has some kind of bullet hell shit and 2D kind of stuff that coming out of nowhere every fucking 5 mins. Instead of make the game interesting and fun to play, it irritates me. In addition, game also has some kind of ''Philosophy'' that is in the level of Socrates XD. Dont get me wrong i am into that shit. I could cry and ended up just staring to ceiling and question my existence. I did at some point in my life to be honest. But in a game this level of shitness, then trying to be SOMA, Silent Hill 2 or Spec Ops: The Line, its just ridicilous. Game cant even decide whether to leave breadcrumbs for you or just tell the straight fuck up to your face what the fuck its about. Being clich√©, doesnt mean good or bad. But if you played or watched or read thing and you are not 10 years old, you'd guess every step on this game. The game gives us facts, we accept them as true, and then game subverts them as if they are a reveal, when in reality we already knew that and now we're just confused.By the time we get to the desert, we are fighting robots who are going ''I am scared!'' and ''Go away! Please!'' and as we kill them 9S goes '' Do you think they understand concept of being scared?'' and also points that they wear clothes. Then they also see they having ''sex'' and one of them rocking a baby. Later on, our lovely characters discuss it: ''Hey 2B, why do these machines do this thing or do that'' boo hoo and etcetera, 2B will go ''Emotions are forbidden'' like every fucking shitty dandere or kuudere character. Like i said, if you are not 10 years old you would say ''Is this game seriously going to drag this 'what does it mean to be alive' plot-point out for whole game?'' Spoiler alert.. yep. PC port is awful, too. I literally had to download a mod to fix these fucked up controls. Soundtrack is actually one of few thing that this game do. And thats it. It has been in my mind to play this game since the entire internet full of 2B fan made things and many games that  had nier stuff in it. Not even mentioning nier fans. I expected this game to be something like my second Ori but ended up to be an ubisoft game. My disappointment is immeasurable about this game. My advice to PlatinumGames, just stay in Bayonetta. But looking back to Bayonetta 3, maybe dont do that too. And other advice to Toko Yaro, quit directing, you are not cool or mysterious. You are just a creep that is eager to make us stare, based on cutscenes, right up to sexy women's skirts. Its so grisly everyone is fine with that. Remember when i said ''brain dead community'' yep thats it. This weird voyeurism sits around 2B like an audience of jeering men, some kind of feeling. I usually dont mind this kind of stuff, in fact i have a porn game in my main account, but this is too much. I have never felt this wtih any other gaming character. I do appreciate that characters can be eye candy and i do encourage it. And I am not sjw or any kind of thing but there is someting so intrinsically creepy about how the game constantly frames 2B. Everything about 2B is just the Thermian Argument incarnate, really. for example, using ''Self Destruct'' option causes a huge AOE explosion, which can be useful, but more serves as a way to remove 2B's skirt. But when you ''Self Destruct'' 9S, he'll still wear shorts. Why? Or as you are walking around the world, the camera always puls itself slowly back and points upwards slightly, angling from below up into her skirt, so you can see constant slips of her ass. i feel like it's sat next to me throughout my entire playthrogh, a hand on my shoulder and a creepy voice in my ear going ''Hey lets look up her skirt, shall we'' zzz. She has been so explicitly designed for the activation of neurons in monkey brains. I dont know dude. I didn't get very far because it has the worst in-game camera I have ever dealt with, no locking onto enemies or any sort of control, and half the time what you're fighting won't even stay on screen. It plays weirdly like an arcade shooter but with no additional control to account for the 3d nature of the game, which means you're usually just shooting or stabbing blindly hoping to hit something. It's disappointing because I really wanted to see the story, but the gameplay is INFURIATING.

The game play is excellent but I was utterly surprised by the existentialist, philosophical story that asks the player to ponder questions about existence, consciousness, religion, race, and ethics in extremely clever fashion. The combat is top notch and rewards grinding for power ups. The game is packaged immersively throughout in a way I've never experienced before. This is gaming as literature, as art, all while being incredibly fun. Truly a masterpiece effort in the genre.

DO NOT BUY THE PC VERSION OF THIS GAME. 

The game itself, is actually pretty fun and enjoyable....when it works. But getting it to work is a pain. Every single time I load the game it resets ALL settings to the default values. Which is a huge problem because you have to change a lot of settings to get the game to work properly, Every time I boot up the game I have to spend 15 minutes navigating the multiple options screen to get everything back to the settings I wanted.

The biggest issue of these is the resolution. For whatever reason I cannot comprehend, the game be default will load the LOWEST resolution possible on launch, which is SO BAD that you can't even read the text on the menus to change it. I had to find a Youtube video of someone else's playthrough, where they go into the options screen, so I could discern what buttons to press to make my resolution something readable, And I had to memorize this sequence of button presses because the settings reset EVERY SINGLE TIME.

If you google "Nier settings reset" you'll find that this is a common problem with the game, You'll also find multiple "workarounds" posted around the web, none of which have worked for me. How such a well known problem has gone unaddressed is beyond me. Despite showing 140 played at the time of this review, I am sad to say that I am not even 1/3rd of the way through the game, as much of my time has been spent trying to resolve these technical issues, and constantly redoing my settings, rather than enjoying the game.

Game 82 of my backlog.

**Spoiler free**

+ Combat system is easy to learn, somewhat difficult to master
+ Fun hacking minigame
+ Great voice acting
+ Incredible soundtrack
+ Interesting story
+ Great variation of RPG and Arcade(ish) gameplay
+ Lots of upgrades, collectibles, and side quests
+ A set of difficulties ranging from anything to a casual playthrough to a complete hardcore nightmare
+ Great visuals, so take lots of pictures with F12
+ Loads of endings, with the "main endings" all being obtainable without having to do any questionable side content. Just play through the game, and get the regular endings. Then go back and attempt to get all the optional endings. You aren't going to miss anything



- Hacking minigame gets mildly redundant at times due to how much it's required at certain points in the game.



I have to give props to the English voice actor for 9S (Kyle McCarley).

This is gonna be my first and maybe only negative review for single player game, since I would give negative only to games with outrageous and forced micro transactions. I've been playing this slog of a game for three years, completing first ending playthrough on normal difficulty in 24 hours, plus 47% of insufferable boredom of side quests, and two hours of second main characters "perspective".
  By playing a lot of different games throughout many years you start to see patterns and reasons why game design was made this particular way. Even in bad games you start to enjoy certain positive and well made parts, and excuse developers for mistakes or blemishes when there are clearly an effort and passion put into it, providing at least unique and new experiences to a player.
  There are a lot of bad games,  unfinished games, or frustrating games, and we can like and dislike them for different reasons. This game suffers from most devastating characteristic - bland boredom... which accumulated with a sense of wasting time. That's why I cannot excuse it in anyway. Oh, and a huge disappointment, since it was hyped up by everyone and everywhere.
   Deep and sophisticated story, as claimed by fans, is a shallow joke and cheap melodrama with good voice acting, I even watched some lore videos and footage of other endings to be sure that I am not missing any "deep meanings" of this plot. Let me tell you, most "human" story stuff & somewhat interesting character development is in the novels or other extra content BUT NOT IN THE GAME!!!
   Gameplay hooks you at first with variety of combat and animation but gradually becomes two button mashing attack and dodging left or right by looking at enemies flashing red eyes, in visual epileptic cacophony of explosions where you see nothing. I spent substantial amount of time to unlock all skills and plug in chips configuration builds, it's there but you will opt for most optimized combat build 90% of time anyway since enemies are almost the same (except centipedes and kamikaze drones) AND you wouldn't switch to it often anyway because you cannot do it during combat, PLUS there are like FOUR stages of extremely slowly animated submenus to get through... 
   World building and locations (apart from Amusement park) are so simple, empty and generic, side quests barely provide any context, everything is detached from each other providing no interesting mysteries or narrative or visual storytelling.
   The beloved by fans core idea of this narrative driven RPG is well known topic which was discussed many times and presented way better in classics, or other better contemporary media. Damn even popcorn adaptation of Azimovs books, "I robot" movie was better than this.
   The only good things are music, some bosses, and animation choreography for combat. The rest is just suffering of an experience, especially quantity of UI submenues, occasional camera movement and pc port....

[h1] [i] A Masterpiece [/i] [/h1]
Bought this game almost 2 years ago cause it was on sale and it looked cool and now I finally got to reaching the [E]nd.

The music hits hard from the very beginning; and it fits the location you're in or the activity you're doing like a glove. The game is masterful with the audio, the visuals, the mechanics, and finally, the plot. 

The only way I can describe the experiencing the story is that it's like watching a flower with a myriad petals bloom in an accelerating time lapse: you do not know how long it'll take, you do not know how much faster it can go but the only thing that you do know is that it's a beautiful sight to behold. I don't think I'm capable of elaborating on that without spoiling something because every part of this story, every emotion it evokes, needs to be experienced first hand.

Having played this, I'm raring to try the other games from Yako Taro and of course, watch the anime as I've heard that it offers yet another perspective to the events that unfold within the game.

If you like solo RPG games and can afford it, I wholeheartedly recommend playing this [i] masterpiece [/i] of a game.

I definitely have my problems with this game, but overall, I recommend it. The writing, music, story, characters, combat and design are all great, but the world exploration and progression are.. infuriating. The zones have a lot of areas that look like you should be able to get to/through them, but there are invisible walls EVERYWHERE. What look like doorways and hallways are almost always blocked off. The fact that there's any platforming in this game is confusing because there are VERY few places where you actually can jump to get a chest or traverse zones. As far as my issues with progression goes, I often found myself just aimlessly wandering around trying to figure out where exactly I was supposed to go to move the story forward. Luckily each ending is only a few hours away from the last, at the worst, but it took me about twice as long to get anything done than people without ADHD.

As a whole package, the game is fun. The characters are interesting enough, the voice acting feels coherent and is produced well, too. I also think the random little interactions you stumble upon are charming as hell and promote exploration, but like I said, that aspect is frustrating. I WANT to explore, but there aren't many signs in the world to differentiate where you can and can't go. To put it simply, how you move through the world looks like a PS4 game, but FEELS like a PSP game. What made me stick around was the writing, art/design and the music; the music is REALLY fun! It reminds me of Kingdom Hearts in a lot of places, but also has some more Pokemon-esque bits, both of which have very well produced scores. I plan to play more of this game in the near future. 

Oh, side-note: I found a build that essentially makes me invincible very early on, so the combat was a bit lost on me. It was just hold RB and mash X while running in a circle, while kills, damage and time all heal me. If I DID get hit, I had another plug-in/chip that made me use a healing item automatically. The only time I died was on one of the compactors on the assembly line that kills you instantly.

if you're will to go for the ride it's a thought provoking game. I do recommend playing the first nier game first cause there a bunch off notes and Easter eggs that come from the first game and knowing about that first brings the enjoyment up even more 9/10 I want more.

Before I rave about this game for a minute, the PC port does indeed suck. Please get a mod loader like NAMH and then install FAR and NAIOM to fix graphical and control settings. This game is basically unplayable on K + M without both

With that being said, this game is fucking amazing, and one that you CANNOT understand or get the most out of until you get the E ending after three playthroughs and change where you are left with the hardest choice you will probably make as a gamer. Sci Fi elements are a backdrop to a massive amount of existentialism about what anything even means anymore. All set to a soundtrack that is an infinite well of pure FIRE for any situation you are in

Combat arguably for an action JRPG is nothing special, its a pretty basic hack and slash mechanics wise, but there's plenty there to make combat encounters exciting (well, beyond the fact that you will be punished beyond repair for just blind rushing into combat without the right upgrades and tactics, or in some cases, not even wanting to fight to begin with :) ). Combat is mainly a good backdrop for this insane story. My biggest complaint about combat is moreso when you start route B and your heavy attacks are replaced by hacking that takes you out of the moment to play Cyberspace Enter the Gungeon over and over. Also, gold enemies are an absolute warcrime

This is an absolute must play game even though it rarely, if ever, goes on sale. Very much worth its price

NieR:Automata quickly became one of my favorite games of all time.  It comes with a rich and complex story that really pulls you in deep emotionally and leaves you torn philosophically.  The music is truly amazing and is my all-time favorite, along with Nier Replicant.  

The action is grand and keeps your heart pumping.  The voice acting is superb and the environments are beautiful, even with all the destruction and dark tone.  

My complaints are minor.  The main one that comes to mind are all the invisible walls that prevent you from proceeding through huge visible gaps.  It's annoying, but only an afterthought compared to the overall experience this game presents.  It's a masterpiece in my opinion.  Art and storytelling at it's finest.

The music, setting, graphics and game-play are great. The story is interesting and immersive. I find that the atmosphere of NieR:Automata really immerses you in the world. All and all, I can understand why this game is loved by many.

First off, urgent advice: before attempting to play NieR:Automata on mouse and keyboard, install the Input Overhaul Mod (NAIOM) - the game is NOT playable without it, and I mean it - in some parts of the game it's impossible to do what's needed because of ridiculous controller>mouse mapping. Some other quality of life mods are recommended too - look up the definitive mod guide on Nexus.

Second urgent advice: do not stop playing once you see the end titles for the first time, this is only about half of the story. It's more than worth it to continue until you've obtained endings A-E; it's not just other perspectives later on, it's also literally a continuation of the story.

-------------------------------

On one hand, NieR:Automata really deserves a 9/10, but on the other it deserves at most a 7/10. In the end, I'm giving it an 8/10, and below I'll explain why.

It deserves a 9/10 because in many ways it's an utterly brilliant game. The concept of the world is fascinating, the few main characters are very authentic, and the story (once you get to the >actual< end!) is so powerful that it left me emotional for days. The world design is charming and memorable, despite sub-par graphics in the vanilla version, voice acting is amazing (the Japanese voice-over is hugely recommended), and the soundtrack is otherworldly - even though there aren't too many tracks there, they're SO GOOOD that I didn't want to stop playing the game just because of the music. Combat is fun and well-balanced too, with a satisfying progression curve. Maybe the strongest suit though is that the game is original and surprising in so many ways. I won't give examples here because it's amazing and you have to see it for yourself! But let's just say that there are at least 6 different modes of gameplay, with virtually seamless transitions.

And then we get to the second part - why it deserves a 7/10 at most. It's really down to the fact that I felt compelled to give two pieces of advice at the beginning of the review - part of it is due to it being a terrible port, and part due to questionable design decisions. The game is literally unplayable on mouse & keyboard, which is just unacceptable. Some examples: negative mouse acceleration in 3rd person mode (the faster you move the mouse the slower the camera movement), and broken aiming in side-scrolling mode (mouse movements cause the crosshairs to jump up or down, but it jumps back to horizontal after each increment). Luckily modders sorted this out (in say 98% - there are still minor issues at some stages).

And by far the most questionable design decision in my view is the decision to split the game into three playthroughs, forcing the player to essentially replay the game with only minor changes and additions after "finishing" the story, in order to get to the actual second part of it, which let's just say is CRUCIAL. Even though at the end of the first playthrough the game tells you "please continue" I wasn't sure if I wanted to or if it was worth it - I looked online and saw some people saying it was worth it, so I did, but also saw plenty of people saying they gave up because of the repetitiveness, which is SUCH A SHAME. After playing through the whole thing and thinking and reading about it a lot, I remain unconvinced that this was necessary - I think the different perspectives and elements of the second playthrough could be integrated into the first, just like different perspectives were integrated at the beginning of the 3rd playthrough. It would avoid alienating many players, and make for a more cohesive and less grindy experience.

After all the experience was so amazing that I couldn't give less than an 8, but I wish I could give more.

Nier: Automata manages to be greater than the sum of all its parts. The combat is satisfying, but pretty bland. The story is a strange hodge-podge of rehashed dystopian tropes and Philosophy 101. The area you'll see is tiny, the quests are annoying, at best. The gameplay is repetitive.

The final ending, though? Brings it all together. I considered putting the game down several times, but was told to keep going until ending E. And here I am, recommending you do the same. It ended up being the most satisfying ending in any game I've played. If you start playing it, keep playing until ending E. It changes the entire game. Honestly, I didn't like the GAME itself all that much, but it still managed to blow my mind. 

There are many games that are art, but Nier manages to leverage the game medium's unique capability for interaction and delivers its art in a way that no other medium could.

Lovely music, beautiful world design, interesting setting/story. Combat can be fun. Yet...

There is an inherent problem with balancing a games difficulty around the use of instant heal potions, especially when they are so plentiful. Normal difficulty is an absolute joke. One of the easiest games you could ever play. A boss might hit you for 20% of your health, but you have 297 healing potions...

Which brings us to difficulty settings. Normal is a joke, but hard mode is an even bigger joke. Hard difficulty just means 90% of everything will one-shot you. An attack that dealt 20% damage before, will now kill you. I don't even want to imagine very hard difficulty. The only way it could be harder is if they made it so you die in real life.

This itself is made more annoying by the fact that you don't always respawn in or anywhere near the boss room. Once I had to run through a cave, wait in an elevator, run through a city, watch 3 cinematics/unskippable dialogue to get back to the point I was at in the boss fight.

And for those of you who like to explore the world, find secrets and the like. The game has a lot of that, but is somewhat held back by the endless amount of invisible walls everywhere.
it's not meaningless, everything is not meaningless....

"Nier: Automata" is a visually stunning and emotionally powerful action RPG developed by Platinum Games and published by Square Enix. The game tells the story of androids 2B, 9S, and A2 as they fight to reclaim a post-apocalyptic world overrun by machines.

One of the most notable aspects of "Nier: Automata" is its seamless blending of multiple genres, from hack-and-slash combat to bullet-hell shoot 'em up sequences. The game's combat is incredibly fluid and satisfying, with a variety of weapons and abilities at the player's disposal. Additionally, the game's open-world structure allows for plenty of exploration and discovery.

But where "Nier: Automata" truly shines is in its narrative and characters. The game's story is a poignant meditation on the nature of humanity, consciousness, and free will, with unexpected twists and turns that keep the player engaged from beginning to end. The characters are equally well-crafted, with each android possessing a distinct personality and backstory that adds depth to the game's overarching themes.

The game's presentation is also noteworthy, with gorgeous graphics and a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack composed by Keiichi Okabe. The game's visuals range from bleak, post-apocalyptic landscapes to neon-drenched cities, all of which are rendered with breathtaking detail.

Overall, "Nier: Automata" is an exceptional game that manages to combine gameplay, storytelling, and presentation in a way that few other games have achieved. Its themes and characters will stay with players long after the credits roll, making it a standout title in the modern gaming landscape.

I don't know if any other game can take this one's spot in my heart. Not gonna lie, this game's gameplay, story, and music are all exquisite, but it's the BGMs that really grab your attention and make you want to play more. 

About the story. I recall playing this game when it was released in 2017. All these years passed, the lore and story of this game remain deeply rooted in my heart. To me, it is more than just a game, so feel free to try it for yourself.

About the optimization, I would say now it is acceptable; back in 2017, when I stated it was buggy. but now you will have an unforgettable experience. The New Nier Automata anime has also been released. I strongly suggest to avoid watching it if you want to play the game first, but it is also on the verge of being a masterpiece. 

Overall, I think Nier Automata is unique and I don't think you'll ever come across anything similar to it in the future. With its masterpiece-level story, combat, and music, I give it a 9.6/10.   

Thank you for taking the time to read my review.

Ingredients:

1 pound ground beef
1/2 onion, chopped
1 clove garlic, minced
1 tablespoon chili powder
1 teaspoon ground cumin
1/2 teaspoon paprika
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
8-10 taco shells
Toppings (such as shredded lettuce, diced tomatoes, shredded cheese, sour cream, and salsa)
Instructions:

Preheat your oven to 350¬∞F (180¬∞C).

In a large skillet, cook the ground beef over medium heat until browned, stirring occasionally.

Add the chopped onion and minced garlic to the skillet and continue to cook for a few minutes, until the onion is soft.

Add the chili powder, cumin, paprika, salt, and black pepper to the skillet, and stir to combine. Cook for another minute or two.

Arrange the taco shells on a baking sheet, and spoon the beef mixture into each shell.

Bake the tacos in the preheated oven for 5-10 minutes, or until the shells are crispy and the filling is heated through.

Serve the tacos with your favorite toppings, such as shredded lettuce, diced tomatoes, shredded cheese, sour cream, and salsa.

This game is AMAZING. One of the best video game I have played.

The soundtrack is one of the best I have heard, I could listen to it for days. The combat is smooth. The art is beautiful. 2B and A2 are best girls. Story is good, some side quests are simply heart-breaking. (I am so sorry, Pascal.)

Some of the things i felt surprising was animal riding, I did not think I would be so glad about being able to ride a moose in a game doing quests. But I really enjoyed that. And 2B riding a boar looked hilarious. And also another thing that i found surprising was the water physics. The clothes get wet when you go into water. I did not expect that, it was so trivial, but felt so good. And Thank you Yoko Taro for letting me buy Achievements in game. I truly do not have the heart to go through some of the evil endings. Especially after knowing what Pascal have went through.

I felt like the few things that could improve was the boss fights. Could be a tad more difficult. And perhaps Day-Night system? Even characters in game questions the existence of nights. (I find that hilarious though).

And thank you, the 8 to 10 people who helped me achieved Ending E. I should have at least known your name, but I was too focused at that time. Thank you.

1. Play this game as spoiler free as possible!
2. In order to experience the story in its entirety DO NOT STOP AFTER THE FIRST ENDING! The story isn't finished until you reach at least the 3rd ending (not including any of the 21 joke endings you can get along the way), and even then I highly recommend doing the 4th and 5th endings as well which just require repeating the final fight of the 3rd end through the chapter select that gets unlocked afterwards.

I made a point of playing Nier Replicant before Automata and, while it took a long time for me to warm up to Automata by comparison, I think this game shines brightest when looking back on it after finishing it. Admittedly the combat in Automata, while complex and good, is not a kind of combat I particularly enjoy, and combined with my confusion regarding the story based on prior knowledge from Replicant I really didn't understand the hype surrounding Automata for quite a while. Trust me when I say that it pays off. The 3rd playthrough had me on the edge of my seat from start to finish and the 5th ending is quite possibly the most moving moment I've felt in gaming, and on paper it doesn't even feel like it should be but in the moment it just pulls you in so masterfully. I'm still not sure which is my favorite between Replicant's charm and impact or Automata's big picture story but between the 2 of them this series is competing with Dark Souls to be my favorite ever, and I think it's winning.

Was really let down after hearing so many good things about it.
Combat is not bad but, it's a hack and slasher that has been done better by many other titles.
The story feels as though the writer picked up an introductory books on philosophy and had the idea that they must make a game about it.
Small map with quickly boring locales that you'll have to traverse at least twice if you've looking for a "full experience".
While the melee combat is decent, the parts where you have to hack or fly the flight suit are infuriatingly unenjoyable. 
I think I can truly say my biggest complaint is having to repeatedly play the same series of events for minor differences that could have been written another way so you're not having to do the same thing twice or sometimes more. 
Truly, the disappointment I feel toward this game is infuriating to say the least.

Listen to me, [b]this is the only review that you will need[/b] in order [b]to decide whether or not you should buy this game[/b].

Keep in mind that [b]this game is not for everyone[/b]. [u]Do not listen to the fanbase[/u]; [b]In my opinion[/b], the game is just a great excuse to tell a [b]very good and intricate story[/b].

I will try to avoid typing a wall-text, although it will be hard. Also [b]the review is spoiler-free[/b].

[h1]Setting Up[/h1]
You can [b]enhance your game experience[/b] by using the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1156086818][b]HD Texture Pack Mod[/b][/url] and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=914437196][b]Special K[/b][/url]. Also, this is a very personal preference but, [b][u]YOU MUST CHANGE[/u][/b] the voices to [b]Japanese[/b]. Trust me, [b]it is a huge upgrade[/b] (unless you hate Japanese).

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game is set in the [b]year 11945[/b], where the [b]humanity has abandoned Earth and fled to the Moon[/b] after it was [b]invaded by aliens using a powerful machine-lifeforms as weapons[/b]. To reclaim our planet and fight against the machines, the [b]Council of Humanity[/b] creates [b]YoRHa[/b], an elite military force of androids.

[b]NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢[/b] has [b]one of the best stories[/b] that I have ever seen, blending [b]sci-fi[/b] with [b]existential philosophy[/b] to create a thought-provoking narrative. [b]It is totally worth playing just for that[/b]. However, I must admit that at beginning [b]I had to force myself to play[/b] because [b]the game didn't hook me at all[/b]. After reaching a certain point of the story,[b] I just couldn't stop playing[/b].

Most people will tell you that you must [b]finish the game multiple times[/b] in order to enjoy it. [b]Well, that's not true[/b]. A [b]single playthrough is enough[/b], just [b]aim to reach lvl +50[/b] while naturally playing.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game is set in an [b]open world full of secrets, enemies, resources and quest[/b]. The side-quest  [b]are a little bit repetitive and lacking in variety[/b], also [b]completing some of them[/b] may [b]require a lot of [u]backtracking[/u] at the beginning of the game[/b], which can be a pain. Fortunately, at some point [b]you will unlock teleports which make it much easier[/b] to get around and complete quests.

You can [b]customize your character[/b] with unique [b]weapons[/b], [b]plug-in chips[/b] and [b]special pod skills[/b].

The combat system is a [b]great mix[/b] between [b]hack-and-slash[/b] and [b]bullet hell[/b] games. However, [b]once you have a consistent weapon and plug-in chip loadout[/b], it becomes [b]extremely easy[/b] [i](in my case, I was one-shotting everything, [b]even bosses![/b] that's why I said that the game feels like an excuse to tell a story)[/i].

Just take note that [b]many people complain that the game's scenarios are poor and empty[/b]. But let's be realistic:[b] We are in a dystopian world with a well-crafted and well-told storyline, so it makes sense for the world to be like that[/b]. Perhaps they were expecting to play a different type of game, such as a [b]musou game[/b] ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

[h1]DLC[/h1]
[b]The DLC is a great and fun addition that is totally worth playing[/b]. 
It unlocks [b]three different colosseums[/b] (each one with its own rules) that will test your strength.

As you complete the different levels, [b]you will unlock special skins and items[/b]. Also, if you manage to complete the higher difficulties, you will unlock [b]an extra ending[/b].

If you are wondering about the DLC name [b]3C3C1D119440927[/b] it means:
‚ü° [b]3 C[/b]ostumes
‚ü° [b]3 C[/b]olosseums
‚ü° [b]1 D[/b]ream
‚ü° A date: [b]11944[/b]-[b]09[/b]-[b]27[/b] (you must figure out ingame what this date means, just remember that the game starts at 11945-03-10)

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]I recommend this game if..[/b][list]
[*] You are looking for an immersive and emotional storyline that explores philosophical themes.
[*] You have recently watched the anime.
[*] You like games with multiple endings.
[*] You don‚Äôt mind pressing random buttons and still killing everything.
[*] You enjoy completing collectibles such as monsters, items, fish, etc.
[*] You love exploring and discovering the game's deep lore.[/list]

[b]I don't recommend this game if...[/b][list]
[*] You are easily bothered by camera issues that can be disorienting during combats or in tight spaces.
[*] You are looking for a challenging game or with frantic action.
[*] You don't like heavy anime-style character designs.
[*] You expect a wide variety of sidequest and enemies.
[*] You are looking for fanservice.
[*] The game is not on sale.[/list]

The music and booty was good and all. But besides that, it was pretty disappointing.

* Needs a few mods to fix some underlying bugs wrt rendering
* The combat is pretty average, towards the end it was a spam-fest against sponges
* Visually it's poor, the characters are ok, but the environments are terrible for example
* Gets a bit grindy at times. For example, one of the first quests required me to reload a few times as the enemies didn't drop an item I needed
* You have to play the game multiple times to get the "full experience", there are some minor changes, but the first two are largely the same
* The story was highly philosophical and tended to rely on not explaining things, leaving the player to ponder the meaning of life. There's also a whole bunch of stuff that seems to be crammed into it from previous titles which are never explained
* Cringy characters that needed more time to be fleshed out

[h3]Story[/h3]
I may have spent 40 hours in the game.
But I spent easily double that on YouTube diving into the full Drakenguard and NieR storyline.

Yoko Taro is a fucking madman genius and this game series is a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
There will likely never be another game series like this because a game like this only works once.

And boy did it work.
Do yourself a favor and play Replicant first and then Automata,
then catch up with Drakenguard, extended media, and put everything into perspective by watching this:
https://youtu.be/9WU1mvH6bqo
[spoiler]Yes, it's 6 hours. Yes, you will watch it. I won't even have to ask[/spoiler]

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
Gameplay wise this game is even more fantastic,
Platinum games rolled up every game they made in here.
You got a twin-stick shooter, you have an amazing action combat system with multi-weapon combos and some of the best animations in the business, you got one of the most interesting mod systems in any game. Every gameplay aspect is even grounded in lore.

[h3]Music[/h3]
THEY MADE A WHOLE NONSENSE LANGUAGE FOR THIS AND IT SOUNDS GOD TIER

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
In the end, no words will be enough to praise this game. It is the definitive video game to ever exist.
it's like the Voyager Golden Record of video games and humanity.

Although this game is mediocre from gameplay standpoint in my opinion, suffers from lack of dialogue, strange pacing and an excessive reliance on reading the subtext, is overpretentious with its philosophical references and clumsy in its tonal shifts, it still delivers one of the heaviest emotional impacts in all of media I have consumed. And, if that is what the creator - Yoko Taro - intended, then it did its job well, and is a really good game. I'm happy and thankful that I spent those 60 hours on it. 
(Written at the time of an emotional height after achieving ending E.)

Edit: Totally forgot about a few things. First: gorgeous soundtrack by Keiichi Okabe, which haunts my music playlist for already two months now, and it's really well mixed, appearing almost as if dynamic (maybe it is dynamic, and I'm just setting the bar too high). Second: awesome collabs with FFXIV and Punishing: Gray Raven (the reason why I even picked up the game). I have no idea if Taro himself was involved in them, or it's just fromsoft being greedy and realizing the potential profit from a collab, but I really liked those (oh and also there were Soulcalibur 6 and FFXV ones I guess). Third: I would really like to thank Yoko Taro for this game, as his creativity inspired me to actually continue some stuff of my own, and showed me that sometimes following rules, genres, or a readers' critique too harsh to be called a critique, would just ruin the work, and authors ought to follow one's heart a tad more often. So thank you, magnificent bastard, and go forth with your goofy ahh mobile gacha.

Yes, you need to play this game. 

Combat 10/10
Story 10/10
Art 10/10
Music 100/10

I played this day one back when it came out on PS4. I instantly was hooked from the very beginning sequence. I am going to keep this brief. The music is some of the best in the industry. The soundtracks themselves are masterpieces. This is the only game I have actively went out of my way to get my hands on a physical copy of the music on a CD. I live in Japan so I was able to track down the official CD and get it for myself.

The combat is fun and intuitive. Some weapons I believe are just straight up broken compared to others. But, all weapons can easily be used to beat even the toughest endgame bosses. Platinum games really does know how to make action combat games. If you like action combat, this is definitely worth a grab.

Art is just beautiful even for a PS4 era game. Especially the character models of the main cast if you know what I mean.

The story needs you to complete endings A B C D E to understand fully the real ending. Unlike Nier Replicant, Automata makes each play through feel different even if story points are generally the same between ending A and B. I enjoyed working through each story as the characters were all likable to a degree. Without going into spoilers I will say I generally felt bad for most characters throughout the game. Especially once you start going through ending C. I am not one to tear up or feel sad after seeing events unfold in movies or games but this game tugged at my heartstrings. Someone was definitely cutting onions around me I swear.

Overall: This is easily a 10/10 game and I highly recommend everyone play it. If you liked Nier Replicant or didn't like it for it's repetitive nature, then I think you will like this game. This is Nier Replicant but better in every single way.

Came in expecting a great game, left feeling like I just played a japanese mobile game with a "story" that demands you play 2 playthroughs before the story actually starts. Also not to mention the character design for the androids being atrocious. Only thing saving it is the soundtrack, but the game's too much of a mess to make me continue. If you like boring yourself, buy it I guess

NieR: Automata is not just a game, it's an immersive experience that defies conventional storytelling. Its fast-paced and satisfying combat system blends seamlessly with a hauntingly beautiful world, creating a sense of melancholy that only the best of games can evoke.

But what truly sets NieR: Automata apart is its ability to make players think. Its complex storyline and multiple endings offer a thought-provoking journey that leaves a lasting impact on the player, long after the game is over.

The game's attention to detail is simply astounding, from the breathtaking visuals to the exceptional soundtrack that will transport you to another world. Each boss battle is a unique challenge, requiring players to adapt their strategy and think on their feet, making each victory all the more satisfying.

NieR: Automata is a true masterpiece, showcasing the artistic potential of video games. It's a game that challenges the norms of the industry, and stands out as a beacon of creativity and innovation. If you're looking for an unforgettable gaming experience that will leave you thinking about it for years to come, NieR: Automata is the game for you.

NieR:Automata is a game that has managed to captivate players from all over the world with its incredible story, breathtaking visuals, and mesmerizing soundtrack. This game, is truly a masterpiece that pushes the boundaries of what a video game can be.

One of the most impressive things about NieR:Automata is the way it seamlessly blends different genres of gameplay. The game includes elements of action, RPG, platforming, and even shoot-em-up games, making for a truly unique and engaging experience. The combat system is smooth and intuitive, and players can customize their characters with a variety of weapons and upgrades.

But what really sets NieR:Automata apart from other games is its incredible story. The game tackles some deep and thought-provoking themes, such as the nature of consciousness and what it means to be human. The characters are well-written and complex, and the plot is full of unexpected twists and turns that keep players on the edge of their seats. The game also has multiple endings, each with its own unique story and perspective, encouraging players to replay the game and discover all its secrets.

Another standout feature of NieR:Automata is its stunning visuals and soundtrack. The game is beautifully designed, with detailed environments and character models that bring the world to life. The soundtrack, composed by Keiichi Okabe, is a masterpiece in its own right, featuring a mix of haunting vocals, orchestral arrangements, and electronic beats that perfectly complement the game's themes and atmosphere.

This is a game that deserves all the praise it has received and more. It is a true work of art that pushes the boundaries of what a video game can be. If you are a fan of action games, RPGs, or just great storytelling in general, you owe it to yourself to play NieR:Automata.

NieR: Automata is a masterpiece of a game that will take you on an emotional roller-coaster ride. The game has amazing soundtracks that will leave you humming for days. The graphics are fantastic, and the game's story line is incredibly captivating, weaving together complex themes of humanity, identity, and purpose in a dystopian future.

Playing on medium difficulty, I spent close to 50 hours immersed in this game, and I thoroughly enjoyed every moment of it. The combat mechanics are smooth and satisfying, and the game world is expansive and immersive, full of secrets waiting to be uncovered.

While I didn't complete many side quests, the ones I did undertake were engaging and rewarding. The game's replay value is also incredible, as there are multiple endings to discover.

Overall, NieR: Automata is a must-play for fans of action-adventure games, and it comes highly recommended. The game's thought-provoking story line, fantastic soundtracks, and polished game play make it a true gem in the gaming industry.

- The chip system works well, both in the story, [deleting the HUD, etc.] as well as allowing a lot of unique and fun builds

- The different routes system as a whole is very nice, but is some places does stagnate a bit [Route B is fundamentally just Route A gameplay wise, but only slightly different in a few sections]
- I am personally not a big fan of Hack and Slash games and the gameplay did feel quite repetitive after a while, especially in Route B, and as such that takes away a bit from its replayability

This is the greatest piece of art in the 21st century. The thesis of the game is hidden until the end of your 3rd playthrough, when the credits roll. What it does in that moment surpasses the imagination--I truly believe it reaches artistic heights on parity with the likes of the greatest novelists, painters, composers, etc. As an actual game, there are a few flaws, notably in how the game manages difficulty and the mostly sameyness of 9S' route. However, these are minor gripes. This is the only video game in existence which I think should be mandatory play, which I believe should be studied in higher education, and passed down from generation to generation as a cultural landmark in human artistic achievement.

Flawless.
That is the only word befitting such a beautiful game which is rightly praised as highly as it is.
The gameplay is smooth, sleek and easy.
The locations are stunning and unique, from the muted black and white of the space station you visit to upgrade yourself, also known as The Bunker, to the lush and verdant abandoned city which nature has rightfully reclaimed as her own you cannot help but just stop and pan the camera to take it all in.
The soundtrack is worthy of every award going, it fits the atmosphere of any situation from the unforgiving and deadly desert, to being attacked by an operatic killer robot, you will have this album downloaded just to listen to its beauty all over again.
The story is one so heartbreaking, volatile, dark, and poignant it still sticks in my head. The antagonists may seem twisted and deranged, but by the end when the credits roll, you will stop and wonder; were they as bas as they seemed?
All in all do yourself a favour and get lost inside this world. 2B and 9S are waiting.

Extremely underwhelming, I genuinely don't understand the hype for this game.

PROS
+ Music and soundtrack are legit impressive.

CONS
- Combat system is extremely shallow, especially by PlatinumGames' standards.
- Muddy visuals and poor environmental detail, installing a texture replacement mod is practically a requirement to play.
- Hacking mini-game and shoot'em up sequences, while novel at first, get tiresome fast.
- Tons of shallow, repetitive, and unsatisfying fetch quests that have you retreading the same ground over and over and over again.
- Exasperatingly melodramatic story that keeps hitting you over the head with its narrative themes. Very cringy characters and an overabundance of r/im14andthisisdeep type existentialism.

Great story, epic battles, and cool characters, both the ones you play and that you meet. Though it can be a bit tough to go back into as the first fight is rather tough and you can't save right away, which is a bit of shame, once you get used to the controls, you've unlocked quite the adventure.

NieR:Automata‚Ñ¢ was an insanely Overrated Game for me.
I would give it a neutral review if that was possible, but I think it needs more ciritcal reviews and not only overly positive ones that really don't tell much other than: OMG BEST GAME EVER.
For me it was more of a "meh" game.

No technical difficulties on my end, which most negative reviews have, so what's the problem?

-Boring and repetetive gameplay [spoiler] looking at you second playthrough  [/spoiler]
-Very basic combat stystem: normal attack, heavy attack, ranged fire and dodge (with small additions)
 Enemies are just damage sponges on higher difficulties and I didn't feel any interest on playing at a higher difficulty, which I 
 usually do in every game
-Visually boring world design

-Story started ok, but got a bit annoing for me.
Game is about philosophical questions about human existence and life in general, but sadly not done very well. 
(inspired by Existentialism I guess)
At least for me it didn't work out. Might appeal to younger people that never were confronted with those questions or ideas.
I cannot explain else why people might like the story that much, and at the same time it is not done that well sadly.
What characters do and how they feel made often no sense to me. [spoiler]for example when 9S goes "mad" or how you want to 
call it. 
Sure he might sink into despair because of the events that happened but ye, felt just like the standard "charakter goes insane in 
animes for no reason bollocks"
Especially when there were multiple occasions where he just could have talked to A2 about 2B's death and so on.[/spoiler] 
There are quite some other logical problems in the storytelling.

The story was also very predictable to me.
There were very few things that I didn't see coming for example [spoiler] the death of 2B[/spoiler]. 
Also the game tries very hard to make you care about all those characters, so hard that I couldn't care less.
It was so obvious that the storytelling just tries to build up that emotional bonding to the characters just for the reason to then [spoiler] kill pretty much all of them later in the game. [/spoiler]

So this game might appeal to a certain audience that likes the story, for me it sadly didn't work and the gameplay itself was not interesting enough for me to carry it.

I went into this game blind, I had no expectation and had no idea what I was getting myself into. I only knew NieR from the abundance of[b] Amazing [/b] art of 2B's massive personality. Naturally, I became curious about her personality and wanted to learn more about her. But instead of just learning more about her, what this game had to offer was more than just that. This game has an amazing and engaging deep story, strong and memorable characters, one of the best and most beautiful soundtracks in a game, great gameplay and fantastic graphics. It's honestly the best single player game I've ever played since the Yakuza franchise. I'll try to avoid any spoilers in this review.

[h1] Story [/h1]

Aliens have taken over Earth and built machines to beat humans. Humans has no choice but to escape over to the moon in order to survive. Now humans wants to reclaim back Earth, humans have created androids in order to fight against the machines. Simple no? No. This couldn't be further from the truth. As you play the game and go through all the quests and side-quests, the simplicity goes away and there's more to this than meets the eye. You uncover the mysteries and learn a lot more about the story and the characters. The storytelling in this game is incredibly unique and something I've never seen before. The story goes extremely deep and you easily get sucked into it. 

[h1] Characters [/h1]

Aside 2B's amazing personality, the cast of main characters and NPC's in this game is really great. The 3 main androids, 2B, 9S and A2 have amazing character design, good personalities, and backstory. Out of the three, my favorite would be A2. I love her voice, personality and I really enjoyed her chemistry with Pod. In general, they're all badass and interesting.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The combat gameplay in this game is fantastic and feels satisfying. It's a hack and slash game, a lot like Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance. The upgrading system called plug-in chips feels rewarding to use once you start upgrading and it makes combat more diverse and fun. 2B and A2 have similar controls but 9S has a hacking mechanism which I found to be alright.   The difficulty really amps up in the second half of the game. I played the game on hard difficulty and I find that the perfect difficulty to play on if you want to challenge yourself.

[h1] Soundtrack [/h1]

I really really enjoyed the Soundtrack/OST of this game. I enjoy game soundtracks a lot and NieR Automata absolutely delivers it. The soundtrack really ties into the story so well and the emotional moments of the game. I enjoyed the idea of changing the soundtrack right after a certain quest ends or during a certain moment, it changes the mood of the game. It enhances the game and quests and puts an emphasis on soundtracks even more. My favorite would have to be [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ABvi5qegodY] "Voice of no Return." [/url]

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

I didn't play this game vanilla, I had modded the game on my first playthrough. I had heard that the port was not done well and you needed to mod the game so you can fully enjoy the game. So I did, I installed FAR, Reshade with Clean Reshade Present, High Texture Pack and Better Cutscene using [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/nierautomata/mods/140] NAMH [/url] and the end result is the game looking absolutely gorgeous. The scenery of every place, the Desert, the Cities, the Forest Kingdom looked amazing. I would stop from time to time just to take in the view and just admire the beautiful view and sky. I can't recommend enough modding this game to enhance your experience even more.

[h1] Con [/h1]

-It requires some modding to make the experience of the game even better.
-Not enough A2 screentime.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

I came for 2B's personality, came out depressed after finishing all routes. This game has made me emotionally invested in its story and characters. I played it for a week straight and I don't regret it at all. To put it simply, I fell in love with the game, the characters, soundtrack, and world. It has surpassed everything I thought this game would be and it has blown my heart in pieces.

Nier Automata is a masterpiece of gaming that is sure to captivate and immerse players in its beautifully crafted world. The story is a complex, emotionally charged journey that leaves a lasting impression, and the stunning graphics and epic soundtrack only serve to enhance the experience.

From the very beginning of Nier Automata, players are immediately thrust into a world that is both strange and familiar. The post-apocalyptic setting is beautifully rendered, with a level of detail that is truly awe-inspiring. From the crumbling ruins of the city to the overgrown forests and desolate wastelands, every inch of this world has been lovingly crafted and is a testament to the dedication and skill of the game's developers.

But it's not just the graphics that are impressive; the story of Nier Automata is equally engrossing. Set in a world where humans have been forced to flee to the moon and leave Earth to the machines, the game follows the adventures of androids 2B and 9S as they fight to reclaim their planet. Along the way, they encounter a cast of unforgettable characters, each with their own motivations and secrets.

The narrative of Nier Automata is both deeply philosophical and deeply emotional, exploring themes of identity, free will, and the nature of humanity. The game does not shy away from tackling difficult questions, and the result is a story that is both thought-provoking and heart-wrenching.

Of course, no discussion of Nier Automata would be complete without mentioning its stunning soundtrack. Composed by Keiichi Okabe, the music perfectly captures the mood and atmosphere of the game, from the haunting melodies of the ruined city to the epic orchestral pieces that accompany the game's most intense battles. The voice acting is also superb, with the talented cast bringing each character to life in a way that is both authentic and moving.

In short, Nier Automata is a game that is truly greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are breathtaking, the story is unforgettable, and the soundtrack is nothing short of sublime. Whether you're a fan of action games or simply appreciate a good story, this game is an absolute must-play.

Well executed story + player interactions - awful creative decisions. (Minor Spoilers)

I'll keep it short, I'm leaving this negative review because of some poor creative decisions made by the dev team when making this game. 

For one, if you don't do any of the rather dull fetch/side quests whilst playing through as 2B and 9S, you find yourself woefully under-levelled later. To the point where simple machines become harder to beat than set-piece bosses, and why would I be interested in eating a fish given to me by the token comic relief character for a secret ending, when the main story is so enthralling?

Next, when playing as 9S, I just couldn't master the hacking mini-games, which took away from the gameplay significantly. 

Later on, after a long period playing as 2B where I couldn't save, I became A2, and fought a boss that I struggled for a long period with. After this, I awoke as 9S, and realised I needed more healing salves. I went to the trader in the resistance camp, and found that I had to sell a bunch of my stuff before being able to buy more. I began spamming sell on all my useless junk items, before accidentally selling my 'OS Chip' - which for some fucking awful reason, was hidden in my inventory. If you sell this random item, you die. Le funny secret ending is unlocked, and you re-spawn. I re-spawned 2 hours of game-play earlier. Fuck that. 

The general map layout is also repetitive and boring. Having to play through the city ruins for the 8th time as 9S became a little dull. The collision on the map is also just broken. 

The game offers fun and innovative combat though, which was by far my favourite non-story part of the game. I'd recommend playing the first play-through as 2B for sure - a fun little experience. The story definitely picks up past this, but the game design just didn't do it for me personally. A let down.

**Spoiler Free**

In the scant amount of time I had experienced with Nier, I can finally say I understand the hype behind this game. 

I would normally not give reviews on games but Nier has both recontextualized how I view my life: both the good and the bad. The story,sound, and pacing are all phenomenal. It is one of those games that I wish I could relive the first time playing over again.

[h1]Excellent combat and an unique experience[/h1]

I got this game at launch back in 2017 on PS4, platinumed it and bought it again here on PC because I think great like this can't be locked to old hardware. On PC the game is eternal and can be played with higher quality now and in the future.

It's great to be able to replay favorite games on more modern and capable hardware, as it can transform the experience quite a bit.
With incredibly fluid and fast paced combat, Nier Automata is a joy to play. Everything feel good and responsive to control. The characters are great with cool designs, paired with an interesting story that put a lot of questions related to human behavior that cannot be explained by logic. It's a story about machines and androids fighting each other and developing human emotions in the process and in consequence bringing the complexity of the human mind with it, including the bad things.

Another interesting part of this game is how unique it is considering how it interacts with the player and the things that you can do. There are multiple endings and many other stuff that I can't really talk about without entering spoiler territory. Most of it become evident near the ending of the game.
If you know Yoko Taro, you know what I'm talking about. The guy is crazy and genius at the same time, and he brings all the craziness into the game lol

Graphics are average, it still looks like a PS3 game but the art style and designs make up for it by a lot.
The soundtrack is also top notch. Nier Automata does so many things right that the graphics aren't really an issue.
The PC Port is also good right now. I played at 1440p 60fps Max settings on a RTX 2060 Super, no frame rate drops, no stutters, no crashes. Zero issues. It's very polished the way it is right now, but I know it's been a very long journey since launch with patches and that Square Enix haven't provided quality support for this game on PC.

I absolutely recommend this game. It's one of my favorite games ever.
Good characters, excellent combat, good soundtrack and very unique stuff that you won't see in other games.
Just keep in mind that to truly beat the game, you have to finish it 3 times. First you play as 2B, then you play as 9S which is the game story but with his perspective, and then you play the last route with A2, which is the continuation of the story afterwards and the true ending. The A2 route is the best in the game and is incredibly fun to play.

If you see this game on sale and you're interested in playing it, just buy it immediately. Square Enix almost never puts this game on sale. It may be on sale now, but keep in mind that it stayed over a year without any discount.

Im writing this because I feel like the reviews dont really match what this game is. At first this might look like a wierd anime hack and slash but this could not be further away from what it is. I dont want to spoil so I wont say anything about the story at all but this game is one of the most (if not the most) inovative games from storytelling to gameplay I have ever played. After 100% of the game, I can say that it deserves all of your money. Bought it during the Spring Sale, and I must say that it is one of the best game in my library. You definitely need to 100% it to unlock the true essence of NieR: Automata.

If it matters, I'd like to say I got this game when it was half off at $30. In the state the game is in, or at least it was for me, full price being $60 isn't worth it.

While I'm unsure how often it happens, I unfortunately ran into a bug that caused only the game's screen to freeze, yet the game itself kept playing as you can hear menu sounds and such going on when you press the controls. I tried to remedy this with the FAR mod, which did end up making the game run more smoothly, but it did not solve my issue. As you cannot save during the first section of the game, I had to restart from the beginning when this happened, and could not finish the first section.

As for the gameplay, I did enjoy what time I spent playing without bugs. This issue simply tired me out trying to restart from the beginning multiple times to see if the issue was resolved, and I was unable to figure out how to fix it.

Edit 03.28.2023: Years later and after a PC rebuild, I am no longer running into the mentioned issue. Perhaps it was patched, a rare oddity, or my previous system had more trouble handling it than expected (despite being able to run newer games fine). I plan to rewrite this review once I have completed the game.

[h1] Weird beginning [/h1] When I first started playing this game I was honestly put off by the bullet hell beginning and seemingly simplistic enemies and action. I dropped it barely an hour in. But there was a part of me that knew I didn't give this a game a real chance and it turns out that part was very right.[h1] Second time's the charm[/h1] Years later and with some JRPG experience I picked it up again and boy haven't I been able to put it down since! I don't really want to go into all the details of why this game is great but let me just say that no game about robots (or maybe any game) has ever been able to touch on the core of what it is to be human and to feel and ... 2B (hah).[h1] Singing the praise[/h1] The combat is great and the bullet hell flight unit segments are few and far between to the point where they're a nice change of pace. The music is ...unbelievable. The characters are simple on the surface but certainly offer depth when you're inclined to look for it. I don't even want to comment on the story and lore.[h1] Conclusion[/h1] So if you're like me and you were put off by the bullet hell flight unit intro and the simple looking enemies, don't be, it gets really good really fast and stays good pretty much throughout the experience. It is one of those rare "core videogames" where I would argue if you enjoy video games in general you will like this.[h1] Spoilers [/h1] Mild spoilers for a little advice:[spoiler]There is no harm in focusing on the main story quests until you unlock fast travel, nothing will lock out at that point. If you feel like you might burn out while at the same time being compelled to do the side content don't be, you get another chance to do most side content later, so feel free to push the story as much as you want. You'll understand once you get there.[/spoiler][h1] Edit[/h1] Steam seems to have effed up review formatting so there's no line breaks for some reason. That's why there's these unnecessary headlines everywhere lmao.

Nier: Automata is an incredible game that takes players on an emotional journey through a beautiful and haunting world. The game's story is expertly crafted, weaving together complex themes of humanity, morality, and the meaning of existence in a way that is both thought-provoking and deeply moving.

The gameplay is also top-notch, with a seamless blend of action-packed combat and exploration that keeps you engaged from start to finish. The combat system is fluid and intuitive, allowing for a wide variety of play styles and approaches to each battle.

But what really sets Nier: Automata apart is its stunning visuals and mesmerizing soundtrack. The game's post-apocalyptic world is a wonder to behold, with richly detailed environments and character designs that are both beautiful and haunting. And the soundtrack, composed by the legendary Keiichi Okabe, is an absolute masterpiece that perfectly captures the game's melancholic tone.

Overall, Nier: Automata is a must-play for anyone who enjoys action-packed games with deep, thought-provoking stories. It's a truly unique experience that will stay with you long after you've finished playing

Combat system is really fun. I was excited to get new upgrades and new weapons. 

But the mapping and minimap system was garbage. I got lost 90% of the time I was in the game. 

There are cracks on walls where you think you can pass from there, but you can't because invisible walls blocking the cracks. And when there is a really poor map design, you constantly force yourself to get thru those cracks. 

Constant changing camera angles should be nice normally, but it actually makes you get lost easier. If only mapping system were clear, I would recommend this game.

A fantastic game that takes you on a ride of a lifetime.

The combat is great, even though you do the same thing over and over it doesn't feel too repetitive since the game forces and gives you the option to change the way  you fight. The story works perfectly fine as a standalone game, but knowing a few things from previous installations might prove handy. Grapchis are very good, if not the actual graphical quality, but the graphic design is top-notch. The soundtrack is amazing, so much so that I bought it separately and listen to it all the time. Regarding the port, I had one crash and no real performance issues, though I do think it necessary to install FAR on every machine.

Overall this game will be the ones I'll reminisce about and come back to in the years to come. I've never seen anything quite like NieR:Automata and am extremely glad I picked it up.

Oh, and, there is the fanservice. It's up to the individual player to form their own opinion of it, but it never got to the point of bothering me.

Post-100%-achievements edit: Many years and an almost complete replay later, my opinion of NieR Automata hasn't really changed. Combat is still fun and engaging, although maybe there are a few more annoying bits than I remembered. Or I just suck at two-stick stuff. Story was definitely more impactful the first time around, but it was still a pleasure to go down somewhat of a memory lane. And as I'd written in my OG review, having played a bit of Replicant did affect the experience, although not game-changingly. Definitely would undergo amnesia just to play this game for the first time again.

Nier Automata is another marvel from the man himself: Yoko Taro. I finally got it on PC after a couple play throughs on console. And man does it still hit home hard. Platinum nailed the gameplay and combat. Reminded me more of Bayonetta than the original Nier. Music is still incredible and simply beautiful. Game looks great, albeit a little muted in the color area. The open world is also well done. The areas are unique and really make the world breathe. No bugs or issues to note. The story is simply amazing. It is not deep, in fact, it is very simple, yet very effective at what it is trying to portray. Get all the main endings to really feel the weight of the story. The characters also make you root and cheer for their success. There is really nothing negative to say about this game. I hope Taro, Platinum and Enix can work on a new game, or the very least remake DRAKENGARD!

The only nitpicks I have is there is one scene with 2B that you have to travel to a certain area with a certain issue (do not want to spoil it, but you will know it when you see it) it is still awkward after all these years. But that is my opinion. and the 2nd is grinding. Just like Nier, grinding for the weapons is less tedious than Nier, but it is still rough. and the 3rd nitpick is locking the Replicant costumes behind the hard arenas. They are basically end game content, so that is a disappointment, but not hard to get to level 99. It did not quite reach the story and characters of Nier Gestalt/Replicant, but it is still a better game overall.

With that all said and done, Automata is a great sequel? to the original Nier. Automata is the better game. While Nier is weaker on the gameplay and combat, the story and characters IMO are just better. I suggest to play Replicant 1.22 first as they do reference it a little bit, so it makes Automata that much better. Just get both games. If you like a great story and characters Replicant is for you, but if you like a great overall game, then Automata is for you. Just get both and then question everything in your life. Get this game already.

For a very long time, I legit thought this was a game for perverted weebs. Being a recovering weeb myself, I shunned it for quite some time, thinking that despite hearing snippets of what the story was about I still probably would not enjoy it. Then, I heard the soundtrack...

I asked a few friends who I knew had played the game before for recommendations. I have enjoyed other Platinum games in the past, Metal Gear Rising: Revengence (not a word) being my favorite from the studio. With the soundtrack in my head and endorsements in hand, I went ahead and bought it. After finishing it, my mind may have been changed on my favorite Platinum game.

This was a slog, but a great one. If you have played any of the Sonic Adventure games, the structure will be similar. You play the game 3 times, and each time it's different. Each time the story changes, more information about the world is drip fed to you, and you slowly discover the truth behind everything. It's very well done. The game play, story, and music all keep you engaged. I give a strong recommendation to anyone who enjoys spectacle fighter games.

For Achievement Hunters: [spoiler] There is a shop that you unlock after completing the final story line that allows you to purchase achievements that you may have missed along the way, which is awesome because there is a ton of content that can be missed. Please note that [i] not all achievements can be purchased here[/i] which I found out the hard way. I would recommend using a guide if you want to complete the game 100%, but to avoid spoilers for the story, skim for "Endings" and for "Weapons". This should hopefully allow you to do what you need to without spoiling things too much, because there are parts of the story that could have less impact if you read about them beforehand. There is an excellent guide by Cynic 0055, I would highly recommend using.[/spoiler]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay is similar to most hack and slash games (like devil may cry series) and it has its own unique mechanics. Enjoyable for the most part. 8/10

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
It could use some improvements in certain areas (like better lighting in specific areas, not going to spoil), but it still looks awe inspiring. 9/10

[h1] Story [/h1]
I will not spoil it for you. This is the main selling point of the game. The characters,plot,areas,humor, etc are all crafted for you to have a great experience. You need atleast 3 playthroughs to understand everything (each playthrough changes the perspective of the story + continuation of last part). Here is a tip instead: don't watch a "let's play" or a stream or read online reviews about the game. if you get  a major spoiler, the game is no longer as enjoyable as it could be.
Definitely a masterpiece 10/10

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The second selling point of this game. The music is top-notch. It never gets repetitive and you will find yourself humming along in no time. 10/10

[h1]Performance[/h1]
I have a dying hdd, i7-8750H, 8GB ram, gtx 1050 Ti. I am able to run the game on 1920x1080 Ultra 50-60 fps (55 fps average) with very very few fps drops (due to dying hdd). I fail to see what the people who claim "the game is poorly optimized" are talking about.
I will update this section once I get an ssd.
EDIT:: After getting an SSD and upgrading RAM, it runs 60fps smooth with no drops at all.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
While the game can be played with keyboard and mouse, it just feels weird to do so. It is a way better experience to use a controller.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Ignore all the memes about 2B. The characters will grow dear to your heart that you won't be able to think of them that way. This is the type of game that makes you think and strikes a chord inside you. I consider this game to be game of the year 2017 (not official, while botw isnt bad at all, nier:automata is just more immersive story wise)

I've only just started at the time of writing this but man I'm in love with this game so far. Great personality, super cool world, music and characters. Not to mention the shifts between different styles of gameplay, this game just oozes charm. Big fan

K I'm gonna just lay it all out on the table, this might be my favorite game of all time (given my other favorites are Fallout New Vegas, Shadow of the Collossus, Dark Souls, and Silent Hill 2). Imma give a list of Pros and Cons to describe how almost perfect this game is.

Also as an important note: I highly recommend anyone that's interested in playing this game to at least look up a walkthrough of Nier 1, because it gives more context to the story of Automata. There's a lot of really amazing moments that you'll miss out on if you didn't play/watch Nier 1. I recommend the Nier Lp by the SuperBestFriends

Pros:

+Fantastic Combat that's simple on the surface but with many layers if looked a bit deeper. This is an overall huge improvement from the first game since Nier 1's combat is overall not great.

+Segments that shift the gameplay game, making it more and more fresh all the time. Every now and then the game will change from 3d action game to a shmup (Shoot em up) to a twin stick shooter. Nier 1 also had these shifts, which helped it quite a bit given it's mediocre gameplay.

+Amazing fully realized and thematic story that would be impossible to tell in any other medium. This is not an exaggeration, anyone that disagrees straight up didn't finish the game.

+Fantastic English dub. Everyone gives their all in this one, especially whoever played 9S.

+Great amount of customization. While it isn't Dark Souls levels, there's many different weapons to choose from, many different plugin chips that give abilities to your character.

+Tons of (mostly)Fantastic Side Quests, often giving insight to the world of Nier along with fun banter between the main characters.

Alright, now I'm gonna get into the bad stuff. Don't worry, this won't take long.
Cons:

-I can't ignore this issue. The PC version isn't great overall. If you're interested in getting this game, I'd honestly recommend getting the PS4 version over this. However if this is your only choice, or you don't care, there is a few work arounds. Specifically a mod called FAR, it's more or less the DSfix of this game. If you want the game for your PC, I highly recommend getting that mod, as it fixes a lot of the problems the PC version has.

-There's some sidequests that are really gimmicky and not fun to play, which can especially be annoying for the completionists.

And that's it, honestly those issues are so minor (except maybe the pc issue for some people) that I can't imagine anyone having any actual issue with the game because of it.

Overall, I'd highly recommend it for anyone that likes video games. To some, it just might not be the type of game you like, and that's ay-ok, but I really hope you give it an honest try before judging it. Because this game is something that holds a really special place in my heart, and is something I will be playing for years to come.

This is my introduction to the series, so all of the nuances to the game were so refreshing and keeps my short attention span engaged. The visual design and aesthetics combine the modern JRPG style with a unique and captivating mix of almost goth, film noir, and apocalyptic themes with sensational clarity. The gameplay is easy to comprehend for those who are versed in action RPGs, but rich and in-depth enough with additional elements of ranged tactics and customization of skills and passive abilities. It is also difficult enough to keep you focused in every battle so that it never really feels like your grinding or endlessly battling nuisance enemies without any real reward. 
The sound design, voice acting and music are right at home with the world and the characters. There's tension, conflict, beauty, somber moments, and subtle shifts to make the player feel part of the experience and really immersed in the environments. 
Bottom line is this game is a blast to play, story rich, intriguing, breaks the mold of what action RPGs feel like while still keeping to a successful formula that is easy to grasp. NieR:Automata is the modern equivalent of an open-world, Mega Man RPG with multiple themes fueled by stunning graphics and effects, and held up by creative and detailed art and sound.

(Revised) First class character, first class scene, good story, with bad game control. The POD aiming assist is basically non-existent and fighting enemies in the air is absolutely not fun. I don't recommend anyone playing NieR on PC with mouse/keyboard. It is only designed for controllers.
