NieR: Automata is one of those games that don't come out often. Just like Elden Ring it's a game that releases so a good amount of hype and then proceeds to blow everyone's expectations out of the water.
I want to preface this review with telling you that i am very biased to NieR: Automata. Nier together with 2 other games is a game that got me through a tough time in my life. So much that i even incorporated the virtuous Treaty, one of the heavy blades 2B starts with, into my first tattoo. So do keep this in mind.

NieR: Automata made by Square Enix in cooperation with Platinum Games brought the entire NieR series to a new direction the entire series sorely needed. There is a very good reason why you never heard of the NieR series before Automata, the simple explanation to this is that NieR, NieR Replicant (not the remasterd one that came out in 2021)  and NieR Gestalt largely missed the mark in terms of gameplay. Reviews of NieR point at how the game didn't look good, the controls felt clunky but the story was good.
Sadly this is many cases a flaw of Square Enix, Square is good at making interesting stories and if looked at the recent mainline games quite good at making a game look apealing but the gameplay of action games have always been tough for them.
Slide in Platinum Games, a studio incredibly well known and well loved in the gaming space for their (mostly) flawless creation of high stakes action games such as but not limited to: The Bayonetta series, Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance and in this case NieR: Automata and you get a legendary combination.
But enough background and gloating, let's get to the review shall we?

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
NieR: Automata is first and foremost an action game focused on quick reflexes and stylishly killing whatever stands in your way. This begins with your weapons which are mostly divided up into 4 major archetypes: Small swords, Large swords, Spears and Combat Bracers, The latter of which being combat gloves. All 4 can be held in what order you want but a max of 2 weapons can be equipped. Be that a large sword and a spear, 2 Combat Bracers or any other combination you can think of. Together with this you also slot Plug-In chips into your character. These can range from auto regeneration to firing off shock-waves every time you attack and range from level 1 to 8. These are however limited to the amount of storage you have, increases of this can be bought from merchants and storage usage is determined by the level the Plug-In chips you have installed.

[h1]Soundtracks[/h1]
In terms of Soundtrack no words i could say would do it much justice, yes it is just that good. There is a very valid and good reason why this game has gotten 3 awards for best soundtrack! The soundtracks of NieR: Automata are ones I frequently come back to because they are just that good. This coupled with the fact that overall sound design is flawless here makes for an experience you won't soon forget.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Visuals are in a way a hit and miss. NieR: Automata was first and foremost a console game, this very much shows itself in the PC version that has rather low quality textures and models when compared to the console versions. Things that are fixed with the help of mods but these do not (in my opinion) count for a review of the base game. 

The console to PC porting also shows itself rather unsightly in terms of controls, the keyboard controls aren't well done in the slightest. Controls that don't make sense or straight up demand you hold a button that only gets in the way while fighting. Issues that sadly immediately go away the moment you play this with a controller, making it basically mandatory to own a controller that can connect to your PC.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Story-wise NieR: Automata is an easy 10/10 and a definite must experience. You can't however expect to have seen the full story in just one playthrough. As some of you might already know NieR: Automata needs 3 playthroughs in total, the first of which being the story through 2B's eyes, a combat unit created with the task of eliminating all machines, asking you the question of 'what puts humans apart from machines if the same behaviors can be seen from both', The 2nd being that same story through 9S' eyes, a recon unit that has to start working together with 2B due to some unforeseen circumstances. The third being a new story that I will not tell you anything about as it is the better of the 3.

[h1]Level Design[/h1]
Last but not least is level design. NieR: Automata is an open world game set on an earth that was broken down by some outside force (which i will not tell you about what this was for story's sake) yet now houses various hostile machines. These locations are a spectacle to behold and do make you want to look for even more beautiful scenes. Luckily these don't suffer from the aforementioned visual issues as much as more closed parts of the game does.

Overall I can recommend NieR: Automata to a great deal of you reading this. With stunning sound design, breathtaking views, satisfying combat and absolutely gorgeous level design it should already be in your library or wishlist.

This game was a great experience, and it easily became one of my most favorite game in it's genre. It has interesting characters and story. Loot and combat system are wel performed since everything you find is usefull and every encounter has it's meaning. 
To finish a base story you have to play the game three-times. You get three main endings as you witness the story from the perspective of three characters (every playthrough is different). Then you have a fourth ending whitch adds some flavour to all of it. And then if you don't have enough you can obtain another 23 (24 with DLC) smaller, less significant endings which are fun and adds some more reasons to replay the game. Hell, I didn't even get them all for now. 

Pros and Cons:
+ Story and Characters
+ Entertaining combat and progression system
+ Multiple storylines and endings
+ High replayability value
+ Lots of interesting mechanics such as upgrading your character with plug-in chip that you develop on your own
+ Weapon variability and combinations

- Side quest are mostly fetch-errands and can feel repetitive

In the end I think the game is worth the money and your time. I haven't had such a great time with a game for a while. For me NieR: Automata is 9/10.

"A Love Letter to Philosophy enthusiasts"

Summary
How this game works basically is they bait you with sexy android waifus then educate you about philosophy. Some of the NPCs are named after actual Philosophers, which actually showcase their philosophy and everything wrong with it(Except for Sartre, this game definitely hates Sartre). 

Gameplay(7/10)
Combat: You get to play as 3 different androids, 2 of is just an upgrade of each other but one of them lets you posses other robots by hacking into their system through a bullet hell interface. I've heard lots of westerners hating on the combat, calling it mindless button mashing but that's completely false if you take a minute or 2 to check out the combos and movement. It only takes a minute to learn I swear. The NPC Robot possession mechanic is great but it DOES NOT let you fly with units that are clearly supposed to fly (kinda annoying TBH)

Open World: The invisible walls sucks poopoohole though, it makes sense for before Ending B because you need permissions to do certain stuff but the game implies(through narrative) that you're on you're own after Ending B but the Invisible walls still exist T^T  I mean I get why it's there but it just sucks especially after playing something like BOTW

Scripted Areas: The game goes from twin stick shooter, side scrolling gradius-like shooter, shoot em up(angled and top down), 3rd person. platformer, angled shooter, bullet hell etc. Very refreshing. I love stuff like this but you're definitely gonna hate it if you're a mono-genre kind of person(no shame)

Mounts: Kinda annoying that there's this 2 second wait time before you can mount a pig/moose

Difficulty: Doesn't affect the story, hard mode just takes away your ability to lock on

Sound Design(10/10)
The music is context based, the instrument changes based on what you're doing or where you are in the game. UI Clicks sounds good too, especially the pause (not the menu) SFX is satisfying. THE ENGLISH VOICES ARE ACTUALLY GOOD, I usually go with Japanese Audio when playing Japanese games but the English VAs did an outstanding job, bravo bravo 

Graphics(8/10)
UI is great, it's definitely one the best if not the best. It's completely customizable and you can even turn it off(Rare for a Japanese game), and turning it off actually affects your stats. 

PC Graphics for this game is poopoo compared to the console version, I played in 4k and 2k, some of the textures are eyecandy then boom a 240p jpeg texture attached to a crate, but overall it's great especially the characters(A2 and 2B's ass is 10/10). But when it's good, it's REALLY good 

The Animation is excellent, A2 and 2B's slow walk animation is super hot. Their lips don't move in game while they're talking with each other though(like Dark Souls), kinda weird but forgivable. The lips doesn't sync with the English dialogues during cutscenes though

Literally one of my favourite series of all time. I love Nier, and Automata is still breathtaking to this day. I recently started playing again on PC, and the nostalgia/fresh controls (keyboard+mouse instead of controller) have made it a unique experience. I still prefer controller, obviously; but even on mouse and key this game is phenomenal and the control scheme is pretty well streamlined to make it easier for you. I 100% recommend this game to anyone who has thought about playing or anyone who's on the fence about it. You'll absolutely love it. The story is intense and deep, the characters are amazing and go through development throughout the game, there are cameos and callbacks for those who remember Replicant, there are nods to other games, and (if you're into that sort of thing) there's plenty of "assets" you can view through your playthrough. If you aren't into that sort of thing: you can adjust the camera to make it follow your character more closely, which will solve that issue. If that's your argument for not playing this masterpiece, just adjust some settings and get through the story. It's worth it, trust me.

Sad robot game 10/10. 

 On a serious note, from what I can tell, Square Enix did update this game's PC performance since Spring of 2021. After an hour of playing I felt that the F.A.R mod isn't necessarily required anymore to have a good game-play experience but I would still recommend it.

I was used to modern AAA graphics and other gameplay style like red dead 2, witcher 3, last of us 2, etc, so I didn't like the game and wasn't sure if I should carry on. BUT. It was foolish of me to make such hasty assumptions. After a few hours the game mechanics clicked, the story made sense, the depth in lore and twists in characters arcs upon each new route and play through, the satisfying combat, the dlc... This game is indeed amazing and I'm glad I finished and got all the achievements. TLDR Came for 2booty, stayed for the masterpiece.

Having played Automata after the Replicant remake/remaster/rewhatever, it's difficult to exactly place my thoughts. Almost everything that made Replicant the special experience it was still applies here. Well, almost. And most of that game's faults still remain. Aside from arguably the biggest one, but I'll get there.

Automata has a somewhat less impressive main cast of characters, or at least they didn't resonate as strongly with me. Even after fully completing the game and reading a bunch of side materials, I couldn't tell you much about 2B as a person. Same applies to 9S too, to be honest, but at least he receives a major character development in the third act of the game - said third act being the game's highest point by far, in part due to just how ballsy the narrative choices get. It's far exceeding Replicant's narrative there and doesn't commit that game's cardinal sin - which was Replicant's "Route C". This game doesn't really force you to replay it, but genuinely continues after Endings A and B. Route B, while repeating the events of Route A doesn't exactly repeat it's gameplay, then paves the way for Route C's massive impact, which finally reveals that, for all of its poor implementation in the original Nier, the Yoko Taro approach to multiple endings can be utterly ingenious when done right.

The game really shines in creating a very specific atmosphere. I've heard Taro's storytelling described as "melancholic" and I think that's the right term to describe it. The world, the themes, the sidequests - everything seems designed to make you feel a weird mix of nostalgia, sadness with a mild dash of hope.

The gameplay is really fun and dynamic and it very seamlessly mixes many types of games, from 2D to 3D, from bullet hell to hack n'slash and so forth. Neither feels lackluster and neither is boring. However, the difficulty balance is... just wrong. The action gameplay really feels hampered by RPG mechanics, especially the leveling system. It's far too easy to overlevel and kill any challenge, Normal mode is already easy enough as it is. Meanwhile Hard is usually just as easy... only everything kills you in 2 hits. So - the gameplay is good, but it could really benefit from removing EXP and levels in favor of a more action game-like approach to progression and a difficulty level about halfway between Automata's Normal and Hard.

Ending E is something I have little to say about without spoiling it. Many people resonated with it emotionally, quite strongly even. I did not. In fact, I don't even like it. Maybe you'll consider it profound. Maybe not. Even then, the game would be worth it even without it. I mean, I found both Endings C and D quite satisfying, which may have been one of the reasons why Ending E just didn't do it for me. It definitely is original and there's a vision behind it - even if it was one I failed to vibe with.

All in all, I like this game. A lot. And it's good. Way above average, even. I wouldn't exactly call it a masterpiece - but, like all of Yoko Taro's previous work, it has a stroke of genius about it. Even Drakengard 1, otherwise a bad game, had moments that showed potential, which Automata realizes - hell, in some parts of Route C, Drakengard 1's influence is felt more strongly than in either Replicant/Gestalt or Drakengard 3. Nier: Automata is a good game, more than worth anybody's time and money. And I honestly hope (not without ample reason to believe it) that the next time Taro makes something bigger than Voice of Cards, I will be able to genuinely call it a masterpiece.

The soundtrack is better than a masterpiece though.

Good story and great gameplay to go along.

Nier Automata is an action-packed game that left a lasting impression on me. I was hooked by its world, captivating story, and engaging gameplay.
The game's narrative is both complex and thought-provoking, exploring themes of existence, purpose, and the human condition.

The gameplay is a blend of hack-and-slash action and RPG mechanics. The combat is fluid and rewarding. 
In addition, the music score is simply stunning. The game's beautiful soundtrack perfectly complements it and enhancing the overall gaming experience.

The score features a mix of orchestral and electronic elements, creating a unique and immersive soundscape. Overall, Nier Automata's music score is a masterpiece in its own right, and is one of the many reasons why this game is truly a work of art.

Overall, I would highly recommend Nier Automata to anyone who enjoys a good story-driven game with satisfying gameplay. It's a game that truly stands out from the crowd, and one that I'll be thinking about for a long time to come.

I loved every moment of this game! For those fond of bullet hell segments and fast paced combat with a range of difficulty, I totally suggest trying this out!

[h1]Glory to Mankind - The superb game that is NieR: Automata.[/h1]

[b]NieR Automata is one of those scarce, rare games that can make such an lasting impression onto the player even years after experiencing it.[/b]

It had been roughly six years since I first laid my eyes upon Yoko Taro's masterpiece, and something just drawn me in [spoiler]and no, I don't mean it was 2B's ass- well, sorta[/spoiler]. There is a Brazillian youtuber in which I'm an decade old subscriber called "Zangado", whose made a video back in 2017 playing the prologue of Automata and sharing his initial thoughts. The first thing that stood out to me back then was the [b]music[/b], it is so different from anything I heard at the time that it just took a grasp of me, being something so beautiful and mesmerizing, [i]I knew I've just founded a gem between marbles.[/i]
My first impression with the gameplay was pretty positive, I haven't seen a game mix bullet-hell mechanics to hack-n slash before, the camera positioning also being very dynamic, making the gameplay reinvent itself whenever it could.
The story told in the game's prologue is a bold one: about an yet unknown android called 2B and her partner 9S, both having the mission to destroy the Goliath class enemy inside an abandoned factory. Looks plain on first sight, but the way it is told makes it stand out, much so that even after all these years, I still wondered what had happened with both 2B and 9S after their final resolution in the prologue.

[h1] 2B or not 2B? Here lies the question [/h1]

Fast forward to 2023. In this very year, I had the pleasure to play the game for the first time- [i]and it wasn't what I was expecting in any way, instead being much more than I could ever possibly fathom.[/i]

NieR is a game were the player really has to have the balls to continuously keep getting through, because you're drawn so deep into the story that mere events can change your entire mood depending on it, and I particularly had to take a break after a certain point because it was so much to bear, and that's something that never ocurried to me before, I could really feel the characters, the story, having a deeper meaning inside of me as it went on.

With no rush at all, I went beyond the limits in this game, making the most that I could had on a first playthrough, embracing my mistakes as they were out of my reach, trying to learn as much as possible via the game files, cutscenes, clearing out interactions with other NPCs, since this was the game I was craving for so long after all and I am NOT- a single bit- unsatisfied.
NieR Automata really can, and really WILL touch you deep with is storytelling and music, making itself an very lasting experience aside from every game you've played, because this is not just a silly little game, this is art in it's purest form. 

Have a taste of its terrific music- by Keiichi Okabe!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gibu0sJQwkM

Thank you for reading my review. I really hope you do play the game and if you want to, share your thoughts with me!

This game is really something special. 

     In an age when huge publishers like Sony have convinced many people that the only way to properly convey a games themes and ideas are through the conventions of film, Nier Automata is shamelessly and beautifully a video game. Nier is unconcerned with polygons or performance capture technology or hiring Hollywood animators to crunch into mental breakdowns for the sake of few more pixels on Nathan Drakes roguishly-raised eyebrow. 

     This is a game that truly needs to be played to fully understand its story and its characters. No amount of wiki entries can tell you all there is to be experienced in Nier Automata. It uses its gameplay and its mechanics to enhance its themes and musical score and characters in a hundred small ways over the course of its multiple routes and playthroughs that has rarely been attempted, let alone well executed, coming to a powerful and moving point in the games final moments. 

     The true ending of this game affected me so deeply that it reset my emotional response threshold. The way Yoko Taros characters and themes and unapologetic weirdness weave into Platinum Games masterfully satisfying character action and Keiichi Okabes powerful and emotional score has genuinely changed how I've thought and behaved since fully completing Nier Automata. I'm more easily moved by art and life and nature, even simple kindnesses shared between strangers. I've been inspired to express my love and appreciation for my friends and family in large or small ways more often, and I finally came out to my parents. 

     This game has genuinely changed my life for the better, for now and the foreseeable future...

This game is an absolute masterpiece. Everything from the story, the characters, the music and the game play, it is without a doubt one of, if not the greatest games I've ever played. It often plays like a movie or an anime due to the cut scenes which I think adds to how phenomenal it actually is. You become extremely attached to the characters and although some of the events that happen to them are heartbreaking, it increased my resolve to see it through until the very end. Some critiques are that the upper tier difficulties are very unforgiving as well as the initial tutorial but other than that I have very few others. If you're on the fence in any way whatsoever I highly suggest you stop whatever you're doing and purchase / play this game immediately.

Nier Automata is a great game. This port, however, is flawed. Without mods, the game has a massive amount of stutter in the cut scenes, and background textures are a lower resolution. Square-Enix really dropped the ball on this port. HOWEVER... there are third party mods that address these issues. If you install FAR (Fix Automata Resolution) and an HD texture pack, the game will run smoothly and look much better.

Pros:
- Interesting story
- Controls are intuitive and responsive
- Variety of weapons and upgrades to suit your playstyle
- Variety in the gameplay, switching seamlessly between third person action, 2D platforming, bullet hell shooter sections, hacking, etc.
- High replay value with multiple endings to unlock
- Fishing

Cons:
- Not a lot of strategy in the combat, it often felt like I was just mashing buttons while my character did elaborate combos with no real thought behind it
- Bad port "out of the box" (fixable with mods)

If you don't mind installing the mods, then I recommend playing through this at least once (through the first ending at least).

Putting yourself in place of the characters and asking what choices you would make and why is a door to contemplations that nowadays are rare, despite their importance.

There is no absolute right or wrong, and chasing such a thing only leads to eternal confusion. what truly matters are the things we treasure most at the core of our being. i struggle to never lose track of that amidst the infinite chaos of life, circumstance and society. so when all those external factors fail me, my core remains
i came 9 times climbing a ladder

I definitely recommend everyone to play this masterpiece from Yoko Taro, gave a lot of positive emotions! A delightful plot and its presentation with unexpected twists, interesting characters, a large number of endings (only 4 main ones), divine music without exaggerating at all (each track added to my playlist), good slasher combat and insanely atmospheric game! 10/10. Glory For Mankind
Sad robot game is very sad. Still, its a fantastic story game.

Classic Square Enix PC port job of a beautiful game as always. The PC version of the game has noticeable LOD and texture issues that takes away from the vanilla experience of the game that you'd otherwise get when playing the Playstation version, I highly recommend playing this with a Special K injector and a texture pack of some sort if you're playing for the first time.

Nier Automata is a perfect vessel for a narrative that only video games can execute as a medium. It's storytelling at it's finest really. It's a game that takes full advantage of its medium to make a story that would not be compatible within a show or a standard book.

The music is incredible and is probably the next best aspect of the game after the storytelling. The song they use for the end credits is used in a rather unique way due to the multiple endings. Multiple versions of the same song that all build up to the final ending. It made the final ending feel much more conclusive to hear a familiar tune in a new light.

The gameplay itself is pretty standard hack and slash nothing overly impressive there. If anything it's a step down from its predecessor NieR:Replicant.

Definitely worth giving a try if you're into story rich games.

You uhh you don't need a review of Nier Automata. The trick with Nier is that it only truly works once; if you prefer fantasy family drama to sexy robots, maybe play the first Nier first? If you don't have a preference, play this first, because it's probably the better game.

It's hands down just the best game I've ever played. it's not a perfect game, but the ways it hits make up for the few flaws. Steam sucks for having really in-depth reviews because of character limit, but if you're thinking about if this game is worth it or not, you'll just have to just what I say at face-value and decide for yourself. I think starting off with what is mediocre and then moving on to what I think is the best way for this.

The bad: Overleveling really trivializes the game and there are really not challenges going past level 60, the world itself isn't terribly large, there are no benefits to having a high-end PC (this is actually a good thing as well -- I'll explain later), some of the art design for the buildings in the open world seem artificial and not like they were actually a part of a long dead civilization.

The good: Standalone, it's one of the greatest stories in a video game ever told and if you've played the other Nier games and Drakengard it becomes arguably THE greatest story ever told in a video game (I think playing the entire franchise up until this point is important to really understand the full narrative being told), the characters are all charming in their own way and every time you see anyone do something whether it's main cast or side cast you think 'this character is my favorite,' there are a lot of small details that really make you nostalgic over your own life experiences, even though much of the world lacks a defining character of a long-gone civilization the atmosphere and the world itself conveys very strong sensibilities and emotions, the game looks great on the lowest settings (there is very little distinction between max settings and minimum settings), the combat isn't quite on the level of Devil May Cry but it is sophisticated enough that you can really do a lot mechanically (mods help this as there are damage reduction mods on Nexusmods where you're not just killing everything 1-2 hits), there is replayability with each ending serving a different purpose and allowing people with different life experiences and relationships to pick their favorite one by the end of their experience.

This isn't a happy game -- it is very depressing and at times nihilistic with bits of happiness spread throughout. Often times, the good things that happen to the characters are conditional or payed for down the line. Nobody gets anything for free in this world and it makes you face the reality we live in real life that things are finite and fleeting but the beauty it makes allows us to cherish these things regardless of where the journey ends. It really answers the question of whether or not it is better to have loved and lost or not loved at all.  I can't say enough good things about how compelling this game is once you play it. It's emotionally profound and the flaws you might see early on melt away the more you learn about the characters and the world they exist in.

If there's ever a time to take a risk with your money on a game you're not sure you'll like, I can't think of a better game I would bet money on would win anyone over. This should universally be considered a magnum opus for the medium.

NieR Automata is a game that promised to deliver a unique and groundbreaking experience with its visual style and gameplay mechanics. However, my experience with the game was severely hindered by repeated crashes. Despite being advertised as a game with innovative and exciting features, I was unable to experience any of these myself as the game crashed 10 times in just one hour of play.

This level of instability is unacceptable and greatly detracts from the overall experience of the game. As a result, I cannot recommend NieR Automata to anyone who is looking for a stable and enjoyable gaming experience. If you're looking for a game with innovative gameplay and unique visual style, there are many other options available that offer a more stable and satisfying experience.

This game has ONE OF THE BEST MUSIC ever, heavenly good, you need to play it to know, because music is intertwined with gameplay, you won‚Äôt fully understand how good the music is if you merely listen to the OST.

I won‚Äôt give his game 10 out of 10, because of mediocre graphics. Just simply saying: as a 2017 game, the graphics could be much better. 

This game is very special in the way it tells the story. After playing Nier Automata, I felt all of JRPG I played before were too predictable and simple. This game brings the story telling to a new level.

I highly recommend this game, 2B is just a cover girl for its complicated and rich story.

One of the greatest games I have ever played. It is very well rounded. If you are an anime fan, this is the game for you. 

Pros:
Gameplay: Excellent. The modality of gameplay changes creatively throughout the game. The fluidity in movement during combat is excellent. It takes sometime getting used to the bright light from a firing pod but once you do and you get used to it, you will fall in love with the combat. It is very anime like as you can flip over enemies, and teleport midmovement to dodge enemies. Its perfect. Enemies can get challenging too, this game is definitely a challenge, if you want it to. But its easy to change the difficulty also if you are having a lot of trouble beating an enemy. 

Story: Excellent. It covers some very heavy topics for a game centered around combat. You also need to continue after you beat the game to really become truly immersed to the story and gameplay, which is great since continuing the game changes a lot after you beat it the first time. 
-Philosophical deep conversation. 
-Some plot twists, and hidden images that you pick up on as you continue the game and enhance the experience. 
-There is excellent character development, and the characters are truly lovable. 

Greatest music I have ever heard in any video game and the music complements active gameplay creatively which other games do not do, and have yet to do. 

Cons:
-Sometimes the enemies (Not the bosses) can get repetitive especially when you continue after beating the game once. But I can overlook this since the enemies get new abilities, that make the game tremendously more challenging when you play it again after beating it once. 
-It forces you to use characters that you may not want to use to advance the plot, but its only temporary. 
-The open world really puts fine limitations on how far you can travel. Like an invisible wall stops you from exploring other areas. But this can be a pro if you don't like to be overwhelmed by a vastly open world.
